DOC.HEAD: Two Sailors Held Up By Seven Youngsters
DOC.TEXT: Authorities searched Tuesday for seven children _ one possibly as young as 6 _ who surrounded two sailors in a parking lot and held them up with a Western-style pistol, police said. The sailors were too startled late Sunday by the big handgun clutched with both hands by one of the children, who appeared to be the oldest at 13 or 14, to provide police with a detailed description of the group. The youngest of the children appeared to be 6 or 7. ``They couldn't give good descriptions because they were looking at a large Western-style gun _ you know, like cowboys and Indians _ the old, long-barreled pistol,'' said Orlando police Lt. Mike Mankins. ``Every indication was that it was real,'' he said of the gun. The youngsters ran off after the holdup. The sailors, Mark Beazley, 19, and John Russell, 18, were on their way from a movie theater to the Orlando Naval Training Center when they were surrounded in the theater parking lot by the children, who demanded money, police said. The youngsters only got a few dollars from the sailors' wallets, Mankins said. One of the boys clubbed Beazley over the head, but he wasn't seriously hurt, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Astronauts Photograph Earth, Tend to Experiments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The five..., with 4 grafs to UPDATE with day eight wake up call; picks up 4th graf pvs, `The astronauts'...
DOC.TEXT: SUBS 11th graf, `Dunbar had ...' to conform.

Space shuttle Columbia's astronauts photographed North Africa for a film documenting damage to the planet Monday as they whirled around the world on their seventh day in space. Clear skies gave the astronauts the chance to shoot pictures of Lake Chad, the Nile Valley and fires in Kenya for a giant-screen IMAX film called ``Planet Earth'' on the damage man and nature are doing to Earth. After a full day's work and an eight-hour rest, Mission Control awoke the crew about 11:15 p.m. to begin their eighth day in space. As has become the practice, they were awakened to the strains of a college fight song in honor of the astronauts' alma maters. For Tuesday it was the University of Colorado, from which crew member Marsha Ivins graduated in 1973. The song is based on the tune ``Battle Hymn of the Republic.'' ``Good morning buffaloes,'' Ms. Ivins responded, referring to the school's mascot. Earlier Monday, the five crew members also worked on several medical and scientific experiments that have been the focus of their 10-day flight since the two main objectives _ releasing a satellite and capturing another _ were completed last week. Columbia is scheduled to land Friday at 2:59 a.m. PST. The astronauts' work day began a little early when their sleep was interrupted Sunday by a buzzing alarm that indicated a brief problem with a navigation system. Five unexplained signals from a sensor on the system tripped the alarm but posed no threat to the mission, officials said, and the astronauts returned to bed. When they woke up as scheduled two hours after the alarm sounded, Mission Control told them scientists had monitored the suspect unit, but detected no further problems. Columbia commander Dan Brandenstein then successfully tested the system and put it back into operation. ``Everything is going well,'' flight director Al Pennington said Monday morning. ``They've had a very good day. In fact, they're having a very busy day today.'' During the day, mission specialist Bonnie Dunbar had difficulty with one experiment in which she must seal the lower half of her body inside a container resembling a collapsible vacuum bag. In the experiment, an astronaut drinks a saline solution and spends time in the container, which gently pulls the body's fluids toward lower body parts. In space, fluids tend to move toward the upper body. Researchers hope the two techniques will prevent astronauts from having trouble standing when they return to Earth. Dunbar had trouble with the device's waist seal, which apparently doesn't work quite the same in weightlessness as it does on Earth, and needed some assistance from Ms. Ivins and mission specialist David Low. Mission Control awoke the astronauts with the University of Washington fight song. Dunbar is a Washington graduate. ``Good morning for your second wakeup of the morning,'' the control center said, referring to the earlier alarm. Ground controllers also apologized to the crew for having to work on a holiday. ``Sorry you have to work through the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday, but you're doing so well that no one wants to give you a break,'' Mission Control said in morning messages sent to the crew via the shuttle's fax machine. Columbia pilot Jim Wetherbee received a special message: a certificate from Sunday's Houston Tenneco Marathon. Wetherbee ran on a treadmill at about the same time his mother, Althea, participated in the 26.2-mile marathon. Mrs. Wetherbee had asked him to be her pace partner in space. Wetherbee's certificate said he ``ran'' the marathon in 5.4 seconds, the time it took him to travel 26.2 miles in orbit. His 70-year-old mother, the oldest female to participate, finished in four hours, 59 minutes and seven seconds. ``You were awarded an honorary completion certificate for the marathon. Many of us were surprised you weren't disqualified for leaving the course,'' Mission Control's message said.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Department Delays Drug Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to note carrier in port
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Department has delayed announcing a White House-approved plan to involve U.S. military forces more deeply in the international war on drugs, a spokesman said Tuesday. ``Some of the aspects of that have been put off for a while following discussions with (Colombian) President Barco,'' Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams told reporters as he announced that the department will not hold a news conference this week on the drug plan as planned. Williams said he expected an announcement on the drug plan after the department releases its budget for fiscal 1991 on Jan. 29. He said he was unsure whether it would be announced before President Bush goes to Colombia in February for an anti-drug summit of the leaders of Andean nations. Under the reported anti-drug effort, the Navy was to operate an aircraft carrier battle group off the Caribbean coast of Colombia on a rotating basis. Pentagon officials have said the Navy would use high-tech radar and surveillance equipment to keep tabs on suspected drug dealers' boats and planes. Peru, Colombia and Bolivia have said they oppose the use of U.S. military to police international waters. Defense Department sources said a week ago that the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy would lead the interdiction effort. The carrier returned to Florida's Mayport Naval Station on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Boat People Who Voluntarily Return Find Difficulties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Dinh Hong Qui is finding it no easy task to begin life anew in impoverished northern Vietnam after voluntarily returning home from the squalid camps of Hong Kong. ``At present I am doing nothing. I haven't any job and I have to rely on my parents,'' the 28-year-old man said in a recent interview in coastal Quang Ninh province. ``For the time being it is very difficult.'' Qui and his wife are among nearly 1,000 people who have voluntarily returned from the British colony after finding their dreams for a new life abroad dashed by the Hong Kong policy of considering Vietnamese asylum-seekers who arrive by boat illegal immigrants. About 44,000 boat people who have sailed into Hong Kong since June 1988 face repatriation against their will unless they can prove they fled political persecution or return voluntarily under a program sponsored by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. Charles-Henry Bazoche, head of the U.N. agency's mission in Hanoi, acknowledged the economic difficulties faced by the returnees but believes that market-oriented economic reforms under way in communist Vietnam will lead to rapid improvement. ``They have made a reasoned, mature decision,'' Bazoche said of the voluntary returnees. ``They know that Hong Kong is a dead end. ``The (economic) situation in Vietnam is evolving very fast. I do believe the next four years will see many more changes,'' he said. ``I am deeply convinced that life in Vietnam is better than in a camp anywhere.'' Bazoche noted the number of boat people seeking voluntary repatriation from Hong Kong has been on the rise, with about 2,000 applications pending. More than 230 of the boat people who have voluntarily returned are from Quang Ninh, a northern province of hauntingly beautiful coastline where sampans sail between islands of dramatic rock formations. Qui and his wife last spring left behind jobs as a factory welder and tourist official with a total monthly salary of about $16 and sold their house to help pay for seats on a boat to Hong Kong, which cost $500 in gold. Soon after they arrived in the British colony, however, they became fed up with the strange food and cramped conditions in the detention centers and decided to apply for repatriation. The couple boarded a chartered flight to Vietnam on Nov. 30 and have been living at the austere brick home of Qui's parents, which is simply decorated with ornamental chili plants flanking the doorway and a poster of Miss Hanoi inside. Qui, whose wife is six months pregnant, hopes he can borrow enough money from friends to start his own mechanical repair business. ``If I'm lucky in doing my business, life will be much better, but if I'm not lucky, maybe not,'' he said. Cao Van Lam, a voluntary returnee who lives with his parents down the road from Qui, wants to start his own carpentry business but also lacks capital. Lam, 25, said he has had difficulty finding work ever since leaving the army last year. ``I just want to have a normal life to do business,'' he said. ``I think my hope will be fulfilled.'' The U.N. agency provides $50 in cash to each returning adult to help with initial resettlement costs, but the money often is squandered. Lam, for example, said he spent the money on cigarettes, while Qui spent part of his grant on beer and wine for a farewell party in Hong Kong. The United Nations also provides Vietnamese who return voluntarily with a monthly allowance of $30 for one year, but Bazoche said what is really needed are development programs in the northern provinces, where most of the boat people set sail. While U.N. officials believe the voluntary return program can play a big role in reducing the number of Vietnamese languishing in Hong Kong camps, another massive influx of boat people this year would trigger demands in the colony for quicker action. Officials in Quang Ninh and the nearby port city of Haiphong say they have launched a media campaign to dissuade Vietnamese from sailing to Hong Kong, about 500 miles to the northeast. Newspapers and radio have stories quoting returning Vietnamese describing ``how hard and painful life is in the Hong Kong camps,'' said Tran Xuan Nguyen, a provincial official in Quang Ninh. The province also has cracked down on people organizing the boat journeys to Hong Kong, with more than 135 defendants accused of such crimes last year, he said. Haiphong officials believe that since August, nobody has left for Hong Kong from the port, a popular staging ground for boat people. They express optimism that the number of departures in the spring sailing season will fall below the massive waves of the past two years. ``I think that the number of people that are going to leave Vietnam will be limited to the minimum,'' said Hoang Ngoc Tri, a Haiphong government official who deals with the returning boat people. ``It's very difficult to predict the actual figure, but we want to stop it immediately, absolutely,'' he said. ``All we can do is try our best.''

DOC.HEAD: Hilda The Hippo Dies After Brief Taste of Freedom
DOC.TEXT: Hilda the hippo, en route to a reunion with her mate Harvey, escaped from her truck on a busy highway but her brief taste of freedom ended in death. The truck Hilda was traveling in jackknifed on a busy highway at Thruxton in Hampshire, 65 miles west of London, and the three-ton hippopotamus escaped. She ambled along the highway nibbling at the grass and even managed a quick nap as passing motorists blinked in disbelief. Several swerved to miss hitting her. But experts said the stress of the accident _ and the trauma of being hauled into another trailer after being knocked out with a sedative _ proved too much for the 10-year-old hippo, who died shortly after her recapture. Local veterinarian Geraint Griffiths said the problem was that it was impossible to get Hilda into the new trailer quickly and give her an early antidote to the sedative because of her sheer weight. Hilda was being transferred from Longleat Safari Park in Wiltshire to Windsor Safari Park, where she was to join Harvey. ``I think she jumped up and tried to turn round and that turned the trailer over,'' said her driver, Mike Vandy. Griffiths was called in to sedate Hilda with a tranquilizing dart so she could be caught and put in a replacement truck. But it took an hour of heaving and pushing to lift Hilda into the truck and the difficult operation was only completed after a vehicle normally used for lifting heavy commercial vehicles was called in to help. A Hampshire police spokesman, speaking anonymously, said: ``She was extremely well-behaved and docile. It's a great shame to hear that she has died.''

DOC.HEAD: Several Former Leaders Threatened With Imprisonment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-East Germany
DOC.TEXT: Bulgaria's former Communist ruler could soon face criminal charges. His East German counterpart, elderly and ill, is under investigation for corruption and high treason, and the former Czech party chief is in limbo, with charges against him still possible. Such is the fate of East Europe's leaders, whose Stalinist systems held 111 million people in the Kremlin's satellite countries in an iron grip for more than 40 years before being swept out by pro-democracy movements. Romania's Nicolae Ceausescu met a violent end. He was executed Dec. 25, in part for ordering his security troops to fire on civilians who eventually overthrew his government. Only Poland's Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski has managed to keep a government post. The most dramatic changes came in East Germany, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia and Romania in revolutions over a 10-week period from October through December. Erich Honecker, the longtime Communist leader of East Germany, was the first to go, ousted by his own Politburo on Oct. 18 as massive street demonstrations swept the country and thousands of citizens emigrated to the West. Prosecutors have been investigating Honecker for corruption and abuse of power. The nation's top prosecutor, Hans-Juergen Joseph, said Monday the investigation had been expanded to include high treason and ``anti-constitutional associations.'' Honecker, 77, underwent what was said to be successful surgery Jan. 10 to remove a malignant kidney tumor. He had been placed under house arrest when the investigations first started. But sources said a security cordon around Honecker's opulent residential compound near East Berlin was removed several weeks ago because ``no legal grounds were established'' to detain him. At least 30 former top officials are under investigation in East Germany and most are under arrest. They include ousted trade union boss Harry Tisch and Guenther Mittag, who oversaw the centrally planned economy. Bulgaria's Todor Zhivkov was dumped by party comrades Nov. 10 after 34 years in power for resisting reforms championed by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He, too, could face prosecution. He has been accused of ruining the economy and leading Bulgaria into international isolation, largely because of his brutal suppression of the country's 1.5 million ethnic Turks. ``We think (the charges) will be abuse of power, fraud ... crimes against the consititution _ depriving the whole people of their rights,'' said Petar Beron, a member of a parliamentary investigatory commission. The panel also is looking into the Zhivkov's alleged diversion of Bulgarian government funds into Swiss bank accounts and misuse of state money to build more than 30 villas around the country. Zhivkov is being ``protected from the wrath of the people'' at his Boyana residence near Sofia, Beron said. His trial date will be set after the investigation is completed, probably in late January. Only one top Communist functionary is known to be under arrest in Czechoslovakia. Miroslav Stepan, the former Prague party boss, was charged with abuse of power, allegedly for ordering the bloody crackdown on demonstrating students Nov. 17 that triggered the nation's peaceful revolution. National Communist Party chief Milos Jakes was ousted on Nov. 24 and his fate is still unclear. A parliamentary commission investigated the crackdown and apparently found that Jakes was not involved. However, a separate Communist Party commission investigating abuse of political power ordered Jakes, Stepan and Vasil Bilak, the party's hard-line ideologist, to resign from the party. Gustav Husak, who came to power after the ``Prague Spring'' reform movement was crushed by the Soviet-led invasion in 1968, resigned as head of state Dec. 10. Husak and 30 other senior officials were suspended from the party by a party congress earlier this month, pending results of the party investigation. Ceausescu was toppled in a bloody revolution that began on Dec. 15. At least half a dozen members of the Ceausescu clan, including son Nicu and daughter Zoia-Elena, are under arrest and awaiting trial. State television reported Monday that another son, Valentin, and ousted officials including former Communist Party secretary Emil Bobu will go on trial this week on charges of bringing economic ruin on Romania and aiding genocide in the killing of thousands by during the December uprising. In Hungary, where reforms came earlier, Janos Kadar was removed as party leader in 1988. He died in July. Kadar's reformist successor, Karoly Grosz, was overtaken by the pace of change and relieved last year by a new group of reformers. They dissolved the Communist Party in October and established a new Western-oriented Socialist Party. In November, Hungarians voted overwhelmingly in a referendum for the party to make all its assets public. The East bloc leader who seems to have best survived the revolutionary turbulence in Eastern Europe is Poland's Jaruzelski, the armed forces chief. The Polish National Assembly elected him president July 19 and he has worked closely since then with the Solidarity-led government. It was Jaruzelski who decreed martial law in December 1981 to crush the independent labor union. And it was Jaruzelski who accepted the power-sharing arrangement last summer when it became obvious that Poland could not be governed without Solidarity's participation.

DOC.HEAD: A Year Later, Francke Death Still Mystifying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: It's been a year since the charismatic director of Oregon's prison system was stabbed to death outside his office. Authorities discount his family's claim that he was killed by corrupt elements within the prison system but concede they have no suspects. The slaying of Michael Francke, one of state government's rising stars, last Jan. 17 distressed this capital city. The fact that a massive investigation has yielded no suspects has kept interest in the case high. It was about 12:30 a.m. and night watchman Stephen Rubino was told to be especially observant as he made his rounds of the Dome Building. As he came to a dimly lit porch at the side of the building, Rubino spotted a large man sprawled on the porch. He was surrounded by bloodstains, and a panel of glass at the porch doorway was smashed. The night watchman had discovered Francke's body. An autopsy would later show that Francke died from a stab wound to the heart. Today, the killing haunts those familiar with the case. ``It's been frustrating,'' says Marion County District Attorney Dale Penn, who has orchestrated one of most extensive criminal investigations in the state's history. Despite interviews with thousands of people, including several convicts, and a reward fund exceeding $20,000, the 20 or so full-time investigators assigned to the case haven't reported any big breaks. Penn said he's convinced the killer is a dark-haired man with a light-colored coat who was seen running from the scene. But that man's identity is unknown, he said. ``I'm not willing to predict when or if an arrest will be made,'' Penn said in an interview. Francke, 42, was recruited from New Mexico, where he was director of prisons, in May 1987. He was known for his dynamic speaking style and his trademark cowboy boots. He apparently was attacked at about 7 p.m. as he was leaving work for the day and walking to his car parked outside the Dome Building, headquarters of the Corrections Department. Despite his mortal wound, Francke managed to make it back to the building where he broke a panel of glass in a doorway before collapsing on the porch. Co-workers found Francke's car, with a door ajar, in the parking lot. But his body wasn't found until five hours later when Rubino made his rounds under orders to be especially alert because Francke couldn't be contacted. Though no arrests have been made, the story has stayed in the news over the past year, due in large part to the efforts of Francke's family. They've publicly prodded investigators to pursue the possibility that Francke was killed to prevent him from exposing high-level corruption in the state Corrections Department. Penn and state officials say no one has produced any firm evidence to back that claim. A recent investigation by a retired judge appointed by Gov. Neil Goldschmidt to look into the possibility turned up no link between Francke's death and alleged corruption in the department. In a report issued last month, retired Court of Appeals Judge John Warden did find evidence of wrongdoing by about 15 corrections employees, most of them guards, but said there was no link between it and Francke's death. But Francke's younger brother, Kevin Francke, said the family doesn't buy the revenge or robbery motives advanced by Penn and others connected with the investigation. Kevin Francke said he finds it especially unlikely that his brother, who went to college on a football scholarship, was killed when he interrupted someone trying to break into his car. He pointed out Francke's money, wallet and Rolex watch weren't taken and that there was no sign of forced entry into the car. ``He wasn't stupid enough to confront an individual with an 8-inch knife,'' Kevin Francke said by telephone from Port Charlotte, Fla. More likely, he said, Francke was silenced before he had a chance to lower the boom on corrections officials, guards and inmates who were involved in an alleged drug ring in the prisons. He said Michael Francke had told him he'd uncovered an organized criminal element in the department. ``Drugs and drug money. I think that's the main thing,'' Kevin Francke said. ``I believe it involved corrections officials, corrections employees and inmates.'' For his part, Penn said his office has given lie detector tests to top corrections officials, and found nothing to substantiate Kevin Francke's allegations. ``I do not believe that corruption within the Corrections Department is a viable motive in this case,'' the district attorney said. ``It is unreasonable to believe that a whole group (of corrections officials) could pass polygraph exams and continue to conceal a conspiracy,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Singapore Bans Import and Export of Ivory
DOC.TEXT: The government of this city-state, long a trading center for wildlife and wildlife products, today announced that it will ban the import and export of ivory starting Thursday. In October, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species adopted a ban on world ivory trading to save Africa's dwindling elephant population, which has dropped from 1.5 million in the 1970s to an estimated 600,000 now _ victims of poachers after their tusks. The ban gives ivory traders until Thursday to sell their stocks. Singapore's ban does not apply to stocks of ivory already registered with the government, the announcement said. It did not disclose how much registered ivory was on hand. Imports of unregistered ivory have been prohibited in Singapore since November 1986, when Singapore became a party to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. In line with other moves by the convention, the Ministry of National Development also announced a ban on the import and export of the Moluccan Cockatoo, Illiser's Macaw and the Tucuman Amazon Parrot, except for those already in stock, as endangered. Also beginning Thursday, import and export permits will be required for the Banded Rattlesnake, Indian Cobra and Rhinoceros Hornbill.

DOC.HEAD: Businesses Clamor for U.S. Aid to Compensate For Looting, Sanctions
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Business leaders say their young democracy will be threatened unless Panama receives financial aid to compensate for the looting, unemployment and destruction caused by the U.S. invasion. ``If the United States truly expects democracy to flourish, you need a flourishing economy,'' said Laurence Berger, vice president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Panama. ``All the goodwill in the world won't mean much when you have growling stomachs.'' Business leaders say the Bush administration has not yet offered any aid to make up for the millions lost due to U.S. economic sanctions imposed to try to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and the widespread looting after the invasion. ``We've been told, `We gave you your freedom and now it's up to you to do what you will,''' said Alfredo L. Maduro, president of the Panamanian Chamber of Commerce. The looting started after U.S. troops invaded Dec. 20 to oust Noriega, and lasted for four days. Hundreds of stores were left without any merchandise, including food, clothes, cars, furniture and electronic goods. The looting is estimated to have cost companies between $1 billion and $2 billion and left some 30,000 people without work, bringing the unemployment rate to about 30 percent in the country of 2.2 million people. ``The word democracy is going to ring hollow unless the country gets help and social unrest is something this new government doesn't need,'' said Berger, whose organization is made up mostly of U.S. business executives. Nearly a month after the American attack, most businesses in the capital of Panama City remain closed and many people fear this will spell dire economic straits for the small nation, already reeling from two years of U.S. sanctions imposed in 1988 to put pressure on the Noriega military regime. Last week, President Guillermo Endara wrote President Bush asking for financial aid. The contents of the letter were not released. A U.S. Embassy official who spoke on condition of anonymity said Endara thanked Bush for the military intervention and ``listed six areas of priority Panama needs help in to rebuild the economy.'' One area Endara said needs rebuilding is the poor neighborhood of El Chorrillo, which was mostly destroyed in the fighting. Noriega's headquarters, a target of the invasion, was located in the district. Engineers have estimated rebuilding the area to minimum standards will cost $40 million to $60 million. The Bush administration has not indicated any aid will be coming, although the U.S. military has said it will rebuild houses and apartments detroyed in the fighting. ``It's a problem that needs attention,'' said Ambassador Deane Hinton. ``I am personally convinced that we will make a significant contribution.'' But, he added, the looting was ``first and foremost a problem of Panama.'' Hinton was in Washington on Monday and was to bring up the issue with administration officials. Although the United States has released $70 million in assets frozen as part of the sanctions, $250 million remains unreleased. Business leaders say sanctions coupled with political unrest have depressed the construction, banking, industrial and tourism sectors and caused skilled Panamanians to leave the country and seek work elsewhere. The chambers of commerce say the standard of living has dropped to what it was 10 years ago, mostly because of the sanctions. They also claim the invasion jeopardized the commercial and insurance sectors. The chambers estimate about $300 to $500 million in aid would be sufficient to stave off further economic woes, and say the United States should help Panama as it did the Dominican Republic after U.S. troops moved in in 1965. ``We are a country of 2.2 million people so a relatively small of amount of help will go a long way,'' said Berger. Government officials say the plundering occurred only because there was an absence of security forces, Panamanian or American, on the streets. The police, part of Noriega's Panamanian Defense Forces, were involved in the fighting. ``There was anarchy in the streets, martial law should have been declared,'' said Berger. He said the troops should have helped prevent looting by barricades and patrols. A key issue of the debate is that many insurance companies do not cover ``acts of war.'' Maduro and Berger say both the Panamanian and U.S. governments should come out with a statement clarifying whether the invasion was indeed war. ``Neither government wants to take a position on whether this was a war or not,'' said Maduro. ``It may be semantics but it has legal implications. A formula has got to be worked out. Or we have to work through a back door.'' They are also asking for: _ Pressure by the U.S. government to persuade insurance companies to recognize legitimate claims. _ Low interest loans in construction and commercial financing. _ Export guarantees to U.S. suppliers that would allow more expanded credit.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Armenian Community Anxiously Watches Azerbaijan Fighting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th, `Ashjian said...,' to UPDATE with reax from Los Angeles. Stands for Watertown, Mass.-dated story on AM-News Digest
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Members of Massachusetts' Armenian community stayed in touch with friends and relatives in Azerbaijan on Monday and urged Moscow to prevent the bloody ethnic conflict from escalating into civil war. ``There are thousands of Armenians who live in Azerbaijan and their lives are very insecure at this point,'' said the Rev. Dajad Davidian of St. James Armenian Church in suburban Watertown. ``What we want to see is some kind of public security take place.'' Dikran Kaligian, executive director of the Armenian National Committee of the Eastern United States, said the Boston area's 50,000-member Armenian community is the second largest in the nation outside of Los Angeles. In New York City, Armenian-Americans demonstrated Monday outside the Soviet Mission, appealing for an end to the bloodshed. ``It's one of the saddest moments in contemporary history,'' said Archbishop Megrob Ashjian, prelate of the Armenian Church of America and a protest leader. ``In the eyes of the civilized world, genocide is perpetrated.'' About 100 protesters waved American and Armenian flags, chanted ``Gorbachev, stop the killing!'' in reference to the Soviet leader, and sang a nationalistic anthem that translated as: ``The enemy wants to kill us but we are here to stay.'' Ashjian said there are about 1 million Armenian-Americans, 150,000 of them in the New York City area. In Los Angeles, Garen Yegparian, executive director of the western office of the Armenian National Committee, blamed the Azerbaijanis, most of whom are Shiite Moslems, for the clashes with the Armenians, who mostly are Christians. ``What they've started is not unexpected for us,'' said Yegparian. ``It's in line with their previous behavior.'' Kaligian's Watertown-based organization has been in constant contact with Soviet Armenians. ``In Azerbaijan everyone is involved because it's a matter of life and death,'' he said. The violence broke out this weekend between predominantly Moslem Azerbaijanis and mostly Christian Armenians, who are battling over Nagorno-Karabakh, a mainly Armenian region of 160,000 people controlled by Azerbaijan since 1923. Official reports Monday said hundreds of Azerbaijanis and Armenians fought with submachine guns, helicopters and armored vehicles taken from military bases, and that at least 37 had been killed. Kaligian said the death toll was probably a great deal higher. ``Those are obviously the initial figures,'' he said. ``The actual numbers are difficult to get because foreign newsmen are barred from the region.'' Manoog S. Young, chairman of the board of The National Association for Armenian Studies and Research in suburban Belmont, predicted the hostilities could be quelled before a full-scale civil war broke out. ``I don't think it's a classic civil war situation,'' he said. ``I think before it will be allowed to get to that point I'm sure the Soviet troops will intervene and put a lid on it.'' ``Somehow Moscow has got to exert more influence. They have to bring a stop to the bloodshed that's going on,'' he said. ``It's come to the point that unless they get some control, this will blow completely out of proportion.'' Kaligian said the reasons behind the fighting were not simple. ``This situation is often being portrayed as a religious struggle or an age-old struggle,'' Kaligian said. ``This is a political issue, and an issue of survival.'' Davidian said the Armenian community believes the Azerbaijanis have more troops and more arms than the Armenians, making the battle difficult to win. ``One of our big fears right now, in the past week _ is now that they've torn down the barriers _ we have a real fear that heavy military equipment is being taken into Azerbaijan.'' Davidian said the civil strife in Azerbaijan has taken a toll on the victims of Armenia's devastating December 1988 earthquake. ``Most of the supplies that come in from land come in through Azerbaijan. These supplies are effectively being blockaded,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Couple's House Divided by Dispute
DOC.TEXT: A couple found themselves stuck with just half a house after a legal dispute divided their two-section modular home. ``It's really something,'' would-be homeowner Michael Cady said Monday. ``Our living room is there and two bedrooms. Over at (the supply company) they have the kitchen, the bathrooms and the other living room.'' The problem began Jan. 5 when Penn-Lyon Homes of Selinsgrove, Pa., delivered the modular house in two sections. One section was put on the foundation at the Cadys' lot. Then, a deputy sheriff showed up with a court order. The section still on the truck was seized and taken to L.P. Adams, the building material company. Adams claims it is owed $14,000 by the Cady's contractor, Pegasus Construction Services, which distributes Penn-Lyon homes. But the Cadys' attorney, Mitchell Boraski, said the house belonged to the couple because they had given a $36,000 check to the Penn-Lyon driver. On Monday, Thomas J. Hamel, an attorney for L.P. Adams, said the company never intended for the Cadys to become caught in the dispute. He said an agreement has been reached that will allow the Cadys to move into their western Massachusetts home this week. ``Instead of having the Cadys out in the cold with only half a house I've agreed to suspend my levy if Penn-Lyon will escrow the funds they've received,'' Hamel said. Andrew Hochberg, attorney for Pegasus owner Vincent Carchedi, said his client had tried to work out terms to pay the L.P. Adams debt to no avail. ``He's a building contractor. He's trying to make a living in a soft market,'' Hochberg said. Cady said he and his wife, Laurie, have been saving for seven years to buy the home, and they had videotaped the arrival of the first section. Mrs. Cady said she had returned to work when her sister, who was working the video camera called her to say the house was being seized. ``It was just horrendous,'' Mrs. Cady said. Cady, who recently was certified as a teacher, said his wife and their two daughters are eager to move into the $74,000 house. ``The only thing we've paid for right now is the foundation and obviously they can't take that,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dole Says Cut Aid to Israel, Give More to Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. Bob Dole says the United States should cut foreign aid to Israel, Egypt, the Philippines, Turkey and Pakistan by 5 percent and give the money to new democracies in Poland, Hungary, Panama and other countries. Dole, a Kansas Republican who is the Senate minority leader, made the suggestion in an opinion piece published in Tuesday's editions of The New York Times. The five countries he named as targets for reductions receive more than two-thirds of U.S. foreign assistance. ``Does it make sense, at this historic moment, to provide these countries practically all of our aid at the cost of foreclosing dramatically promising new aid initiatives in Eastern Europe or other important countries?'' Dole wrote. ``What about, for example, those Latin American nations in the front lines in the war against drugs?'' A 5 percent cut in aid to Israel, Egypt, the Philippines, Turkey and Pakistan would free about $330 million, Dole said. The United States plans to spend $14.5 billion on foreign aid this year. Of that, Israel is allocated $3 billion and Egypt is to receive $2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: `Born on the Fourth of July' Nation's No. 1 Movie for Second Weekend
DOC.TEXT: ``Born on the Fourth of July,' starring Tom Cruise as an American patriot whose attitudes about war are changed by his combat experience in Vietnam, was the nation's favorite movie for the second week in a row. ``Born on the Fourth of July'' collected $8 million, according to Entertainment Data Inc. The black divorce comedy ``The War of the Roses'' with Michael Douglas and Kathleen Turner grossed $5.7 million for second place. The action-adventure movie ``Tango & Cash'' was third with $5.4 million. ``Internal Affairs,'' the new police drama starring Richard Gere as a corrupt and sexually obsessed cop, opened well in fourth place, netting $5 million on 975 screens. In fifth was director Steven Spielberg's ``Always,'' grossing $4.2 million. In sixth was ``The Little Mermaid'' with sales of $3.85 million. ``Steel Magnolias,'' the ensemble drama with Sally Field and Olympia Dukakis heading the cast, landed in seventh with $3.7 million. ``Glory,'' the story of a black Union regiment in the Civil War, collected $3 million for eighth place in its first week of wider release on 392 screens. Rounding out the top 10 were ``Back to the Future Part II'' with $2.75 million and ``Driving Miss Daisy'' with $2.7 million on 277 screens. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Monday as tallied by Entertainment Data. 1. ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' Universal, $8 million (weekend gross), 1,315 screens, $6,105 per screen, $23.8 million (total gross), four weeks in release. 2. ``The War of the Roses,'' 20th Century Fox, $5.7 million, 1,559 screens, $3,651 per screen, $61 million, six weeks. 3. ``Tango & Cash,'' Warner Bros., $5.4 million, 1,556 screens, $3,469 per screen, $38.6 million, four weeks. 4. ``Internal Affairs,'' Paramount, $5 million, 975 screens, $5,172 per screen, $5 million, one week. 5. ``Always,'' Universal, $4.2 million, 1,162 screens, $3,610 per screen, $26.1 million, four weeks. 6. ``The Little Mermaid,'' Disney, $3.85 million, 1,521 screens, $2,532 per screen, $60.9 million, nine weeks. 7. ``Steel Magnolias,'' Tri-Star, $3.7 million, 1,372 screens, $2,730 per screen, $56.3 million, nine weeks. 8. ``Glory,'' Tri-Star, $3 million, 392 screens, $7,705 per screen, $3.7 million, five weeks. 9. ``Back to the Future Part II,'' Universal, $2.75 million, 1,641 screens, $1,675 per screen, $104.1 million, eight weeks. 10. ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' Tri-Star, $2.7 million, 277 screens, $9,840 per screen, $5.1 million, five weeks.

DOC.HEAD: US Donates 75 Percent of Contraceptives to Third World
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government gives three-quarters of the contraceptives donated to Third World countries, including nearly 7 billion condoms over the last two decades, according to the Agency for International Development. Since 1968, the agency ``has purchased $567.7 million worth of contraceptives for distribution to 75 countries _ 6.9 billion condoms, 1.6 billion cycles of oral contraceptives, 49.7 million intrauterine devices and 16.5 million vaginal foaming tablets,'' the agency reported. Duff Gillespie, the agency's director for population, said overseas orders for condoms rose from 535 million in the 1988 fiscal year to 735 million in the year ending on Sept. 30. He said the increase was due in part to the fight against AIDS, but also to the growth of the agency's population activities. Details of the population program appeared in the fall 1989 edition of ``USAID Highlights,'' an agency publication distributed to reporters last week. Gillespie said the agency has overcome some of the hostility to family planning of many Third World leaders, who have suspected a hidden western policy of countries to keep down their influence by reducing their population. ``These countries have had growth that's historically unprecedented,'' he said in an interview. He said in Africa the population is expected to double in 24 years at the present rate of increase and leaders are trying to cope with increasing demand for schools, housing and social services. ``In places like Kenya the government is enthusiastic for family planning,'' said spokesman Jerry Lipscomb. Kenya, in east Africa, has one of the world's highest birth rates. The Central Intelligence Agency estimates its population of more than 23 million people is growing by 4.4 percent a year _ eight times as fast as the population of Japan, for example. The agency cited one program in Kenya that serves an area of 350,000 people. It said 43 percent of the married women there now practice birth control, compared with only 17 percent in the country as a whole, and women there average 5.2 children compared with 7.7. The publication noted the U.S. government does not support abortion or what it called coercive family planning. President Reagan's anti-abortion policy led to a tense controversy with Congress over the United Nations Fund for Population Activities. Because the fund helped China, where abortion was reportedly forced on some women, U.S. contributions were opposed by Reagan and many of his supporters. Last November President Bush refused to sign a bill on foreign aid until Congress cut out a provision of $15 million for the fund. Since 1981, the agency has spent $2.9 billion on population control activities, ranging from research to financing popular songs about the dangers of pregnancy. The agency publication said in 20 countries where it spent the most money, the average number of children per family has dropped from 6.1 in the 1960s to 4.5 in the late 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: In Shift to Democracy, More Pain Than Progress at Times
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Throughout much of Eastern Europe, there is a sense of exhilaration as the new decade dawns with the demise of authoritarian rule giving hope for a freer, more prosperous future. Latin America was imbued with somewhat the same spirit 10 years ago when, one by one, discredited military dictatorships were surrendering power to elected civilians. The democratic transformation of that region is now almost complete but, in one sense, Latin America's evolution has brought more pain than progress over the past decade; the average citizen is poorer now than in 1980. East Europeans may face a similar plight. Poles got a taste on New Year's Day of how difficult the transition is from communism to a free market system. The prices of gasoline and bus fares were doubled on Jan. 1 while the cost of heating oil and electricity rose four-fold. It will be a while before Poles live like Parisians. The experience in Latin America must make some nostalgic for the era of corrupt dictators. The 1980s are known in the region as the ``lost decade,'' a time when up to half of its export earnings were consumed by foreign debt repayment, when the average annual inflation reached 470 percent and when all the main indicators of economic performance _ production, investment and consumption _ were below the levels of 10 years ago. There were riots last year in two of the better-off countries, Argentina and Venezuela. Ironically, the country with the best economic performance was Chile, where the generals are, for the time being, still in charge. ``The decade of democracy has also been a decade of disillusion,'' writes Douglas Payne of Freedom House, a pro-democracy research group in New York. He blames powerful traditions of monopoly, regulation and protectionism inherited from the colonial era and the ``huge, money-guzzling state corporations and corrupt, no-work bureaucracies'' that were created during the 1960s and 70s. Indeed, Cuban President Fidel Castro thinks his country is doing quite well next to the Latin American democracies the United States has assiduously promoted over the past decade. Many of his countrymen, of course, disagree. Castro has said Cuba is the only country in Latin America which has not closed factories, schools or hospitals. ``We're the only country which is developing modestly but strategically,'' Castro said in an appearance before the National Assembly. That body approved a resolution pledging ``the island will first sink into the sea before we agree to pull down the banners of the revolution and socialism.'' The resolution was approved on Dec. 27, just a few days after the people of Romania ousted a system much like Cuba's in one of the most remarkable mass uprisings in modern history. It was a regime which, except for secret police hirelings, seemed to have no defenders, and the pattern was much the same last year elsewhere in Eastern Europe. The question now is whether that region will suffer the same economic fate as the new democracies in Latin America. Robert D. Hormats, a former top State Department economic affairs expert, warns the transition and the new leadership in Eastern Europe could be jeopardized if living standards do not quickly improve. ``Economic transformation will take years,'' Hormats says. ``In the near term, cutting subsidies for food and rent, closing obsolete plants and laying off redundant workers could lower living standards.'' He says the West ``would make one of the great mistakes in history if it refuses to spend the several billions needed to help countries through this hard period.'' It is more difficult, Hormats says, ``to create successful market economies than tear down failing socialist economies. It will be harder still if Eastern Europeans do not work together, and if the West fails to help them do so.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for The Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
AT&T Has Nationwide Problems in Placing Long-Distance Calls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with company saying problem solved. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `The problem...'
DOC.TEXT: AT&T's phone system had major problems connecting long-distance calls throughout the country Monday due to trouble in new electronic call-switching centers, the company said. Half the calls in the nation on the AT&T system were not going through after 2:30 p.m. EST, about the time the problem was first noticed, said Daisy Ottmann, a spokeswoman for American Telephone & Telegraph Co. The company reported that the problem was fixed by 11:30 p.m., but spokeswoman Sally Sherwood said she could not provide any more details immediately on how the network was returned to normal. ``Obviously through a very long, laborious process they were able to detect the problem and fix it,'' Ms. Sherwood said early Tuesday. For much of the day, callers received recordings saying all circuits were busy and calls could not be put through, AT&T spokesmen said. The problem seriously affected telemarketers, airline reservation centers and other heavy phone users. ``In my 20 years, I have not seen a situation that affected as many cities as this,'' spokesman Burke Stinson said at the company's Basking Ridge, N.J. offices. MCI Communications Corp. and US Sprint, the No. 2 and No. 3 long-distance carriers after AT&T, said they had no problems with their networks. The difficulties were traced to software that runs computerized call-switching gear that AT&T began installing in 1987, Ms. Sherwood said. The problem was found in what is called the call signaling system, which routes telephone calls. The signaling system is composed of computerized data that is electronically overlaid on the data that carries the voice portion of a telephone call, she said. The signaling data includes the phone number of the party making the call and the number of the intended recipient of the call. Ms. Ottmann said it was believed that the trouble began in one of the approximately 100 switching centers operating, and then spread to other centers. ``It's like striking the church bell in a steeple and all the other bells resonate _ this is a vibrating or resonating problem,'' she said. ``That seems to be in the software, or at least it's being transferred in the software.'' ``We've never seen anything like this before,'' she added. ``It's everywhere and the effects are random.'' She said the company is in the process of installing a new version of the software. It was not known whether this was part of the problem, she said. Ms. Ottmann said the had company all but eliminated sabotage or a computer virus as the cause. ``That's the only thing we've pretty thoroughly ruled out.'' Ms. Sherwood said the company has installed 110 of the new switching centers, but not all of them are on line. Stinson said the trouble appeared to be affecting a substantial number of the operating centers. But, he added, said some of the calls that didn't go through were due to the deliberate blocking of lines by AT&T to enable it to diagnose the problem. ``We have hundreds of people around the country trying to diagnose and correct this,'' he said. Stinson said the problem was affecting all AT&T's lines, including toll-free 800 numbers, except for private lines that companies lease between their offices or plants. He could not say how a software problem could crop up at so many switching centers at once. A number of heavy users of toll-free lines reported difficulties. Cindy Sheffield, phone systems manager for the Marriott hotels reservation office in Omaha, Neb., said the problem was ``devastating'' for her office because it wasn't receiving calls from prospective customers. The office was receiving only 10 percent of its normal call volume after the problem began, she said. Fidelity Investments, a Boston-based mutual fund operator, said callers were having trouble getting through. ``It did have quite extensive impact,'' said spokeswoman Tracy Gordon. American Airlines received about two-thirds fewer calls than normal on its reservation lines after 2:30 p.m. EST, airline spokeswoman Mary O'Neill said in Fort Worth, Texas. Trans Mid-America, a marketing company in Omaha, Neb., specializing in temporary motor vehicle license sales, couldn't make any long-distance or 800-number calls, said company vice president Florence Waymire. ``We're dead in the water here today,'' she said. David Haller, branch manager for Omaha's Dial America Marketing, said that if the phone problem wasn't repaired soon his magazine-subscription company would lose a minimum of $20,000, ``and that's conservative.'' United Airlines reported minor problems with its reservation system. But Susan Brushaber, a Chicago-based reservation agent for the airline, said United's phone system is designed so that callers are patched into a local phone number.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Wrangle Over Social Security Trillions
DOC.TEXT: Debate over Social Security is heating up even before Congress gets back to business, with the trillions of dollars in baby boomers' future retirement benefits casting a huge shadow over the political argument. Customary political rhetoric has been turned upside down, with a leading Democrat calling for a payroll tax cut and the White House responding, ``No way.'' The outcome may determine whether the massive Social Security trust fund, bolstered by long-range payroll tax increases enacted in 1983, will continue to be used to mask the size of the federal budget deficit. In an era of perennial budget shortfalls, the Social Security trust fund helps pay the government's day-to-day operations instead of building up a nest egg. Lawmakers are faced with whether to take painful action now _ such as tax increases and spending slashes _ or do nothing until the next century. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., added urgency to the debate with his proposal to immediately cut the Social Security payroll tax. The White House said Thursday it opposes the idea. But in today's anti-tax climate, which President Bush has played to in calling for a cut in the capital gains tax, Moynihan's plan ``could suddenly sprout wings and fly very high,'' said Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. The 1983 increase in the payroll tax was enacted partly to help brace the government for the retirement of the 75 million members of the baby boom generation, which will begin around the year 2010. The latest increase, to 7.65 percent on Jan. 1 from 7.51 percent, will bring in nearly $280 billion this year. The total reserves should peak at $12 trillion in the year 2030, but dwindle rapidly thereafter. By law, the money is not stashed away, but invested in treasury securities, where it collects interest. The Treasury Department uses the money the same way it uses other funds it pockets from securities sales _ to pay the government's bills. The money pouring into the Social Security trust fund also helps make the overall federal deficit appear smaller _ $52 billion smaller last year. That will turn around in the next century: people who are working now will be drawing retirement funds and the government will have to redeem all the maturing securities the Social Security system will cash in to pay retirement benefits. The shapes up as a major problem with no end to the government's red ink in sight. Moynihan _ who was a member of the 1982 Social Security commission _ would cut the payroll tax by 0.14 percent now and by another 0.96 percent next January. He would begin boosting rates again in the year 2015, giving the country 25 years of lower taxes he says will help the economy grow and allow it to better afford the higher levies later. His plan would also shrink the Social Security surplus and thus pump up the overall federal deficit, turning up the political heat to address the budget shortfall. ``It has now become clear that the administration intends to use the Social Security payroll tax as an ongoing, permanent source of revenue for the general purposes of government,'' Moynihan, chairman of the Senate Finance Social Security subcommittee, said when he announced his plan last month. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater derided the plan last Thursday. ``The Social Security system is sound. Let the Democrats fool with it, not us,'' he said. Moynihan's cut would cost $62 billion over the next two years, and critics say it would shift the burden of financing baby boomers' retirements to later generations. ``This smacks a little bit of the Reagan philosophy, which can be summed up as `Don't visit your grandchildren, just send them the bill,''' says Rep. Andrew Jacobs, D-Ind., chairman of the House Ways and Means Social Security subcommittee. But the proposal could be irresistible to lawmakers, who love a chance to cut taxes. ``We've been called by offices from both sides of the aisle,'' says lobbyist Judy Schub of the American Association of Retired Persons, which so far has shied away from Moynihan's plan. ``It's got a lot of appeal.'' Moynihan's proposal is one of several Social Security bills Congress will face when it returns from its winter recess on Jan. 23. Since last January, about 20 bills have been spawned excluding the Social Security trust fund from deficit calculations. Many concede the political appeal of the off-budget proposals is probably unstoppable. In a measure of the idea's appeal, the White House says President Bush will include a version of the plan in the fiscal 1991 budget he presents Congress on Jan. 29.

DOC.HEAD: Army to Test Program to Destroy Chemical Weapons
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: The Army plans to start burning about 30,000 tons of chemical weapons in a project _ designed to make the world safer _ that is arousing concern in some of the eight states where the destruction will occur. ``We feel it is a risky scenario,'' said Linda Kaplovitz, an environmentalist who lives near the Aberdeen Proving Ground, where tons of mustard blistering agent are stored and will be burned. ``We don't want another Bhopal or Chernobyl, God forbid,'' she said. Such fears are overdrawn, said Col. Walter L. Busbee, commander of the Army's ``chemical demilitarization'' program. He was interviewed at his headquarters, a low cinder block building overlooking the Chesapeake Bay, 25 miles northeast of Baltimore. The nine-year, $3.1 billion project has undergone rigorous scientific scrutiny, he said, adding the burning will not begin until he is satisfied with a test program due to begin in March on a remote Pacific island. Congress has ordered the Army to destroy almost all of its aging chemical arsenal by 1997. After the 16-month test, destruction will begin at eight other sites in Maryland, Kentucky, Alabama, Utah, Indiana, Oregon, Arkansas and Colorado. Under pressure from Congress, the Army scheduled destruction last at the two most populous sites, Aberdeen and at the Lexington-Bluegrass Army Depot in Kentucky, Busbee said. Environmental concerns are twofold: that a destruction facility could explode or leak, and that the exhaust cannot be scrubbed clean. Each part of the facility will be sealed against leaks and reinforced against explosions, Busbee said. ``I'm not telling you that there will never be an accident or an incident,'' he said, but added, ``the probability, we think, is very low.'' Mrs. Kaplovitz cited a long list of possible pollutants from the facility, including dioxins, which researchers blame for ailments ranging from headaches to birth defects, cancer and toxic poisoning. The environmental organization Greenpeace International has warned that gases given off at the test site, on Johnston Atoll 800 miles southwest of Hawaii, could harm marine life. ``We feel that the Army has ignored quite a few major environmental concerns,'' said Sebia Hawkins, a Greenpeace activist in Washington. The Army's approach was recommended by the National Academy of Sciences and the plans were reviewed by the Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Health and Human Services. Harvard University chemist Matthew Meselson said the facilities are likely to cause less pollution than many urban refuse incinerators because the chemical reactions are more predictable and more easily monitored. ``There is something that has to be recognized here, and that is that we are going to do this once. We are not building something for mankind for its indefinite future. It doesn't have to be the last word in technology,'' said Meselson, who previously has challenged the government on other issues. Busbee's organization is to begin the test run of its first full-scale destruction facility on Johnston Atoll in March, burning chemical agents that were stored on Okinawa until 1971 and others that are scheduled to be moved from West Germany sometime in the next two years. ``If it operates as it is designed, and I will not operate it any other way, nothing will come down but a plume'' of nearly pure exhaust, said Busbee. The weapons to be destroyed are decades old and consist of the nerve agents Sarin and VX, and the mustard blistering agents H, HD and HT, contained in mines, artillery shells, rockets and storage tanks. Although the Bush administration is negotiating a global convention to ban chemical arms, it also is producing a new generation of so-called binary weapons. Chemical components in the binary weapons are kept separate until use, which Army officials say makes them safer to store or destroy. Destruction at each site will vary according to the chemicals there. Each will include two incinerators to burn the agent at 2,700 degrees Fahrenheit, said Busbee. The first incineration should destroy the poisons instantly, and the second, the ``afterburner,'' is insurance, he said. The fumes will be scrubbed and will be monitored for toxic substances, he said. Incineration in the continental United States will not start ``until it has been proven that is a safe way to do it,'' said Rep. Larry Hopkins, R-Ky. The Kentucky legislature passed a law requiring that the incinerator exhaust be 99.9999 percent pure, which Busbee says is the Army's target.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Burning Poison Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Army plans to begin destruction in March of its stock of aging chemical weapons, which are stored in eight states, West Germany and a remote island in the South Pacific. The program, according to current projections, will last nine years and cost an estimated $3.1 billion, including management and research costs. Here are the nine sites where chemical agents would be destroyed, with the percentage of the arsenal at each, the type of munitions and the estimated cost of each disposal facility, and dates of construction, operation and completion, according to the most recent Pentagon data.

JOHNSTON ATOLL, 800 miles southwest of Hawaii, claimed by the United States since 1958. Stored there is, or will be, 6.6 percent of the total arsenal by chemical agent weight, consisting of munitions moved from Okinawa in 1971 and being moved by sea from West Germany at a cost of $28.4 million within the next two years. The main island, consisting of 630 largely manmade acres, is the site of Johnston Atoll Chemical Agent Disposal System, which in March is scheduled to begin a 16-month trial period and to complete its work by June 1994. Construction began in November 1985, and according to the most recent public estimate by the Army, will cost $278 million.

ALABAMA, Anniston Army Depot, built in 1941 on 3,009 acres 50 miles west of Birmingham. Stored there is 7.1 percent of the total stockpile by agent weight, consisting of the nerve agent Sarin, known as GB, the nerve agent VX, and the mustard blistering agents H, HD, and HT, in cartridges, projectiles, rockets, mines and one-ton containers. Construction to commence September 1991. Weapons destruction to begin March 1995 and end April 1997 at an estimated cost of $245.8 million.

ARKANSAS, Pine Bluff Arsenal, established in 1941 on 14,454 acres 35 miles southeast of Little Rock. The arsenal still manufactures chemical warfare materiel, filling hand grenades, rockets and shells, producing and testing such defensive equipment as masks and protective clothing and designing new equipment. Stored there is 12 percent of the stockpile, consisting of agents HD, HT, GB and VX in cartridges, rockets, mines and one-ton containers. Construction to commence September 1991. Weapons destruction to begin in March 1995 and end in December 1996 at an estimated cost of $227.4 million.

COLORADO, Pueblo Army Depot Activity, established in 1942 on 22,654 acres 14 miles east of Pueblo. Stored there is 9.9 percent of the total stockpile, consisting of agents HD and HT in cartridges and projectiles. Construction was to begin in June 1992. Weapons destruction was to start in November 1995 and last until February 1997 at an estimated cost of $212.2 million.

INDIANA, Newport Army Ammunition Plant, established in 1942 on 6,990 acres 30 miles southeast of Danville. Stored there is 3.9 percent of the total stockpile, consisting of nerve agent VX in one-ton containers. Construction to begin in June 1992. Weapons destruction was to begin in April 1995 and last until July 1996 at an estimated cost of $113.9 million.

KENTUCKY, Lexington-Blue Grass Army Depot, established 1941 on 14,450 acres nine miles East of Lexington. Stored there is 1.6 percent of the stockpile, consisting of agents H, GB and VX in projectiles, rockets and one-ton containers. Construction to commence September 1992. Weapons destruction to begin March 1996 and end February 1997 at an estimated cost of $ 193.45 million.

MARYLAND, Aberdeen Proving Ground, established in 1917 on 73,000 acres by the Chesapeake Bay 25 miles north of Baltimore. Five percent of the total stockpile by agent weight, consisting of mustard blistering agents, kept in one-ton containers. Construction to commence June 1992. Weapons incineration to begin April 1995 and end September 1996 at an estimated cost of $128.1 million. Aberdeen is also the site of a $35 million facility to train all personnel who will operate destruction facilities nationwide.

OREGON, Umatilla Army Depot Activity, established in 1940 on 19,700 acres 8.5 miles west of Hermiston. Stored at Umatilla is 11.6 percent of the total stockpile, including agents HD, GB and VX in projectiles, rockets, bombs, mines, spray tanks and one-ton containers. Construction was to begin in June 1992. Weapons destruction was to start in April 1995 and end in July 1996 at an estimated cost of $261 million.

UTAH, Tooele Army Depot, established in 1942 and spread over seven locations. The main depot complex consists of 136,804 acres, where 42.3 percent of the total stockpile is stored, including agents H, HD, HT, GB, VX and L in projectiles, cartridges, rockets, bombs, mines, spray tanks and one-ton containers. The depot also includes a prototype Chemical Agent Munitions Disposal System, on a 19,364-acre tract. Construction began in September 1989. Weapons destruction was to start in February 1993 and end in April 1997 at an estimated cost of $381.27.

DOC.HEAD: Running for President Gets Members of Congress on TV, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress get much more attention from television network news when they run for president than for their nuts-and-bolts work in Washington, says a new study. Democrat Richard Gephardt barely rated a mention on the evening news for his congressional work on the federal tax code, but a bid for the presidency in 1988 propelled him into prime time. The same was true for Albert Gore Jr., Lloyd Bentsen, Paul Simon and Dan Quayle, who found that mention on CBS, NBC and ABC was the result of their political aspirations rather than their jobs in Congress. ``As an everyday member of Congress, they might not ever be mentioned,'' said Joe S. Foote, a former congressional staffer and chairman of the radio-television department at Southern Illinois University in Carbondale. In fact, 44 percent of the House members were never mentioned on the nightly news programs during 1987-88, Foote's study said. ``As the 1980s passed by, congressional backbenchers found it was harder and harder to break into the national spotlight as defined by ABC, CBS and NBC,'' Foote said. The result is that some of the newer and younger members of Congress have ``fewer and fewer opportunities to influence public opinion,'' he said. ``We rarely hear their ideas.'' Foote, who has conducted the annual analysis of lawmakers' TV visibility for nearly a decade, said the study released this week shows that Gephardt, who made an unsuccessful bid for the Democratic presidential nomination in 1988, was mentioned just 25 times on the nightly news in 1985-86 during the 99th Congress. During the 100th Congress, shortly after Gephardt announced his candidacy in February 1987, he totaled 253 mentions that included use of his name in a report, a film clip or an interview. Foote based the study on the Television News Index and Abstracts at the Vanderbilt University News Archive in Nashville, Tenn., which tracked mentions on the evening news programs of the three networks. Cable News Network was not included. For other lawmakers, the jump from obscurity to often-mentioned was a major leap after they sought the presidency or vice presidency. Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., a 1988 presidential candidate, was mentioned 35 times in 1985-86, 104 in 1987-88. Sen. Albert Gore Jr., of Tennessee, another 1988 Democratic hopeful, rose from 27 mentions in 1985-86 to 209 in 1987-88. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., rated 15 mentions in 1985-86, but 200 in 1987-88. Dan Quayle, the Republican senator from Indiana, received six mentions in 1985-86, but skyrocketed to 172 in 1987-88, which included his election as vice president. Heading the list of mentions among the lawmakers who sought higher office was Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., with 276 in 1985-86 and 486 in 1987-88. By virtue of those totals, Dole also led all 100 senators in TV exposure in 1987-88. Gore was second with 209, Simon was third with 200 and Sen. Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the 1988 Democratic vice presidential candidate, was fourth with 199. During 1985-86, Bentsen managed just 14 mentions on the nightly news. Bentsen edged out Quayle, who was fifth among senators with 172 mentions in 1987-88. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., the chairman of the Armed Services Committee, was sixth with 155 mentions and Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., former Senate majority leader, was seventh with 144 mentions in 1987-88. At the bottom of the list with no mentions from 1987 to 1988 were Sens. Quentin Burdick, D-N.D.; Wendell Ford, D-Ky.; and Harry Reid, D-Nev. In 1987-88, the study found 10 percent of the members of the Senate accounted for nearly 50 percent of all network Senate coverage. Less than 3 percent of the membership in the House made up about 90 percent of the network House coverage during the same two-year period. Gephardt led the list of House members with 253 mentions; former House Speaker Jim Wright, D-Texas, was second with 196; and Jack Kemp, the former New York congressman who was thwarted in his bid for the GOP nomination, was third with 193 mentions. Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., a co-chairman of the congressional Iran-Contra committees, received 89 mentions in 1987-88. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the Armed Services Committee, was fifth with 59 mentions.

DOC.HEAD: Thrift Complain New Federal Rule Breaks Government Pledge
DOC.TEXT: Buyers of failed savings institutions in 1988 are protesting a new regulation that revokes some of the financial breaks they received from the government as part of the deal. The Office of Thrift Supervision says savings and loans must meet new and tougher capital requirements, regardless of whether they earlier received an exemption, known as a ``forbearance,'' from meeting capital standards. Institutions that fail the requirement must come up with an acceptable plan to raise the money or face restrictions on their ability to make new loans and investments. Attorneys representing buyers in the 1988 deals regard the new rule as a double-cross and predict the legal battle over the issue will reach the Supreme Court. ``If this is upheld, nobody will ever feel secure doing business with the government,'' Washington attorney and S&L lobbyist Douglas P. Faucette said Monday. Industry analysts predict some of the 86 rescue deals in 1988 covering 205 institutions could unravel as a result of the ruling, forcing either a second bailout or a payoff of depositors. ``Some would basically be targets for'' government takeover, said James Barth of Auburn University, formerly chief economist of the thrift office. He added the second rescues could be even more expensive than the first round because of changes in the law making it less attractive to own thrifts. Thrift institution owners, under President Bush's bailout plan enacted in August, must put up at least $1.50 in tangible capital for every $100 in loans or other investment the institution makes. Owners of some S&Ls acquired from the government in 1988 had thought the forbearances they negotiated would exempt them from fully meeting the standard. They now learn they will have to risk just as much of their own money as the owners of any other institution. The thrift office, in a statement announcing the new rules after business hours on Friday, said the changes were required by last year's bailout bill. But attorneys representing the 1988 buyers dispute that and complain the government, by reneging on the deals, is in effect illegally seizing private property. Faucette predicted the owners of S&Ls purchased in the 1988 deals will sue the government, joining other S&L buyers from the early 1980s who lost a different kind of accounting break, known as regulatory goodwill. ``To me these cases ... have a profound impact on anyone who does business with the government,'' he said. ``I fear because of the dimensions of this (S&L) scandal, Congress and the public believe the ends justify the means.'' However, Barth said the regulators' decision on forbearances will probably be upheld because it is in the public interest. Requiring S&L owners to risk more of their own capital provides a buffer between losses and government deposit insurance. It also gives S&L owners an incentive to operate their institutions more safely. ``One has to question any sort of capital forbearance,'' Barth said. ``Still, once they were granted, I can understand why the acquirers are extremely unhappy with the rules being changed in the middle of the game.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. May Export More Lumber as Asian Nations Bow Out
DOC.TEXT: Cutbacks in sales of hardwood timber products by some Southeast Asian countries are putting pressure on the United States to export more logs and rough lumber, according to an Agriculture Department report. Indonesia recently announced large increases in export taxes ``that make the export of hardwood logs and lumber nearly prohibitive,'' the report said. The action puts Indonesia among a growing number of Asian countries that are curbing exports of logs and rough lumber in favor of sending furniture and other ``value-added'' products made from wood abroad. ``Malaysia and the Philippines have previously taken action to curb such exports, while Taiwan and Thailand have officially banned commercial logging,'' the report said. ``These actions are increasing the pressure on the U.S. industry to fill this growing gap in international supply.'' The report by the department's Foreign Agricultural Service said the value of U.S. exports of solid wood products were up 15 percent from a year earlier in the first nine months of 1989, while imports were up only 7 percent. Overall, exports were valued at nearly $4.59 billion in the first three quarters of last year. Japan accounted for $2.2 billion, or 48 percent of the U.S. wood exports, mostly as softwood logs. Canada was the second-largest market during the January-September period with $501.5 million, or 11 percent of the total. South Korea was another big overseas buyer at $267.6 million. Analyst Margie Bauer of the USDA agency said the furniture industry is undergoing major changes and there are opportunities for U.S. exporters. ``Currently, Taiwan and, to a smaller degree, Korea are the major furniture exporters in Asia,'' she said in the report. ``The export furniture industries in Taiwan and Korea are facing severe problems such as workers demanding higher wages, a shortage of labor and high production costs.'' Bauer added: ``Thus, the industries are relocating to Southeast Asia, primarily Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia. Manufacturers in Taiwan and Korea rely heavily on hardwood logs from Southeast Asia and hardwood products from North America.'' The recent restrictions on exports by some of the Southeast Asian countries, however, have reduced the supply of relatively inexpensive hardwood logs, she said. As a result, U.S. hardwood logs, lumber, veneers and panel products ``have an enormous potential'' market in the new furniture producing countries. ``While the industry in these countries is young and inexperienced, there is little doubt that it will grow tremendously,'' Bauer said. ``Now is the time for the U.S. industry to work together in educating these countries on the advantages of using U.S. hardwoods in the manufacturing of furniture.''

Farmers begin signing up today in the major 1990 crop acreage programs at local Agriculture Department offices. The signup runs through April 13. Participating farmers agree to set-aside from production part of their base acreage for individual crops. Wheat farmers, for example, will have a basic ``acreage reduction'' program of 5 percent, while feed grains producers will have to idle 10 percent of their base acres. When farmers enroll at local offices of the Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service, they also may ask for advance cash payments of 40 percent of the expected deficiency payments that will be due in the 1990 program. Final settlement, minus the advances, will be made at the end of the crop season when the full deficiency payments are computed. The payments are designed to make up the difference between market prices and a higher target level. The department said recently that the advance payments for 1990 will be reduced by 1.4 percent as required by the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1989.

The National Turkey Federation is looking for entries in its new ``Turkey Lovers Recipe Contest'' for young chefs 12 to 18. Entries can be submitted through April 15 and will be judged on the basis of the recipe itself, the nutritional content of the ingredients, and the food-handling techniques followed during preparation. The federation said the recipes must include at least one pound of fresh or fully cooked turkey meat. Two brief essays describing the nutritional quality and food handling also must be submitted. Further information, including contest rules, are available by sending a self-addressed stamped envelope to: Rules, National Turkey Federation, 11319 Sunset Hills Road, Reston, Va. 22090. The senior event in poultry cooking belongs to the National Broiler Council, which sponsors the annual national chicken cooking contest, which began more than 30 years ago among producers in the Delmarva area of Delaware, Maryland and Virginia. The council took it over in 1972 and made it a national event, giving it a leg up on the turkey people, so to speak.

DOC.HEAD: Met Opera Does First `Gioconda' in Seven Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: ``La Gioconda,'' heard at the Metropolitan Opera during its first season, back in 1883, was presented for the first time this season with a sterling cast, most of them relative newcomers to the Met. Conductor Nello Santi got the sounds he wanted from the Met Orchestra. Monday's was the first performance of the opera at the Met in seven years. ``La Gioconda,'' by Amilcare Ponchielli, is as melodic as a Puccini opera. It's grand opera, needing lavish sets and costumes, which it has from Beni Montresor's designs for the Met's opening week in Lincoln Center in 1966. It also calls for a huge chorus, a big ballet and big, emotional voices. Ghena Dimitrova had a rough edge on her voice in the first two acts in the title role.
