But it's a passionate role so not inappropriate, and her voice was more attractive in the last two acts. The Bulgarian soprano made her Met debut as Turandot in 1987. The Met announced in September that Luciano Pavarotti wouldn't be singing Enzo as planned and Nicola Martinucci would sing. However, Bruno Beccaria, who has a fresh, open-toned, young-sounding voice, sang with vigor and made a triumph. Alain Fondary, from Paris, who made his Met debut in 1988, is just the kind of baritone the Met needs. As a spy he put a menacing edge on his large voice but his vocal beauty flowed through, showing that he needn't always sound evil. His low notes were firm, a couple of very high notes less so. Alexandrina Milcheva, also of Bulgaria and also debuting in 1987, is a mezzo but sounded like a wonderful contralto as Gioconda's mother. Stefania Toczyska of Poland, who bowed at the Met in 1988, was very effective as Laura. Her husband was sung by a worthy Met veteran, Paul Plishka. Laura and Gioconda love the same man _ Enzo. He loves Laura which causes stress, attempted murder and suicide in several directions. ``The Dance of the Hours,'' newly staged this season by Rodney Griffin, doesn't amount to much, not even getting peppy when the famous music speeds up.

DOC.HEAD: Think Tank: U.S. Spending on Education Lags Behind Other Nations
DOC.TEXT: Thirteen other industrial nations spend relatively more on elementary and secondary education than the United States, says a report that challenges President Bush's assertion that results _ not resources _ are the problem. The United States leads only Ireland and Australia among industrial nations, the labor-backed Economic Policy Institute said Monday in a briefing paper ``Shortchanging Education.'' ``If the U.S. were to increase spending for primary and secondary school up to the `average' level found in the other 15 countries, we would need to raise spending by over $20 billion annually,'' said the report. M. Edith Rasell, author of the report, said the results were based on data published by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization and by the federal government. It focused on elementary and secondary education spending for 1985, comparing expenditures as a percentage of national income. The Education Department disputed the study's findings. Deputy Undersecretary Charles Kolb, in charge of the agency's budget, said the institute used ``seriously flawed methodology to reach dubious conclusions.'' Kolb said the institute ``has mixed apples, oranges and moonbeams to produce an indigestible concoction.'' He said the United States ranks among the top five countries by the department's calculations. ``It's fun to play with numbers but it can be a dangerous delusion if used as a basis for public policy,'' he said. ``If nothing else, this report points out the need for better math education.'' The institute's statistics show the United States spent 4.1 percent of its national income on K-12 education in 1985, while the average abroad was 4.6 percent. Sweden spent 7 percent, followed by Austria at 5.9 percent, Switzerland at 5.8 percent, Norway at 5.3 percent, Belgium at 4.9 percent and Denmark and Japan at 4.8 percent. Canada spent 4.7 percent, West Germany and France, 4.6 percent, the Netherlands and United Kingdom, 4.5 percent and Italy, 4.2 percent. Behind the United States in spending, Australia spent 3.9 percent and Ireland spent 3.8 percent. Ms. Rasell said this is the first time ``that economists have examined the factual underpinnings of the Bush administration's claims about education spending.'' The report pointed to President Bush's statement at last fall's education summit that the ``U.S. lavishes unsurpassed resources on schooling ... (and) our focus must no longer be on resources. It must be on results.'' According to the report, ``We recognize that money does not guarantee excellence and we suspect that other changes _ in curriculum, in the status of teachers, and in expectations about students, to name just a few _ will also be fundamental to any improvement in education quality and student achievement. ``But to begin a process of education reform by denying the need to increase spending, especially when U.S. schools are underfunded compared to those in other industrialized countries, places a severely limiting constraint on any plans for educational improvement.'' To show problems with comparing relative expenditures, Kolb said that in 1986, Mississippi spent per pupil 3.9 percent of its state domestic product, while Minnesota spent 3.7 percent. However, in dollars, Mississippi spent only $2,350 per pupil, compared with Minnesota's $4,180. The report acknowledged that the ``U.S. spends comparatively more than other countries on higher education.'' Ms. Rasell said that ``when expenditures on all levels of education _ pre-primary, primary, secondary and post-secondary _ are calculated, the United States is in a three-way tie for second place among the countries studied.'' But when spending on higher education is removed from comparative data, the report said ``the relative position of U.S. spending falls from a three-way tie for second highest in spending to close to the bottom of the group of 16 industrial nations.''

DOC.HEAD: Dole Says Cut Aid to Israel, Give More to Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Bob Dole is proposing that the United States reduce aid to Israel, Egypt, the Philippines, Turkey and Pakistan by 5 percent and give the money to fledgling democracies such as Poland, Hungary and Panama. ``To me, it boils down to this: Are big gains for freedom worth a small cut in a few huge foreign aid programs? I say yes,'' the Kansas Republican and Senate minority leader wrote in an opinion piece in The New York Times today. The five countries he named as targets for reductions are the largest recipients of U.S. foreign assistance. They receive more than two-thirds of U.S. foreign aid. ``Does it make sense, at this historic moment, to provide these countries practically all of our aid at the cost of foreclosing dramatically promising new aid initiatives in Eastern Europe or other important countries?'' Dole wrote. ``What about, for example, those Latin American nations in the front lines in the war against drugs?'' A 5 percent cut in aid to the five countries would free about $330 million, Dole said. The United States plans to spend $14.5 billion on foreign aid this year. Of that, Israel is allocated $3 billion and Egypt is to receive $2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Is Done After Decades
With PM-Bulgaria, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Victims of Stalinist murders and repression in Bulgaria saw their cause vindicated at last when Parliament voted to rehabilitate dozens who suffered in dark years of jails and political trials. Two prominent victims: Nikola Petkov, executed in 1947, and Ivan Todorov, dead of alleged suicide after his arrest in 1965, were among dozens of people whose honor was officially restored by parliamentary vote on Monday. Petkov, leader of the once powerful Bulgarian Agrarian Union party, died as Communists moved throughout Eastern Europe to establish the monopoly on political power that was voted out of Bulgaria's constitution on Monday. Many of Petkov's associates also died in Bulgaria's purges, which have never been fully examined. Todor Zhivkov, the hard-line Communist leader ousted Nov. 10, discouraged close examination of a past during his 35 years in power. The less powerful Social Democratic Party was also a victim of the Communist repression in those years, although it was not banned outright, recalled a witnesss, Ruen Krumov, former editor of the Socialist newspaper. At least 29 prominent members of his party went to jail, Krumov told reporters. He spent five years in labor camp. ``I'm very happy,'' he said as justice was done after decades. ``They asked us what we wanted, and we got what we wanted.'' Earlier, Mikhail Genovsky, an elderly deputy from the Bulgarian Agrarian Party _ the rump of Petkov's party, allowed by the Communists under strict control _ expressed more bitterness about the long-silenced history that now haunts the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. ``The blood that has been shed, we cannot forget,'' he urged Parliament, recalling how ``they even sent a murderer all the way to Prague'' to kill another Agrarian leader. As in Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Poland, where parties long subservient to the Communists have now found an independent voice, the Agrarians in Bulgaria had been pushing for Petkov's rehabilitation even before Zhivkov's ouster. The suppression of the Agrarians in the 1940s enhanced not only the political monopoly of the Communists but also paved the way for collectivization of Bulgaria's traditionally strong, peasant-based agriculture. The totalitarian intolerance also doomed Todorov, who was arrested for his alleged part in plotting against Zhivkov in 1965. Said to have committed suicide, he is believed to have been murdered. Others rehabilitated Monday included Lyudmila Slavova, the 28-year-old leader of the Socialist youth when she was murdered in jail in 1948. As the country embarks on a journey into its past, Bulgarian newspapers have recently carried several articles about the victims of repression and their rehabilitation. Genovsky called for more frankness. The history of his party, he stressed, was swallowed by the Communists who under Zhivkov kept the party strictly limited to 120,000 members. ``This was no history,'' Genovsky told deputies. ``History is a science ... We have yet to undertake a scientific history of the Bulgarian Communist Party and the Agrarian Party.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final item to restore first name of Bettman in 2nd graf; Version moved on sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: The National Basketball Association is taking the air out of a $1 million one-on-one duel between superstars Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls and Magic Johnson of the Los Angeles Lakers. ``A one-on-one game between Michael and Magic is neither something that (the NBA) would want to sponsor itself or have some other promoter do. NBA basketball games and the talents of our players are something that the NBA and its teams should be promoting, not third-party promoters,'' said Gary Bettman, NBA senior vice president and general counsel, told the Chicago Sun-Times. The only exceptions to the rule are exhibition games for charity, Bettman said. The proposed contest would consist of two 15-minute halves to be broadcast on pay television. The winner would receive $1 million, with any additional money going to charities of the players' choices, said Ross Levinsohn, a New York-based spokesman for Jordan.

DOC.HEAD: Now Chain Saws Are for Art, Too
LaserPhoto MR1
DOC.TEXT: Chain saws aren't just for massacres anymore. Now they're for art, too. In Vermont, as in some other rural areas of the country, the power tool best known for felling trees _ or as a prop in horror movies _ is being used to sculpt figures out of wood. Along Route 100, between Waterbury and Stowe, roadside menageries have sprouted, featuring life-size bears, buffaloes, eagles, moose, skunks and giraffes carved with a chain saw. At one shop, hidden behind layers of sawdust, ear plugs and a pair of welding goggles, Max Osorio bobs and jabs like a boxer _ except he's armed with a chain saw and his opponent is a block of wood. Wood chips fly. Curious tourists stop and watch. But Osorio does not stop. It takes him eight hours to make a 6-foot bear or Indian, the two pieces that sell the most. Osorio starts with a tree trunk and envisions the figure. Then, he hacks at it with unwavering attention, and recognizable parts begin to appear. First the coarse head, the beak, then a wing, the talons, and slowly, an eagle is born. ``It is still very rough, but when you consider I am working with a chain saw, it's remarkable,'' boasted Osorio. ``I try to make the most detailed, realistic sculptures as possible with the tool,'' said Osorio, who placed second last summer in the fourth-annual World Championship Chain-saw Contest in Hill City, Minn. ``It just takes practice.'' Osorio, a naturalized U.S. citizen who was born in Mexico, began carving after working as a dishwasher in Stowe. ``One day I drove by a place and saw the wooden bears _ they were selling them for $800 _ and I thought to myself, `I could do that,''' Osorio said. Carving wasn't as easy as it looked, but he started with a 12-inch seated bear and has worked his way up to life-size animal and human figures. ``Once I learned how, I wanted to do more than just the static bear sitting, doing nothing. I try to get detail and action,'' he said. There is plenty of action in Osorio's latest creation, an old man on skis chasing a buxom skier in a bikini. Even the locals turn their heads. Osorio, like other Vermont carvers, learned the craft at the Spinning Wheel, a Route 100 gift shop. Owner Milo Marshall said he learned the skill six years ago from an Arizona man who was traveling through Vermont. Marshall's wife, Emma, said half of the shop's $400,000 gross annual income comes from chain-saw sculpture sales. After two years at the Spinning Wheel, Osorio moved to the Mousetrap, a gift shop down the road. Some of Osorio's sculptures sell for $2,000, and most between $250 and $500, with a 10 percent commission to the shop, but Osorio is reluctant to disclose how much he makes. ``All I'll say, is for somebody without a degree, who doesn't speak good English, it's a good living.'' One statue of an Indian that Osorio made was so perfect, he said, he wanted to keep it for himself so he put a high price on it. ``But a man from Long Island came and his girlfriend liked it. He was not scared of the price,'' Osorio said. The man also paid Osorio to drive it to Long Island, where the man wanted to stand the 10-foot Indian behind his desk. With three shops on Route 100 in Waterbury selling chain-saw sculptures, the competition is fierce, but friendly. ``If the place down the road specializes in pigs, I won't do a pig,'' Osorio said. ``But bears, everybody does the bears.'' Pine Tree Creations, the smallest of the three, feels the competition, owner Doug Joslyn said. He said he recently put up a sign that now brings more tourists to his shop. ``But if I had a quarter for every person who took a picture, I'd be better off than selling them,'' said Joslyn. Mrs. Marshall said tour buses often stop in her shop. ``Some buses stop just because the people on the bus start screaming, `Stop!','' she said. ``The life-sized buffalo stopped traffic for a long time.''

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: They show up on television as often as six times a day, the advertisements with pastoral scenes of waves, fields and forest, the soothing voiceovers that ask existential questions about eternity and values. ``A new vision, more idealistic,'' the voice promises. Despite the lack of automobile in the ad, many recognize the spot as a commercial for Infiniti, the Japanese luxury car. But to some New England viewers, not all is as it appears. A series of advertisements parodying the Infiniti approach has had New England talking, laughing and watching. ``Questions. What are we for? Why am I here?'' asks a voice narrating one of the parodic spots, as the camera shows a forest scene. The voice continues: ``especially when Oldsmobile is having a great sale right now.'' The camera cuts to a plug from an Oldsmobile spokesman, a few shots of cars, and a running track of the theme song ``This is not your father's Oldsmobile.'' When the scene returns to the forest, the voice asks: ``What is a factory-to-dealer incentive anyway?'' It trails off, wondering: ``How much wood could a woodchuck chuck, if a woodchuck could chuck...'' To the makers of the Infiniti ad, imitation is the best form of flattery. ``I think it's a terrific parody. They did a terrific job of playing around with our ad,'' said Chuck Kushell, executive vice president, general manager at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc. Advertising of Los Angeles, where the Infiniti ads were made. In a November Gallup poll for Advertising Age magazine, the Infiniti series had the best recall of all of the ads that month among 1,000 viewers surveyed, ``over Coke, over McDonalds,'' Kushell said. Sidney Zussman, president of The New England Oldsmobile Dealers and the owner of West Street Motors in Methuen, said his group loved the ads _ and that sales at Oldsmobile went up 25 percent during the holiday markdowns that were publicized by the ads.
DOC.HEAD: Laserphoto HL1 of Jan. 15
DOC.TEXT: Katherine Summers mined the hills west of here for 30 years, but it was in a Missoula grocery store that she finally struck it rich. The 78-year-old widow is the state's first jackpot winner in Lotto America, sharing a $3.5 million prize in Saturday's drawing with a Wisconsin man. Mrs. Summers said Monday she plans to use her $1.75 million in winnings to do some prospecting for gold in Alaska. She wants to buy a small van and head north for the summer to visit relatives and ``pan the beaches at Nome.'' Next winter she has her sights set on Australia and New Zealand. Beyond that, Mrs. Summers is not sure how she will spend the estimated $70,000 a year after-tax winnings. ``What do you do about long-range plans when you're 78 years old?'' she asked with a laugh. Mrs. Summers, from the town of Basin, splits the jackpot with Thomas Petzko, 56, a retired sheet-metal worker from Milwaukee.

DOC.HEAD: Smoking, Cholesterol Increase Risk of Heart Disease Before Age 35
DOC.TEXT: Young men who smoke or have high cholesterol levels are more likely than others to show signs of heart disease before they reach age 35, a study shows. The study is the first to link blood cholesterol levels and smoking directly to hardening of the arteries, a precursor or heart attacks and strokes, one of the study's directors said. Dr. Henry McGill said Monday that smoking in young men was a stronger risk for artery damage than he had anticipated. ``In this age group, smoking and cholesterol are about equally bad,'' said McGill. ``What surprised me ... was the effect of smoking.'' The findings, which McGill presented at the American Heart Association's annual science writers' forum, are based on autopsies of about 300 15- to 34-year-old white men who died violent deaths or in accidents. The results support the contention of many cardiologists, including McGill, who favor early steps to prevent heart disease. ``I really believe that the future of prevention of heart disease in middle-age people has got to start in childhood,'' he said. By age 34, one-fourth of the subjects already had what doctors call ``raised lesions'' in their arteries, representing the beginning of hardening of the arteries. Hardening of the arteries can lead to blockage of those blood vessels, which in turn can cause a heart attack or a stroke. Some doctors disagree with the suggestion that prevention of heart disease should begin in childhood. The heart association recommends that healthy children should consume less than 300 milligrams of cholesterol per day and moderate their intake of fats. But some doctors believe the evidence is not yet strong enough to make such recommendations, McGill said. Only one previous study had looked at hardening of the arteries in young people, McGill said. That was a study described last year by Dr. Gerald Berenson of New Orleans, who found that artery damage in 40 children and young adults was worse in those who had high levels of the so-called bad cholesterol, known scientifically as low-density lipoprotein, or LDL. McGill's study, led by Dr. Robert Wissler of the University of Chicago, is the first to link the artery damage in young people to smoking and ``good cholesterol'' _ high-density lipoprotein, or HDL. To illustrate how important the effects were, McGill said that a 25-year-old man who smoked and had high levels of good cholesterol would have twice the artery damage of a 25-year-old non-smoker who had low levels of LDL. The findings were the first report from the study, which is continuing and eventually will include 1,800 subjects. The study will explore how atherosclerosis is linked to high blood pressure, diabetes, inherited factors and many other processes inside arteries, McGill said.

DOC.HEAD: New CBS Entertainment Chief Maps Out Plans for Reviving Network
DOC.TEXT: The newly appointed president of CBS Entertainment says the network must overhaul its antiquated prime-time lineup to rise out of last place in the ratings. Jeff Sagansky, who joined CBS two weeks ago from his position as president of Tri-Star Pictures, said the current schedule appeals to viewers ``well over 45'' years old, and that the network ``is programming too narrowly in that direction. ``I don't think the network can be just a narrowcasting vehicle,'' Sagansky said Monday night. ``We do need more comedies,'' he said. ``The question is which night do you open a comedy night on?'' Sagansky confessed that CBS is in worse shape than NBC was 10 years ago, when that network was in distant third. Sagansky said one of the obstacles to CBS' comeback was that the current television marketplace is more competitive. He said that one of the network's top priorities is re-establishing contacts with some of Hollywood's more dynamic producers. He said he would offer fresh talent the chance ``to do the show that they've always wanted to do.'' Sagansky, whose record at Tri-Star included such flops as ``Lock-up'' and hits like ``Steel Magnolias,'' said that the network's struggling ``Pat Sajak Show'' would undergo several changes beginning in February, but was in no immediate peril of cancellation. He defended his recent cancellation of the cult favorite drama ``Beauty and the Beast,'' saying its ratings ``came to have no future.'' ``Wolf,'' which he also canceled, was ``done in ... by very bad ratings.'' He said he hoped that in five years, the length of his contract with CBS, he would have returned the network to first place. Part of his plan, he said, rested with the re-introduction of one-hour dramas, which have given way to situation comedies in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Angered At Communists, Protesters Ransack Secret Police Headquarters
LaserPhotos NYY5,7
DOC.TEXT: Communist authorities warned that efforts to build democracy were in jeopardy after East Germans gripped by new revolutionary fervor stormed the headquarters of the despised secret police and ransacked it. Hundreds of thousands of other protesters took to the streets Monday night across the country, expressing anger at Communist leaders for not moving faster to dismantle the secret police and implement reforms. They demanded the ouster of the Communists. Three months after a peaceful popular revolt toppled old hard-line Communist leaders, the party still essentially controls the government, media, economy and bureaucracy. In the southern city of Cottbus, several dozen protesters pelted the local secret police building with rocks and clashed with guards in an unsuccessful attempt to storm it, news reports said. The Communist-led caretaker government, feeling the greatest pressure in weeks, said the storming of the secret police headquarters in East Berlin posed ``the gravest danger'' to efforts to establish true democracy. Communist Premier Hans Modrow rushed to the building and, through a loudspeaker, pleaded with the protesters to stop. He appealed for the demonstrators ``to stay in a dialogue'' with his shaky governing coalition. Alternately facing angry interruptions and applause, Modrow also professed ``full understanding'' of the rage stemming from decades of repression at the hands of the secret police. The protesters shouted ``We are the people! We are the people!'' as they rushed into the secret police building Monday afternoon. They scattered documents and looted wine, food and clothing from storerooms and closets. They filled stairways with papers, ripped out drawers from offices and broke windows. Several ripped down a picture of Communist leader Erich Honecker, who was ousted in October, and trampled it. About 60 police on hand at the time did not try to stop them, according to news reports. No injuries were reported and many in the crowd appeared calm and good-natured as they milled through the headquarters. Reports of the size of the crowd of protesters ranged from tens of thousands to 100,000. The protesters dispersed by late evening. East German television said a citizens' committee and regular police officers sealed off the building after the protest. The police agency is being dismantled, and it was not clear how many people were working at the headquarters Monday. Earlier Monday, Modrow offered opposition groups a far greater say in running the caretaker government before free elections set for May 6. However, the protests appear to be reaching further into virtually all parts of society and age groups. Increasingly, children and elderly people are taking to the streets with other protesters. The New Forum opposition group had called Monday's protests to challenge how the caretaker government is running the country. After the storming of secret police headquarters, state-run television interrupted its programs several times to broadcast a warning against further violence. ``The democracy that is just now developing is in the gravest danger,'' said the warning. The statement called for ``calm and reason,'' saying the protest ``had gotten out of control.'' The Rev. Rainer Eppelmann, an opposition leader, said he regretted the violence but said the government should take the attack as an ``alarm signal'' and fulfill its pledge to abolish the secret police. Government officials at talks with the opposition Monday morning described the strength of the secret police and the weaponry controlled by the agency, including rifles, rocket-propelled grenades and machine guns. Televised reports on the meeting, including the announcement that the security apparatus had accounted for more than 1 percent of the national budget, may have set off the attack in East Berlin. Negotiators at the talks voted to force Egon Krenz, who was ousted as Communist Party chief on Dec. 3 after six weeks in office, to appear and answer questions about the party ties to the secret police. Also Monday, tens of thousands of workers walked off their jobs in several cities, including East Berlin, to demand an end to Communist power and complete abolition of the secret police. Official news media also reported that a total of about 500,000 people demonstrated against the Communists and secret police in at least a dozen other cities on Monday evening. About 150,000 people mounted a noisy protest against the Communists in the opposition hotbed of Leipzig. They also chanted slogans in favor of German unification and waved dozens of West German flags. In Cottbus, about 50 people broke away from the main group of several thousand and clashed with police guarding the secret police headquarters there, the official ADN news agency said. The protesters threw stones and broke windows in an effort to storm the building, but police forced them back, the agency said. Earlier Monday, chief national prosecutor Hans-Juergen Joseph announced that he plans indictments for high treason against Honecker and the ousted leader's former secret police chief, Erich Mielke. The charge could result in a death sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Teen-ager Fined For Underage Drinking at Governor's Mansion
DOC.TEXT: An 18-year-old was fined $65 for underage drinking in connection with an investigation into a reported rape at the governor's mansion. David Ebach, starting quarterback for his high school football team, did not appear in court. His guilty plea was entered Monday by his lawyer. Circuit Judge James Anderson said the lawyer acknowledged that Ebach was drinking at the mansion on Nov. 28, but did not indicate how many people were involved. On Nov. 30, police received a report that four boys had raped a girl at the mansion on the evening of Nov. 28. Gov. George Mickelson and his wife, Linda, were out of town at the time. Their 17-year-old son, David, is the only other permanent resident of the mansion. His whereabouts that evening have not been disclosed. The governor has called the rape allegation unfounded, but has refused to make any detailed comments about the investigation. Three juveniles have been charged, but their names and the allegations against them have not been disclosed because of their age.

DOC.HEAD: One of Every 80 East Germans Helped Secret Police
With PM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: One of every 80 East Germans worked or informed for the secret police, and 3,200 employees did nothing but tap telephones and open mail, according to the official assigned to dismantle the dreaded agency. Manfred Sauer said the huge state security apparatus cost 3.6 billion marks last year, the equivalent of $2 billion at the official rate of the time. That was 1.3 percent of the entire national budget, Sauer told the seventh weekly negotiating session between the Communists and opposition on Monday. He spoke just hours before tens of thousands of people ransacked security police headquarters in East Berlin. Sauer said Erich Honecker, the hard-line leader ousted in October, expanded the agency dramatically after gaining power in 1971. By the end of the 1980s, there were 85,000 agents and 109,000 regular informants in a nation of 16.3 million people, Sauer said. He added that, besides the 3,200 agents assigned to telephones and mail, 5,000 were engaged in other forms of direct spying on citizens. His disclosures were the most comprehensive yet about the workings of the secret police. All information was stored in computers, he said, and the aim of the Honecker regime was ``total, comprehensive surveillance'' to frustrate dissent. Honecker built a ``disproportionately large'' surveillance system and tried ``to solve political problems with methods of penal law,'' Sauer said. Domestic spying has ceased and ``all directives against dissidents were stopped by the government ... on Nov. 29,'' Sauer told the meeting. He said 30,000 agents had been fired, new jobs were being sought for 22,500 more and ``the rapid dismissal of another 20,000 within the shortest time possible'' was being arranged. Those remaining would be needed to supervise the dissolution of the agency, Sauer said. The Interior Ministry has set Jan. 25 as the deadline for retrieving all weapons from former secret police agents, including 124,000 pistols, 76,000 submachine guns, about 3,500 grenade-launchers and and 342 anti-aircraft guns. East German officials say the country faces an increasing threat from neo-Nazis, which many in the opposition see as an attempt to justify keeping the secret police or replacing them with a similar organization. Interior Minister Lothar Ahrendt read a report at Monday's meeting that said ``neo-fascist, anti-Semitic and anti-foreigner'' dangers exist throughout the country.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Damages Village Police Station, Homes
DOC.TEXT: A bomb in a parked van exploded at a western village, damaging the local police station and more than 50 homes, police said. No one was reported injured. No group immediately claimed responsibility for Monday's attack, but suspicion inevitably fell on the Irish Republican Army, which is fighting British rule in the province. In a statement, Belfast police headquarters said the bomb completely demolished one home beside the police station in Sion Mills, which is about two miles from the border with the Republic of Ireland. The police station, the apparent target, was extensively damaged. The building was empty at the time. Like many other country police stations in Northern Ireland, it is only manned part time. Police said the bomb in the back of the van was spotted by local people, who warned neighbors to flee before the explosion. The mainly Roman Catholic IRA wants to unite predominantly Protestant Northern Ireland with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland under socialist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Infant Heart Transplants Proving Successful
DOC.TEXT: Transplants are proving to be a successful treatment for babies born with a deadly heart defect, according to the first detailed study of such operations. The report, being published next month, shows that 23 of 28 heart recipients continued to do well several years after receiving the transplants as infants, said Dr. Welton Gersony of Columbia University in New York. The operations were performed by Dr. Leonard Bailey of Loma Linda University Medical Center in California, who gained fame by transplanting a baboon heart into the tiny patient known as Baby Fae. Gersony predicted Monday that Bailey's report would convince many surgeons of the value of infant heart transplants, and that the use of the transplants would spread rapidly across the country. The infants who underwent the transplants were born without the left side of the heart. The condition, known as hypoplastic left heart syndrome, occurs in one of 3,000 to 5,000 American babies, Gersony said. The only alternative to a transplant is a procedure called the Norwood operation, which offers only about a 30- to 40-percent chance of survival past two years, Gersony said. Without an operation, death usually occurs within weeks. Gersony said Bailey's report also demonstrates that it is possible to simplify the process of obtaining donor infant hearts for transplant. Bailey had thought it was necessary to bring the donor babies to Loma Linda and remove their hearts there. He has now shown it is possible to remove the heart and ship it separately, as is done with adult donor hearts. Donor hearts often come from infants born with fatal nervous system defects, Gersony said. Increased attention to infant heart transplants has enlarged the supply of donor hearts, according to a report at an American Heart Association meeting in November. ``In two years, we haven't lost a child on the waiting list for a donor heart,'' said one of Bailey's Loma Linda colleagues, Dr. Steven Gundry. At that meeting, Gundry reported on 17 infants given heart transplants because of other severe heart defects. Only one of them died, of pneumonia. The others had normal heart functions up to four years after surgery, Gundry reported. Gersony said Bailey's forthcoming report suggests that the immaturity of infants' immune systems makes them less likely than adults to reject transplanted hearts.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Officials Ask Bush to Communicate with Mandela
DOC.TEXT: Eight former federal officials are trying to get President to write Nelson Mandela in his South African jail as a way to encourage negotiations between the white government and the nation's black majority. The eight said contact from Bush ``could well contribute'' to Mandela's release and return to political life. Their call was issued Monday under the auspices of the Foreign Policy Institute. Affiliated with the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, the institute seeks consensus positions that can be endorsed by former officials representing a range of political philosophies. The statement was signed by Harold Brown, former secretary of defense; William T. Coleman Jr., former transportation secretary; Barbara Jordan, former Democratic congresswoman from Texas; Melvin Laird, former defense secretary; Edmund Muskie, former secretary of state; Herman Nickel, the Reagan administration's ambassador to South Africa; and former Republican senators Charles McC. Mathias of Maryland and Charles Percy of Illinois.
DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson Launches His Own D.C. Statehood Drive
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson, one of the District of Columbia's newer residents, is launching his own effort to get the district admitted to the union. ``D.C. statehood is a mainstream issue,'' Jackson declared Monday. ``We need to go to work ... mobilizing people all over the country. We want democracy and not tyranny.'' Jackson said the campaign, which began on the national holiday honoring slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King, ``would give substance to the dream'' that King espoused. Jackson, who moved to the district last year, was joined at the opening of the Rainbow Coalition's D.C. Statehood office by local and national politicians, local labor leaders and mayoral hopeful Sharon Pratt Dixon. Democratic National Committee Chairman Ron Brown, a former Jackson aide and D.C. resident, noted that statehood for the nation's capital was a plank in the 1988 Democratic platform. The district now has one, non-voting delegate to the House of Representatives.
DOC.HEAD: Democratic Leader Says Blacks, Jews Must Work Together
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Democratic National Committee says blacks and Jews must take care to keep their political bonds intact despite differences over various issues. ``Differences that can anger and even enrage cannot be allowed to divide us,'' Ron Brown told an observance Monday at the Israeli Embassy of Martin Luther King's birthday. ``We must realize that the differences between our communities are not recognized by David Duke and the Ku Klux Klan; that race hatred and religious persecution walk hand-in-hand,'' he said. Duke is a former Klan leader serving in the Louisiana Legislature. He has ties to neo-Nazi groups and is president of the National Association for the Advancement of White People. Brown, the first black to be elected to the Democratic Party's chairmanship, was the featured speaker at the fifth commemorative observance held at the embassy. He said that just as King took his message outside his church and into the streets, ``We must leave behind this gathering of elites, and carry a message to those in our communities who are not here _ the poor and disaffected, the uneducated, the prejudiced and the angry people who search for targets and scapegoats. ``That message is this: it is not Jews that have bombed and threatened civil rights leaders, and it is not blacks who are painting swastikas on synagogues,'' Brown said. ``We do not threaten one another.''

DOC.HEAD: Son of British Actor Alan Bates Dies in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Tristan Bates, a 19-year-old twin son of British actor Alan Bates, has died of a stroke. His death in Tokyo was confirmed today by a modeling agency. He was in the city for his work as a fashion model when he died Friday night near his apartment, according to Gloria Askew, president of the Askew agency. The young model appeared with his twin brother, Benjamin, on a front cover of the October issue of monthly Popeye magazine. He was planning to go to a drama school after working in Tokyo. His 65-year-old father is a leading British stage, screen and television actor. He is currently in Tokyo also, with his wife, Victoria Ward. His movie credits include ``A Kind of Loving'' in 1962, ``Far From the Madding Crowd'' in 1967, ``Women in Love'' in 1969 and ``A Voyage Round My Father'' in 1983. In that movie, he starred with the late Lord Olivier. Details about the funeral were not immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Commuter Plane Crashes into Mountainside, All 23 Aboard Killed
DOC.TEXT: A propeller airplane carrying 23 people slammed into a mountain in stormy weather shortly after takeoff and everyone on board was killed, officials said. A rescue patrol that reached the crash site at 9 p.m. Monday, about 12 hours after the crash, recovered all 23 bodies, said Juan Felix Barrantes, head of the Civil Guard. The twin-engine commuter plane, a Spanish-made Aerocar, belonged to Servicios Aereos Nacionales, a subsidiary of Lineas Aereas Costaricense S.A., the national airline. It had a Costa Rican crew of three. Carlos Jimenez, a spokesman for the Public Security Ministry, said the plane crashed into 1,500-foot Pico Blanco Mountain, about 10 miles southwest of the capital's Juan Santamaria Airport. Jimenez said 10 passengers were foreigners, but he could not provide names. Officials at the Canadian Embassy said the security ministry had informed them that seven or eight of the passengers were thought to be Canadian. There were unconfirmed reports the passengers also included U.S., Swiss and Panamanian citizens. Officials said the bodies would be brought down from the mountain today. The aircraft had taken off for Palmar Norte, a town in southern Costa Rica, when apparently it was driven against the mountain by a gust of wind, Jimenez said. Jimenez gave no details except to say the weather was foggy and that a strong storm was blowing through the area when the plane took off.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks In Major Loss, Dollar Edges Up
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index followed up its worst single-day drop in more than two years with a slightly larger plunge today, while the dollar edged up against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average fell 666.41 points, or 1.8 percent, closing at 36,850.36, its lowest level since the 36,881.53 closing Nov. 27. The market was closed Monday for a national holiday. On Friday, the Nikkei lost 656.36 points, then its worst one-day plunge since 731.91 on Nov. 19, 1987, following a crash on Wall Street. So far this year, the Nikkei has lost nearly 2,000 points, or 6.8 percent. ``The market was marred with sell orders all day long,'' said Ichitaro Watanabe, a dealer at Nikko Scurities Co. ``It was the result of a combination of unfavorable factors hitting the market all at once.'' With investors dumping issues, the index began its dive as soon as the market opened today, and quickly fell below the 37,000-point level, dealers said. ``Nobody was buying,'' said Yoshio Shimoyama of Nikko Securities. ``Everybody was watching and waiting.'' Dealers and analysts have said the Nikkei's recent fall has resulted largely from falling government bond prices caused by the weakening yen. The yen's weakness also has intensified existing pessimism in the stock market, they said. ``But over the weekend, the regional conflict worsened in the Soviet Union and the New York market fared poorly overnight, aggravating the market's pessimism,'' said Keiichi Nishida, a dealer at Kidder Peabody. Dealers said the fall in bond prices is likely to stop soon because yields are approaching an appropriate level, around 7 percent, but a recovery in stock prices is unlikely before Japan's general elections in February. ``Right now, market players see no encouraging sign to buy issues,'' said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst at Nomura Securities. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 145.75 yen, up 0.40 yen from Friday's close of 145.35 yen. It opened at 145.85 yen and ranged between 145.65 yen and 146.07 yen. Traders attributed the U.S. currency's strength in Tokyo to its rise against most major foreign currencies Monday, while the New York and Tokyo markets were closed for holidays. The central bank's dollar-selling intervention kept the dollar from rising more steeply, said a trader with the Bank of Tokyo, speaking on condition of anonymity. Kyodo News Service said the bank sold more than $400 million. The bank does not comment on its exchange market activities. The Bank of Tokyo trader said the lower stock and bond prices prompted market players to sell yen. Chizuko Satsukawa, a trader with Chemical Bank in Tokyo, said the yen will remain weak for the time being. ``Concerns over the election are prompting market players to get rid of the yen, which helps the dollar become stronger,'' she said. But a sharp plunge by the yen is also unlikely while the Bank of Japan is actively selling dollars, Ms. Satsukawa said.

DOC.HEAD: Stuart Shooting: The Crime Is Still the Major Mystery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Despite the intense scrutiny given the Charles Stuart case, investigators still are not entirely sure of the answer to the major remaining question in the twisted drama: Who shot Stuart and his wife, and how? Police are leaning toward the scenario that Stuart, who died Jan. 4 in what is believed to be suicide set off when a brother implicated him, shot his wife and himself last Oct. 23. But they cannot rule out a different gunman. In a hospital interview several days after the shootings, Stuart told police an assailant entered the back seat of their car at a red light, forced him to drive to a remote area of the city, robbed the couple, and then shot them. In a short time, police came up with a suspect with a long criminal record. Stuart's deception, legal experts say, got the investigation off on the wrong track by shifting the focus away from him and the physical evidence. ``It's very common that once the police have a suspect who satisfies them they will stop looking at other people,'' said lawyer Alan Dershowitz, a Harvard Law School professor. ``They don't want the defense later saying that they were looking at other people because they had doubts about your case.'' It has been determined that three bullets were fired that night: One hit the roof of Stuart's car, one hit Stuart in the stomach, and one struck his wife. An affidavit indicates Carol Stuart was struck on the left side of the head, which would seem to rule out a gunman shooting from the outside right of the car. The possibilities remain that Stuart could have shot his wife and then himself, that another person could have shot both of them from the rear or the outside left of the car, or a combination of the two. An investigator who would not be identified by name said Stuart's car was examined by the city crime lab and that the angles of the shots appeared consistent with Stuart's account. When asked where the results of that examination might be obtained, the investigator said: ``I don't know that anything was ever put into writing; I never saw any paper on it.'' Dershowitz said investigators have a tendency to avoid producing documents that defense attorneys might later poke holes into. Police would not comment when asked if fingerprint and fiber checks were made on the car, which Stuart traded in on a new car after he left the hospital in December. Authorities have said Stuart was a suspect _ as are all husbands and wives when a spouse is slain _ but only a remote one because they had no reason to doubt him until he was implicated by his youngest brother. In hindsight, a question about the shootings might have been stirred by a comment Stuart made in the very early moments after the crime. In his car phone plea for help, Stuart was asked if his wife was shot. He told the police dispatcher: ``Yes. In the head.'' The dispatcher asked: ``In the head?'' Stuart responded: ``Yes, I ducked down.'' Was Stuart saying that he avoided being shot because he ducked or that his wife was hit because he ducked _ an almost impossible result of a shot fired toward Stuart from the back seat? The investigator indicated Stuart was not pressed on the point. Stuart might also have been pressed when, according to an affidavit, he was interviewed in the hospital several days after the shootings. Although Stuart could not tell the dispatcher where he was the night of the crime until he drove to a major thoroughfare, in the hospital he was able to steer investigators to a street _ where he said the shots were fired _ so obscure that it cannot be found on at least two detailed city maps. Of witnesses who said the arrested suspect, William Bennett, admitted the shooting, one has since said he was coerced into making those statements, and another has said he was coached by investigators. Bennett has been cleared but remained in jail on other charges. John Julian, a spokesman for the Suffolk County district attorney, who is in charge of the investigation, said the office stands by its procedures. Meanwhile, investigators have turned to Charles Stuart's youngest brother, Matthew. Matthew has said, through his lawyer, that Charles arranged for him to follow Charles to a meeting place, where Charles tossed him his wife's bag and a gun, and that Matthew then left, having no indication that a shooting had occurred. He said the bag and gun were thrown in a river in Revere. Had Charles or someone else already done the shooting? That would mean Stuart had driven to the meeting place and tossed the bag while he was suffering from a life-threatening injury. The gun believed used in the crime was pulled from the river last week and is being analyzed by the FBI crime lab. A grand jury has taken a recess in the case. One prosecutor has said the panel might not indict anyone, and that no one may ever know what happened. ``Just about anything's still possible,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Man-Animal Skirmishes Rising in Yellowstone
With PM-Buffalo Comeback, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Tourists who ignore warnings not to feed the wildlife are doing so at increasing risk at Yellowstone National Park, where some animals have begun to bite the hand that feeds them. While rangers do not have specific figures showing an increase in animal attacks, they have noticed that in recent years more and more coyotes, bighorn sheep and other animals have learned to associate man with food because of the handouts tourists offer. ``I was riding a snow machine two winters ago, I guess, toward Old Faithful and there was a coyote in the road and we stopped and the guy with me wanted a photograph of it,'' recalled Ranger Norm Bishop. ``He pulled his camera out and I started to pull mine out. The instant I touched that bag the coyote was almost in my lap. ``He instantly associated the sound of that plastic bag with potato chips, Fritos, hamburger, whatever, he was ready for it,'' said Bishop. ``It was really unsettling to me. I didn't like an animal that close to me eager to have what I had.'' Skirmishes between humans and animals can be fatal. In recent years, a French tourist was fatally gored by a bison, and a Montana photographer was killed by a grizzly bear he was hoping to photograph. Last year, a black bear who repeatedly forced hikers up trees and ravaged their backpacks for food was killed by rangers. A recent coyote attack on a cross-country skier likely was simply a case of the skier surprising the animal, park officials believe. ``We know that grizzly bears, occasionally black bears, and mountain lions and coyotes are all dangerous to people,'' Bishop said. ``But in most cases, not all but in most, what we see is that the animals, particularly the bears that actually killed someone, were bears that were habituated by people feeding them.'' Part of the problem, according to park spokeswoman Marsha Karle, is the growing number visitors to Yellowstone, which reported a record 2.9 million last summer. ``We can't have rangers behind every tree,'' she said. And the animals have grown somewhat lenient to man, Bishop said. ``Most of the time the animals are so darn cooperative. They're just doing their own thing,'' he said. ``We have elk here in Mammoth that you can walk within 10 feet of them. Some of them don't get up. Some don't even look up. ``The animals are basically saying, `Hey, all we want to do is stand here and eat. You guys, as long as you don't approach us and show signs of harming us, you're OK with us,''' he said. ``The laissez faire arrangement works great, as long as people don't get within the personal space ... of the animal. But you get within that space of that animal, they're like us. If you crowd me aggressively, I'm going to push. ``When the bison has the pushing equipment that he's got, I don't want to be pushed,'' said Bishop. Visitors are inundated with literature about Yellowstone's wildlife when they enter the park, officials said. ``We have just tried really hard to educate people, gently, and in a forthright manner, to say, `Look, the animals are big, they're strong, they're fast, they're capable of doing you fatal harm,''' Bishop said. ``So respect them, keep your distance, act predictably, except in really rare circumstances, you'll stay out of trouble.''

DOC.HEAD: 16 Acquitted, 4 Convicted in Drug Smuggling Trial
DOC.TEXT: Sixteen men, mostly boat captains and truck drivers, have been acquitted in what authorities said was a marijuana smuggling ring with links to deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. Four of the 20 co-defendants were convicted Monday on the fifth day of deliberations in the 2{-month trial. ``I think the entire trial was a defeat for the prosecution,'' said Rick Michot, a defense attorney. The defendants had been charged with conspiracy, importation and distribution. Federal prosecutors said the defendants smuggled 48,000 pounds of marijuana into North Carolina in 1982 and 280,000 pounds into Louisiana in 1983. They planned to smuggle 1 million pounds into Missouri in 1984, prosecutors said, but were foiled by the arrest of ringleader Stephen Michael Kalish. Kalish testified as the star prosecution witness that what he called the ``Master Blaster'' load was to arrive a few days before he was arrested. Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Lombardino, the chief prosecutor, refused to comment after the verdicts, saying a related trial of 25 people is coming up. The cases resulted from the same investigation that led to Noriega's 1988 indictment in Tampa, Fla., on drug charges. Kalish testified that he once gave Noriega a $300,000 ``present'' for helping arrange a Panamanian banking network to launder drug profits. He said the network he set up with Noriega laundered $50 million to $100 million a month for the Medellin cocaine cartel of Colombia. One juror, Rowdy Lege, 30, said some members of the panel ``voiced concern'' over Noriega's involvement, and the possibility of retaliation by drug lords. Convicted on 16 counts were Jerry Hughey of Austin, Texas; Jim Swope, also of Texas; and Max Wade, no hometown available. They could be sentenced to 170 years in prison. Steve Ellender of Houma, La., was found guilty on six conspiracy counts and innocent on seven others. He could be sentenced to 30 years. U.S. District Judge John Shaw postponed sentencing until after a background check of the four. Patricia Thomas, Ellender's attorney, said she will appeal on grounds of an ``inconsistent verdict.'' Some of the defendants who were acquitted said it was a bittersweet victory. ``I feel kind of used,'' said Phillip Watkins. ``Win or lose we've already lost.'' Clark Nash of Missouri said he's broke, and doesn't know what to do. ``Everything I've worked for for 30 years went to my lawyer,'' he said. Kalish, who said his drug-smuggling organization operated from the late 1970s through 1984, is currently in prison. He pleaded guilty in Tampa in 1987 to a charge of continuing criminal enterprise. In November, Jay Foreman, a pilot who said he flew a private airplane for Kalish, testified that Noriega was a passenger aboard the plane several times. Originally 187 people were accused in the case, but many plea-bargained or were culled for separate trials. The judge acquitted three before the defense opened. Officials say about 90 of those indicted remain fugitives. The conspiracy centered on the smuggled marijuana. The other charges dealt with aiding and abetting the importation and distribution. Hughey, Swope and Wade were convicted on all those counts, plus three each of wire fraud, interstate commerce and the illegal distribution of funds from the conspiracy. In the next trial, for Feb. 12, 19 of the defendants are accused of higher-level involvement in the ring. Among them is Harold ``Doc'' McGhee, manager of the rock groups Bon Jovi, Skid Row and The Scorpions. Kalish identified McGhee as the link between the smuggler and a Colombian drug supplier. McGhee was given a suspended sentence after pleading guilty to importing marijuana in North Carolina.

DOC.HEAD: Runways at Shuttle Landing Site Cracking and Sinking
With PM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: Ground-water pumping by the Antelope Valley's growing population is cracking and sinking the dry lakebed runways famed as landing strips for space shuttles and test pilots. During a California Water Commission hearing here last week, Air Force officials said the floor of Rogers Dry Lake has subsided 3 feet in some places, and is broken by fissures up to 3 feet wide, 2 feet deep and hundreds of feet long. The Air Force has been able to keep using the clay runways only by filling in the cracks. ``We're seeing severe cracks throughout the whole lakebed,'' said Col. Peter Walsh, civil engineer for the Mojave Desert military base. Many space shuttles have landed on dry lakebed runways, although Columbia was scheduled to touch down on a concrete landing strip on Friday. The U.S. Geological Survey is conducting a $6 million, five-year study of the problem and other water-use issues for the Air Force. ``It's very obvious ground-water pumpage is having an impact on the subsidence at Edwards Air Force Base,'' said John Klein, district chief of the survey's water resources division. Klein said the sinking and related drinking-water shortages at Edwards will continue unless ``major steps are taken to limit further withdrawals'' of ground water. Water use has climbed during the past decade as the population of the Antelope Valley, which includes Lancaster and Palmdale, doubled to almost 200,000. Air Force officials are urging local water agencies to use less ground water and use more water brought from the north via the California Aqueduct. The water table at Edwards dropped from about 10 feet below the surface in 1948 to a recent level of 100 feet underground, Klein said, adding it is difficult to determine how much of the drop is caused by population growth. Edwards is 300,000 acres, the second-largest Air Force base in the continental United States. It is home to the famed Flight Test Center whose pilots were glorified in Tom Wolfe's book ``The Right Stuff.''

DOC.HEAD: Tainted Water Recalled in Six States
DOC.TEXT: A batch of spring water that smelled like kerosene was recalled from stores in six states after a woman who drank some of it was hospitalized. Pocono Pure Mountain Spring Water recalled 7,000 one-gallon bottles from Pathmark and Shop-Rite supermarkets in Delaware, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Connecticut, New York and Massachusetts on Monday. Store officials removed all Pocono spring water products from the shelves. The tainted water was in clear vinyl bottles with identification numbers 26582-00050 and expiration dates of Dec. 26, 1991 and Jan. 4, 1992. Carl J. Petro, president of Pocono Artesian Waters Co. of Mount Pocono, Pa., said he suspected the problems were with the containers and not with the water. He said water bottled the same day as the recalled bottles, but put in different containers, was not tainted. The company has sent samples of the water and containers to an independent laboratory for tests, Petro said. Petro said the tainted water ``has a petroleum odor to it. It smells more like kerosene.'' The bottles were recalled after Delaware state police learned that Jettie Quigley, 38, of Chadds Ford, Pa., became ill Sunday after drinking water she purchased at a Pathmark store in Wilmington. Quigley, who complained of chest pains, was in satisfactory condition Monday at Riddle Memorial Hosptial in Lima, Pa. Petro said that about 10 months ago, the company had a problem with 4,000 bottles of water in similar containers. The water, however, was sampled before it was delivered to grocery stores. A company investigation did not reveal the source of the smell, Petro said. He refused to identify the manufacturer of the container. In both cases, employee tampering has been ruled out, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Emnity Between Armenians, Azerbaijanis Has Historical Roots
With PM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The antagonism between Armenians and Azerbaijanis that has led to deadly clashes in the Soviet Caucasus has deep historical roots and religious and ethnic overtones. Armenians claim that after the Soviet takeover in Azerbaijan, the republic was given large chunks of territory like Nagorno-Karabakh and Nakhichevan that was historically part of Armenia with majority Armenian populations. They blame Josef Stalin, a native of the Caucasus who was the top Soviet official for nationality problems before becoming Communist Party leader and dictator. Under Azerbaijani rule, Armenians assert, Nakhichevan has been virtually rid of its Armenian population. In Nagorno-Karabakh, which is still predominantly Armenian, the local population was long deprived of basic services and cultural activities like Armenian-language television and radio broadcasts, Armenians say. For their part, Azerbaijanis note the 1977 Soviet Constitution gives them control over Nagorno-Karabakh and that the so-called autonomous region cannot join Armenia without Azerbaijani consent. ``Without Shusha, Azerbaijan has no soul,'' an Azerbaijani saying goes, referring to a town in Nagorno-Karabakh that historically has been populated by Azerbaijanis. Most Azerbaijanis, a Turkic people, are Shiite Moslems; most Armenians Christian. In 1915, an estimated 1.5 million Armenians perished at the hands of Ottoman Turks. Many Armenians today refer to Azerbaijanis simply as ``Turks,'' showing they do not distinguish between their Soviet neighbors and the authors of the genocide against their people three-quarters of a century ago.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Crashes Into Mountain; All Survive
DOC.TEXT: All 16 people aboard a commuter plane survived after it struck a mountaintop during a snowstorm and plunged down a hillside in a crash landing some passengers called a miracle. ``We started bumping up and down and I didn't know where we were or what was happening,'' said Nicole Blohm, a 20-year-old passenger. ``Apparently we were sliding down the mountain at that time. I knew we had crashed. I was thinking, ``This is it.''' Monday's crash of the SkyWest turboprop in northeast Nevada was one of three airline mishaps in two days. A Boeing 747 jetliner carrying 257 people lost power for five minutes over the Pacific Ocean on Sunday, but the Philippine Airlines pilots restarted the engines and landed safely in Honolulu, the company said. In Colorado on Monday, a fire broke out in an engine of an Aspen Airways plane shortly after takeoff, but the plane returned safely to the Grand Junction airport for an emergency landing, officials said. None of the 26 passengers was injured. In Nevada, most of the passengers walked away from the crash after the plane, Flight 5855, went down four miles west of the airport in Elko. The plane was bound for Reno from Salt Lake City via Elko, a town of 8,800. Four people were admitted to Elko General Hospital in fair condition and 12 others were treated and released, according to a nursing supervisor. The captain, who suffered a broken leg and at least two broken ribs, was the most seriously injured, the hospital said. ``I think it is a miracle none of us died,'' said 18-year-old Kristina Blohm, Nicole's sister. The year-old Metro III twin-engine plane, carrying 14 passengers and two crewmembers, crashed when the pilot was attempting an instrument landing during the snowstorm. Helicopter pilot Ted McBride, who spotted the wreckage, said the plane apparently clipped the top of a 6,463-foot mountain. The plane then became airborne briefly before skidding about a quarter of a mile down the steep slope. McBride said the crash probably would have been more serious had the plane slammed into level terrain instead of losing velocity as it skittered down the snowy, treeless slope. No one aboard was thrown from the plane and its fuselage was intact on the mountain, rescuer Pete Schory said. ``Right now, I'm feeling that the outcome is wonderful,'' said SkyWest President Jerry Atkin. ``The thing you hope for in these situations is for all survivors. It's certainly unpleasant to have such a thing happen, but I'm very pleased with the outcome.'' There was no immediate indication of what caused the crash, Atkin said from St. George, Utah, where the airline is based. But he said the plane was 500 feet lower than the pilot believed. SkyWest serves 44 cities in eight Western states: Nevada, Wyoming, Montana, Idaho, Colorado, Utah, Arizona and California. It has 500 flights a day and serves more than a million passengers a year. In Colorado, an engine on a Convair 580 propjet caught fire about five minutes after takeoff from Grand Junction for Denver, authorities said. Officials said the pilot cut the engine, and the plane landed under power from the remaining engine. The fire was out when the plane landed, witnesses said. ``The folks who were getting off the plane had smiles on their faces, and I was surprised,'' said Jeff Wendland, a spokesman for Walker Field airport. ``I expected to see a lot of white faces.'' There was no immediate comment from the Denver-based airline. In Hawaii, the jumbo jet was 135 miles from Honolulu and about to start its descent from 37,000 feet when its four engines went dead, according to Enrique Santos, airline vice president for communications. The pilot, Capt. Eduardo Reyes Jr., proceeded with the descent and power was restored in all engines at 25,500 feet, Santos said. He added that the flight proceeded normally and landed in Honolulu without further incident. The aircraft has been grounded at Honolulu pending examination by the Federal Aviation Administration and the airline.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``If the United States truly expects democracy to flourish, you need a flourishing economy. All the goodwill in the world won't mean much when you have growling stomachs.'' _ Laurence Berger, vice president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Panama, urging aid to rebuild from the looting, unemployment and destruction that followed the U.S. invasion.

``This smacks a little bit of the Reagan philosophy, which can be summed up as `Don't visit your grandchildren, just send them the bill.''' _ Rep. Andrew Jacobs, D-Ind., chairman of the House Ways and Means Social Security subcommittee, in opposing a proposed payroll tax cut that would save workers $62 billion over the next two years and, critics say, shift the burden of financing baby boomers' retirements to later generations.

``We're dead in the water here today.'' _ Florence Waymire, a vice president of Trans Mid-America, an Omaha-based marketing company that was unable to make any long-distance calls because of a nine-hour phone outage, AT&T's most widespread ever.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose in hectic early European trading today, boosted by unrest in the Soviet Union and East Germany, currency dealers said. Gold prices also rose. News late Monday that the Soviet Union had declared a state of emergency in the Nagorno-Karabakh region and that fighting between Azerbaijanis and Armenians continued had triggered a decisive rally in the dollar, traders said. The storming of the secret police headquarters in East Berlin by tens of thousands of East Germans late Monday also contributed to a firmer U.S. currency, they said. ``The dollar is very strong on the news from Russia,'' said one trader in Milan, Italy. The mounting ethnic tension in the Soviet Union is leading to a ``flight into quality,'' he said, referring to investors' preference to hold dollar funds in times of political uncertainty. ``Everyone's looking at the political situation in the East bloc right now,'' said one trader at a major West German bank in Frankfurt. ``I think the dollar is on the way up, but it'll go very cautiously.'' The market is also positioning itself for the report on U.S. business inventories in November later today and the U.S. November trade figures on Wednesday, traders said. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.40 yen to a closing 145.75 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 145.53 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _1.7095 West German marks, up from 1.6965 _1.5270 Swiss francs, up from 1.5120 _5.8115 French francs, up from 5.7625 _1.9250 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9015 _1,273.25 Italian lire, up from 1,261.375 _1.1640 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16225 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound. It cost $1.6520 to buy one pound, compared with $1.6620 late Monday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $413.00 a troy ounce, up from $412.00 bid late Monday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $415.25. In Zurich, the bid price was $414.10, up from $412.40 bid late Monday. Earlier, gold in Hong Kong rose $1.67 to close at a bid $413.77. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.30 a troy ounce from Monday's $5.24.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Throws Wet Blanket on Life in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Pollution, overcrowding and other ills of urban life may leave the busy residents of Japan's capital unfazed, but it took just a few inches of snow today to delay tens of thousands on their appointed rounds. The season's first snowfall forced a two-hour closure of Tokyo's international airport. Commuter and inner city trains ran late. And 23 people got hurt in falls on slippery streets, the Kyodo News Service reporting, quoting fire officials. All the breakdowns and confusion stemmed from a snowfall that left only 3 to 5 inches around the area that sometimes survives winter without any storms leaving snow on the ground. Authorities ordered New Tokyo International Airport at Narita, about 35 miles northeast of Tokyo, to close in the late afternoon to clear wet snow from a runway. The airport authority said 23 incoming flights were diverted to other airports in Japan and 12 departures were delayed. About 50,000 morning commuters were delayed by slow-running trains. Japan Railway officials reported 76 high-speed, inter-city ``bullet trains'' ran behind schedule after the snow started falling overnight, Kyodo said.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Plan to Press For Noriega's Release on Bail
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for Manuel Noriega said the defense team will push for the deposed dictator's release on bond since the government has opened a ``Pandora's box'' by requesting a detention hearing. ``I don't think the government will be able to establish the facts necessary for the court to pretrial detain our client without any bond,'' attorney Steven Kollin said Monday. ``He's presumed to be innocent, he's entitled to a bond. ``That is our system of jurisprudence, and we feel that under these circumstances that should be the ruling.'' Noriega's lawyers initially did not ask for a bond hearing in his drug trafficking trial in part because they questioned the jurisdiction of the court, Kollin said. Kollin and his co-counsel have said they probably will file pretrial motions claiming Noriega is a head of state and immune from prosecution. But Kollin says the government's action _ which led to the scheduling of a detention hearing Jan. 26 _ has ``put us in a posture that we would have to deal with that issue (of detention) and we feel we will be successful.'' Noriega reportedly has been held in a basement apartment in the Miami federal courthouse since arriving in the United States Jan. 4. A February 1988 U.S. indictment accuses the ousted general of taking $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin cartel to turn his nation into a way station for cocaine traffic. He could be imprisoned up to 145 years in prison and fined as much as $1.1 million if convicted. On Friday, a federal magistrate set a $1 million bail for one of Noriega's co-defendants, Daniel Miranda. But that ruling was immediately appealed by prosecutors, blocking Miranda's release. Miranda, charged in the same 1988 indictment, is accused of flying $800,000 in laundered drug money from Fort Lauderdale to Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Five Die of Carbon Monoxide Poisoning in Their New Home
DOC.TEXT: Carbon monoxide fumes from a furnace killed a woman and four youngsters, including three of her children, who were found dead in their new house, authorities said. City inspectors had deemed the furnace unsafe in September and ordered it shut off after fumes from it felled at least one person then living in the house, but a city official said it was unclear whether the problem ever was fixed. The victims moved into the one-story, two-bedroom home a week ago today; unpacked moving boxes were scattered throughout the house when the bodies were found, police Lt. Rich Resling said Monday. The victims died Wednesday evening from carbon monoxide poisoning, said El Paso County's deputy coroner, Michael Stewart. They were identified as Sophia Gerardo, 34; her sons, Daniel Gerardo, 9, Nash Gerardo, 11, and Mario Ortiz, 13; and her nephew, Mark McPeak, 15. Carbon monoxide instead of carbon dioxide can be produced when a heater fails to burn fuel adequately, Stewart said. Stewart said the woman may have been aware that something was wrong because she apparently tried to pull herself upright by grabbing a plant stand, which was found toppled next to her. ``It looked like she was trying to get out,'' Stewart said. The body of McPeak was found in the bathroom, where he probably went after feeling nauseated, Stewart said. The other children were found in bed and probably died in their sleep, he said. Resling said a neighbor alerted police Sunday after peering into a window and seeing a body. An officer became ill from fumes while examining the house, Resling said. ``In about two minutes, he would have passed out,'' Resling said. ``He was lucky to get out of there.'' City Utilities Department inspectors measured the carbon monoxide level in the house Sunday at 800 parts per million, twice the lethal level. City spokesman John Henry said that on Sept. 9, a previous occupant of the house was overcome by carbon monoxide and taken to a hospital, and that inspectors that day ``red-tagged'' the furnace as unsafe. Henry could not say whether the furnace had since been repaired because the city does not perform follow-up inspections. Former tenant Brenda Hogsett said in an interview published in today's Colorado Springs Gazette Telegraph two people were sickened in the September incident and the building's 75-year-old owner, Darrell Atkinson, was aware of it. She did not know if the furnace had been fixed. Atkinson, who was distraught over the deaths, declined to comment, the newspaper said. Dallas Lopez, a friend of the dead woman, said he also was aware of the past problems with the furnace. ``They had all kinds of city workers and the fire department looking around,'' he said, adding that they later said they fixed the problem. Resling said police were continuing an investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Government Blames Trial Delays on Defendants
DOC.TEXT: The chief prosecutor says leading figures from the deposed Ceausescu regime are going on trial this week on charges ranging from complicity to commit genocide to undermining the national economy. The comments Monday from Prosecutor-General Gheorghe Robu represented the first time the revolutionary government has outlined the charges against people who were once among Romania's most powerful officials. He was quoted by the official Rompres news agency as saying pre-trial investigations and the taking of depositions had been hindered because ``many of the ex-officials can hardly write, even though a good part of them held a doctorate in science.'' Critics have complained that the new government is not moving fast enough against high-ranking officials of the ousted regime of executed Communist dictator Nicolae Ceaucescu. Robu said that Nicu Ceausescu, the most notorious of Ceausescu's children, would be among those tried this week. As local Communist Party chief in the Transylvanian city of Sibiu, Nicu reportedly ordered members of the Securitate special police to open fire on demonstrators during the revolution that toppled Ceausescu last month. Nicu's sister, Zoia-Elena, and brother, Valentin, have also been arrested. Valentin, who was a member of the Communist Party's policy-setting Central Committee, is also to go on trial this week with other Ceaucescu associates and members of the special police. Among other defendants to be tried this week, according to Romanian television, are former Interior Minister Tudor Postlenicu and former Communist Party Secretary Emil Bobu. The country's new leaders, the National Salvation Front Council, have not said exactly when or where the trials would take place. But Rompres told The Associated Press that trials for special police members would be held Friday in the western city of Timisoara, where the revolt began Dec. 17 when security forces massacred anti-government protesters. Officials had earlier said the trials would begin Monday, and there was no explanation for the change. The genocide charge refers to victims of Ceausescu's 24-year reign of terror as well as the thousands of Romanians killed by the special Securitate police during the revolution. The charge of undermining the economy stems from the havoc wreaked by Ceausescu's policy of exporting food and fuel to pay off Romania's foreign debt of more than $10 billion between 1982 and last year. Also Monday, the government announced an amnesty for crimes committed before the revolution. However, it excluded former Ceausescu functionaries, murderers, rapists and terrorists, the term now applied to Securitate members. The issues of whether to ban the party and capital punishment will be submitted to a popular referendum on Jan. 28. Capital punishment was outlawed after the Ceaucescu executions. At a news conference Monday, government spokesman Dragos Munteanu also defended Dimitri Mazilu, vice president of the provisional government, against charges that he had once been connected with the Securitate and should therefore be ousted, Rompres said. Even if Mazilu was a Securitate officer at the beginning of the Ceausescu regime, Munteanu said, ``for the last five years, he has been an outstanding spokesman against Ceausescu's regime.''

DOC.HEAD: Snow In West; Warmer in Midwest, East
DOC.TEXT: A January thaw was in the works today as mild, moist winds from the Southwest ushered unusually warm temperatures into the East. A new storm system neared the West Coast today, bringing rain to Oregon and to northern and central California. Sunny skies in the Southeast were expected to spawn record readings. Temperatures more consistent with late March will prevail in the Northeast today. Highs today were expected to be from the low 30s along the Canadian border to the low 50s in New York City. A cold front stretching from New Mexico to Wisconsin trailed the warm air eastward. The National Weather Service expected the cooler air to reach the mid-Atlantic states on Thursday. Gulf moisture ahead of the front will bring increasing cloudiness Wednesday, followed by showers Wednesday night and Thursday. A snow advisory was in effect for the Oregon Cascades. Six or more inches of snow were expected in the northern mountains by today. A foot or more of new snow was possible in the Sierra Nevada's higher altitudes. South Dakota's Black Hills braced for 3 to 6 inches of new snow. Arizona's White Mountains expected up to 6 inches of snow by today. Low pressure over Colorado will move eastward, spreading clouds across much of the Midwest. Fog and drizzle could develop over southern Iowa into Illinois and Missouri. There was a chance of light snow over parts of Nebraska and South Dakota as temperatures gradually cooled. New England expects cloudy and breezy weather Wednesday. Rain or showers were forecast for Vermont, and a mix of freezing rain, sleet and snow was anticipated for Maine and New Hampshire. Monday's hot spots were Laredo and Presidio, Tex., both with a reading of 82. DOC.HEAD: Ex-President Duarte Given Last Rites
