DOC.TEXT: Former President Jose Napoleon Duarte, who is suffering from terminal cancer, has received last rites, his doctor said. Dr. Jose Luis Saca said Duarte was given last rites Monday. Saca said Duarte, who also has pneumonia, was in ``very critical'' condition. Saca said Duarte, 64, was getting heavy doses of antibiotics and being fed intravenously. Duarte survived an earlier bout of pneumonia in September, when he was also given last rites. When his gastric cancer was diagnosed in May 1988, doctors said he had about 16 months to live. Duarte, a founder of the centrist Christian Democratic Party, handed over power in June to another freely elected president, rightist Alfredo Cristiani. The transition was a first in El Salvador, which has a history of coups, military dictatorships and civil war.

DOC.HEAD: Memorials But Also Violence on King Holiday
DOC.TEXT: Thousands marched and prayed and church bells rang on the birthday of slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr., while protesters demonstrated against states, schools and businesses not observing the federal holiday. Three Ku Klux Klansmen handed out leaflets in New Hampshire, fights broke out between blacks and whites in Louisiana and South Carolina and racist graffiti was sprayed on signs on a California highway named after King. King's survivors and others remembering him in services around the nation said they harbored no illusions that his work was finished. ``It's great that we celebrate his birthday but this day should be a day where we recommit ourselves to finishing his dream,'' King's son, Martin Luther King 3rd, who was 10 when his father died in 1968, told 500 people at a DePaul University church after leading a candlelight march Monday night. King's widow, Coretta Scott King, spoke in Atlanta at an annual ecumenical service at Ebenezer Baptist Church, where her husband delivered some of his most stirring orations. ``Now is the time to organize a global non-violent movement based on Dr. King's teachings, to put an end to the scourges of poverty, hunger, racism and bigotry, war and militarism,'' she said. Security for the service was heavy following recent racially motivated mail bombings in the Southeast. Bomb-sniffing dogs inspected the church beforehand; visitors were required for the first time to pass through metal detectors, and police took up posts throughout the church during the service. Security also was heavy for a March of Celebration held later in downtown Atlanta. Police estimated 400,000 people watched. A former top King lieutenant, the Rev. Hosea Williams, complained that the parade trivialized the day and wasted money better spent on the poor. ``This has been prostituted more than any other holiday except Jesus Christ's birthday,'' he said outside an Atlanta housing project. About 25,000 people lined Los Angeles' streets for the fifth annual King Birthday Celebration Parade down a boulevard named for him, and 2,500 turned out for an annual breakfast in Boston. In Memphis, Tenn., about 300 people gathered at The Lorraine Motel, where King was assassinated on April 4, 1968. ``We didn't want the children to think that Martin Luther King's birthday was just another day for watching television,'' said Mardest Van Hooks, a Memphis teacher who helped bring a group of youngsters to The Lorraine. The Washington-based Federal Holiday Commission said bells chimed at 12:30 p.m. EST in all 50 states and 144 countries. The Liberty Bell in Philadelphia was tapped three times. The New York Stock Exchange paused for a moment at noon. The holiday, first celebrated in 1986, fell on King's actual birthday for the first time. In New Hampshire, one of four states without any form of King holiday, students at high schools in Concord, Milford, Merrimack and Wolfeboro staged protest rallies. ``Martin Luther King wasn't just for black people. He changed everything for everyone, not just black people,'' Merrimack Valley High senior John Morin, who is white, told fellow students. In Arizona, where the King holiday has long been a bitter controversy, a Phoenix crowd estimated at nearly 15,000 heard lawmakers and community leaders at the Capitol urge them to vote in a referendum this fall over whether to let a King Day observance become law. A bill to make the day a holiday was introduced Monday in the Idaho Senate. Montana also has no form of King Holiday, while some other states keep workers on the job but mark the day in other ways. About 200 people protested outside a bank in Buffalo, N.Y., that stayed open. Norman Eenith, 35, held an outstretched dollar bill and said, ``This is what it's all about.'' In New Orleans, following a parade in King's honor attended by tens of thousands, two whites were arrested after a fight in which a black man was hit with nail-studded boards, officials said. At Garrett High School in Charleston, S.C., one of several area schools that canceled the day off to make up for days lost during Hurricane Hugo, about five black students angry at having to attend school on the holiday assaulted two white students, Principal Rex Whitcomb said. Police helped restore order. In San Diego, two signs on 10-mile stretch of highway named for King were painted with swastikas and the letters ``SWP,'' thought to stand for ``Supreme White Power,'' police said. In Florida, a county commissioner said he received numerous telephone threats after he protested a newspaper advertisement depicting King, a birthday cake and a garbage truck. The ad said trash would be picked up as usual Monday. ``All of a sudden I recognized that I felt a particular fear that as a young white man, fairly protected growing up, I had never felt before _ what so many people in this group must have felt,'' Yordon said.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Protest in Mongolian Capital
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Mongolians rallied for reform in the third street demonstration in their Communist country's capital in the past month, a foreign source said today. The source said the demonstrators, led by the newly formed Mongolian Democratic Union, criticized former leader Yumjaagiyn Tsedenbal and Mongolia's Communist Party Politiburo. The protesters, who numbered up to 5,000, were peaceful and ``good-humored'' and police made no attempt to interfere, the source said. The temperature was about 4 degrees below zero during the gathering Sunday on the steps of a movie theater in Ulan Bator. The Democratic Union, a group thought to be made up of reform-minded intellectuals and artists, also led open-air rallies on two Sundays in December. Those demonstrations drew far fewer people, with crowds estimated at several hundred to 1,000. The group reportedly has adopted a draft charter and petitioned the nation's parliament for official status. The source said demonstrators at today's protest carried banners calling for Tsedenbal to be put on trial and urging a faster pace of perestroika, or reforms like those championed by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Tsedenbal, purged in 1984 after more than three decades in power, has been criticized by the current government for his forced collectivization policies and his ``bureaucratic centralism.'' Mongolia, a nation of 2 million people spread across the vast deserts and grasslands of eastern Asia, has cautiously followed the reform policies taken by its protector state, the Soviet Union. However, the government has said the pace of reform has been too slow, and members of Parliament have called for fundamental changes in price and wage systems in the state-controlled economy. The source said it was not clear whether political upheaval in East Europe was influencing events in distant Mongolia and it was probably ``wrong to rush toward expectations'' of dramatic changes in the country. Other sources agreed that while the momentum for reform was picking up, advocates of change appeared willing to work within the system and not directly confront the ruling party. The government had no official reaction to the protest.

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Leader Denies Unrest
DOC.TEXT: The leader of Albania accused the Western news media of concocting false reports of unrest in his country and rejected the democratic reform gripping the rest of Eastern Europe. Communist Party chief Ramiz Alia said in a speech Monday to factory workers in Tirana, the Albanian capital, that the reports of upheaval were ``lies and falsity.'' His remarks were distributed by the official news agency ATA. ``Recently, in continuation of the events that occurred in the countries of the East, the fantasy regarding Albania has been diversified. Such a fantasy is reflected in some organs of the Western press,'' Alia said. The tide of reform elsewhere in Eastern Europe has left Albania as Europe's last bastion of Stalinism. Referring to a report by the Yugoslav news agency Tanjug that special measures in Albania resembled a state of emergency, Alia told the workers: ``With such filthy things does the Yugoslav news agency nourish world public opinion.'' ``We say ... that (a) state of emergency, demonstrations, unrest and killings are found nowhere in Albania.'' Accounts in the Western media have told of gunfire and possibly deaths in some Albanian cities. Foto Cami, a member of the ruling party Politburo, said on state radio and television Friday the reports of unrest were ``slanders'' and ``anti-Albanian inventions.'' On Saturday, ATA quoted a man it identified as Paolo de Nicola, an Italian diplomat, as calling the reports ``groundless.'' Alia said Monday: ``We are sure ... the anti-Albanian campaign ... will end like a soap bubble, because it is based completely on lies and falsity. ``Our people have chosen their own way of development and only they and no one else know and decide on what should be done and what steps should be taken, what changes are demanded by time and the process of socialist development and how'' they should be achieved. Albania is an isolated country of 3 million million people.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Blast Industrial Use of Ozone Killers
DOC.TEXT: An environmental group today criticized the continued reliance by industry on three widely used ozone-destroying chemicals, saying that while some companies are cutting back on their use others are relying on them even more. The Natural Resources Defense Council produced industry figures showing more than 200 million pounds of the chemicals were released into the atmosphere by more than 3,000 companies in 1987, the last year for which complete figures were available. Partial figures for 1988 show continued heavy use of the chemicals with ``the vast majority of companies ... yet to take any concrete steps to phase them out,'' said David Doniger, a lawyer for the NRDC. ``Their delays threaten the health and safety of all Americans.'' The subject of the NRDC study are two chemicals widely used as metal-cleaning solvents _ methyl chloroform and CFC113 _ in the aerospace, computer and electronics industries. The third chemical is carbon tetrachloride, which is primarily used in the United States for manufacture of chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs. The three chemicals are among those that when released can drift high into the atmosphere where the chlorine component reacts with the Earth's protective ozone layer, causing destruction of the ozone. The three chemicals currently account for 37 percent of the chlorine attacking the atmospheric ozone layer, the NRDC said. The government and industry have acknowleged that the CFCs, including CFC113 used as a solvent and carbon tetrachloride should be phased out. International treaty calls for a phaseout of CFCs and as that occurs the use of carbon tetrachloride also will decline. But methyl chloroform, whose potency for ozone destruction is less than 15 percent that of CFCs, remains unregulated and is viewed by much of industry as a potential ``bridge'' chemical as companies stop using CFCs as a cleaning solvent. ``It's needed for the orderly phaseout of CFCs,'' maintained Carol Niemi, an environmental specialist at Dow Chemical Co., which makes about half of the methyl chloroform produced today. Nevertheless, she said in a telephone interview, industry studies indicate that use of methyl chloroform, although likely to increase in the next few years, is expected to decline over the next decade. Environmentalists argue that industry reliance on any of the three ozone-damaging chemicals should be reduced more quickly. ``Decisions made in the boardrooms of these companies (using the chemicals) will determine whether we succeed or fail in preventing the first truly global environmental catastrophe,'' said the NRDC's Doniger. Using 1987 industry figures provided to the Environmental Protection Agency and 1988 information gathered from a scattering of companies through an NRDC questionnaire, the environmental group sought to determine to what extent companies are continuing to use the chemicals. Comparisons could be made based only on a relatively small number of companies because many of the 3,014 plans that reported 1987 releases to the EPA did not respond to the NRDC questionaire. According to the comparison, however, 194 companies increased their use of the chemicals between 1987 and 1988, although in some cases companies appeared to be substituting methyl chloroform for the more environmentally damaging CFC113s. However, according to the NRDC figures, 223 companies reported a declining use of the chemicals, including some cases in which the cut in emissions was substantial. In the case of methyl chloride, Pratt & Whitney, the Connecticut aircraft engine manufacturer that was the biggest user of the chemical in 1987 with 1.9 million pounds, reported emissions of only 421,000 pounds in 1988. The NRDC said 112 companies reported methyl chloroform emission increases of 2,000 pounds or more in 1988, while 144 companies reported emission reductions; 15 companies reported having stopped using methyl chloroform, and two other sources said they were committed to specific phaseout dates. Although CFC113 is one of the chemicals whose use is expected to be discontinued, 75 companies reported emission increases from 1987 to 1988, while 76 reported emissions decreases and five companies reported having stopped using the chemical. Seven companies reported increaes in carbon tetrachloride emissions between 1987 and 1988, while 12 companies reported emission decreases. Hercules Inc., the No. 1 user of the chemical in 1987, reported it had stopped using it last August, the NRDC said.

DOC.HEAD: A Giddy President in a Solemn Moment: The Imagemakers Slipped
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS name to Sig Mickelson sted Sid Michelson in 17th graf, `Television made'
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: There was something revealing the other day in President Bush's display of ire on television about television. He complained that television misleadingly had caused him to appear callously indifferent to the fate of the U.S. servicemen he had sent to Panama. He had held a news conference on Dec. 21, the day after the invasion. All was going well; Congress and public opinion were rallying behind him, and, a day after dispatching troops, he felt able to announce, ``This operation is not over, but it's pretty well wrapped up.'' He was upbeat, laughing, engaging in banter with reporters. ``Please, Sarah, lighten up,'' he told one reporter. And to another, who asked why the government had put a $1 million bounty on the head of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega: ``His picture will be in every post office in town.'' What Bush did not know was that while he was making ``my frivolous remarks'' _ his words for it _ some of the networks had gone to a split-screen technique to report simultaneously on the arrival at Dover Air Force Base in Delaware of the bodies of the first four U.S. servicemen killed in Panama. So while Bush joshed, the viewers saw conflicting images: a happy-go-lucky president in one corner of the screen and flag-draped coffins in another. ``I could understand why the viewers were concerned about this,'' Bush said at his next news conference. ``They thought their president at a solemn moment like that didn't give a damn.'' Bush said if the networks would tell him the next time he was competing against a compelling news story he would gladly step aside and let the other story have the entire screen. The networks which had carried the split-screen stories disagreed over whether they had mistreated the president. CBS and CNN said they were doing no more than covering the news as the news occurred. NBC chose not to go with the split-screen picture. ABC carried it, but anchorman Peter Jennings apologized, saying the president could not have known of the simultaneous broadcast and the pictures from Delaware could have waited. But the networks rejected Bush's request that they inform him in advance of what they will do in a similar situation. To do otherwise would have surrendered their editorial freedom and made them part of the White House's press apparatus. This sort of thing wouldn't have happened on Michael Deaver's watch, old-timers murmured. Deaver was the presidential aide who devoted much of his adult lifetime to protecting Ronald Reagan's image. No detail was too small when it came to policing what kind of impression Reagan would make. Deaver would have known that the bodies were arriving. Perhaps there would have been a quick trip to Dover, a presidential salute, a solemn sentence or two. In any event, no joking president on television. The Bush White House is image-conscious _ witness the president's anguished cry _ but not as dedicated to image control. Television people, who know when they are being manipulated even if they can't do much about it, like to believe that television, if it watches long enough, ultimately and invariably captures someone's true character. You can't fool the cameras long enough _ that's their fervid belief. ``Television made Joe McCarthy and television destroyed him,'' says Sig Mickelson, former president of CBS News, now teaching at San Diego State University in California. ``If a person is on TV long enough, the truth about him will out,'' says Lawrence Lichty, a longtime student of television and chairman of Northwestern University's Department of Radio, Television and Film. The Bush who America has come to know on television in the first year of his presidency is closer to the genuine article than Roger Ailes' made-for-TV Bush who got elected _ that two-fisted, tabasco-spiced, pork rind-eating flag-saluter who ran for the office. If occasional giddiness is part of the picture, that's Bush too, and, according to the Lichty theory, he's bound to show it.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Mike Feinsilber has covered the news in Washington for 21 years.

DOC.HEAD: `Annie 2' Transformed Into a Revival of `Annie'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, `The revival ...' to fix noun-verb agreement.
DOC.TEXT: A funny thing happened to ``Annie 2'' on its way to Broadway. It will become a revival of the original ``Annie.'' The $7 million sequel to the 1977 musical hit about the world's most famous orphan closes Saturday in Washington and will not open in New York as scheduled on March 1, said David Powers, a spokesman for the show. Instead, director Martin Charnin plans to use much of the same cast, as well as its scenery and costumes, for the revival, Powers said Monday. The revival is expected to reach Broadway later in the season, he added. A date and theater have not yet been announced. It could be an easy transformation _ if it happens. The stars of ``Annie 2,'' Dorothy Loudon as Miss Hannigan and Harve Presnell as Daddy Warbucks, have played in various productions of the originial, including on Broadway where Loudon won a Tony Award. Eleven-year-old Danielle Findley, who plays the title character in ``Annie 2,'' has also played the original in other cities. ``Annie 2,'' which has a score by Charnin and Charles Strouse and a book by Thomas Meehan, is far from dead, Powers said. The sequel will be done this summer at the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn., where the original ``Annie'' started in 1976, and possibly come to New York next fall, Powers said. Critics in Washington lambasted ``Annie 2'' after its Jan. 4 opening at the Kennedy Center's Opera House. ```Annie' was a musical to take to your heart,'' wrote David Richards in The Washington Post, ``but you'll want to take a paddle to `Annie 2.''' He called the book ``preposterous'' and the score ``dull.'' Revisions were started immediately by Charnin. He cut the book and musical numbers for the show, which ran three hours and 20 minutes during its first preview. Many theatergoers complained that there weren't enough orphans in the show, and five little girls were added to the cast. Mike Nichols, Larry Gelbart and Tommy Tune, all of them experienced show doctors, reportedly were asked to come to Washington to look at the troubled show. The plot for ``Annie 2,'' which takes place six weeks after the ending of the first show, revolves around Daddy Warbucks' search for a wife. Miss Hannigan wants the job _ to get revenge on Annie. The original ``Annie,'' also written by Charnin, Strouse and Meehan, almost died at the Goodspeed Opera House in 1976. But Charnin brought in Nichols, who signed on as a producer, and helped him revise the show. With Andrea McArdle replacing Kristen Vigard as Annie and Loudon added as Miss Hannigan, the production went on to open in New York in April 1977, winning the Tony as best musical and running for 2,377 performances.

DOC.HEAD: Foreman Pounds Cooney in `Geezers at Caesars' Match
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS next-to-last graf `The 231-pound ...' to CORRECT that Foreman, sted Cooney, turned to evangelism.
DOC.TEXT: George Foreman, who had a big waistline and an even bigger punch, needed less than five minutes to knock out Gerry Cooney and end Cooney's comeback bid in the match dubbed the ``Geezers at Caesars.'' ``I'm what you call a super-duper big-match heavyweight,'' said the 41-year-old, 253\-pound Foreman after Monday night's fight, sponsored by Caesars hotel and casino. Foreman quickly finished off Cooney, 33, smashing him to the floor twice and knocking him out at 1:57 in the second round. The referee didn't bother to count after the second knockdown. Foreman, who held the heavyweight title in 1973-74, now wants to take on the unbeaten 23-year-old Mike Tyson for the championship. It was Foreman's 20th straight victory since beginning a comeback in 1987 from a 10-year retirement. ``I will probably knock him (Tyson) out a lot faster because he won't back up,'' Foreman said. Cooney said he would retire. ``No more fighting,'' he said. ``There's not going to be any more comebacks for me.'' The 231-pound Cooney was a leading heavyweight in the 1980s but fought only 31 rounds in the decade. Foreman turned to evangelism and founded a church after he retired in 1977. Both fighters were guaranteed $1 million.

DOC.HEAD: Astronauts Concentrate on Experiments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with crew quiet at work, day's activities, new theory on glitch; PICKS UP 7th graf, `One of ...'
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Columbia's five crew members labored quietly today on their experiments, growing protein crystals in zero gravity, melting and resolidifying a metal and photographing the Earth. ``All systems aboard Columbia are clean,'' Mission Control reported as the astronauts worked through the seventh full day of their marathon 10-day mission. There was little radio traffic between ground and space ``to allow the crew to stay on the timeline and get all their various chores accomplished without a lot of interference from the folks here,'' the control center said. ``We just let them go at it, and they've been doing very well.'' Television from the shuttle showed the astronauts busily pursuing the several experiments. There were no further problems with a navigation system that sounded an alarm and wakened the crew Sunday night, and commander Dan Brandenstein stopped a dehumidifier leak that had been a bother almost from the beginning of the flight. Engineers did not have an explanation for the five sensor signals that triggered the alarm, but some theorized they may have been associated with electronics that feed a speed-measuring accelerometer and not with the navigation unit itself. Brandenstein plugged the leak by stuffing a towel in a plastic bag and wrapping it around the pipe that was its source. The astronauts were so busy with their experiments Monday that they went to bed more than two hours late. So Mission Control let them sleep an extra half hour today. But it told them in the package of messages and instructions faxed up this morning: ``Your request for overtime has been disapproved.'' One of the crews' first chores was to dump excess water overboard through a valve. A TV picture showed the expelled water turning to ice crystals as it hit the cold atmosphere of space. As Columbia passed into daylight, the sun brilliantly illuminated the crystal shower. ``Quite a show, isn't it?'' Brandenstein remarked. ``You bet,'' replied Mission Control communicator Tammy Jernigan. Mission specialists Bonnie Dunbar, Marsha Ivins and David Low were busy monitoring an experiment in which the metal indium was being melted and resolidified to determine if space-processed materials can have industrial applications. They also were growing protein crystals in a continuing series of shuttle experiments that could lead to the weightless processing of new, purer drugs to be used to fight cancer, AIDs, high blood pressure, arthritis and other diseases. Medical experiments were aimed at learning how well the human body adapts to weightlessness. Brandenstein and pilot Jim Wetherbee, when not minding the ship, were busy photographing Earth features for a documentary film on how man and nature are damaging the planet. Among the targets were large fires in Kenya and Madagascar and deforestation in Brazil and Haiti. The astronauts accomplished their main goals during the first four days of the mission. They deployed a Navy communications satellite and retrieved an 11-ton science laboratory that they will bring back to Earth so scientists can learn how scores of different materials and systems survived six years in orbit. Columbia is to land in the darkness at 2:59 a.m. PST on Friday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: President Declares 7 Florida Counties Disaster Areas
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has declared seven Florida counties major disaster areas because of crop damage from a pre-Christmas freeze, opening the door to loans and other relief for field hands and farm owners. ``Obviously I am very pleased with the president's speedy response to Florida's request for help,'' Gov. Bob Martinez said. The disaster declaration Monday makes farmworkers in Broward, Collier, Dade, Hendry, Lee, Monroe and Palm Beach counties eligible for federal unemployment compensation for 26 weeks. Farm owners will be eligible for low-interest loans supported by the Farmers Home Administration. The freeze struck Dec. 23, with portions of upper Florida getting snow for the first time in years. The area in the declaration is most of southern Florida, mostly a vegetable growing area. Martinez said he would ask for similar help for citrus areas in central and northern Florida once the extent of damage there has been documented. Martinez had asked Bush four days earlier for an estimated $34.4 million in disaster unemployment assistance to supplement some $4.79 million in state aid.

DOC.HEAD: Top Military Officers Gather for Unusual East-West Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Powell saying changes may lead to reduced NATO, Warsaw Pact presence; picks up 4th pvs, `The three...'
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Colin Powell, the top U.S. military leader, today welcomed initial steps by the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact to reshape its armed forces and said the level of U.S. forces in Western Europe could be changed. Powell, chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, made his comments before top brass from the Soviet Union and 33 other countries in an unusual exchange of views on their governments' military policies. ``There is nothing sacrosanct about the number of American troops stationed in Europe,'' he said. ``There is nothing carved in stone that says that military power in a divided Europe should remain as it has over the last four decades. ``We are hopeful that the process in which we are all engaged will lead to the day when the military demands on both European alliances are greatly diminished,'' he said. Foreign Minister Alois Mock of Austria opened the unprecedented meeting, which is designed to further reduce military tensions in Europe. The military doctrine seminar, scheduled in October, attracted greater attention following the wave of democratic reform that swept Eastern Europe. Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev, the Soviet military chief of staff, also was scheduled to speak. The three-week session marks the first time top military officers of the NATO and the Warsaw Pact, plus the neutral and non-aligned states of Europe, are sitting down to discuss their intentions, plans and arsenals, U.S. officials say. The discussions are being held under the auspices of the negotiations on Confidence- and Security-Building Measures. Western military experts are anxious to hear just what the emerging democracies in the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact have in mind for their defense policies. John Maresca, who leads the U.S. delegation to the confidence-building talks, said officials want ``to understand better what these Eastern European countries are thinking at this time, how their policies are going to evolve.'' Czechoslovakia and Hungary already have said they want Soviet troops off their soil this year. In East Germany, Communist Party leader Gregor Gysi has proposed that all foreign troops leave both Germanys by 1999. ``There is a greater willingness of countries in Eastern Europe to take positions on the basis of what they see as their national interest, rather than just following a position which is dictated to them by the Soviet Union,'' Maresca told a news conference Monday. Western analysts also are eager to hear what Moiseyev has to say about the Soviet Union's military stance. In December 1988, Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced plans to pare his government's defense spending and military forces, including the pullout of 50,000 of the estimated 550,000 troops from Eastern Europe. Moscow has said it is adopting a more defensive military doctrine. ``We would like to understand better what that means,'' said Maresca. Western analysts seek hard evidence of lower spending, fewer troops and reduced arms production. The North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the 16-nation Western alliance, maintains its forces are the minimum needed to defend against an attack. During the seminar, the military officers were expected to present their views, then respond to questions. The give-and-take is designed to fill in any gaps or clear up any confusion. In addition, the officers will have a chance to meet privately for further questioning. The idea behind the meeting is to lessen the secrecy that surrounds military policies. The overall confidence-building negotiations are aimed at finding ways to increase trust among the countries and therefore reduce tensions in Europe. Maresca emphasized that the seminar is an experiment. No report will be made at the end. John Cross, deputy director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, said, ``It cannot but be for the good for the senior military officers and thinkers of both sides to be talking to one another.''

DOC.HEAD: Peaceful Protests Continue On Azerbaijan Border
With PM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Moslems in Soviet Azerbaijan staged a peaceful protest on the Iranian border to demand closed links with their kin in Iran, Tehran radio reported today. The demonstration constrasted with the ethnic violence inside the Soviet republic, where Moscow declared a state of emergency Monday to try to stop the fighting between Azerbaijanis and ethnic Armenians. The Tehran radio broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, said 5,000 Soviet Moslems gathered in below-freezing temperatures Monday along the Araks river, which forms part of the border, to call for free travel to Iran. Shiite Moslems in the Soviet republic of Azerbaijan share a common culture, language and religion with their brethren across the border and have staged several protests in recent days. Earlier this month, thousands of Soviet Moslems went on a three-day rampage and tore down frontier posts, watchtowers and communication lines. They demanded reunification of the Soviet and Iranian Azerbaijans. Impatient with official statements that travel restrictions between the countries will be eased, many Soviet Moslems have jumped into the cold waters of the Araks and swum to the Iranian side for short visits. Tehran radio earlier reported that 30 people swam across on Sunday. This week's peaceful border protests contrasted sharply with scenes inside Soviet Azerbaijan, where militant Azerbaijanis clashed with ethnic Armenians over who should govern the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh. The enclave is a part of Azerbaijan but its residents mainly are Armenian. Moscow on Monday sent in army units and KGB officers to protect residents from widespread fighting. Soviet media reports said hundreds of Azerbaijanis and Armenians have been battling with submachine guns, helicopters and armored vehicles. The violence in Azerbaijan has heightened Soviet fears of Moslem unrest along its southern border with Iran. Tehran has said it welcomes free travel for Soviet Moslems to Iran, as well as more trade and cultural ties across the border. Azerbaijan, once wholly under Iranian control, was ceded to Russia in 1828. In 1946, the Red Army entered northern Iran and set up a puppet republic with the aim of controlling all of Azerbaijan. But the Soviets withdrew in 1946 following an international outcry.

DOC.HEAD: Rights Groups Says Fired Minister Used Torture
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th pvs, `In a...' to CORRECT population figure to 55 million; picks up 8th pvs, `He also...'
DOC.TEXT: A human rights group is accusing the Interior Ministry of using torture against Moslem fundamentalists under the leadership of a man who has just been fired by President Hosni Mubarak. The Egyptian Organization for Human Rights on Mondayyy alleged a rapid rise in torture last year, mainly of the fundamentalists. It said trend has been evident since mid-1987. That was little more than a year after dismissed Interior Minister Zaki Badr took control of domestic security. It also was when a court acquitted 41 security men of torturing suspects while investigating a coup attempt that closelyy followed the assassination of Mubarak's predecessor, Anwar Sadat. His death was blamed on fundamentalists. While denying the torture charges Monday, new Interior Minister Abdel-Halim Moussa continued making appearances to mend fences shattered by Badr's quick tongue. It was Badr's rhetoric, rather than his raids on Moslem fundamentalists, that appeared to prompt the announcement of his dismissal Friday. In a recent speech, Badr said all Moslem fundamentalists, who make up about 1 percent of Egypt's population of 55 million, should be killed. He also savaged a variety of politicians, journalists and other public figures, even his Cabinet colleagues. In its report Monday, the Egyptian Organization for Human Rights said at least one prisoner died last year under police torture. Many others suffered temporary or permanent physical damage, the report said. ``Torture was practiced on a large scale following almost all the waves of mass and individual arrests and detentions, with severe beating, slaps, punches, kicks, rifle butts, leather belts, hosepipe, bamboo sticks and electric batons. In some cases, the whip was brought back into use to beat and torture detainees,'' the report said. It said that in addition to religious activists, victims of torture included labor leaders and prominent leftists. In comments quoted by the Middle East News Agency, the new interior minister responded, ``These claims are absolutely baseless, because prisons in Egypt have their regulations, and the prosecutors and the judiciary have the right to inspect them.'' However, Moussa, who has a reputation for concilation, has tried to assure Egyptians that he's different from Badr. In a speech Sunday, he said religious militancy is a social problem rather than one of law enforcement provided extremists do not break the law. ``Police are at the service of the people and not to insult them,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General to Investigate Intimidation Claims in Stuart Case
With PM-Stuart Shooting
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts' attorney general is investigating allegations that police intimidated two teen-agers into falsely linking a black man to the shooting of Charles and Carol Stuart. Attorney General James M. Shannon also said Monday his office will take a second look at allegations that Boston police were stopping and searching young blacks and Hispanics without sufficient cause. ``They are separate issues. I think it's a mistake to let these issues run into one another,'' Shannon said. ``I don't think anyone should be prejudged here. That was the big mistake in the Stuart story.'' The Stuarts were shot Oct. 23. Charles Stuart, who directed police over his car phone to his dying wife, said a black man robbed and shot them after they left a birthing clinic. Mrs. Stuart, seven months pregnant, died hours later. Their son, delivered by Caesarean section, died 17 days later. Stuart was seriously wounded. William Bennett, a black man with a police record, was identified in the news media as the prime suspect. He was cleared after Stuart was implicated in the shooting by a younger brother and then apparently jumped to his death from a bridge. Two teen-agers have said since that they were intimidated by police into incriminating Bennett. Dereck Jackson, 17, told reporters Friday he was forced to tell police that Bennett confessed to the Stuart shooting in his presense. Eric Whitney, 18, said in a newspaper report that police supplied him with undisclosed details of the shooting and pressured him to recount them to another detective. Both said they testified falsely to a grand jury but returned later and recanted. ``On the allegations about intimidation of witnesses, I'm going to ask my civil rights division to contact the lawyers in that case and see whether they have something they want to tell us,'' Shannon said. ``They haven't come to us yet, but we're not going to let it lie there.'' In September, a Superior Court judge ruled that police had instituted an unconstitutional policy and asked Shannon to do whatever was necessary to ``restrain further unreasonable searches and seizures'' by police. One month later, Shannon said that after talking with Boston police, he was convinced there was no search-on-sight policy.

DOC.HEAD: Both Business Inventories and Sales Rose in November
DOC.TEXT: Business inventories rose rose 0.5 percent in November but business sales rebounded by a brisker 0.7 percent, the government said today. Faster growth of sales than accumulation of goods on shelves and backlots is good news for the economy. If inventories were to pile up excessively, it could mean cutbacks in production and a loss of jobs. However, some industries such as automobiles already are feeling the effects of excessive inventories. Chrysler Corp., Ford Motor Co. and General Motors Corp. all have announced temporary layoffs to reduce the number of vehicles stuck on backlots. Mazda Motor Corp. of Japan is trimming production at its U.S. plant later this month. The Commerce Department said inventories climbed to a seasonally adjusted $796.8 billion in November after rising 0.3 percent a month earlier. That was a bit better than the 0.4 percent increase originally reported. Business sales also rose, to a seasonally adjusted $523.6 billion, after falling a revised 0.5 percent in October. That revision showed a slight improvement over the 0.7 percent drop originally reported. The result in November business activity produced a slight decline, to 1.52, in the ratio of inventories to sales. That means it would take 1.52 months to exhaust inventories at the November pace. The ratio was 1.53 in October. Inventories often rise during periods of slow economic growth as output exceeds demand. The economy has been experiencing sluggishness over the past year as the Federal Reserve keeps a tight rein on credit to slow inflation. But many economists do not feel the ratio is at a dangerous level yet. Retail backlogs rose 0.6 percent in November, while retail sales climbed 0.5 percent. But the Commerce Department reported last week that sales gained only 0.2 percent in December, reflecting a modest holiday buying season. Inventories at the manufacturing level, which represent about 45 percent of the total, rose 0.3 percent. Manufacturing sales, on the other hand, increased 0.5 percent. Wholesalers' inventories advanced 0.5 percent, while their sales jumped 1.2 percent. Overall, inventories were 6.8 percent above those of a year ago, while sales increased 4.4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Their Ruling Monopoly Scrapped, Communists Begin Talks With Opposition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs with talks stalling, details; picks up 20th pvs, `In other...' EDITS to TRIM.
DOC.TEXT: The still powerful Communist Party began talks today with an opposition coalition demanding more democracy, but the two sides immediately stalled over opposition demands for offices and its own newspaper. The disarray, played out for an hour in front of reporters, illustrated the difficulties of trying to move from totalitarian rule to more democracy without basic tools for the transition. The talks come a day after Parliament voted unanimously to repeal the Communist Party's guaranteed leading role, making Bulgaria the last Warsaw Pact country to formally overturn the status that shored up Stalinist structures in Eastern Europe for more than 40 years. The Union of Democratic Forces, the coalition of Bulgaria's still weak and divided democratic opposition, has been pushing since November for its own daily newspapers and for offices. It angrily accused the Communists of stalling on both demands. ``For many years, we know what it means when we don't get an answer,'' said Petko Simeonov, a coalition leader. ``Our slogans and our ideas do not reach everybody. We want what we have to say to be heard by everybody.'' Without an office, Simeonov said the coalition has no venue to coordinate positions in broad talks on the country's future. ``The conditions are unfavorable, as if on purpose,'' he said. Andrey Lukanov, the No. 2 Communist Party official, said the ruling party had done all it could to get authorities to provide offices and newsprint, but matters were no longer in their hands. ``I don't think you should be so suspicious,'' he smiled to the opposition, seated across from the Communists and their allies the Agrarian Party in a brightly lit hall of Bulgaria's National Assembly, or parliament, building. Eventually, the two sides agreed to discuss the issue behind closed doors, with the opposition threatening to withdraw from the talks if the quarrel was not settled. The broad talks are supposed to discuss the transition to democracy and the free elections promised by May. Hindered by ethnic conflict and the remaining power of orthodox Communists in the provinces, change is coming slowly to Bulgaria, where hard-line Communist Todor Zhivkov was ousted Nov. 10 after more than 35 years in power. The opposition won another victory Monday _ a promise that Communist cells will be removed from Bulgaria's police, making it politically neutral, said Petar Beron, an opposition spokesman. The opposition backed its demands with a rally of more than 50,000 people on Sunday, the biggest to date in Sofia. Loudly applauded demands there included the calls for the resignation of Communist Premier Georgi Atanassov, a holdover from the Zhivkov era, and adoption of two-tiered legislative elections in May and November to give the opposition a chance to organize against the still powerful Communists. Opposition forces see the promised elections as a tactic by the Communists to preserve much of their power while the opposition is still untested and weak. In other business Monday, Parliament approved a compromise reached last week to smooth the friction between the country's 1.5 million Moslems, mostly ethnic Turks, and the Slavic majority over last month's decision by the new leadership to restore their Turkish names and customs. Five years ago, Zhivkov had forced the ethnic Turks to take Slavic names. The compromise enforced the Dec. 29 decision _ which sparked fierce protests across Bulgaria _ but insisted that Bulgarian is the official language and affirmed Bulgaria's ``territorial integrity.'' Criticism of Zhivkov peaked during the debate on the sensitive ethnic issue, with deputies condemning the former leader's hasty move last year to allow an estimated 320,000 Turks to flee labor-starved Bulgaria. Some 90,000 have now returned, unable to find work in Turkey and promised a new, more equal life and the restoration of property they abandoned by Bulgaria's new rulers.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Consider Limiting Power of Environmentalists
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court said today it will consider limiting the power of environmentalists to prevent the opening up of federal lands to commercial development. The court voted to review a pro-enviromentalist ruling challenged by the Bush administration. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here ruled last June that the National Wildlife Federation may sue the Interior Department over its plans to change the status of some 180 million acres of public land in Western states and Alaska _ more than one-fourth of the nation's public lands. The federation said it is suing to ``protect federal lands against unwise or premature disposition and development,'' including millions of acres to be opened up to mining and mineral leasing. The move to reclassify the land for development and other uses was made by the Reagan administration in 1985, following a policy instituted by then-Secretary James G. Watt in 1981. The wildlife federation said the Reagan administration violated federal law by opening the land to development without following procedures in the 1976 Federal Land Policy and Management Act. The appeals court said the federation has legal standing to sue because affidavits show some of its 4.5 million members use some of the land for recreation. The appeals court overruled a federal judge who had thrown out the suit. The appeals court relied, for example, on a statement by federation member Peggy K. Peterson, who said she uses land in the South Pass-Green Mountain area of Wyoming. The Bush administration said the appeals court permitted a wholesale challenge to the Interior Department's reclassification based on a vague allegation it will jeopardize use of a tiny portion of the land by wildlife federation members. The appeals court, in effect, has ordered a federal judge ``to assume the role of a nationwide land-use czar'' and determine how millions of acres may be used, Justice Department lawyers argued in the appeal acted on today. Groups supporting the administration position are the Mountain States Legal Foundation, the American Farm Bureau Federation, the National Cattlemen's Association and the American Mining Congress. The case is Lujan vs. National Wildlife Federation, 89-640.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Let Eastern Machinists' Strike Spread to Commuter Railroads
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to let a machinists union strike against Eastern Airlines spread to commuter railroads. The court, without comment, left intact rulings barring sympathy strikes against railroads in New York City, Philadelphia and their suburbs. The machinists, who walked off the job last March 4 after refusing to give more than $150 million in concessions sought by Eastern, remain on strike. Pilots and flight attendants supported the strike for eight months before ending their walk-out in November. The machinists and unions sympathetic to the Eastern strike sought to extend its impact by setting up picket lines at facilities run by the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority (SEPTA) in the Philadelphia area and by Amtrak, the Long Island Railroad, Metro-North Commuter Railroad and NJ Transit Rail in the New York City metropolitan area. The New York City-area railroads carry some 350,000 commuters daily between New York City and its suburbs. The SEPTA trains transport more than 90,000 commuters each day. Federal judges barred the secondary strikes, and the restraining orders were upheld by the New York-based 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and the Philadelphia-based 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The appeals courts said collective bargaining agreements between the railroads and their unions may be interpreted to prohibit such sympathy strikes, at least until the labor dispute is submitted to arbitration. Underlying the issue is a clash between two federal laws, the Railway Labor Act and the Norris-La Guardia Act. The Norris-La Guardia Act limits the power of federal courts to enjoin strikes while the Railway Labor Act sets up procedures, such as arbitration, designed to forestall strikes against railroads. The justices in 1987 ruled that courts generally may not bar railroad workers from extending a labor dispute to other railroads not directly involved in the dispute. But the 2nd Circuit court said the 1987 ruling applies only in cases in which other procedures to end a railway strike are exhausted. The appeals court said the opposite was true in the Eastern case because there had been no attempt through arbitration to end the secondary strikes against the railroads. Since ``there was a risk of immediate and irreparable injury to the railroads and the public,'' the 2nd Circuit court said, the judge acted within his authority in halting the sympathy strikes. The 3rd Circuit court said SEPTA workers do not have the right to violate no-strike provisions in their own collective bargaining agreements by honoring picket lines set up by Eastern employees at SEPTA facilities. Lawyers for the machinists union said the power of unions to fight for fair treatment is weakened by a ban on sympathy strikes. They also said the 2nd and 3rd Circuit court rulings conflict with decisions by other federal appeals courts. There have been reports that the machinists want to use sympathy strikes against the railroads to prompt President Bush or Congress to take action in their walk-out against the airline. The cases are International Association of Machinists vs. Long Island Railroad, 89-427 and 89-674, and Brotherhood of Railroad Signalmen vs. SEPTA, 89-756.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Agrees To Decide Case on Tips to Police
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide what authority police have to stop and question someone on the basis of an anonymous tip that the person is involved in a crime. The justices said they will review an Alabama court ruling that limited such police tactics. A state appeals court threw out Vanessa White's 1987 conviction for possession of marijuana and cocaine, ruling that Montgomery police had seized the drugs after unlawfully stopping her car. The appeals court said an anonymous tip police received about Ms. White was not enough to justify an investigatory stop by police _ and they therefore had violated her constitutional rights. The Constitution's Fourth Amendment bans unreasonable police seizures and searches. Ms. White's two-year probationary sentence was thrown out along with her conviction. The nation's highest court previously has ruled that police can make arrests only when they have ``probable cause'' to believe someone is involved in a crime. But the court has allowed police to make brief investigatory stops _ to stop, question and even frisk someone _ if they have a ``reasonable suspicion,'' a more lenient standard than probable cause. Federal appeals courts and state courts have been divided in recent years when ruling whether an anonymous tip to police can give rise to such a reasonable suspicion. In Ms. White's case, the Alabama appeals court based its decision ``on an individualized evaluation of the particular tip in light of the totality of the circumstances.'' On April 22, 1987, Police Cpl. B.H. Davis received an anonymous telephone call telling him that Ms. White would be leaving a certain apartment at a particular time in a brown station wagon to go to a motel. The caller said Ms. White would have with her about an ounce of cocaine in a brown attache case. Police went to the apartment and kept it under surveillance. They saw Ms. White leave in a brown station wagon and drive to a motel. They then approached Ms. White and told her about the call they had received. An officer asked for permission to search the station wagon, and Ms. White said he could. A brown attache case was found inside, and after Ms. White told officers the combination to its lock, marijuana was found inside it. After Ms. White was arrested, police found three milligrams of cocaine inside her purse. In throwing out Ms. White's conviction, the state appeals court said, ``Because (she) was illegally detained when she gave her consent to the search, the marijuana from the briefcase and the cocaine from her purse are fruits of an unconstitutional detention.'' Such evidence should have been barred from her prosecution, the appeals court said. It added, ``Here, the stop cannot be supported by specific and articulable reliable facts raising a reasonable suspicion that (Ms. White) was engaged in wrongdoing.'' After the Alabama Supreme Court refused to review the case, state Attorney General Don Siegelman filed the appeal acted on today. The justices in 1980 and 1981 turned down requests to decide whether an anonymous tip can justify an investigatory stop. Each time, several justices voted to resolve the issue. The case is Alabama vs. White, 89-789.

DOC.HEAD: TWA Flight Attendants Lose Sex Bias Appeal
DOC.TEXT: Trans World Airlines flight attendants, who accused TWA owner Carl Icahn of sex bias in seeking wage cuts and other concessions that triggered a strike, lost a Supreme Court appeal today. The court, without comment, refused to revive a lawsuit against the airline. The flight attendants sought back pay and other benefits. The Independent Federation of Flight Attendants called a strike against TWA on March 7, 1986. Two months later, the union offered to return to work and accept TWA's demands. About 200 strikers were rehired immediately, but more than three years passed before the last of the 5,000 striking attendants were offered jobs with TWA. The strike was called when Icahn insisted on wage and other concessions for attendants _ 85 percent of them women _ that were greater than cuts he sought to impose against the airline's pilots, machinists and other workers. During the negotiations with the attendants union, Icahn said it would be easy for him to find young, untrained women to be stewardesses for less than he was paying the attendants. When union negotiators said janitors who belonged to the machinists union were offered a better deal than the attendants, Icahn remarked: ``A janitor is a breadwinner (who) probably has got a family at home to support (while) you girls are second incomes and you don't need the money.'' The union said the statement demonstrated bias against women and violated fair bargaining procedures mandated by the federal Railway Labor Act, which governs labor negotiations for airlines and railroads. The strike against TWA should be viewed by the courts as one based on unfair labor practices and not only on demands for more money, the union's lawyers said. Unlike workers who walk off the job over pay and benefits, strikers who prove unfair labor practices by an employer are entitled to their old jobs when they unconditionally return to work. U.S. District Judge Howard F. Sachs in Missouri rejected the union's claims that Icahn was guilty of sexual stereotyping. Icahn's ``breadwinner'' remarks were ``foolish and offensive,'' Sachs said. But he said Icahn apparently was trying to rationalize his negotiating strategy of demanding more cuts from the attendants. The judge said the real reason Icahn made a more generous offer to the machinists was because that union could ``do greater damage to TWA in a strike'' and because Icahn believed it would be easier to replace the attendants with untrained workers. ``There has been no persuasive showing that sex stereotyping governed or influenced Icahn's economic demands, only his rationalizations,'' Sachs said. ``Greedy employers, like greedy unions, have a legal right to try their strength and to enforce demands'' through the collective bargaining process, the judge said. The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the judge's ruling last June. The justices last year made it easier for workers to win suits against employers accused of sexual stereotyping. But that decision was based on a federal civil rights law banning workplace discrimination, not the Railway Labor Act at issue in the case acted on today. The case is Independent Federation of Flight Attendants vs. TWA, 89-783.

DOC.HEAD: Court Action Blocks Refunds of Overcharges
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today blocked indefinitely the effect of a lower-court ruling that could have provided natural gas consumers with tens of millions of dollars in refunds. The justices, granting an emergency request by 21 energy companies, held in abeyance a decision by the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals that could have led to the refunds. Justice Byron R. White last week granted a temporary stay of the appeals court ruling, and the court's order today extended that stay until it acts on a formal appeal to be filed by the energy companies. The New Orleans-based appeals court last Sept. 16 invalidated a 4-year-old federal regulation that allowed gas producers to raise some prices. The appeals court ruled that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission exceeded its authority in 1986 when permitting producers of ``old'' gas to raise their prices and to stop selling to pipeline companies not willing to pay the higher prices. Old gas is from wells that were producing before Nov. 9, 1978. Congress that year approved a partial decontrol of the natural gas industry. Old-gas prices remained controlled, but no caps were imposed on the price of gas from new wells. The commission's 1986 regulation, known as Order 451, allowed the ceiling price of old gas to rise from 52 cents per thousand cubic feet to $2.75. Consumers, distributors and pipeline companies challenged Order 451, leading to the 5th Circuit court ruling. In seeking emergency help, lawyers for the energy companies said they would soon file a formal appeal seeking to overturn the appeals court decision, which they said ``casts into doubt hundreds of gas-supply contracts'' signed since 1986. The justices were told that if the September ruling takes effect it will generate numerous contract disputes and ``introduce a period of great uncertainty in the entire natural gas market _ all during the winter heating season.'' The case is Mobil Oil Exploration v. United Distribution Companies, A-503.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Kill Lawsuits Against Two Pennsylvania School Officials
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to kill lawsuits against two Pennsylvania school officials by two former students who say they were sexually assaulted by their high school band instructor. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the officials are not entitled to qualified legal immunity from being sued by Kathleen Stoneking and Judy Grove Sowers, former students at Bradford Area High School. Both women allege they were were sexually assaulted by Edward Wright, the high school's former band instructor. Both women were band members. Wright was suspended in 1986, and later resigned. He pleaded guilty to criminal charges, including indecent assault, that same year and received a probationary sentence. Both cases were before the justices last year, and were sent back to a federal appeals court for additional study. The 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last Aug. 16 and Sept. 8 that the lawsuits against Frederick Smith, the high school's principal, and Richard Miller, its assistant principal, should go to trial. The appeals court dismissed Frederick Shuey, the now-retired school district superintendent, as a defendant in both suits. Ms. Stoneking was graduated from high school in 1983. Her 1987 suit contends that the school officials failed to protect her. The suit alleges that beginning in her sophomore year, Wright sexually harassed and abused her, and forced her to engage in various sexual acts with him. The suit alleges that school officials knew of complaints against Wright involving other female students. Mrs. Sowers' suit alleges she was sexually assaulted by Wright at his home in June 1979. In separate orders last March and April, the justices told the 3rd Circuit court to restudy the two cases in light of their February 1989 decision that government officials have no constitutional duty to protect citizens from private violence or abuse. That decision shielded child welfare officials from being sued for returning a young Wisconsin boy, Jason DeShaney, to the custody of his father, who subsequently beat him so severely the boy is now permanently brain-damaged. Ruling in Ms. Stoneking's case last August, the 3rd Circuit court cited a major difference between it and the Wisconsin case: ``DeShaney's injuries resulted at the hands of a private actor (his father) whereas Stoneking's resulted from the actions of a state employee. Wright was a school district employee subject to defendants' immediate control.'' The appeals court cited its August ruling in Ms. Stoneking's case when reinstating Mrs. Sowers' suit in September. The cases are Smith vs. Stoneking, 89-780, and Smith vs. Sowers, 89-782.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Killer Facing Death Sentences Loses Appeal
DOC.TEXT: A convicted killer facing death sentences in Ohio, Illinois and Indiana for his murderous crime spree in 1984 lost a Supreme Court appeal today. The justices let stand Ohio court rulings that Alton Coleman properly was convicted and sentenced to die for killing Tonnie Storey, 15, in Cincinnati. Prosecutors said Coleman, from Waukegan, Ill., murdered eight women and girls in three states during a seven-week summer killing spree. Coleman, 34, and his traveling companion, Debra Brown, were convicted in Cincinnati of killing Miss Storey, whose body was found in an abandoned city apartment building, and Marlene Walters, 44, at her home in suburban Norwood. Miss Storey was strangled. Mrs. Walters was beaten to death. Coleman also was convicted and condemned for the kidnap and murder of Vernita Wheat, 9, of Kenosha, Wis., and for killing Tamika Turks, 7, of Gary, Ind. Court records submitted with Coleman's appeal said he also was convicted in the deaths of Virginia Temple of Toledo, Ohio, and her 9-year-old daughter, Rachelle. The records did not identify the two other murder victims. Coleman, called by prosecutors a ``heartless killer,'' was arrested in Evanston, Ill., on July 20, 1984. The appeal acted on today contended that Coleman was convicted unfairly of Miss Storey's murder because the presiding judge refused to move the trial despite ``pervasive and inflammatory'' pretrial publicity in Cincinnati. The appeal also argued that prosecutors should not have been allowed to introduce ``massive amounts of sensational, prejudicial and irrelevant evidence of other serious (then untried) criminal acts.'' The case is Coleman vs. Ohio, 89-6113.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Study Missouri-Kansas Appeal on Gas Overcharges
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to consider broadening the power of states to sue in behalf of gas consumers allegedly overcharged by utility companies. The court said it will hear an appeal by Kansas and Missouri officials who have accused utilities of illegal price-fixing. The appeal was supported by 32 other states seeking to protect their consumers and vigorously enforce antitrust laws. Asked for its views, the Bush administration urged the court to review the issue, saying lower courts have reached conflicting conclusions. Kansas and Missouri officials sued the Kansas Power & Light Co. and Utilicorp United Inc. over natural gas transported by pipeline from Wyoming and used to generate electricity sold to customers in the two states. Some of the natural gas delivered from Wyoming was sold to the utilities' customers. The states alleged that gas-producing companies conspired to inflate the price of the gas, and that the utilities passed on the higher rates to consumers. The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in January 1989 that the states do not have the authority to sue in behalf of residential customers. The appeals court said that only direct purchasers of fixed amounts of gas may sue in such cases. ``Any allocation of illegal overcharges to the residential consumers may require tracing the sale from the wellhead through each level of distribution to establish the amount of illegal gas costs actually paid ... adding new dimensions of complexity to antitrust suits,'' the appeals court said. ``Residential indirect purchaseers of natural gas are not entitled to sue the alleged violators,'' the appeals court said. Kansas and Missouri officials said the ruling conflicts with that of the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, which permitted such suits. The states urged the Supreme Court to resolve the conflict. The 10th Circuit court has jurisdiction over lawsuits in Wyoming, Utah, Colorado, New Mexico, Kansas and Oklahoma. The states that supported the Kansas-Missouri appeal are Alaska, Arkansas, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Florida, Hawaii, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Nebraska, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Jersey, North Carolina, Ohio, Oregon, Pennsylvania, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Virginia, Washington, West Virginia and Wisconsin. The case is Kansas vs. Kansas Power & Light, 88-2109.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Death Row Inmate to Get Hearing
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to hear the appeal of Louisiana death row inmate Robert Sawyer, convicted of a murder in New Orleans 12 years ago. The justices said they will decide whether Sawyer was sentenced fairly. His appeal did not challenge the murder conviction. In his appeal, Sawyer says the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals wrongly refused to apply retroactively to his case Supreme Court decisions barring prosecutors from misleading sentencing juries about their role. Sawyer was convicted of the September 1978 murder of Fran Arwood, who was beaten, scalded with boiling water and set afire after being doused with lighter fluid. The case is Sawyer vs. Smith, 89-5849.

DOC.HEAD: Court Won't Review New Jersey Law on Discount Drugs
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today let stand a ruling that a state may ban pharmacists from selling prescription drugs at a discount. The court, without comment, rejected a challenge to a New Jersey law banning drug discounts and rebates except for medications sold to people over 62. The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled last August that the law, attacked as a form of economic protectionism, has rational purposes and therefore is constitutional. Restricting prescription discounts ``prevents potentially destructive price wars that could erode the integrity of pharmaceutical services,'' the state court said. The state court also ruled that it is reasonable to discourage people from shopping around at different drug stores for the best buy, saying that could undermine the use of so-called drug profiles. The profiles are kept on file by some pharmacists to check for possible allergic reactions or use of incompatible prescription drugs by customers. ``Even if a court cannot ascertain the actual purpose of the statute, it should sustain the statute if it has any conceivable rational purpose,'' the state court said. The law was challenged by Consumer Value Stores (CVS), a chain that in 1985 advertised a special one-week $3 price for most prescription drugs at its stores in Wayne, N.J. Timothy Brophy, a pharmacist at a CVS store in Wayne, was fined $500 by the New Jersey Pharmaceutical Board. The drug store chain said the ban on discounts discriminates against cut-rate pharmacies and hurts economic competition. The chain said the law is designed for ``the economic protection of a limited group in a profession whose lobby in a state legislature is more effective or more powerful than the lobby of others in the profession.'' The law is irrational because customers 62 and older who are more likely to need medication are not afforded the presumed protection of banning discounts, CVS said. ``Consumers are entitled to purchase prescription drugs at a pharmacy of their choice, without undue influence from the state,'' lawyers for the store said. The New Jersey Supreme Court said exempting senior citizens from the ban on discounts is ``a reasonable legislative response to economic pressure on the elderly.'' The case is Consumer Value Stores vs. Board of Pharmacy, 89-801.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Decide Whether Clubs Can Use Food Losses to Offset Profits
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether non-profit social clubs that are generally exempt from federal income taxes can use losses incurred from selling food and drink to non-members to offset investment profits. The court said it will hear an appeal by the Portland Golf Club in Oregon in which at least $4 million in tax revenue nationwide is at stake. The Bush administration urged the justices to use the golf club's appeal to settle a conflict between two federal appeals courts. The golf club is exempt from paying federal income tax on dues and other fees paid by its members. It qualifies for the exemption as a social club ``organized for pleasure, recreation and other non-profitable purposes.'' But the club also receives income from selling food and drink to non-members and in interest from its investments. That income is not exempt from federal taxation. The Internal Revenue Service said the golf club owed $5,298 in taxes for 1980 and 1981. The club said it lost $98,041 those two years from selling food and drink to non-members because its expenses and overhead for that activity exceeded income from the sales. The club sought to use the losses to offset profits from its investments. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in June that the losses are not deductible because the club had not intended the sale of food and drink to non-members to be a profit-making activity. That ruling conflicted with a decision in another case by the 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The Justice Department said the Supreme Court should resolve the conflict. It said there have been several hundred IRS audits over the issue involving about $4 million. The case is Portland Golf Club vs. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, 89-530.

DOC.HEAD: Court Curtails Illinois Law Allowing Store and Theater Shutdowns
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today curtailed an Illinois public nuisance law that has been used to shut down adult bookstores and theaters for up to a year. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that the state law sometimes violates the free-speech rights of bookstore and theater owners. The high court ruled in a New York case in 1986 that states may close down for long periods adult bookstores found to be public nuisances because of the on-premises conduct of their patrons. But the Illinois law in the case acted on today was more sweeping. It permitted closing such stores and theaters if the operators were convicted of selling obscene material. The Illinois law said the establishment could either be closed or could be allowed to remain open if the owners posted a bond that would be forfeited if obscene material was sold on the premises. The case stemmed from an attempted crackdown against the Denmark II bookstore in Kendall County, Ill. The building was leased by Bruce and Cathy Riemenschneider to Sequoia Books Inc. There were numerous obscenity prosecutions against the bookstore from 1982 to 1985, resulting in eight guilty verdicts. But the store remained open for business. Then in 1986, the state sought to declare the bookstore a public nuisance, and a judge ordered it shut down for one year unless Sequoia Books posted a $5,000 bond. The bond was posted, but the judge ruled that obscene magazines then were sold at the store and the bond was revoked. The Illinois Supreme Court ruled last March that the anti-nuisance law was unconstitutional. ``The state argues that the sale of obscene material is the equivalent of the sexual conduct involved'' in the 1986 case decided by the Supreme Court, the state court said. ``We do not agree that the sale of obscene material and actual sexual conduct can be so easily equated.'' The Illinois court said states may not shut down establishments that sell non-obscene material merely because some obscene works have been sold. ``This blunderbuss approach ... is inconsistent with our traditional insistence that the regulation of any form of expression, even of obscenity, be carefully drawn so as not to impact unduly upon protected speech,'' the state court said. The justices had a similar question under study in a Dallas case decided last week. In that case, the court left unanswered whether anyone convicted of certain crimes may be barred from operating a sexually oriented business. Instead, the high court struck down that part of the Dallas ordinance requiring all sexually oriented businesses to acquire special licenses because of inadequate safeguards against licensing delays. The case acted on today is Illinois vs. Sequoia Books, 88-1844.

DOC.HEAD: Maverick Soviet Politician Says Soviet Union at `Turning Point'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to RAISE remarks on Azerbaijan, REORGANIZES throughout; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Boris Yeltsin, the maverick Soviet Communist Party member and parliamentarian, said today that force should not be used to quell ethnic unrest in its southern republics. Speaking of ethnic unrest and economic problems, Yeltsin told Japanese journalists: ``This year is very critical. We are at a turning point _ whether a very ill patient will be able to recover or not.'' Recent ethnic strife has killed more than 56 people in fighting between ethnic Armenians and Azerbaijanis, official reports say. Soviet troops have been deployed to try to stop the fighting, one of the bloodiest conflicts facing the country. Yeltsin said the use of force to suppress local movements for autonomy would only increase the number of republics that wish to secede. He did not say whether he meant force by the army or by the warring ethnic groups. ``These issues should not be resolved through force. We have had enough bloodshed already,'' Yeltsin told reporters at Japan's National Press Club. ``Patience and endurance is necessary. This is the sole possibility I see. There is no other drastic means to settle the situation,'' he told reporters at Japan's National Press Club. Yeltsin also said the Communist Party must be fundamentally reformed, its monopoly on power abolished, and autonomy granted to the nation's republics. Yeltsin repeated his support for President Mikhail Gorbachev's policy of ``perestroika,'' or restructuring. But he said Gorbachev's failure to deal with reform ``in a fundamental way'' had caused a worsening of the situation in the Soviet Union and a drop in Gorbachev's popularity. ``The economy is facing a crisis, and the situation of ethnic groups is at a crucial stage,'' he said. ``The society in general is facing a crisis.'' He said perestroika, following decades of repression, had reawakened ethnic consciousness and allowed citizens to express their opinions freely. But Yeltsin said attempts by Gorbachev to limit the extent of the reforms were like ``trying to extinguish a fire after it starts.'' Yeltsin's remarks, in Russian, were translated into Japanese and then into English. Yeltsin is in Japan on a 10-day speaking tour, which will include a meeting with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Money Laundering, 1st Ld - Writethru, 1st Add, a0546,0441
DOC.HEAD: TAMPA, Fla.: United States.
DOC.TEXT: The plea came as the financial institution was about to go on trial in the first federal prosecution of a major bank on charges of conspiring to aid drug trafficking through secret accounts. One of the defendants, Amjad Awan of Coral Gables, has said he was once Manuel Antonio Noriega's banker, but the Luxembourg bank had filed a motion to keep the fallen Panamanian dictator's name out of the case. The banking company, which operates in 73 countries, was allowed to continue operations in the United States after putting $14 million in escrow to cover the amount the government contended the bank had laundered. In addition to the indictments, the government sued for forfeiture of property and other assets. A defense motion had sought to prohibit prosecutors from mentioning Noriega, which the defense expected because Stephen Michael Kalish is among the drug dealers on the government witness list. Kalish testified for the prosecution in a federal marijuana smuggling trial that ended Monday with acquittals of 16 defendants and convictions of four in Lafayette, La. Kalish, arrested in Tampa in 1984 and serving 15 years without parole, has testified that he secured Panama banking for his marijuana smuggling ring in 1983 by giving Noriega an attache case stuffed with $300,000 in bills. According to the government, Kalish also met with Awan and deposited an initial $2 million from marijuana smuggling into an account with the bank in Panama City. During U.S. Senate testimony before his arrest, Awan said such a deposit was possible but he had no recollection of it. Awan, 41, who was assistant division director of the bank for Latin America in Miami, told Senate investigators he personally managed a secret account Noriega opened at the bank's Panamanian branch in 1982. Awan said Noriega was the only one who could authorize withdrawals from the account, which contained up to $25 million. Awan told the investigators Noriega closed his bank account after the indictments were announced. Awan denied knowledge of any drug dealing by Noriega or the bank. According to the indictment, undercover Customs agents contacted representatives of the bank in 1987 and opened accounts at different branches. Bank officials were to receive drug money and put it in certificates of deposit in one of the branches, agents said. Investigators said bank officials would create a loan at another branch, permit drug traffickers to withdraw the funds, then repay the loan with money in the certificates. The branches used reportedly included locations in France, Panama, Uruguay, the Bahamas, Luxembourg and Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Criminal Charges Considered Following Sacking of Secret Police HQ
