DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with police chief saying protesters broke into anti-espionage section, giving higher damage estimate; picks up 3rd pvs, `In Bonn...' Minor editing thereafter to CONFORM
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors are considering criminal charges against protesters who ransacked the capital's secret police headquarters, national police chief Dieter Winderlich said today. The announcement came hours after East Germany's ruling Communists said the storming of the building Monday showed the country's ``street revolution'' could get out of hand. Winderlich told a news conference that protesters also had broken into the building's section for counter-espionage activities but did not discover the identity of the section's workers. He said the protesters caused hundreds of thousands of dollars in damage to the eight-story building. The building today remained under control of an opposition-led ``citizens' committee,'' regular police officers and government representatives. Also today, workers at a state-owned factory in the city of Gera staged a politically motivated warning strike to show their dissatisfaction with the Communists, according to West Berlin's RIAS radio station. In Bonn, the conservative daily newspaper Die Welt said Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was expected to visit East Berlin in the next two or three weeks. Die Welt, quoting well-informed sources in East Berlin, said Gorbachev plans a ``massive show of support'' for his long-time friend, East German Communist Premier Hans Modrow. Dirk Bachmann, East Berlin's police chief, said opposition groups' calls for restraint had prevented injuries during the storming of the secret police building. The protesters demanded the ouster of the Communists and expressed anger at the government for not moving faster to dismantle the secret police and carry out reforms. Three months after a peaceful popular revolt toppled old hard-line Communist leaders, the party still essentially controls the government, media, economy and bureaucracy. The Communist Party daily newspaper Neues Deutschland said in a commentary that the organizers of protests like that at the secret police headquarters must accept responsibility for the consequences. ``Responsibility also means means having a clear idea about consequences before calling for a demonstration, so that things don't get out of hand,'' the newspaper said in a front-page editorial. It added: ``The call for `no violence,' which has marked the street revolution from the start, becomes a farce when emotions break through the bounds of reason.'' Opposition leaders called for calm and an end to the destruction. A day earlier, New Forum opposition group called for the protests to oppose what it called the ``restoration policy'' of Communists seeking to gain an advantage before the May elections, according to the official news agency ADN. The call was answered by hundreds of thousands of people, including those who stormed the secret police headquarters. Dozens of protesters in the southern city of Cottbus had pelted the local secret police building with rocks, and unsuccessfully tried to enter it. Official news media also reported that about 500,000 people demonstrated against the Communists and secret police in at least a dozen cities on Monday evening. Addressing the crowd at the Berlin secret police headquarters through a loudspeaker system, Modrow asked the protesters ``to stay in a dialogue'' with his shaky coalition government and expressed ``full understanding'' for the rage caused by decades of repression at the hands of the secret police. Hours earlier, Modrow had offered opposition groups a far greater say in running the caretaker government before democratic elections on May 6. The protest actions are reaching further into virtually all parts of society and even all age groups. Increasingly, children and older adults in their 50s and 60s are joining in. East Germany's state-run television interrupted its programs several times to broadcast a warning against further actions like that in East Berlin. ``The democracy that is just now developing is in the gravest danger,'' it warned. Government officials at talks with the opposition Monday morning had outlined a chilling array of rifles, rocket-propelled grenades and machine guns controlled by the secret police. The disclosures, which were broadcast live, included news that the secret police consumed more than 1 percent of the national budget.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Decide If Accused Child Abusers Must Have Confrontation with Accusers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 7-19, In other action, with other cases.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether people accused of child abuse have the right to at least one face-to-face confrontation with their young accusers. The justices, in two cases of enormous importance for child-abuse prosecutions nationwide, said they will consider reinstating the child-molesting conviction of a Maryland day-care center owner and an Idaho woman's child-abuse conviction. Decisions in the two cases are expected by July. They mark the court's second venture into this area of criminal law in the past two years. Stating that the Constitution's Sixth Amendment requires a face-to-face confrontation, the justices in 1988 struck down an Iowa man's sexual-assault conviction because two 13-year-old girls were allowed to testify while protected by a large screen placed in the courtroom between them and the defendant. The Sixth Amendment, in part, says, ``In all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right ... to be confronted with the witnesses against him.'' The 1988 decision appeared to leave unanswered whether there may be exceptions to the face-to-face requirement. In other action, the court: _ Said it will consider limiting the power of environmentalists to prevent the opening up of federal lands to commerical development. The court voted to review a pro-environmentalist ruling challenged by the Bush administration. The case involves a U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruling last June that the National Wildlife Federation may sue the Interior Department over plans to change the status of some 180 million acres of public land in western states and Alaska. _ Agreed to decide what authority police have to stop and question someone on the basis of an anonymous tip that the person is involved in a crime. The justices said they will review an Alabama court ruling that limited such police tactics. _ Refused to kill lawsuits against two Pennsylvania school officials by two former students who say they were sexually assaulted by their high school band instructor. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the officials are not entitled to qualified legal immunity from being sued by the two former students. _ Refused to let a machinists union strike against Eastern Airlines spread to commuter railroads. The court, without comment, left intact rulings barring sympathy strikes against railroads in New York City, Philadelphia and their suburbs. _ Blocked indefinitely the effect of a lower court ruling that could have provided natural gas consumers with tens of millions of dollars in refunds. The justices, granting an emergency request by 21 energy companies, held in abeyance a 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals decision that could have led to the refunds. _ Agreed to consider broadening the power of states to sue in behalf of gas consumers allegedly overcharged by utility companies. The court said it will hear an appeal by Kansas and Missouri officials who have accused utilities of illegal price-fixing. In one of the child abuse cases, Maryland's highest court threw out Sandra A. Craig's conviction, saying her 7-year-old accuser and three other young witnesses wrongly were allowed to testify against her over closed-circuit television. But the state court stopped short of invalidating the Maryland law that allows young children to testify by closed-circuit television, outside the presence of the defendant, in such cases. About half the states have similar laws. The trial judge was constitutionally required to question the children, however briefly, in Mrs. Craig's presence, the state court said. That was the only way, the state court concluded, that the judge could determine whether the children would suffer ``serious emotional distress'' if forced to testify in court with Mrs. Craig present. The judge instead relied on the pretrial testimony of experts in deciding that such courtroom testimony would be traumatic for the children. That violated Mrs. Craig's Sixth Amendment right to confront all adverse witnesses, the state's highest court said. Its ruling cited a 1988 Supreme Court decision. Stating that the Sixth Amendment requires a face-to-face confrontation, the justices last year struck down an Iowa man's sexual-assault conviction because two 13-year-old girls were allowed to testify while protected by a large screen placed in the courtroom between them and the defendant. The 1988 decision appeared to leave unanswered whether there may be exceptions to the face-to-face requirement. In the appeal acted on today, Maryland Attorney General J. Joseph Curran Jr. said the state court ruling in Mrs. Craig's case ``struck an untrue balance between a defendant's constitutional right ... and the compelling governmental interest of safeguarding the physical and psychological well-being of a child.'' The appeal was supported in ``friend-of-the-court'' briefs submitted by 28 states and various children's rights groups. In its ruling last July, the Maryland Court of Appeals said Mrs. Craig is entitled to a new trial on charges that she sexually molested a girl who attended her Howard County day-care center for two years before it was closed in 1986. Mrs. Craig had been sentenced to 10 years in prison for her 1987 conviction on those charges. She also faces trial on charges stemming from the alleged molestation of 12 other children who attended the day-care center in Clarksville, Md. At the 1987 trial, four children were allowed to testify outside the courtroom with only a prosecutor and one of Mrs. Craig's lawyers present. Mrs. Craig and her other lawyer remained in the courtroom, where they could watch the testimony over a closed-circuit television. Mrs. Craig and her lawyer in the courtroom could talk privately with her lawyer in the other room by telephone during the testimony. The four young witnesses were cross-examined by Mrs. Craig's lawyer in the room. In the Idaho case, the issue is whether a defendant's right to confrontation was violated by the testimony of a pediatrician who had examined a 2-year-old girl allegedly abused by her father. Laura Lee Wright and Robert Giles were convicted in Idaho of lewd conduct committed on Mrs. Wright's two daughters, who were then 5 and 2. Mrs. Wright was sentenced to 20 years in prison, but the state Supreme Court threw out her conviction last June 13 and ordered a new trial. The state court ruled that the trial judge wrongly had allowed a pediatrician who had examined the 2-year-old girl to testify about what she told him. The girl did not testify at the trial, and therefore could not be cross-examined by Mrs. Wright's lawyer. The state court said the pediatrician's testimony ``lacks particularized guarantees of trustworthiness and, in fact, is fraught with the dangers of unreliability which the (Sixth Amendment) is designed to highlight and obviate.'' The cases are Maryland vs. Craig, 89-478, and Idaho vs. Wright, 89-260.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Expresses Concern Over Civilian Casualties in Liberia Fighting
DOC.TEXT: The United States expressed concern today over civilian casualties in three weeks of fighting between Liberian soldiers and opponents of President Samuel K. Doe. ``We deplore actions, whether by government troops or insurgents, which lead to such casualties,'' said a statement issued by the U.S. Embassy in Monrovia, the Liberian capital. Sporadic fighting was reported today as government troops continued a search for rebels, who said they have launched another offensive. ``As far as we know, there is still some fighting going on,'' a Western diplomat said in a telephone interview from Monrovia. The U.S. Embassy statement said officials had discussed the fighting ``with governments in the region'' but did not elaborate. It also said officials were encouraging humanitarian groups, including the International Committee of the Red Cross and the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, to help an estimated 20,000 people who have fled the fighting. The government says the rebels, who allegedly came from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24, killed 200 civilians before government troops brought the situation under control. Liberian authorities say 16 government officials were also killed after the rebels attacked the villages of Butuo and Karnplay near the border. But two major human rights groups, Africa Watch of New York and Amnesty International of London, have accused the military of also killing unarmed civilians. Jenkins Scott, Liberia's justice minister, said last week that soldiers killed some civilians but insisted they acted in self-defense. Amnesty International quoted refugees and other sources as saying hundreds of civilian were killed by the rebels and the military. Amnesty International said the fighting has forced 20,000 Liberians to flee to Ivory Coast and Guinea. President Houphouet-Boigny of Ivory Coast said earlier this month that between 8,000 and 10,000 people had entered his country. Charles Taylor, the self-proclaimed leader of the Liberian dissidents, told the British Broadcasting Corp. today his forces had launched a new offensive south of the site of previous fighting. The BBC made no mention of where its correspondent interviewed Taylor, a former Liberian civil servant. Taylor gave no indication of the size of the new offensive. The government says it has captured 11 of an estimated 100 rebels who entered the country in two groups Dec. 24 and is seeking the remainder. Robert Morris, Liberia's assistant information minister, declined to answer questions from The Associated Press. Liberia was founded in 1842 by freed American slaves. President Doe is a former master sergeant in the Liberian army who came to power in a 1980 bloody coup. Last month's invasion was the second attempt to oust Doe in four years.

DOC.HEAD: Court Leaves Intact Award Against California Church
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs lede and 4th graf pvs, Mull, who, to CORRECT that church headquarters now in Montana, sted California.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today left intact a $1.56 million award against a Montana religious group sued by a former member. The court, without comment, rejected arguments that the award violates the organization's religious freedom. Church Universal & Triumphant was sued by Gregory Mull, a 53-year-old San Francisco architect when in 1974 he started taking part in the church's activities. Mull, who died in 1986, moved in 1979 to Calabasas, Calif., site of the church's headquarters at the time, known as Camelot. The church moved its headquarters to Montana in 1986. He said Elizabeth Clare Prophet, the church's spiritual leader with the title Messenger of the Ascended Masters, promised Mull would help design buildings for the group's proposed $33 million ``New Jerusalem'' in Calabasas. According to court documents, the church secretly had abandoned the project without telling Mull. The suit alleged that the church was using his architectural plans to help raise millions of dollars in donations. Mull also accused the church of violating his privacy rights by disclosing details of his sex life given in a ``confession'' to Mrs. Prophet. He also sued the church for inflicting emotional distress, alleging he was pressured into giving up his last $5,500 in savings at a time when he was out of work and supporting his daughter in college. A California appeals court, in upholding the $1.56 million jury award last April, said Mull was subject to ``constant and shameful pressures'' to part with his money, and that he became so destitute he and his daughter took food from grocery store garbage bins. The daughter, Linda Witt, is Mull's heir. The church said the damage award should be overturned because, in part, it was based on prejudicial evidence and ridicule of the church's religious practices by Mull's lawyer. For example, the church said, Mrs. Prophet's husband, Edward Francis, testifed under questioning by Mull's lawyer that he believed he was the reincarnation of Captain Cook. The lawyer then prefaced the next question by saying, ``Let me ask you this one as Mr. Francis instead of Captain Cook.'' The church said the jury also was prejudiced by the testimony of a witness for Mull, who said he once had an adulterous affair with Mrs. Prophet. The church said Mull's suit was based on the claim he had been reduced to ``a slave of the church.'' The resulting damage award ``constitutes an unprecedented threat to the free exercise of religion of minority religious organizations and their members,'' the church said. The justices have rejected two similar appeals recently. In October, they left intact a ruling that an evangelical Christian group must return $5.5 million donated by a department store heiress when she was a member. The court last May refused to shield the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church from being sued by two former California members who said they were brainwashed into joining it. The case acted on today is Church Universal & Triumphant vs. Witt, 89-672.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Communists Call for Extending Austerity
DOC.TEXT: China's Communist Party today called for fiscal austerity until at least 1991, outlined tough measures to lower the boom on non-essential industries, and acknowledged that more workers will lose their jobs. The plan reflects the current conservative leadership's drive to revive state controls over the economy, which were loosened during the previous 10 years of reform and decentralization. It also underscores the desire to give priority to the development of large, state-run industries. The party said some factories, in particular smaller private enterprises, will be closed during the austerity drive. The plan, which also urges controls on consumer demand, was put foward in a lengthy party document on ``economic readjustment.'' The policy paper, carried by the official Xinhua News Agency, does not mention any plans to introduce new market-oriented reforms. Reforms have effectively been put on hold since austerity policies were first adopted in fall 1988 and particularly after the ouster of pro-reform party leader Zhao Ziyang when pro-democracy protests were crushed in June. The 39-point document made public today was prepared for a plenary session of the party Central Committee in November. It has apparently been circulated to party offices. It says the task of restoring order to the economy that began in fall 1988 would take three years or more. The paper also said the nation's spending habits must be sharply curtailed during that time. The party, which under Zhao was moving toward a policy of non-interference in economic affairs, must enhance its leading role in guiding the economy, the document said. It said the nation's economic goals are to bring the inflation rate under 10 percent a year, keep annual growth of the gross national product to 5-6 percent, keep new currency issues down, and balance the budget. The gross national product is the total worth of all goods and services. China achieved some of those goals in 1989, bringing inflation down from a high of more than 30 percent in 1988 to less than 10 percent in the final months of 1989. However, the government's tight credit and suspension of thousands of building projects have led to widespread bankruptcies, plant shutdowns and a growing unemployment problem. In the plan, the party acknowledged that ``some workers will become unemployed.'' China says the urban unemployment rate is approaching 4 percent, up from 2 percent before the austerity drive. The figures do not include millions of rural residents without work because of the slowdown. The government has also fallen further into debt because of decreased revenues and huge subsidies provided faltering state-run factories. Today's report said smaller township enterprises, the backbone of economic progress in rural areas during the past decade, will not be allowed to vie with large industries for raw materials. The plan said private enterprises are a necessary supplement to the socialist economy but must develop ``within the limits of state control.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
International Bank Pleads Guilty in Money Laundering Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES pvs urgent series, UPDATES throughout with details, amount of forfeiture a record. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Luxembourg bank pleaded guilty today in a $32 million global money-laundering case with links to cocaine traffickers and fallen dictator Manuel Noriega, and agreed to forfeit a record $14 million. Under the plea bargain, the two divisions of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International will also receive five years' probation. The plea did not affect charges against six bank officers _ one of whom said he was Noriega's personal banker _ and two Colombians prosecutors say were part of the Medellin cocaine cartel. Their case opened today with pre-trial motions. But under the plea bargain, BCCI agreed to cooperate in prosecuting the remaining defendants. The cash forfeiture of $14 million frozen by the government was the largest ever by a financial institution in the United States, said Dave Runkel, U.S. Justice Department spokesman. BCCI entered the plea as it was about to go on trial in the first federal prosecution of a major bank on charges of conspiring to aid drug trafficking through secret accounts. The more than 30 charges against the two bank entities included tax fraud, failure to report currency transactions over $10,000 and laundering cocaine profits. U.S. District Judge W. Terrell Hodges did not immediately set a sentencing date. He imposed a gag order to prevent parties in the case from talking to the news media, and bank officials and attorneys refused comment on the agreement. During a two-year sting called Operation C-Chase, Customs agents posed as money launderers and penetrated powerful Colombian syndicates, authorities said. According to the indictment, agents contacted BCCI representatives in 1987 and opened accounts at different branches. BCCI officials were to receive drug money and put it in certificates of deposit in the branches, agents said. The branches used reportedly included locations in France, Panama, Uruguay, the Bahamas, Luxembourg and England. Customs agents claimed the money was intended mainly for Colombian drug traffickers. Investigators said bank officials would create a loan at a branch, permit the agents to withdraw the funds, then repay the loan with the CDs. The bank divisions and nine of its officers were indicted in 1988. Noriega is not mentioned in the indictment. Altogether, more than 80 people were accused of participating in drug-related money-laundering in eight U.S. cities _ Detroit, Philadelphia, Chicago, Los Angeles, Houston, Miami, New York and Tampa _ and London and Paris. BCCI, with operations in 73 countries, was allowed to continue doing business after putting $14 million in escrow to cover the amount the government contended the bank had laundered. Among those still facing trial is Amjad Awan of Coral Gables, who claims he was Noriega's banker, managing an account that held up to $25 million. Also charged are Gonzalo Mora Jr., who prosecutors claim operated a money-laundering network based in Medellin, Colombia, to help traffickers, and Rudolph Armbrect, described as Mora's partner. The defense has filed a motion to prohibit prosecutors from bringing Noriega into the case, a move the defense expects because Stephen Michael Kalish is among the drug kingpins on the government witness list. Kalish, arrested in 1984 and serving 15 years, has testified that he secured safe Panama banking for his marijuana smuggling ring in 1983 by giving Noriega an attache case stuffed with $300,000 in bills. According to the government, Kalish also met with Awan and deposited an initial $2 million in marijuana cash into a BCCI account in Panama City. During U.S. Senate testimony before his arrest, Awan said such a deposit was possible but he had no recollection of it. Awan, 41, who was assistant division director of BBCI for Latin America in Miami, told Senate investigators he managed a secret account Noriega opened at the bank's Panamanian branch in 1982. Awan said Noriega was the only one who could authorize withdrawals from the account. Awan told investigators Noriega closed his account when the indictments were announced. Awan denied knowledge of any drug dealing by Noriega or the bank. The other defendants in the case are Syed Aftab Hussain, operations officer of the Panamanian branch; Akbar A. Bilgrami of Miami, director of the Latin American division; Sibte Hassan, an officer with the Paris branch; Ian Howard, a French manager based in Paris, and Iqbal Ashraf of Lawndale, Calif., manager of the Los Angeles branch of BCCI.

Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Tuesday by the Supreme Court.
CHILD ABUSE
The court agreed to decide whether people accused of child abuse have the right to at least one face-to-face confrontation with their young accusers. The justices, in two cases of enormous importance for child-abuse prosecutions nationwide, said they will consider reinstating the child-molesting conviction of a Maryland day-care center owner and an Idaho woman's child-abuse conviction. The cases are Maryland vs. Craig, 89-478, and Idaho vs. Wright, 89-260.
FEDERAL LANDS
The court said it will consider limiting the power of environmentalists to prevent the opening up of federal lands to commerical development. The court voted to review a pro-environmentalist ruling challenged by the Bush administration. The case involves a U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruling last June that the National Wildlife Federation may sue the Interior Department over plans to change the status of some 180 million acres of public land in western states and Alaska. The case is Lujan vs. National Wildlife Federation, 89-640.
POLICE TIPS
The court agreed to decide what authority police have to stop and question someone on the basis of an anonymous tip that the person is involved in a crime. The justices said they will review an Alabama court ruling that limited such police tactics. The case is Alabama vs. White, 89-789.
SEX ASSAULTS
The court refused to kill lawsuits against two Pennsylvania school officials by two former students who say they were sexually assaulted by their high school band instructor. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the officials are not entitled to qualified legal immunity from being sued by the two former students. The cases are Smith vs. Stoneking, 89-780, and Smith vs. Sowers, 89-782.
EASTERN STRIKE
The court refused to let a machinists union strike against Eastern Airlines spread to commuter railroads. The justices, without comment, left intact rulings barring sympathy strikes against railroads in New York City, Philadelphia and their suburbs. The cases are International Association of Machinists vs. Long Island Railroad, 89-427 and 89-674, and Brotherhood of Railroad Signalmen vs. SEPTA, 89-756.
GAS PRICES
The court blocked indefinitely the effect of a lower court ruling that could have provided natural gas consumers with tens of millions of dollars in refunds. The justices, granting an emergency request by 21 energy companies, held in abeyance a 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals decision that could have led to the refunds. The case is Mobil Oil Exploration vs. United Distribution Companies, A-503.
GAS CONSUMERS
The court agreed to consider broadening the power of states to sue in behalf of gas consumers allegedly overcharged by utility companies. The court said it will hear an appeal by Kansas and Missouri officials who have accused utilities of illegal price-fixing. The case is Kansas vs. Kansas Power & Light, 88-2109.
TWA
The court turned away an appeal by Trans World Airlines flight attendants, who accused TWA owner Carl Icahn of sex bias in seeking wage cuts and other concessions that triggered a strike. The court, without comment, refused to revive a lawsuit against the airline. The flight attendants sought back pay and other benefits. The case is Independent Federation of Flight Attendants vs. TWA, 89-783.
CHURCH UNIVERSAL
The court left intact a $1.56 million award against a Montana religious group sued by a former member. The court, without comment, rejected arguments that the award violates the religious freedom of the Church Universal & Triumphant. The case is Church Universal & Triumphant vs. Witt, 89-672.
CABLE TELEVISION
The Court left intact a ruling that cities may fine cable television companies for failing to broadcast enough locally originated programs. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by three affiliated Chicago cable TV firms that said their free-speech rights were violated when they were fined $60,750. The case is Chicago Cable Communications vs. Chicago Cable Commission, 89-747.
DRUGGISTS
The court let stand a ruling that a state may ban pharmacists from selling prescription drugs at a discount. The court, without comment, rejected a challenge to a New Jersey law banning drug discounts and rebates except for medication sold to people over 62. The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled last August that the law, attacked as a form of economic protectionism, has rational purposes and therefore is constitutional. The case is Consumer Value Stores vs. Board of Pharmacy, 89-801.

DOC.HEAD: Letter Bombs Found, Scotland Yard Issues Alert
DOC.TEXT: Authorities intercepted two letter bombs at an army office today, and Scotland Yard warned the public to be on the alert for suspicious packages. Police said the bombs, in brown padded envelopes, were found and defused at the army South East District Headquarters in Aldershot, 40 miles southwest of London. The offices were evacuated, police said. The British domestic news agency, Press Association, quoted army sources as saying the bombs were sent to individual officers, who were not identified. ``The public must be vigilant when opening mail,'' said Cmdr. George Churchill-Coleman, head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch. ``If at all suspicious they must be urged to contact police immediately and leave the parcel alone.'' Churchill-Coleman said military personnel and public officials connected with Northern Ireland affairs should be particularly alert. Two months ago police defused a bomb under a car in west London that was apparently intended for a British army general. Churchill-Coleman at the time would not specifically say the car bomb was the work of the Irish Republican Army but that the group had been carrying out a bombing campaign on the British mainland and ``this appears to be that kind of device.'' Sinn Fein, the IRA's legal political wing, said at the time it knew nothing about the car bomb. The IRA is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland. It wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the overwhelmingly Catholic Republic of Ireland, under socialist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Breaks Out on Tanker in Red Sea; 3 Feared Dead
DOC.TEXT: Fire broke out aboard a small Saudi Arabian tanker in the Red Sea, and three Filipinos among the 34-member crew were lost and feared dead, sources at the owner's company said Tuesday. The rest of the crew of the 21,032-ton Raad Al-Bakri VIII tanker was rescued by vessels responding to a distress signal in the Monday incident, said the sources at the Jiddah-based Bakri Navigation Co., who spoke on condition they not be identified. Many of the crew were picked up from life rafts and taken to Port Sudan. The fire broke out in one of the tanks and quickly spread to the steering room and crew cabin. It was brought under control and the tanker, which was empty, was anchored near Port Sudan.

DOC.HEAD: Argentine Tourist Bus Crash in Brazil, 18 Killed
DOC.TEXT: An Argentine tourist bus flipped over and crashed on a highway in southern Brazil early Tuesday, killing 18 passengers, police said. Another 15 passengers were taken to hospitals in the southern city of Porto Alegre, about 965 miles southwest of Rio de Janeiro, said highway patrolman Decio Schirner. The bus, of Argentina's Ticsa lines, rolled over and wedged in a narrow gap between two bridges on either side of the highway about 36 miles northeast of Porto Alegre, Schirner said. Preliminary reports indicated there were 35 people aboard, all Argentines, he said.

DOC.HEAD: 8 Toddlers Scalded to Death in Soviet Orphanage
DOC.TEXT: Eight toddlers were scalded to death when steam exploded from a broken heating system in their orphanage during a cold spell in the Volga River city of Ulyanovsk, Tass reported Tuesday. The children, ranging in age from 1 to 3 years, died Saturday night after temperatures fell to minus 26 degrees Fahrenheit and part of the city heating system broke down, the official news agency said. The district breakdown coincided with a malfunction of the orphanage's radiator, Tass said, and the pressurized hot steam that spewed from the radiator killed the sleeping children. Ulyanovsk, like much of the Soviet Union, has been undergoing a brutal cold spell in the last three days. On Tuesday, 17 housing complexes in Ulyanovsk, a city of about 460,000 people, were still without heat because of the breakdown, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Delegation to Invite John Paul II to Visit Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: A government delegation headed by Vice Premier Josef Hromadka will travel to the Vatican on Thursday to invite Pope John Paul II to Czechoslovakia, a newspaper reported. Hromadka, who is in charge of religious affairs in the new government, will be accompanied by Archbishops Frantisek Vanak and Josef Sokol, the daily newspaper Lidova Demokracie reported Tuesday. Quoting churches sources in Rome, the newspaper reported Friday that a two-day papal visit to the predominantly Roman Catholic country might take place in June.

DOC.BYLINE: Koran Comic Book Continues to Draw Fire ^By MARILYN AUGUST
DOC.TEXT: The publication of the Koran in comic-book form drew more fire from Islamic groups as the leading religious body of Tunisia called for it to be banned as an ``impious work.'' In a statement made public in Tunis on Monday, the Higher Islamic Council said the comic book ``If the Koran Were Told to Me,'' which has been published in France, has ``brought prejudice against the sanctity of the Koran and Moslems.'' ``The illustration of the teachings of the holy Koran by profane images constitutes sacrilege and heresy,'' the statement said. The Koran is the sacred book of Islam. According to Moslems, it contains the words of God as revealed to the prophet Mohammed. The comic books are the work of Youssef Seddik, a Tunisian-born academic who has lived in Paris since 1983. He was in Tunis and not immediately available for comment, according to his wife, Saida. Seddik, 46, said in an interview earlier this month that his goal was simply to make the Koran more accessible to young people, and not to violate the sacredness of Islam. The Tunisian religious body condemned Seddik for not having consulted experts in Islamic jurisprudence before publishing the comic books and appealed to Islamic groups and the publishing world to ``act efficiently so as to prevent the repetition of such acts and thus preserve the inviolability of the sacredness of Islam.'' The series of comic books was criticized last week by Mohammed Faidallah, head of Islamic Jurisprudence at Kuwait University, as ridiculing the sanctity of the Holy Koran. He was quoted as calling Seddik ``a new Salman Rushdie,'' the Indian-born British novelist condemned to death last year by the late Ayotollah Ruhollah Khomeini for ``The Satanic Verses.'' Rushdie has been in hiding ever since. ``My husband was completely astounded by the fact that people are comparing him to Rushdie,'' Mrs. Seddik said Tuesday. ``He expected some people not to like it, but he never dreamed he would be accused of blasphemy.'' The comic book illustrations are accompanied by exact quotations from the Koran, complete with chapter and verse references.

DOC.HEAD: Sets Talks With Egyptian, Israeli Ministers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 5 grafs new to update with Egyptians' arrival; picks up at pvs 4th graf, Whether the
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III, renewing his attempt to open Mideast peace talks, was meeting today with Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid to try to settle a dispute over the Palestine Liberation Organization. The squabble is delaying the start of negotiations and could block implementation of an Israeli plan for elections on the West Bank and in Gaza. Baker also plans to meet on Thursday with Israeli Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin. Abdel-Meguid, accompanied by Osama el-Baz, a key adviser to President Hosni Mubarak, arrived in Washington this morning and was expected to remain in the capital for several days. Rabin was due here after midnight from Los Angeles and will see Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Wednesday and Baker and Brent Scowcroft, the national security assistant to President Bush, on Thursday. Whether the PLO should play a role in negotiations _ if they ever get started _ is the main stumbling block as Baker tries to launch step-by-step negotiations leading up to elections on the Israeli-held West Bank and in Gaza. Baker has conducted most of his diplomacy by telephone to Cairo and Jerusalem. It has left him frustrated and warning the parties that problems in other parts of the world were demanding his attention. Egypt, the only Arab nation to sign a peace treaty with Israel, is serving as a channel to Yasser Arafat's PLO. In that mode, Egypt accepted with reservations last month an invitation from Baker to a three-way meeting here with Israel. The reservations sought some PLO control over Palestinian participation further down the road. Israel, meanwhile, accepted the invitation with the condition that the PLO, which is sworn to Israel's dismantling as a Jewish state, be excluded from even an off-stage role. The clash over the PLO has delayed setting a date for Baker's three-way meeting with Abdel-Meguid and Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens. ``There are many other areas in the world clamoring for his attention, areas where the circumstances are producing change,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said last week. ``We hope to see the same kind of impulse that will produce change in the Middle East and we're prepared to do all we can to promote it.'' She added: ``We have continued to try to make progress and lay the basis for a trilateral meeting ... If this effort does fail it certainly won't be due to a lack of effort or will on the part of this President (Bush) or this secretary of state.'' There is no indication, however, that the administration will try to exert pressure on Israel by threatening to reduce U.S. aid. Still, Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole today suggested reducing aid to Israel, Egypt, the Philippines, Turkey and Pakistan by 5 percent and diverting the money to countries such as Poland, Hungary and Panama. ``To me, it boils down to this: Are big gains for freedom worth a small cut in a few huge foreign aid programs? I say yes,'' Dole wrote in a column in The New York Times. The unexpected trip by Abdel-Meguid and el-Baz follows two visits to Cairo in a week by Arafat. An Egyptian Foreign Ministry spokesman said Monday that the two officials ``are going to try and push forward Middle East peace efforts'' with Baker. Abdel-Meguid also will hold talks with officials of the International Monetary Fund, seeking easier terms for Egypt, a poor country with a booming population. The PLO insists that it must ``name and be seen to name'' the Palestinian delegation to future talks with Israel, and that the agenda be open. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is trying to confine the negotiations to the elections he has proposed for the 1.4 million Palestinian Arabs who live on the West Bank and in Gaza. The elections are designed to produce a five-year experiment in limited self-rule, which would be followed by broader negotiations. The PLO, which seeks to take over the West Bank and Gaza and to establish a state carved out of Israeli territory, has denounced Shamir's plan _ which has Baker's backing _ as a ploy.

DOC.HEAD: Romanians Demand Visas Despite New Freedom
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 Romanians demonstrated outside the U.S. Embassy to demand immigration visas. ``Our families have been ruined, our future ruined, because of our politics,'' said Cristin Popescu, a spokesman for the group, which staged the protest Monday. Popescu, a 31-year-old father of five, said the demonstrators were still demanding to go to the United States as political refugees, despite the overthrow of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, because it was their desire to leave Romania that often brought on their troubles. Virginia Young, the embassy's consul-general, agreed the protestors had been ``caught in the middle'' since they suffered for trying to leave Romania before the revolution, but for one reason or another were not eligible under U.S. immigration rules. ``They lost jobs or schooling for their children because they asked for passports from the Romanian government or had relatives in the United States,'' Mrs. Young said. Under Ceausescu's regime, few Romanians were allowed to leave, even temporarily, and it was illegal to talk to foreigners without permission. Mrs. Young said the embassy has been in contact with about 200 families for up to two years who wanted to move to the United States but were not eligible. The marchers, whose backs bore signs saying ``American visa,'' marched around the embassy in silence. Popescu, the spokesman for the protesters, said that despite Ceausescu's overthrow and the promise of free elections, they still feared for their future. ``We don't have trust. A re-evaluation needs a long time. The Communists have deep roots here,'' said Popescu. He added that protesters also remained worried about the secret police. ``We know security people who've not yet been dismissed,'' he said. Popescu said the protesters were delighted that Ambassador Alan Green Jr. agreed to meet with them, but they still planned to demonstrate outside the embassy each week. Mrs. Young said Green had agreed to pass along the group's concerns to Washington but could make no promises. ``They are a group that we have concerns about,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Town Strikes in Protest of Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of angry Israelis, shouting ``bread and work,'' blocked roads and clashed with mounted police in northern Israel on Tuesday after a pipe factory owned by the ailing Koor conglomerate was closed. Burning tires and a bulldozer blocked the road outside Hatzor Haglilit, a town of 7,000 people eight miles north of the Sea of Galilee. The protest followed the firing of 150 workers from the Habonim Pipe factory, which is jointly owned by Kibbutz Kfar Hanassi and Koor. Koor, an industrial conglomerate which employs 22,000 workers and is owned by the Histadrut trade union federation, is threatened with liquidation and is selling off assets, including some of its 100 subsidiary companies. Koor owes $950 million to creditors abroad and is considering two buyout bids, one by the U.S.-based Shamrock Corp. and the other from Canadian financier Mark Belzberg. The conglomerate's chairman, Arnon Gafny, resigned Monday in a dispute over how to save Koor from liquidation, and the board decided to stop all debt payments to Israeli banks until next week. Koor spokesman Amnon Bar-Noy said the board acted as it did because of a shortage of cash and the hope that a comprehensive bail-out agreement with the government and the banks would be reached by next week. He said Koor, which at its height had 31,000 workers and 150 companies, planned to either sell the pipe factory or close it for good. The demonstrators clashed with a column of police, reinforced with mounted officers and a special anti-riot unit. Police moved in when protesters blocked the highway and arrested four. Criminal charges also were filed against a junior high school principle for allowing pupils to attend the demonstraiton, said Police Assistant Inspector Yaacov Ganot. The head of the town council, Yossi Elul, told Israel radio the demonstrations would continue until the jobs are returned. ``We burned tires. We closed the main road. We traded punches, but after all we are closing our own home,'' he said. Hatzor is a development town, a community created around small industry in the 1950s and settled by Jews from Arab countries. Many such towns are suffering high unemployment as the industries fail. Shlomo Buchbut, deputy chairman of the Development Town Forum, was quoted on Israel radio as saying the government must help Koor industries recover because its collapse would mean social unrest ``every week in a different development town.''

DOC.HEAD: Former USGS Chief Geologist Charles Anderson Dies at 87
DOC.TEXT: Charles Anderson, a former chief geologist of the United States Geological Survey, has died at the age of 87 following a 10-year battle with Alzheimer's disease. Anderson died Jan. 9 in Pomona. Anderson taught at the University of California at Berkeley from 1928 to 1942, when he joined the USGS. He specialized in the fields of ore deposits, volcanic rocks and pre-Cambrian geology. In 1952, he was named chief of the USGS mineral deposits branch in Washington, and served as chief geologist and head of the division from 1959 to '64. He then worked in the Menlo Park, Calif., offices until 1972. Anderson is survived by his wife, Helen, three grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. No funeral service was planned.

DOC.HEAD: North Dakota Woman Dies at 109
DOC.TEXT: Anna Strand, believed to be the oldest North Dakotan, has died at the age of 109. Strand, who had lived in a nursing home for the past 10 years, died Jan. 10. A memorial service was held Monday. ``A neighbor asked her once what her secret to long life was,'' recalled Strand's son, Melvin. ``She said, `If I told you, it wouldn't be a secret.''' Strand was born in Numedal, Norway, in 1880. She moved to North Dakota in 1907 and homesteaded near Ambrose the following year. S.F. Hoffner, executive director of the state Centennial Commission, said commission records showed Strand was the state's oldest citizen. Survivors include a sister, Gina Carlson, of Crosby, whose 98th birthday was Monday, two sons and a daughter.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors: Drug Figure Claims Parenthood to Avoid Seizure of Property
DOC.TEXT: An illegitimate child is at the center of a legal tangle preventing the state from auctioning more than $500,000 in logging equipment confiscated from a drug trafficker. Robert ``Slim'' Hamilton, 52, head of a narcotics ring broken up last year, signed a court agreement a year ago, before he was sentenced to 50 years in prison, to provide $420,000 for support of the child he says is his. But prosecutors say Hamilton signed the agreement to avoid having his property seized under a 1983 law that allows authorities to confiscate assets used in drug operations or bought with drug profits. The district attorney's office is challenging the agreement in court. The assets include bulldozers, flatbed trailers, pickup trucks, a tool truck, three other large trucks and log-loading equipment. Between Hamilton's indictment and conviction, a woman claimed in court that he was the father of her child and asked for child support. Hamilton agreed he was the father and consented to provide $420,000 in past, present and future support. The district's attorney office is asking that a judge declare the agreement invalid because it was done to protect his assets. No hearing date is set on that motion.

DOC.HEAD: Petition to Reactivate Court Order on Union Carbide Compensation
DOC.TEXT: An activist group asked a court Tuesday to implement a 1988 judgment ordering Union Carbide Corp. to pay $147 million as interim compensation to victims of the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster. A petition filed in Bhopal District Court by the Poisonous Gas Episode Struggle Front demanded implementation of an April 4, 1988, order issued by the Madhya Pradesh State High Court at Jabalpur. That case had originated in the District Court at Bhopal, the capital of Madhya Pradesh, and the site of a massive gas leak on Dec. 3, 1984, from a pesticide plant run by Union Carbide's Indian subsidiary. At least 3,598 people were fatally injured and 20,000 others suffered ill effects from the methyl isocynate gas that spewed from the factory yards away from shantytowns housing tens of thousands of people. Vibhuti Jha, the front's lawyer, said the petition sought the implementation of the High Court order for $147 million in interim relief. Jha said the relief order was now worth about $198 million because of accrued interest. The Bhopal District Court took no immediate action on the petition. It was not clear if the petition was vaild because all previous and prospective damages suits were anulled by a settlement approved by the Indian Supreme Court on Feb. 14, 1989. Union Carbide had deposited the settlement amount with the Supreme Court in compensation for the disaster, but the money has not been distributed because of various challenges. The settlement had been concluded by Union Carbide and the former government of Rajiv Gandhi. Last week, the new government of Prime Minister V.P. Singh said it backed victims' claims that the compensation amount was too small. Gas victims and activists charged that Gandhi government had no right to declare itself the sole representative of all claims and that the settlement itself was unfair. On Dec. 22, the Supreme Court ruled that the government did have the right to be the claimants' sole representative. The claim that the settlement was unfair is still pending before the Supreme Court in New Delhi. Union Carbide said Monday the settlement remains binding even though the new Indian government has disavowed it. ``There is simply no basis for overturning it,'' Joseph E. Geoghan, Union Carbide vice president and general counsel, said at the company's headquarters in Danbury, Conn. At least 500,000 people have asked for compensation, according to Madhya Pradesh state officials processing the claims.

DOC.HEAD: Cruising May Be Banned in City Where Movie Based
DOC.TEXT: Too much cruising along the Modesto strip that inspired George Lucas to film ``American Graffiti'' has led city officials to propose banning it. City officials have drafted ordinances that would prevent anyone from driving by certain checkpoints along McHenry Avenue more than once in four hours. Another ordinance would make it illegal to loiter at night along streets in this city 90 miles southeast of San Francisco. The ordinances, which have not yet come before the City Council, were spurred by Police Chief Gerald McKenzie saying up to 5,000 cars cruise McHenry some evenings. ``The threat of civil unrest is very real and demands our attention and best efforts to avert a disaster,'' McKenzie wrote the city manager. Lucas, who grew up in Modesto, based ``American Graffiti'' on a fictional night in 1962 of cruising 10th Street and McHenry Avenue. Lucas is famous for the ``Star Wars'' trilogy. The popularity of the 1973 movie has led to thousands of youngsters descending on McHenry the first Saturday evening after high school is out in June to celebrate ``Graffiti Night.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Senator Revisits Home His Family Fled in 1933
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Rudy Boschwitz clambered up the creaking stairs he last walked down as a toddler when his family fled the Nazis 56 years ago. Revisiting the Berlin house in which his parents lived until he was nearly 3, Boschwitz recalled the day of Jan. 30, 1933. ``The same day, my father came home and told my mother we would leave,'' the Minnesota Republican said Tuesday. ``And we went within six months.'' Boschwitz said the trigger for returning to his birthplace was the opening of the Berlin Wall. ``I've never been back,'' he said. ``With the reunification, for many practical purposes, of the city and maybe because I'm getting a little older, I had a yen to take a look at my roots.'' He and his parents, both Polish-born Jews, fled Berlin for Czechoslovakia in the summer of 1933 and ended up in New York, where Boschwitz spent the first three decades of his life. While Boschwitz, 59, tried to piece together memories from his Berlin days, the past was vivid for Frank Schiff, a childhood friend who lived in the same house and whom Boschwitz met again by chance years later. ``It looks very familiar,'' Schiff said, once inside the 1915-vintage art deco apartment building. The house, on busy Hohenzollerndamm avenue, is in what is now a West Berlin residential area that emerged relatively unscathed from fierce fighting at the end of World War II. ``It was very pleasant here before the Hitler period,'' said Schiff, a 68-year-old retired economist from Alexandria, Va. A German Jew, he too was uprooted and fled with his family to the United States in 1936. Boschwitz returned on a rainy day to a city that was extensively rebuilt after the war. ``It's a nice place,'' was his first impression. West German businessman Eberhard Naundorf and his wife, Christine, said they were glad to welcome Boschwitz back into the apartment they now rent. ``The war has created so many people who try to find their roots,'' said Mrs. Naundorf, herself of Polish-German descent. On a four-day trip to Germany, Boschwitz visited the Berlin Wall after arriving Monday. He chipped out a few pieces. East Germany opened the wall along with its other western borders on Nov. 9, under massive pressure from street demonstrators and an exodus of tens of thousands of its citizens. In a sign of the changing times, Boschwitz was due to meet East German Foreign Minister Oskar Fischer and opposition groups, and tour East Berlin. He also will meet with Minnesota soldiers stationed in West Berlin.

DOC.HEAD: Florio Sworn in as New Jersey Governor
DOC.TEXT: Democrat James Florio was sworn in as New Jersey's 49th governor today and called for a special session of the Legislature to bring down some of the highest auto insurance rates in the nation. The eight-term congressman from southern New Jersey took the oath of office just after noon after resigning his House seat. Florio succeeded the enormously popular Thomas Kean on a day of prayers, parades and platitudes and inherited deep problems that stand to make his first year in office a trying one. Kean, a Republican, was barred from seeking a third straight term. ``Let me tell you now that my goal is a simple one: When I leave here, I want to be remembered as the governor who brought new ideas to preserve old ideals,'' Florio said. Backing up a campaign pledge to attack auto insurance rates averaging about $1,000 per car, Florio in his inaugural address called for a special session of the Legislature on Monday but gave no hint as to how he would bring down premiums. ``We will bring back fairness to a system that has abused the drivers of New Jersey for too long,'' Florio declared. He also avoided other problems confronting his administration, such as a mounting revenue shortfall and burdensome property taxes. Florio was elected in November, scoring a wide margin of victory over Rep. James Courter, R-N.J. It was Florio's third try at the state's highest office. In 1981, he lost to Kean by the smallest margin ever in a New Jersey gubernatorial election. A special election must be held to replace Florio in Congress. No date has been set.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Reached Over Home for Retarded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last three grafs, bgng, `Chicago Heights ...' with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Justice Department comment.
DOC.TEXT: A judge in a landmark housing discrimination case approved a settlement today that will allow construction of a group home for retarded people in suburban Chicago Heights. U.S. District Judge William T. Hart approved a consent agreement requiring the suburb to issue a previously denied permit for construction of the home by Residential Facilities Management Services Inc. of Galesburg. The city, while not admitting to any discrimination, also agreed to pay $45,000 in damages _ $30,000 to RFMS for construction delays and $1,000 to each of the 15 people who will eventually live in the home. The agreement settles lawsuits filed last summer by RFMS and the U.S. Justice Department under a Fair Housing Act amendment, passed in March, barring discrimination against the handicapped. At issue was a May 1 vote by Chicago Heights City Council denying the permit for the home. The lawsuits contended the City Council was motivated by opposition from residents fearful of and prejudiced against the retarded. The Justice Department lawsuit was the first case brought by the government under the Fair Housing amendment. ``Our hope is that this (agreement) will be noted by other communities, not only in the Chicago metropolitan area of Illinois, but nationwide _ that it's impermissible for them to deny access to living accomodations on behalf of developmentally disabled persons,'' said Richard E. Friedman, attorney for RFMS. The company operates 55 group homes in 35 other Illinois communities. Justice Department spokeswoman Deborah Burstion-Wade said the settlement may make it easier for the government to obtain court orders in future cases involving the refusal of local governments to grant permits for group homes. Department lawyers were considering legal action elsewhere as well but chose to await the results of the Chicago Heights case, she said. The settlement should also encourage cities to comply with federal law, she said. Chicago Heights maintained the permit was denied because RFMS had not supplied necessary documents with its application. ``The fact that the inhabitants happened to be developmentally disabled was not a factor,'' said the suburb's attorney, Nick J. Di Giovanni. Under the agreement, the company pledged that the home will not be used to care for mentally ill or emotionally disturbed patients. ``We hope other communities will get the message that the handicapped have rights under the Fair Housing Act,'' said James P. Turner, acting head of the Justice Department's civil rights division. ``If local officials don't pay attention to those rights, they will pay damages for violating them.'' Turner credited Chicago Heights officials with ``seeing that it was not in the city's best interests to continue fighting this lawsuit.''

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Bush Says Women Should Be Allowed to Serve in Combat if Strong Enough
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush said today she thinks women should be allowed to serve in combat if they are physically strong enough because ``certainly emotionally and mentally they are more than able to compete with a man.'' Mrs. Bush answered with a ``qualified yes'' when asked in an interview whether women should serve in combat. ``If I thought a woman physically could pick up someone who was wounded and carry them to safety, if I thought they could throw a hand grenade as far as a man, then I would say fine. Because I think certainly emotionally and mentally they are more than able to compete with a man.'' ``They can shoot as well. They can fly as well. The only problem I would have is if it risks somebody else's life because they couldn't throw a hand grenade as far or carry (someone), that would be the only thing.'' President Bush has said he would be willing to listen to recommendations from the Pentagon about the possibility of women serving in combat, but that the women who fought in Panama were not in combat roles. In the U.S. Panama invasion, women were not assigned to combat units, but some found themselves under fire in performing support duties. The first lady also said she helped Bush keep the invasion of Panama secret. She said she was told about it the day of the invasion, before it happened, but ``I knew something was going on'' a few days ahead because of all the presidential advisers who were coming and going from the White House. When deposed Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega finally surrendeered to U.S. forces, after several tense days in the Vatican embassy in Panama City, Mrs. Bush said the president ``came racing through and said, `We got him'.'' ``I'd say he was pleased, pleased that it was over without more bloodshed,'' she said. She said she has been ``a little testy'' about all the letters she receives from people who don't think it's safe for the president to attend the upcoming drug summit in violence-torn Colombia. She said she would prefer that the summit be elsewhere _ ``I wish it would be right here'' _ but ``I can't change his mind or make those decisions ... I have no input on that.'' Asked about her health, Mrs. Bush said she was ``cautiously optimistic'' that her recent series of radiation treatments would cure the irritated eyes and double vision she suffers as a result of Graves disease, an immune system disorder. She said she still is having trouble, but that ``I'm so eager to be better that I think I'm better.''

DOC.HEAD: Parents To Serve Detentions for Children's Truancy
DOC.TEXT: Three parents who let their daughters skip school for a rock concert have volunteered to serve detention time in the principal's office in place of their children. ``I'm 33 years old and I'm taking my first detention ever,'' Chris Thompson said. ``Everyone I've told this to thinks it's the funniest thing they ever heard.'' Mrs. Thompson, her husband, Paul, and a neighbor, Colleen Lupiezowiec, said they will serve their daughters' detention time Wednesday when the students are off from school because of an administrative day. They said they allowed their daughters, junior high school students, to take a day off so they could attend a concert in Milwaukee by New Kids on the Block. The concert was not scheduled to begin until 7 p.m., but Ms. Lupiezowiec said she and the children left in the early afternoon because she had business to conduct in Milwaukee, about 70 east. Mrs. Thompson says her daughter, Melissa, was home sick in the morning but went to the concert anyway. ``I think she would have left if she had the plague, she was that excited about it,'' she said. Michael Buehler, superintendent of Cambridge schools, said the pupils would have been excused if they and their parents had told the school the truth. Instead, the daughters were given detentions, but school officials agreed to let the parents serve the time. ``The parents came up with a novel idea that shows accountability and being a good role model means owning up when you do something wrong or don't use the best of judgment,'' Buehler said. Ms. Lupiezowiec said she will sit in Principal Lowell Holtz's office for 7 hours _ 3{ hours for each for her two daughters.

DOC.HEAD: Opening in Berlin Wall Yields Louisville Man's Lost Dog Tag
DOC.TEXT: Carroll Witten has gotten a memento of his days as a World War II prisoner of war from an East German family _ thanks to the historic opening of the Berlin Wall. In 1945, a year after his B-17 bomber was shot down over Germany, Witten and about 40 other POWs were being marched from Poland to a POW camp at Bad Muskau, near the German-Polish border. During an overnight stop at a barn, Witten lost his brass POW identification tag. He had all but forgotten the tag until he got a call from Berlin last month. On the Sunday after the Berlin Wall was opened on Nov. 9, an East German family visiting West Berlin for the first time approached U.S. Army Capt. James Allen and gave him a tarnished brass tag. The tag bore only a four-digit POW number and the words ``Oflag Luft 3,'' a designation for a prison camp for air officers. Allen said the family told him they had found the tag in the rubble of their old barn, which had burned in 1988. Using Red Cross archives, Allen traced the number to Witten, now 65. Witten said Allen telephoned him in early December from Berlin and that, when asked, he could clearly remember his prisoner number. ``I said, `Sure, I couldn't forget it ... 4854,''' Witten said. ``He said, `You're the guy.''' Just before Christmas, Allen routed himself through Louisville on a flight from West Germany and gave Witten the long-lost tag. ``It was a funny feeling when I held this tag in my hand again,'' Witten reflected. ``Unbelievable.'' Witten said Allen has promised to get the exact address of the family who found the tag so he can get in touch with them. ``I want to write them, and I'd like to go back to Germany, maybe in a year, and see them,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Questions Raised Over Killing of 3 Robbery Suspects in Belfast
DOC.TEXT: Two plainclothes British soldiers who foiled a weekend robbery in Belfast left behind three bodies and a tangle of questions: Did they give a warning? Why were they there? To what unit did they belong? Most crucially, witnesses claimed the soldiers kept firing after the masked robbers lay wounded on the sidewalk. And once again, the British government was denying that its forces in Northern Ireland have orders to shoot to kill. ``I find it hard to believe that reasonable force was used,'' the Rev. Paddy McWilliams said Tuesday at the funeral one of the victims. ``There is no shoot-to-kill policy for the security forces in Northern Ireland,'' said Brian Mawhinney, a high-ranking British official in the province. ``The only people who are conducting a shoot-to-kill policy in the province are terrorists.'' Such allegations go back to 1982 when six people were killed in three separate police operations over a three-week period. All were unarmed, although five were acknowledged to be guerrillas. In 1987, three Irish Republican Army members were gunned down in Gibraltar while plotting a car bombing. Both incidents were followed by charges of cover-ups. The human rights group Amnesty International told the British government last year that official secrecy and lack of prosecutions ``would contribute to allegations of official involvement in deliberate, planned killings.'' In the incident Saturday, witnesses and police agreed that two of the slain robbers appeared to be armed and wore black ski masks also used by IRA gunmen. Their guns proved to be non-working replicas of a Mauser submachinegun and a Bruni handgun. The third victim, who was shot as he sat in a stolen getaway car, was not masked or armed. Authorities have not identified the two soldiers, nor have they said whether any warning was given. There has been no official response to claims that two of the victims were shot as they lay on the sidewalk. The government won't even identify the soldiers' unit, which is believed to be an elite surveillance group. The Royal Ulster Constabulary, the province's police force, said the soldiers came across the incident by chance. ``What precisely happened next, and why, is properly the subject of the investigation now being rigorously pursued by the RUC,'' Peter Brooke, the top British official in Northern Ireland, told the House of Commons on Monday. Sinn Fein, the IRA's legal political wing, claimed Saturday there had been intensive security force operations in the area the day before the shootings. Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency, said Tuesday that government sources had confirmed reports by witnesses that two more soldiers were at the scene. The RUC said Tuesday it had arrested a fourth robbery suspect, who reportedly hid in the betting shop and slipped away before police arrived. The dead men all had criminal records. Edward Paul Hale, 21, who was buried Tuesday, had two convictions. He had also been shot in the elbows, knees and ankles by the IRA in 1987 for ``anti-social actions.'' Peter James Thompson, 21, the other masked man, had a record of six convictions and the man in the car, Joseph McNeil, 42, had 28 convictions, police said. Within hours of the incident, Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams issued a statement accusing the security forces of ``coldblooded murder.'' Spokesmen for the Social Democratic and Labor Party, the largest mainly Roman Catholic party in Northern Ireland, also called the shootings unjustified. The Irish government is demanding an explanation. Defenders of the security forces said the incident had to be seen in the context of Northern Ireland's intractable strife. ``Security officers do not get a second chance from the IRA, and it must be considered a reasonable action on the part of security forces when confronting those who present themselves as armed to safeguard lives by shooting them,'' said Peter Robinson, deputy leader of the Rev. Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party. In two decades, 870 members of the army, the RUC and the Ulster Defense Regiment have been killed in Northern Ireland. John Stalker, an English police official assigned to investigate the 1982 killings, recommended prosecuting 11 RUC officials, and instead was removed from the case. He said he reached no conclusion about the existence of a ``shoot-to-kill'' policy, but said in 1988 that the circumstances ``pointed to a police inclination, if not a policy, to shoot suspects dead without warning rather than to arrest them.''

DOC.HEAD: Midway and O'Hare Fogged In
DOC.TEXT: Heavy fog stopped traffic at Midway Airport this morning and caused cancellations and long delays at O'Hare International Airport ``We're fogged in on every front,'' said Lisa Howard, a spokeswoman for the city's aviation department. O'Hare, considered the nation's busiest airport, is a hub for a large segment of the nation's east-west air traffic. Many inbound flights were 30 minutes to an hour late at O'Hare, Ms. Howard said. United Airlines canceled 14 flights from O'Hare, and there were scattered cancellations by other airlines, she said. Flights in and out of Midway were put on hold at about 7:15 a.m. Midway Airlines and its Midway Commuter, whose flights make up about 70 percent of the traffic out of Midway Airport, said the carrier had canceled 146 flights by noon, said airline spokeswoman Roseanne White. The National Weather Service reported dense fog throughout much of northern Illinois that reduced visibility to near zero early this morning. Some improvement was expected by mid-morning.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Experts Slam `Racist' AIDS Pamphlets
DOC.TEXT: Pamphlets claiming whites will be wiped out by AIDS unless they isolate themselves from blacks have been condemned by medical experts as a right-wing plot to create public hysteria. Hundreds of the ``Facts on AIDS'' pamphlets have been distributed in areas around Johannesburg recently by a group urging whites to ``save the white race from extinction.'' AIDS experts say the pamphlets are completely misleading and are intended to create fear and racial tension. Police said Tuesday the pamphlets had not caused any problems and they could not take action against the unknown authors because no public complaints had been received. ``We could not do anything until there was evidence it was subvertng public morals,'' a police spokesman said. The pamphlets claim that AIDS can be spread by casual contact, including via toilet seats, swimming pools, multiracial churches, multiracial hotels and distribution of communion wafers during church services. The pamphlets appeared at a time when the South African government is moving to desegregate some public facilities as part of its stated aim of ending apartheid. Many whites strongly oppose the attempts to end desegregation in public facilities. Dr. Dennnis Sifris, a senior AIDS specialist at Johannesburg Hospital, said the pamphlet was ``ridiculous'' and completely misleading. ``It's obviously put out by an extreme lunatic fringe group who are trying to scare everyone,'' he said. The three-page pamphlets produced by a previously unknown group called the AIDS Information Distributing Society claim many South African blacks have acquired immune deficiency syndrome and whites must protect themselves from infection. Whites are urged to avoid areas where the races mingle, such as integrated hotels and churches, and to have black servants tested each month to ensure they do not have AIDS. The South African government used to claim that the African National Congress, the main black political movement, was bringing AIDS into the country when its infected guerrillas infiltrated across the border. The claims have been dropped as the government has taken a more moderate position on dealing with the ANC. Professor Ruben Sher, head of the South African Medical Research Council's Aids Center, said the pamphlets make erroneous claims, including assertions that AIDS is spread by casual contact and through mosquito bites. Sher also criticized the pamphlets' suggestion that whites make their black servants take regular monthly tests to ensure they do not have AIDS. ``This is a blatant racial slur,'' Sher said. Johannesburg newspapers said nothing was known about the group behind the pamphlets. South Africa has reported about 300 AIDS cases among whites, with an unknown number of people afflicted by the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV. Although no firm statistics are available, AIDS is thought to be more widespread among blacks, reflecting the major spread of the disease among heterosexuals in some other African nations. Scientists say AIDS is spread by sexual intercourse, through contaminated blood or syringe needles, and through infected mothers to unborn children.

DOC.HEAD: Fifth Trident 2 Launch Successful
DOC.TEXT: The Trident 2 missile program Tuesday had its fifth consecutive successful test launch of the Navy's newest and most powerful weapon. The submarine Tennessee, cruising under the ocean about 200 miles offshore, fired the unarmed 44-foot missile about 11 a.m. EST, sending it to an ocean target several thousand miles down the Atlantic tracking range. The Tennessee is expected to fire one more test missile this week before the Trident 2 is pronounced operational, overcoming two fiery failures in its first three launch attempts. Each Trident 2 sub will carry 24 of the missiles, each capable of delivering up to 12 nuclear warheads to different targets more than 5,000 miles away. Greenpeace anti-nuclear activists who halted a Trident 2 launch by penetrating the launch zone last July were not present this week.

DOC.HEAD: Genscher Says 100,000 Ethnic Germans Will Leave for West Germany
With AM-Bulgaria, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: More than 100,000 ethnic Germans plan to emigrate from Romania to West Germany despite the fall of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said Tuesday. Genscher met Monday and Tuesday with leaders of the ethnic German community, and he said they told him that between 60 percent and 80 percent of Romania's 220,000 ethnic Germans would take advantage of the lifting of emigration restrictions enforced by the Ceausescu regime. The ethnic Germans, as well as other minority groups like the Hungarians and Serbs, were persecuted under Ceausescu's forced assimilation policy. Since 1978, Bonn has paid an average of about $5,900 to the Romanian government for each of about 130,000 ethnic Germans allowed to emigrate to West Germany. Most of the Germans in Romania are descendants of immigrants from the German provinces of Swabia and Saxony who settled in the rich farming lands of what is now Romania starting in the 13th century. Genscher said Monday that about 80 percent of Romania's Germans had applied for exit visas during the Ceausescu years. During his trip to Romania, Genscher has stressed the importance of the governing National Salvation Front Council quickly creating trust among minority groups in democratic developments, and ending discrimination against the German ethnic minority. Genscher said that although the West German government wants the living conditions of the Germans improved, Germany would welcome any who wanted to emigrate.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo Unveils $51.3 Billion Budget; Calls For Tax Cut Delay
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo, unveiling a $51.3 billion state budget, today called for about $700 million in higher taxes and fees and proposed that New Yorkers forgo a promised income tax cut in 1990-91. Cuomo, a second-term Democrat considered a potential 1992 presidential contender, said New York needs the extra money to deal with budget deficits and combat drug abuse and AIDS. New York's tax revenue has been hurt by earlier tax cuts and an economic slowdown in the Northeast, he said. Under his spending plan, the overall budget would grow 9.3 percent. Included in his proposal for additional revenue was a call for an increase in the cigarette tax of 5 cents a pack to 38 cents. In October, the state's maximum income tax rate is scheduled to drop from 7.5 percent to 7 percent unless Cuomo gets his way. With or without the drop, New York's rates would still be the highest in the Northeast. Republicans and business leaders have argued that the final phase of the four-year tax cut approved by Cuomo and the Legislature in 1987 must be preserved. Liberal Democrats and social service advocates have said the state needs the money. The final phase of the tax cut would translate into a savings of $134 this year for a family of four with two wage earners and an annual taxable income of $50,000, according to state officials. Freezing the tax cut could provide the state treasury with an extra $400 million for the fiscal year that begins April 1.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Try To Restore Order In Embattled Region; State of Emergency Declared
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with thousands more troops sent to region; picks up 6th pvs, `The official...' INSERTS 1 graf after 15th pvs, `I would...' with White House saying state of emergency order justified; picks up 16th pvs, `The flareup...'
DOC.TEXT: The Kremlin today sent thousands of reinforcements to enforce a state of emergency in parts of the southern Caucasus, where fierce battles raged between hundreds of well-armed Azerbaijanis and Armenians. At least 56 people have been killed and 156 injured in ethnic strife in the republic of Azerbaijan since Thursday, Interior Ministry spokesman Vladimir A. Yanchenkov said today. Yanchenkov told a briefing that authorities had recorded 167 ``pogroms'' and cases of arson. Civilians, mostly Armenians, are said to have been murdered at random in ethnically motivated attacks that provoked the gun battles. Soviet TV reported tonight that more than 5,000 Soviet Army soldiers and 6,000 internal security troops had been dispatched as reinforcements to the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh in Azerbaijan and in the neighboring republic of Armenia. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the Soviet Presidium proclaimed a state of emergency Monday night, empowering the government to use units of the Soviet Army, Navy and KGB to put down the ethnic unrest. It was not known how many troops were sent to the region since ethnic clashes began Saturday. The official news agency Tass said 2,000 people armed with anti-aircraft guns and other artillery today were massed on hills around the disputed region. ``We can't bring ourselves to pronounce it aloud, but what is happening now in Karabakh, in northern Azerbaijan, can be termed unambiguously a civil war,'' correspondent O.
