Most of the remaining price controls were lifted on Jan. 1 and prices have soared again ahead of wages. The television report said the reasons for work stoppages at two other mines in Walbrzych and two more near the industrial city of Katowice were similar to those given by workers at the Thorez mine. Miners in Walbrzych had warned last week they would strike if their demands for a reduction in administrative personnel were not met. It was difficult to determine how many people were likely to become unemployed as a result of the reform program, but from 400,000 to 5 million could lose their jobs, PAP said. Among the components of the plan, enacted by the government, are tight credit, a tough wage policy and a drastic reduction of state subsidies and steep price increases for energy, transportation and communications. The fund can cover about 200,000 jobless with unemployment benefits for several months, the news agency said. There are also plans to create 25,000 new jobs for those dismissed and another 10,000 for invalids, PAP said. About 10,000 will be offered small loans to start private businesses. The fund also will provide equalizing payments for 50,000 workers who lose their jobs due to group dismissals or are forced to accept lower paying jobs. The fund relies on mandatory contributions from workplaces, but the state will step in with contributions from the budget if more funds are needed, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: 5.3 Quake Rattles Northern California
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with revised magnitude, quake felt from Point Arena to Eureka area. Picks up 5th graf, `The Richter....'
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake struck along California's North Coast on Tuesday, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or damages. The quake, measuring 5.3 on the Richter scale, struck at 12:08 p.m. about 50 miles south of Eureka, the U.S. Geological Survey in Menlo Park reported. The state Office of Emergency Services in Sacramento and University of California-Berkeley Seismographic Station also estimated the quake at 5.3. ``It seemed long and just kind of weaving. It wasn't real, real strong here,'' said a woman with the Eureka Police Department who only identified herself as Diana. The quake was felt along the North Coast, the region above San Francisco, from Point Arena near the Oregon border, south to Willits and in Lake County. State emergency officials reported that residents in the small town of Petrolia said items were knocked off shelves, but that there was no other damage. Petrolia is near a land formation known as Punta Gorda, almost directly at the point where the San Andreas Fault enters the Pacific. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in the strength of the shaking. Thus, a reading of 7.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one of 6.5. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area, 4 moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, 6 severe damage. A 7 reading is a ``major'' earthquake, capable of widespread heavy damage, and 8 is a ``great'' quake, capable of tremendous damage. On Oct. 17, a major quake measuring 7.1 on the Richter scale struck Northern California, killing 67 people, injuring about 3,000 and causing $7 billion in damage. The San Francisco earthquake of 1906, which occurred before the Richter scale was devised, has been estimated at 8.3 on the Richter scale.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Visits Housing Project to Praise Residents Anti-Drug Efforts
DOC.TEXT: President Bush dropped in unannounced on a public housing project Tuesday to salute residents for holding all-night vigils against drug dealers. ``We simply have got to win this fight,'' he declared. The president used his visit to the Charles Houston development in this Washington suburb to promote both his administration's battle against drug pushers and legislation to encourage more home ownership among public housing residents. ``With home ownership comes pride. Along with ownership comes strengthening of the family. So our program is aimed at this whole concept of home ownership,'' Bush told a group of community activists. The president praised the courage of residents who, for the last four weekends, have staged all-night prayer vigils and camped out in drug-infested areas. Speaking to a group of anti-drug activists in the kitchen of a community center, Bush said he had dropped by ``to say `thank you' to those in the community who are standing shoulder to shoulder with those who are fighting this drug menace. We simply have got to win this fight.'' Bush was accompanied by Jack Kemp, the secretary of housing and urban development, on the early-afternoon tour. Kemp said the visit should be seen as a signal to drug dealers that ``public housing no longer is going to be a free haven'' for their activities. Bush and Kemp discussed the adminstration's $2.1 billion package, introduced in November, to provide matching federal grants to make it easier for public housing residents to buy their dwellings. The president called on Congress to act on the measure when it reconvenes Jan. 23, and to pass a long-languishing proposal for urban enterprise zones that would give businesses tax breaks for establishing in inner cities. Security was tight for Bush's foray into the high-crime neighborhood; reporters travelling in his motorcade were not told of his destination until he arrived. Helicopters hovered overhead and the area was cordoned off by police. In mild spring-like weather, a steadily building crowd gathered outside hastily assembled police barricades to watch Bush, Kemp and other members of their entourage visit an a unit in the development and then the community center about a block away. ``We were just driving by,'' Kemp joked. Their first stop was the home of community activists Pete and Corina Jones in one of many of the two-story brick buildings that make up the housing project. ``I was a little shocked to see the president come into my house,'' Jones said later. ``It shows we do have a president who cares.'' The president praised Ramona Younger, leader of the Alexandria Public Housing Residents Council and an organizer of the all-night vigils. ``I've been inspired by the stories I've heard of her leadership, her toughness, her willingness to take these people on,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: ``CBS Evening News'' Third in Ratings by Narrow Margin
DOC.TEXT: The once-dominant ``CBS Evening News,'' now trailing ABC's ``World News Tonight'' in ratings, was third last week, national audience estimates showed Tuesday. ABC's newscast, anchored by Peter Jennings, easily won the week ending Jan. 14 with a ratings average of 11.9. It was the 12th time this season the program has triumphed over CBS's newscast, according to an ABC spokesman. Tom Brokaw's ``NBC Nightly News,'' which usually is in third place, was second in ratings last week with a 10.9 average, edging out Rather's newscast, which was third by a narrow margin of one-tenth of a ratings point. Acording to the A.C. Nielsen Co., each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. CBS officials had no immediate explanation for Rather's third-place finish, which last happened in the final week of December, according to CBS. Last week, one major CBS affiliate, KPIX-TV in San Francisco, shifted Rather's program to an earlier 5:30 p.m. PST start time. But it isn't known yet if that was a factor in the week's Nielsen returns for the program, said Michael Eisenberg, CBS vice president for audience measurement. ``We couldn't point to that as the only reason right now,'' he said in an interview Tuesday. ``We're studying the matter and trying to find out what the reasons are.'' In a news conference in Los Angeles over the weekend, Rather said, ``I intend to keep right on keeping on. It's true, the `CBS Evening News' is a work in progress ... we're constantly trying to improve.'' Asked about his delivery of the news from a standing position, the anchorman said, ``I've always wanted to stand and do the broadcast. I don't think that's cosmetic.'' Rather and CBS News President David Burke said they were unable to explain the ratings tumble. But each discounted speculation that some of it was due to Rather's much-publicized on-air confrontation with then GOP presidential candidate George Bush during a ``CBS Evening News'' interview in early 1988. Burke blamed part of the program's ratings slide on what he called statistical errors in the Nielsen ratings system and on the programs of other broadcast outlets such as the 24-hour Cable News Network. ``There is increasing competition from CNN, which means you don't have to make an appointment to watch the news anymore, you have it on all the time, and I think they do a fine job,'' Burke said.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: There was a cake, flowers, guests, a judge to perform the ceremony and the bride wore a blue chiffon gown. The groom didn't know anything about it. Frances Upchurch, 45, staged the surprise Monday in her office. Groom Vance Helms, also 45, thought he was coming to pick her up for lunch. ``Everywhere we called, for flowers, food, everywhere _ nobody believed that the groom didn't know about the wedding. It took a lot of explaining, especially to the judge we asked to perform the ceremony,'' Ms. Upchurch said. The couple had planned to have a brief civil ceremony later this week, said Vance. But when he opened Ms. Upchurch's office door he was greeted by Judge Robert J. Smith, a large crowd of other people, and cameras. Vance backed out and closed the door. ``When I saw (the judge) in those black robes, that was when I realized that this was the real thing,'' Helms said. ``Are you ready?'' asked the judge. ``Yes,'' Helms replied. ``We have the reputations of being the dullest, most respectable people you know,'' Ms. Upchurch said. ``We're the last people you would expect to do something like this.''

You meant to see that art show at the museum but it closed before you got there. Or, you didn't want to stand in line. Or, perhaps the exhibit never came to your city. Could it be you're a couch potato? Don't fre. Art museums are entering the video business, making tapes of exhibitions for those who want something a little more highbrow than ``Batman'' or the latest installment of ``Friday the 13th.'' The Museum of Modern Art on Tuesday became the latest institution to enter the video stores with a 60-minute tape tied to its ``Picasso and Braque: Pioneering Cubism'' exhibit. The unprecedented exhibit, with nearly 400 art works from 14 countries, including the Soviet Union, closed Tuesday and cannot travel because of lenders' concerns, said Richard Oldenburg, the museum's director. So for art lovers who could not see the show in New York, ``This is the best substitute we can provide,'' Oldenburg said. ``It certainly comes alive a lot better than any catalog can, no matter how good the catalog is.'' The tape will be distributed by a Chicago-based company, Public Media Inc., under its fine arts label, Home Vision. Edward Ruehle, a company spokesman, said Home Vision's more than 300-title catalog includes about a dozen videos tied to museum exhibitions. The MOMA tape will sell initially for $19.95. Other exhibit-related tapes have been produced by such institutions as the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Blaze in Textile Workshop Building Kills 16, Injures 10
DOC.TEXT: Fire swept through a building housing textile workshops Tuesday, killing 16 young workers and injuring 10 others, police said. The blaze started on the second floor of a five-story building in the central Istanbul district of Kumkapi, a police officer said. The flames quickly spread to other floors containing the textile workshops, the officer said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Most of the dead had been unable to leave their synthetic-fabric weaving workshops because of the intensity of the fire and suffocated, he said. He said 10 others who had been injured were taken to hospitals. One was in serious condition. A firefighting official said he suspected the blaze began in the electrical system but that authorities had yet to complete their investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Another Evangelist Pleads In PTL Case
DOC.TEXT: The evangelist who introduced PTL founder Jim Bakker to secretary Jessica Hahn pleaded innocent Tuesday to charges that he lied to a grand jury about his motive for setting up the fateful meeting. John Wesley Fletcher, 49, a frequent guest on Bakker's TV show, entered the plea to one perjury count before U.S. Magistrate Paul Taylor, who set trial for the court's April term. It was the disclosure of hush payments to Ms. Hahn following her 1980 sexual liason with Bakker that eventually led to the demise of Bakker's multimillion-dollar PTL television empire. Bakker is now serving a 45-year federal prison term after being convicted last fall of fraud and conspiracy. He was found guilty of bilking followers who sent him $158 million in exchange for free lodging guarantees at his Heritage USA Christian retreat in nearby Fort Mill, S.C. Another former Bakker associate, the Rev. Sam Johnson, did not appear in court for his arraignment on perjury charges. Court officials said Johnson's attorney had given notice that his client would waive his right to appear at his arraignment. The attorney, Bill Osteen, told the U.S. District Court clerk's office that he would enter Johnson's plea Wednesday. Last month, Johnson said he intended to plead innocent. Both men are accused of lying to the special grand jury that investigated PTL's operations under Bakker's leadership. That panel met for 17 months before indicting Bakker and three of his former associates. Fletcher had met Ms. Hahn when he conducted revival services on New York's Long Island, where she was a church secretary. Fletcher told the grand jury during one appearance that he didn't introduce Bakker and Ms. Hahn with the idea that they would have sex. But during a later appearance before the grand jury, Fletcher said sex was the motive behind the introduction and that Bakker had told him to ``Get me a woman.'' Prosecutors said they don't plan to call Ms. Hahn as a witness at Fletcher's trial. Fletcher told reporters he is working part-time with his brother in the roofing business in Durham. He declined to comment on the charges following the hearing. Johnson, former pastor of Heritage Village Church at PTL, is accused of lying to the grand jury about the source of a $10,000 loan that he made to one of Bakker's aides. The money eventually was given to Ms. Hahn to keep her quiet about the 1980 encounter with Bakker, the indictment said. Johnson gave the money to former PTL executive vice president Richard Dortch in November 1984. Ms. Hahn later received $265,000 in PTL money in exchange for her silence, the indictment said. Dortch, who was charged with Bakker, pleaded guilty to fraud and conspiracy charges and was sentenced to eight years in prison and fined $200,000. Two other former Bakker associates _ brothers James and David Taggart _ were convicted of evading tax payments on more than $1.1 million in PTL funds that they used for personal expenditures. If convicted, Johnson and Fletcher each face up to five years in prison and fines of up to $250,000.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Bush Listening to Rosalynn Carter
With AM-Barbara Bush
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush said Tuesday that she's been maximizing the time she spends swimming each day by listening to the ``fascinating'' story of a former first lady. ``First Lady From Plains'' by Rosalynn Carter was the first tape Mrs. Bush used in the new waterproof pouch and headset a friend gave her for her daily 1-mile swim. She puts her own cassette player inside the pouch, which straps on with a belt. ``Actually it's a fascinating book, because she has a lovely voice,'' Mrs. Bush said about Mrs. Carter, who reads excerpts from the book. The two first ladies recently had lunch at the White House. Mrs. Bush, who also has read books by Betty Ford and Lady Bird Johnson, said she will write a book of her own based on 30 years of diaries after leaving the White House. She doesn't envision using negative portrayals as Nancy Reagan did in ``My Turn.'' However, Mrs. Bush refused to criticize that style. ``Each person does their own thing,'' she said, promising her book won't be a ``kiss and tell.''

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Reached Over Home for Mentally Retarded
DOC.TEXT: A Chicago suburb agreed Tuesday to allow contruction of a group home for the retarded in a federal court settlement that may ease efforts to build housing for the handicapped across the nation. Chicago Heights also agreed to pay $45,000 in damages and report for five years all actions affecting housing for the handicapped. ``We hope other communities will get the message that the handicapped have rights under the Fair Housing Act,'' said James P. Turner, acting head of the Justice Department's civil rights division. ``If local officials don't pay attention to those rights, they will pay damages for violating them,'' Turner said. Under the consent decree approved by U.S. District Judge William T. Hart, Chicago Heights agreed to issue a zoning permit before week's end to Residential Facilities Management Services Inc., of Galesburg, Ill. The permit will allow construction of a group home for 15 retarded adults. The agreement settles lawsuits filed June 20 by the Justice Department and the next day by the corporation charging the City Council violated the Fair Housing Act when it voted May 1 to turn down a request for the zoning permit. The lawsuits were the first brought by the government under the Fair Housing amendment enacted last year to protect the handicapped. The lawsuits contended the City Council vote was motivated by opposition from residents prejudiced against the retarded. Chicago Heights, while not admitting to any discrimination, agreed to pay $30,000 to RFMS for construction delays and $1,000 to each of the 15 people who eventually will live in the home. The city contends the permit was denied because RFMS had not supplied necessary documents with its application. ``The fact that the inhabitants happened to be developmentally disabled was not a factor,'' said Chicago Heights lawyer Nick J. DiGiovanni. He said the city agreed to the settlement ``in recognition of the cost saving of not having to go to trial to be vindicated.'' Under the agreement, Chicago Heights officials also must report to the federal government for the next five years any other applications they receive from anyone wanting to operate a facility for the handicapped. They must report within five days any changes made in local laws governing such facilities. RFMS must submit site plans and other documents to the city, and pledge that the home will not be used to care for mentally ill or emotionally disturbed patients. It also must limit the number of residents to 15. Justice Department spokeswoman Deborah Burstion-Wade said the settlement may make it easier for the government to obtain court orders in future cases involving the refusal of local governments to grant permits for group homes. ``Our hope is that this (agreement) will be noted by other communities, not only in the Chicago metropolitan area of Illinois, but nationwide _ that it's impermissible for them to deny access to living accommodations on behalf of developmentally disabled persons,'' said Richard E. Friedman, attorney for RFMS, which operates 55 group homes in 35 other Illinois communities. Group homes for the handicapped, usually established in residential neighborhoods, are designed to encourage independence. Residents live under supervision, but are given greater responsibility for everyday decisions than in other facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Officials Look into Claims Murdered U.S. Agent was Corrupt
LaserPhoto MO1
DOC.TEXT: Mexican authorities are looking into claims that a murdered U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent was actually in league with drug traffickers, Mexico's attorney general said Tuesday. At a memorial service for 44 Mexican narcotics agents killed in the line of duty, Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo said Mexican officials had no independent corroboration of press reports that the DEA agent, Enrique Camarena, was corrupt. ``We are checking the basis of those reports,'' said Alvarez, who refused to give further details in a brief encounter with reporters. The reports, which involved marijuana busts in northwestern Mexico, surfaced last week after the broadcast of the NBC-TV miniseries ``Drug Wars,'' based on Camarena's murder in 1985 by top Mexican drug traffickers. U.S. officials have denied Camarena was corrupt in any way, noting the charges were old and never backed by any evidence. The miniseries, which showed corrupt Mexican officials aiding narcotics traffickers and thwarting the investigation of Camarena's murder, caused controversy in Mexico. Comments on NBC News programs that followed the miniseries angered Mexicans by suggesting the corruption that killed Camarena still exists. Alvarez's remarks overshadowed a speech by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari to 400 law enforcement officials and relatives of the dead officers in which Salinas vowed to press the fight against official corruption. ``The first condition for attacking narcotics trafficking is to dismantle and destroy the networks of corruption that protect it,'' Salinas said. Salinas has made an effort to remove drug trafficking as an irritant in U.S.-Mexico relations, winning praise from U.S. officials for vigorously pursuing drug traffickers. Such pursuit has resulted in the seizure of 36 tons of cocaine in the 13 months Salinas has been in office _ more than was seized the previous 10 years. Nevertheless, the government newspaper El Nacional published a front-page story Friday that quoted anonymous sources as saying Camarena had been murdered because he had betrayed the drug traffickers he worked for. DEA spokesman Frank Shultz in Washington said there was ``not a scintilla of evidence whatsoever that Enrique Camarena was involved with the traffickers in any way other than an adversarial role.'' Elaine Shannon, author of the book ``Desperados,'' on which the miniseries was based, said Mexican authorities began attacking Camarena's integrity in 1985 in order to divert attention from themselves and even tried to set up a fake bank account to prove Camarena took dirty money. ``It's rather sad that the Mexican government is reduced to this transparent attempt at slander rather than to try to improve their government's own ability to enforce their laws, protect their citizens and bring drug traffickers and the people who killed Camarena to justice,'' Shannon said. Kingpins Rafael Caro Quintero and Ernesto Fonseca Carrillo were sentenced in December to 40 years in prison without parole for the Camarena murder, but many U.S. officials believe the full story has not been told. The memorial ceremony at Mexico City's airport was hastily arranged to demonstrate Mexico's commitment to the fight against drug trafficking following the Jan. 7, 8 and 9 ``Drug Wars'' broadcasts. Meanwhile, a Mexican advertising group bought full-page ads in The Washington Post, The New York Times and the Los Angeles Times to outline Mexico's anti-drug efforts. The ads cost a total of $124,340. ``Drug Wars'' itself appeared in English on Mexico City's cable TV system, and a Mexican network broadcast a program Sunday that purported to expose the program's errors and included mention of the accusations against Camarena. NBC has defended the program and its reporting since then. Mexican officials say the controversy will not affect working relations between the two governments, especially in narcotics. ``We do not deny our problems, nor do we look for excuses for our errors,'' Salinas said. ``Although the great majority of our agents have demonstrated great valor in fighting drug trafficking, I repeat, we will energetically punish those who involve themselves in drug trafficking,'' he said. Salinas' promises to fight corruption were given an added edge by the arrest of four Mexico City police officers on rape charges. The attorney general's office refused to comment on published reports at least three of the accused had been bodyguards for Javier Coello Trejo, the assistant attorney general in charge of the fight against drug traffickers.

DOC.HEAD: Gun Control Advocates Ask For Ban On Importing Semi-Automatic Pistols
With AM-School Shooting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Gun control advocates Tuesady marked the first anniversary of the massacre of five California schoolchildren by announcing they want a government ban on imports of semi-automatic assault-style pistols. ``These are killing machines,'' said Susan Whitmore of Handgun Control Inc., adding that the organization will petition the government Wednesday to eliminate imports of such pistols as the Uzi and the HK-94, shorter versions of assault-style rifles banned last summer. Among the 43 types of assault-style rifle imports banned last July was the popular AK-47 model used by 24-year-old drifter Patrick Purdy to kill five children and wound 29 others and a teacher on Jan. 17, 1989, at a school playground in Stockton, Calif. But the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms as well as the National Rifle Association say banning the imports of the pistols will be a lot more difficult than the banning of the rifles. The handgun regulations in place for the past two decades were intended to rule out cheap ``Saturday night specials,'' not well-made, sophisticated assault-style weapons, said ATF spokesman Jack Killorin. Those handguns that met the criteria ATF established after Congress approved the Gun Control Act of 1968 _ including such things as barrel length, round size, overall length and weight _ have been considered to have met the sporting use requirement imposed on all imports, he said. The ATF had more leeway to ban imports of the semi-automatic assault-style rifles because ``in essence, a new form of weapon had appeared ... that had been relatively unexamined under the law. Now you look at the issue of handguns and the degree to which that has been examined. ... This is an area that doesn't lack examination. It has been established and in practice for over 20 years.'' Because of the extensive legislative history and long-standing regulations for handgun imports, ``It would be much more difficult for us'' to ban certain handgun imports, he said. ``I don't know how one would design criteria that would exclude the firearms they're talking about and not exclude all the other firearms,'' said Jim Baker, the NRA's director of governmental affairs. ``I think that Handgun Control would like to ban anything that there's a political or emotional opportunity to ban, and this is consistent with that policy.'' But David G. Mengebier, Handgun Control's legislative counsel who wrote the petition, said that, like the assault-style rifles banned last July, the assault-style pistols also reflect new technology and a new situation that calls for new regulations not accounted for in the legislative history. ``All of the factors which ATF considered persuasive in banning the importation of semi-automatic assault rifles are present and applicable to semi-automatic assault pistols,'' the petition says. ``With the exception of their length, semi-automatic assault pistols are identitical to semi-automatic assault rifles in terms of their evolutionary development, design, physical components and intended use,'' the petition says. Killorin said the ATF could look at how the pistols are being used ``in real life. One of the things that drove the issue of the semi-automatic assault (rifles) were the astonishing numbers that were beginning to appear for importation. We may take a look at how many of these are coming in. These may not be a significant import item.'' Mengebier said in an interview that his organization has not been given access to import figures for 1989 because they are considered proprietary information, but he said, ``It's safe to say that thousands have been authorized for importation or are being imported.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Poison Proclamation
DOC.TEXT: President Bush urged Americans to learn how to prevent childhood poisonings as he signed a proclamation Tuesday designating March 18-24 as National Poison Prevention Week. The United States, by congressional decree, has observed Poison Prevention Week during the third week of March since 1961. In that time, there has been a 93 percent drop in the number of deaths in children who accidentally swallow medicines or household chemicals. Accidental poisonings claimed the lives of 450 children under age 5 in 1961, according to an estimate by the Consumer Product Safety Commission. In 1987, the latest year statistics were available, 31 children died from accidental poisoning. ``While many tragic deaths have been prevented in recent years, we still have much work to do,'' Bush said. ``Accidental poisonings can be prevented if parents, grandparents and other guardians keep medicines and household chemicals out of the reach of children. Adults should also be sure to store all potentially harmful substances in packages with child-resistant closures.''

DOC.HEAD: NBC Chairman Keynotes Network Challenges for the '90s
DOC.TEXT: The survival of U.S. television networks in the 1990s will depend on how they compete in a rapidly changing marketplace, NBC President Robert C. Wright told TV programmers Tuesday. ``The major broadcast networks are still locked into essentially one business and one traditional source: revenue from advertisers,'' Wright said in the keynote address to the 27th annual gathering of the National Association of Television Programming Executives. ``The cost of network programs is outpacing the growth of that revenue, and 3{ broadcast networks and 27 cable networks are bobbing around today in a modestly growing advertising marketplace.'' Networks will see more new competitors, a diminished audience share and ``their very modest profit margins continue to shrink,'' he said. ``The boundaries are disappearing,'' Wright said, but governmental regulations are forcing the networks ``to live behind television's equivalent of the Berlin Wall.'' He cited Fox television's emergence as a competing network and Japanese electronics giant Sony Corp.'s purchase of CBS Records and Columbia Pictures. Movie studios buy TV stations and cable TV subsidiary Turner Communications has one of the largest TV and film libraries in the world. Against this backdrop, the networks ``scream for freedom from the shackles of obsolete, anti-competitive government regulations,'' Wright said. Specifically, Wright cited the Federal Communications Commission's financial-interest syndication regulations _ known in the industry as ``fin-syn'' or FISR. The regulations bar NBC, ABC and CBS from having a financial interest in programs they don't produce themselves, and also prohibits the networks from being in program syndication or sharing revenues from syndicated programs. NATPE's annual meeting is the largest marketplace for syndicated programming in the world, but the network presence is minimal. ``The financial rules are an outgrowth of positions taken in the 1960s. They were intended to make the 1970s more competitive,'' Wright said. In 1983, after four years of hearings, the FCC, Federal Trade Commission, and the Commerce and Justice departments concluded that the rules should be abolished, he said. Political lobbying by the movie industry kept the rules alive, he said. Letting the networks have a stake in entertainment programs would help networks pay the bill on news and sports and support network services to affiliates. ``Anything that restricts our ability to compete for quality entertainment programming also restricts the opportunity and profitability of more than 600 network-affiliated stations,'' Wright said. ``Financial interest doesn't guarantee us anything. It only gives us an opportunity to produce and derive some ancillary benefit from our success on the air,'' Wright said. Wright, in offering a series of predictions for the 1990s, said the ``Berlin Wall'' of fin-syn rules ``will collapse and fall under its own weight.'' He also predicted that the creative financing techniques of movie making will move into TV production. ``Distributors, producers, exhibitors and syndicators will all have crossover interests and investments,'' he said. Program standards will continue to stretch, he said. ``Some services will do very nicely with programming that would be totally unacceptable on other networks,'' he said. The major networks will continue to meet the standards of most Americans, while others ``flirt with niche audiences who march to a different drummer.'' Wright said the 1990s will be an exciting decade for television, with more programs needed to fit the growing array of services to the viewer. ``Less bureaucracy, more entrepreneurship, less history, more future,'' Wright said. ``The creative, the patient, the focused will survive. The slow, the encumbered, and the backward-looking will fail.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Increasing Sugar Import Quotas By 14 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter announced Tuesday a 14 percent increase in the amount of foreign sugar that can be imported by U.S. processors from 39 countries. Yeutter said the increase boosts the sugar import quota to 2,584,865 metric tons for the period Jan. 1, 1989, through Sept. 30, 1990, an increase of 325,000 tons. ``This change in the level of the quota is necessary to counter the tightness in domestic sugar supplies caused by the unexpectedly low production of beet sugar and damage to the Florida and Texas sugar cane crops resulting from the December freeze,'' Yeutter said. New country-by-country allocations announced by U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills showed increases for nations approved to ship sugar to the United States. However, Panama continued to have its quota suspended and will not be allowed to ship to the U.S. market at this time, she said. Quotas are used to restrict the amount of foreign sugar that can enter the United States, thus protecting domestic producers from lower-priced foreign sugar being dumped on the U.S. market. Revised allocations for the period Jan. 1, 1989 through Sept. 30, 1990, in metric tons of 2,205 pounds each, included: Argentina, 104,160. Australia, 201,054. Barbados, 16,957. Belize, 26,646. Bolivia, 19,379. Brazil, 351,238. Canada, 26,646. Colombia, 58,136. Congo, 16,070. Costa Rica, 49,758.5 Dominican Republic, 426,331. Ecuador, 26,646. El Salvador, 71,034.1. Fiji, 21,737. Gabon, 16,070. Guatemala, 116,272. Guyana, 29,068. Haiti, 16,070. Honduras, 47,490.4. India, 19, 379. Cote D'Ivoire, 16,070. Jamaica, 26,646. Madagascar, 16,070. Malawi, 24,127. Mauritius, 29,036. DOC.HEAD: War-Games Promoter Denounced for ``Get-Rushdie'' Game
DOC.TEXT: A promoter of ``executive war games'' said Tuesday he is having second thoughts about a contest whose objective is the mock assassination of novelist Salman Rushdie. ``Perhaps, with hindsight, it was an unfortunate idea,'' said Ian Lawson, director of Skirmish, a country lodge where executives work off stress by fighting mock battles. Bob Gregory, a spokesman for Rushdie's publisher, Viking Penguin, denounced the game as ``disgraceful and in bad taste. Here's a human being in hiding for fear of his life and they're making a game out of it. It's beyond belief.'' Rushdie has been in hiding for 11 months following the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's appeal to Moslems to kill him for writing ``The Satanic Verses,'' a novel some Moslems find blasphemous. Contacted by telephone at the lodge near Guisborough in northern England, Lawson said the game entailed one team chasing a man in a luminous dinner jacket who carries a shield called ``The Book,'' while the opposing team defends him. The players try to ``shoot'' him with paint guns while he tries to escape to a safe spot called ``The Publishers,'' and then to another place called ``The Safe House,'' Lawson said. He said he had not meant to offend anyone, and was trying to contact Viking Penguin to apologize. He said that in view of the criticism after the story surfaced in the local press, he might drop the Rushdie angle from the game. ``Those who come to play are not coming to shoot Salman Rushdie. They come to have a fun day out and enjoy a variety of games, including this one,'' he said. Lawson said another game being developed for the lodge is ``The Noriega Game,'' in which one team defends a player representing the ousted Panamanian dictator, while the other side tries to kidnap him.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Hears Illinois Case Related to Political Patronage
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The free speech rights of three Illinois residents were violated when they were rejected for state jobs or promotions because they failed to support Republicans, an attorney told the Supreme Court on Tuesday. In a case that will determine whether partisanship must be put aside when public employers hire, promote or transfer, attorney Mary Lee Leahy asked the justices to apply past rulings that ban firings. ``Jobs are important to people, promotions are important to people,'' Mrs. Leahy said. ``The state has an obligation to be neutral when granting the benefits that are stake in this case,'' she said. Mrs. Leahy represents two men and a woman who say their job status suffered because they did not vote in Republican primaries or give money to the party. Their lawsuit, which had been thrown out by two lower courts, targets Gov. James R. Thompson, the Republican Party of Illinois and leaders of several state agencies. Mrs. Leahy said the governor's office has controlled all new hires since 1980. In her written brief to the court, she included a form that is used to screen state employees who seek a promotion and live in Sangamon County. The form asks employees to declare how they, or in some cases their parents, voted in primary elections. It also asks whether the person would be willing to work for Republicans during an election. The attorney for Thompson and Illinois Republicans said officials followed the state personnel code, which require tests when people apply for a job. ``All the people who were hired or promoted qualified under the code,'' attorney Thomas P. Sullivan said. But he also acknowledged that when officials examine the field of qualified candidates, they might favor someone who has the same political stripe. Sullivan said that hiring political supporters stimulates good government because the employee is likely to appreciate the job and, in turn, serve the public well. Both attorneys were interrupted several times by the justices. Justice Antonin Scalia said many political scientists believe patronage simply is ``part of the spoils system,'' and helps preserve the country's two-party system. Mrs. Leahy replied: ``This is not a way to preserve a two-party system, but a one-party system.'' The Supreme Court, in a 1980 ruling that significantly weakened patronage, said government workers may not be fired solely because of their political affiliation unless that affiliation was an appropriate requirement of carrying out their jobs. The court, however, did not address the issues raised in the Illinois case: hiring, promotion and transfer. The lead petitioner is Cynthia Rutan, who has worked for the Illinois Department of Rehabilitative Services since 1974. She has applied for promotions but has not received one. She also has not supported Republicans, unlike people who were promoted over her. Franklin Taylor has worked for the Illinois Department of Transportation as an equipment operator for 21 years. He sought a promotion in 1983 and said he was rejected because he did not have an endorsement from Fulton County Republicans. The third petitioner is James Moore. He said he has tried to get a state job, particularly with the Corrections Department, since 1978, but has failed because he could not obtain the signatures of the Pope County Republican chairman and a local GOP lawmaker.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Seeks Explanation Of Reported Shamir Comment
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Tuesday it asked Israel to explain reported comments by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir that the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip should be used to settle Jews from the Soviet Union. The department warned that money given to Israel by the U.S. government cannot be used to settle immigrants in the occupied territories, where about 70,000 Israelis live among 1.7 million Palestinians. The U.S. Embassy in Tel Aviv has contacted the Israeli government about the remarks Shamir made Sunday night to a meeting of his right-wing Likud bloc, a U.S. official said. Israel expacts as many as 300,000 Soviet Jews will arrive in coming years under the liberalized policies of Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, and Shamir aides want to direct the flow of immigrants to the territories. ``For a large immigration we need the Land of Israel, a great and strong Israel,'' Shamir told the Likud. ``We will need a lot of place to absorb everybody,'' he added. The statement was broadcast Monday on Israeli radio. The term ``Land of Israel'' is used by Likud members and other hardliners in references to Israel and the occupied territories, which were captured from Jordan and Egypt by Israel in the 1967 Middle East war. We ``are seeking to clarify what he actually said,'' said State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. ``We do not provide U.S. government resources or funds for settlement of new immigrants in the occupied territories. Our current program is explicitly limited to Israel and not the occupied territories.'' Shamir has also come under attack from the left-leaning Labor Party, his partner in the coalition government, which advocates trading some of the occupied land for peace. Israeli officials say they need $3 billion to absorb 100,000 immigrants over the next three to five years. They are seeking at least $350 million in donations from American Jews and have asked for the U.S. government to guarantee $500 million in housing loans.

DOC.HEAD: New Refugees Commissioner Takes Office
DOC.TEXT: The new U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees began work this week, heading an agency with limited funding and whose former chief resigned amid allegations of misuse of funds. ``It's no joke to lead an organization that is supposed to help 15 million people in such a difficult time and with an extremely tight budget. Still, my old dream has been fulfilled,'' Thorvald Stoltenberg was quoted Tuesday as saying. Stoltenberg, 58, a former Norwegian foreign minister and ambassador to the United Nations, was elected for a four-year term by the U.N. General Assembly on Nov. 20 to replace Jean-Pierre Hocke. A UNHCR statement said Stoltenberg appointed Douglas Stafford, an American, as Deputy High Commissioner for Refugees. Stafford was formerly in charge of finance and administration at the U.N. Development Program in New York. Although Stoltenberg is responsible only for political refugees, he was quoted as telling the Oslo newspaper Aftenposten that he cannot ignore those who fled poverty rather than persecution. Hall said Tuesday the worldwide refugee population rose by 700,000 last year, swelled by an influx into Ethiopia of people fleeing the conflict in neighboring Somalia and Sudan, and by continuing movements of refugees from Mozambique into Malawi, southern Africa. Afghans constitute the largest refugee population, about 5.5 million in Pakistan and Iran. The UNHCR is trying to implement an austerity package to cut a $40 million deficit carried over from 1989. Spending is to be limited to $190 million the first half of this year. Hocke, Stoltenberg's Swiss predecessor, resigned following allegations he misused a special educational fund financed by Denmark and Sweden to upgrade air tickets from business class to first class. Stoltenberg served as Norwegian foreign minister from March 1987 until Gro Harlem Bruntland's Labor party government resigned in October. He then took up the U.N. ambassadorship in New York.

DOC.HEAD: State Sees No Explosion Hazard in Nuclear Waste Tanks
DOC.TEXT: Washington state officials have tentatively concluded that chemicals put in tanks of radioactive waste at the Hanford nuclear reservation do not pose a serious risk of explosion, the state's top health official said Tuesday. Kristine Gebbie, secretary of the state department of health, said preliminary results of a study by state health and ecology officials found no special hazard existed from the chemicals. She said a conclusion had not been reached. The existence of the chemical ferrocyanide in the waste tanks, and the possibility that the mixture could trigger a massive explosion, was detailed in a 1984 study for the Energy Department that was kept secret until last fall. The chemical was added to the tanks in the mid-1950s to help separate the radioactive metals from the liquid waste. The wastes were generated by the Hanford nuclear reactors, which produced plutonium for the nation's atomic weapons. Ms. Gebbie disclosed the state's preliminary assessment of the potential hazard in response to questions from reporters after a meeting with Energy Secretary James D. Watkins. Ms. Gebbie is chairman of a panel of experts advising Watkins on ways to restructure and improve the department's health research activities. She provided no details of the preliminary study of the tank waste hazards.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Hosts Dinner for Susan Eisenhower and Her Soviet Fiance
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Roald CQ
DOC.TEXT: Soviet space scientist Roald Z. Sagdeev and his fiance, Susan Eisenhower, were the guests of honor Tuesday night at a White House dinner given by President Bush and his wife, Barbara. Ms. Eisenhower, 38, a granddaughter of former President Dwight Eisenhower, and Sagdeev, 57, announced last week that they will be married in Moscow on Feb. 9. Other guests at the private dinner were Soviet Ambassador Yuri Dubinin and his wife, Liana; NASA Administrator Richard Truly and his wife, Coleen, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft; American Express chief executive officer James D. Robinson III; Anne Eisenhower, a granddaughter of the late president; her brother David and his wife, Julie Eisenhower II, the daughter of former President Richard M. Nixon. Also attending was public relations executive Bob Gray. Ms. Eisenhower met Sagdeev when he was a member of the Soviet delegation to the Chautauqua Institution@Eisenhower Institute Conference on U.S.-Soviet relations. Sagdeev is a member of the Congress of People's Deputies and heads the theory division of the Space Research Institute.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Lawmaker Says Perestroika Facing Toughest Test
With AM-Soviet-Unrest
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet lawmaker said Tuesday that sending the army into the Caucasus to deal with feuding Armenians and Azerbaijanis puts Mikhail Gorbachev's perestroika policy to its toughest test. ``We think that perestroika is now experiencing its most serious and most dangerous period,'' said Sergei Stankievich, a member of the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies. ``I think it is one of the most serious setbacks,'' he said in an interview from Moscow with Britain's commercial television Channel 4 News. Stankievich added, however, that he considered the move necessary to stabilize a volatile situation and eventually would bring both sides to the negotiating table. Speaking in English, he said there was danger in using the army in Azerbaijan because it might then have to be used elsewhere to put down uprisings in other Soviet republics contending with ethnic disputes or pro-independence movements. ``It is a real danger for us since we have unrest in many regions of the country. We should avoid the possibility of making the army the universal tool of perestroika in other regions,'' he said. Stankievich said the unrest in Azerbaijan and the Baltic republics presented a real danger of perestroika being derailed. ``But we think as soon as we have a real breakthrough in our economy, as soon as we show we are very serious in our devotion to radical political reform, then ethnic tension can be eased,'' he said. Stankievich was described in the program as a radical lawmaker for Moscow and a critic of Gorbachev. He explained that he and those who think like him are critical in general of Gorbachev's ``inconsistency and devotion to half-measures.'' ``We hope Gorbachev will survive in this very intensive conflict and that he will make his choice in favor of further changes. We shall support him in his reform efforts and we shall defend him against any conservative attack,'' Stankievich said. He was asked by interviewer David Smith if ``politicians like him who enjoy great popular support'' would now rally behind Gorbachev. ``We have no other way out but to use the army to stabilize the situation in order to stop bloody violence in our Caucasus,'' Stankievich said of the unrest, which has left at least 56 people dead. ``We cannot stand aside from all this _ we cannot be only eyewitnesses because the lives of thousands of people are at stake. So we should react and use state force but we should try to find some form of inter-ethnic reconciliation.'' The legislator said he favored creation of a new autonomous republic with its own government for Armenians inside Azerbaijan in the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh, ``with new opportunities for the development of Armenian culture there.'' Stankievich said Gorbachev missed the best time for such a solution which was ``at least two years ago,'' when violence first developed between the two communities.

DOC.HEAD: James Florio Sworn in as New Jersey Governor
DOC.TEXT: Democrat James J. Florio became New Jersey's 49th governor Tuesday, promising to use new ideas ``to preserve the old ideals.'' Florio, an eight-term congressman from southern New Jersey, succeeds Republican Thomas H. Kean, who could not seek a third consecutive term. Kean will become president of the private Drew University in Madison. ``After 15 years in Washington, I return to New Jersey,'' Florio told more than 1,800 people crowded inside the War Memorial hall near the Statehouse. ``As I look out on this vast audience, let me simply say, it's good to be home.'' Florio, 52, succeeded the enormously popular Kean on a day of prayers, parades and platitudes, but also inherited deep problems that stand to make his first year in office a trying one. Backing up a campaign pledge to attack soaring auto insurance rates, Florio called for a special joint session of the Legislature on Monday to unveil his long-awaited strategy. New Jersey car insurance premiums average about $1,000 per car and rank among the highest in the nation. Florio won the Statehouse on his third try last November by trouncing GOP nominee and fellow U.S. Rep. James Courter. ``My goal is a simple one. When I leave here, I want to be remembered as the governor who brought new ideas to preserve old ideals,'' said Florio. After his address to the War Memorial throng, Florio led the first inaugural parade in New Jersey in more than 50 years. A $500-a-plate Inaugural Ball capped the list of festivities on inauguration day.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force to Let Women Crew on Cargo Airdrops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: REWRITES throughout to CORRECT that women now may be crew members on cargo airdrop missions, sted will be allowed to parachute from such planes. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Barbara Bush
DOC.TEXT: The Military Airlift Command has removed restrictions barring women from being crew members on cargo airdrop missions, an Air Force spokesman said Tuesday. Women now may serve as pilots, co-pilots, loadmasters, flight engineers or crew chiefs on C-130 or C-141 transport planes, said Air Force Capt. George Sillia. Women earlier had been barred from serving as crew members on airdrop missions. The decision will affect about 100 women among its 4,800 pilots and a like number of women among enlisted crew members, Sillia said. Previously, women crew members were allowed to fly on C-141 aircraft to a specific location, unload the cargo and return. However, women had not been allowed to be crew members on the C-130, except the WC-130, a weather reconnaissance plane. The decision was made Dec. 14, six days before the U.S. invasion of Panama during which Army women were reported to have taken part in combat, Sillia said. The intervention delayed the formal announcement. The command determined that airdrop missions don't fall under the Defense Department's February 1988 ``risk rule,'' which says a non-combat mission or unit can be closed to women if officials deem that the risks are equal to or greater than those of the combat mission they support. During the Panama fighting, Army Capt. Linda Bray directed a successful raid by her military police company on a dog kennel defended by Panamanian Defense Forces in a widely reported incident that renewed the debate over the role of women in the military. Federal law prohibits women from serving in combat units in the Air Force and Navy, while Army regulations ban such activity in that service. However, some members of Congress have called for a change in policy. On Tuesday, Barbara Bush said it would be fine with her for women to serve in combat if they were physically strong enough because ``certainly emotionally and mentally they are more than able to compete with a man.'' The crew change is a result of the command's review of recommendations in the Defense Department's February 1988 report, ``Task Force On Women in the Military.'' ``All positions are continually being reviewed,'' Sillia said. ``We're trying to open as many as possible.''

DOC.HEAD: Rafsanjani Survived 2nd Assassination Attempt: Source
DOC.TEXT: Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani survived an assassination attempt by a bodyguard this month, reportedly the second such incident since October, an informed source said Tuesday. The source, a Tehran resident speaking from a European capital by telephone, said he learned of the attempt about two weeks ago from a presidential bodyguard. The source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said another of Rafsanjani's bodyguards tried to shoot the president but was overpowered by two men before he could pull the trigger. The two men were injured when the gun went off, he added, but Rafsanjani escaped unharmed. The source had no other details. There has been no mention of the attempt in the news media of the Islamic Republic or by Iranian dissident groups, usually quick to report any sign of instability within the leadership. Powerful radicals within the Iranian government, who believe Rafsanjani's pragmatic policies pollute the pure Islamic ideals preached by the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, have been openly attacking his policies. Former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Montashemi, leader of the radical camp and Rafsanjani's most formidable foe, was dumped by Rafsanjani when he formed his new Cabinet in August. Sources say rivalry between the two has exacerbated since Mohtashemi secured the Tehran seat in last month's parliamentary elections. The reported attack was followed by a crackdown on Ayatollah Ali Montazeri, once Khomeini's designated successor and now one of the government's staunchest critics. The source said shopkeepers in the holy city of Qom, Montazeri's home town, went on strike after the senior cleric was arrested for a few hours. The Iranian opposition group Mujahedeen Khalq had reported Montazeri's arrest Jan. 6 but said he was released after several hours when tension mounted in the city. Rafsanjani, 55, reportedly survived an earlier similar assassination attempt by another bodyguard last October. At a press conference with foreign reporters in Tehran, Rafsanjani denied there had been an attempt to assassinate him for several years. The attack was reported to have followed a secret meeting by Rafsanjani and his Cabinet, during which a plan was suggested to pull the country out of the economic doldrums. Last week Iran's supreme spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who supports Rafsanjani, delivered a stern warning to the radicals to stop undermining the government's efforts to improve political and economic conditions in the country. Khamenei, whose commandments as spiritual leader are considered religioulsy binding, threatened to ``act in all instances'' when his orders were not obeyed. He called those who did not abide by his commandment ``traitors,'' and said efforts to undermine Rafsanjani's government amounted to ``national treachery.''

DOC.HEAD: Masked Raiders Attack Boat People in Hong Kong, 1 Dead
DOC.TEXT: Twenty masked and armed attackers on Tuesday night rushed into a hut in a Vietnamese boat people detention center and attacked those inside, killing one and injuring seven, police said Wednesday. Police quickly brought the situation under control, but no arrests were reported. A police investigation was launched. One of those injured was hospitalized. A police source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that because the detention center is a closed camp, authorities believe the attackers are also boat people living in other huts. In the past months many fights erupted in the camps, with boat people using iron bars, swords and lances as weapons. About 56,000 Vietnamese boat people now are housed in squalid camps in Hong Kong. About 12,000 of them arrived before June 1988 and are considered refugees eligible for resettlement, but the rest arrived later and are being screened. If they are classified as illegal immigrants, they must either go home voluntarily or be repatriated by force to Vietnam. On Dec. 12, Hong Kong repatriated 51 boat people against their wishes. In London on Tuesday, British lawmakers Lord Ennals and Timothy Raison said they found no evidence of force in that repatriation and no evidence that those sent back were persecuted on their return. Ennals and Raison, both former Cabinet ministers, said in a report that the involuntary return ``involved an element of overkill in the police presence and equipment used before departure and on board the aircraft.'' However, they said they reported finding no evidence of force being used and said it was the method of return to which the boat people objected. The two visited Vietnam last week at the British government's request. They said they found in every case that the motives of the 51 repatriates for going to Hong Kong were economic. Ennals told a news conference he was unhappy about further forcible repatriation. Raison said it was important to show Vietnamese they could not go to Hong Kong, a British colony, in hopes of moving on elsewhere. Britain has decided that many boat people went to Hong Kong to seek a higher standard of living and not to escape political persecution. On Monday, Amnesty International criticized the Hong Kong government's treatment of boat people, accusing police and security forces of beating them. The human rights organization said investigations of official brutality were quashed by the agencies involved. Britain and Hong Kong called the report unfounded and denied any brutality.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Jailed with Baby Celebrates Freedom With Champagne
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf `Officials were...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with government refusing comment on alleged inadequate medical help. Pickup 15th, `Pickles, 64...'
DOC.TEXT: A teen-age mother who was jailed with her infant daughter after pleading guilty to 10 theft charges celebrated her release Tuesday at a champagne reception. ``I only hope the future holds happiness for me,'' said Tracey Scott, 19, who had admitted she let friends walk out without paying for their goods at the Huddersfield supermarket where she worked as a cashier. Court of Appeal judges on Monday suspended a six-month sentence given to Ms. Scott by Northern Circuit Court Judge James Pickles who said he wanted to deter women from getting pregnant to avoid jail. Ms. Scott, who was not in court Monday, appeared at a brief hearing before the appeal judges in London on Tuesday and agreed to serve two years' probation. Lord Lane, the lord chief justice, told her Pickles should have put her on probation rather than send her to jail. He said Monday Pickles had been told before he sentenced Ms. Scott that two women he had jailed for stealing from the store had been freed on appeal. Yet, he said, Pickles insisted that for helping them ``to loot'' the store, Ms. Scott deserved a custodial sentence. At a party given by neighbors in Huddersfield, 160 miles north of London, Ms. Scott said she wanted to see her lawyer before commenting on Pickles or the two weeks she spent in jail with her 3-month-old daughter, Alesha. ``It's just great to be home,'' she said. ``The first thing I did was have a bath. It was wonderful.'' Ms. Scott said she did not know that she had won her appeal until she was in court Tuesday. Her attorney, Ken Green, said it was ``disgusting'' that no one told her she had won her appeal. Green said she was very bitter toward Pickles. ``She hopes the highlighting of her case will direct attention to other mothers and babies who are in prison,'' he said. Ms. Scott claimed Tuesday night that mothers were denied proper medical help for their sick babies at Styal women's prison in Cheshire in northwest England, where she was jailed. When she arrived at Styal, she said some of the babies there had been suffering from diarrhea for up to two weeks. She said a prison doctor had examined them and declared they were all right. ``Some of the mothers were hysterical,'' she said. ``Every feed for the sick babies was coming up _ they couldn't keep it down. The women were desperate for some outside medical help. They needed proper medical advice _ it was worrying.'' A Home Office spokesman, who by custom was not identified, said it was not the department's policy to discuss individual cases. Pickles, 64, said he didn't want the mother and child to be separated. He said that while he didn't accuse Ms. Scott of getting pregant to avoid going to prison, he was afraid other women might get that idea. Lord Lane said when he quashed the sentence that Pickles ``seems to us to have been concerned more with the public import of what he was doing and saying, rather than the justice of it.'' Pickles is one of Britain's most outspoken judges and frequently draws controversy for his sentencing. Last year, he jailed a woman who was too frightened to testify against a man accused of beating her up. In January, he opted for probation for a child molester, saying the man would have been picked on by bullies in prison and that the arrest and court appearance would likely have a chastening effect. Pickles, a judge since 1976, insists he is humane. He twice delayed sentencing Ms. Scott until he was sure a place was available for her and the baby in youth custody, where conditions are less strict. Pickles reportedly was out of the country on vacation and has declined to comment on the case.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Say `Street Revolution' Could Get Out of Hand
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 7 `We have' to insert dropped word `it.' Pickup 8th, `Hundreds of...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BER4
With AM-Bulgaria, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East Germany opened criminal investigations Tuesday into protesters who stormed secret police headquarters, and the nation's police chief said demand for reform must not turn into something resembling civil war. Warning strikes for higher pay and faster reform hit several cities, twinned with a condemnation of the government decision to raise prices. In Bonn, the West German capital, Chancellor Helmut Kohl bowed to pressure and scrapped plans to sign an agreement on closer ties with Communist Premier Hans Modrow's caretaker government before East Germany's May 6 elections. Even members of Kohl's own coalition said signing of such an agreement must wait until a democratically elected government takes over after free elections. Kohl told a news conference immediate on Tuesday that help is needed for East Germany's ailing economy, adding that ``the situation in the German Democratic Republic had gotten more difficult.'' The East Germany Communist Party daily Neues Deutschland called it a ``street revolution'' and national police chief Dieter Winderlich said of Monday's storming of secret police headquarters: ``We have to do everything so that the reform process can go forward with the peaceful means that have characterized it to date, to keep it from resulting in occurrences resembling civil war.'' Hundreds of thousands of East Germans took to the streets Monday to step up pressure against the Communists, with protesters at the secret police building also breaking into the counterespionage area. The conservative Die Welt daily newspaper said in Bonn that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was expected in East Berlin in two or three weeks. It said Gorbachev, himself the target of domestic unrest, plans a ``massive show of support'' for his longtime friend Modrow. East Germany's sprawling secret police headquarters in East Berlin on Tuesday remained under control of a ``citizens' committee,'' regular police and government representatives after Monday night's rampage. East Berlin prosecutor Gerhard Krueger said he was assigned by the nation's top law enforcement official to investigate the most serious incidents during the storming. Krueger said possible charges included hooliganism, theft, trespass and serious damage to property. He said the government was trying to enlist opposition groups in ``close cooperation'' to track down suspects. The government has pledged to dismantle the secret police, but opposition leaders still express doubt it will follow through. Many protesters Monday night looted the building, carrying away clothing, wine and equipment. Some also broke into the section for counterespionage activities, but did not succeed in discovering the identities of the section's workers, Winderlich said. He put the number of people who stormed the complex at 50,000 and estimated damage in the hundreds of thousands of dollars. The morning after the rampage, East Germans staged ``spontaneous work stoppages'' in several East German cities, West Germany's ZDF-TV network reported. East Germany's state television also reported warning strikes. ZDF showed film of a public transport walkout in Gera, a city about 110 miles south of East Berlin. Workers at a state-owned factory in the southern city also reportedly staged a six-hour strike. ``The people were using the warning strikes to protest against the policies of the Communist Party and its still-lasting influence in the factories,'' ZDF said. ``The strikers especially criticized the dismantling of the state subsidies at the current time.'' The new government has started abolishing price subsidies by raising prices for children's clothes and related articles. The government says apartment rents and costs of other essentials also will rise. ``The sacred cow has been slaughtered,'' the government declared in ending price subsidies, which have held down prices of goods, services and housing for decades. Modrow himself has condemned warning strikes, saying the economy must run ``without disturbances'' to pull out of an increasingly serious slump. Neues Deutschland said organizers of protests like that at the secret police headquarters must accept responsibility for the consequences. ``Responsibility also means means having a clear idea about consequences before calling for a demonstration, so that things don't get out of hand,'' the newspaper said in a front-page editorial. ``The call for `no violence,' which has marked the street revolution from the start, becomes a farce when emotions break through the bounds of reason.'' Opposition leaders issued appeals for calm and urged demonstrators to avoid further violence.

DOC.HEAD: Rain And Snow In West And On Plains
DOC.TEXT: A storm spread rain and snow into dry northern California on Tuesday, while a broad band of precipitation dropped rain on the southern Plains and snow on the northern Plains. Temperatures climbed to record highs from Iowa to Pennsylvania. Northern California was doused by its second storm front since last week, and meteorologists said the drought-fearing region was finally moving into more of its typical wet winter pattern. ``We're into the storm track now,'' said meteorologist Randy Hartley of the National Weather Service. California Drought Center spokesman Bill Helms in Sacramento said the weekend's rain and snow helped reservoirs, ``but we're still pretty far behind.'' Shortly before noon, a pilot reported a funnel cloud about five miles southwest of Hollister, Calif., about 60 miles south of San Francisco. Northeast of San Francisco, 2 to 4 inches of snow accumulated at higher elevations in the Truckee-Lake Tahoe area from Monday night into Tuesday. Advisories for more snow were posted over northwestern California, the Shasta-Siskiyou area, and the Sierra Nevada north of Sequoia National Park, with as much as 8 inches of additional snow possible at elevations below 7,000 feet and up to a foot possible in higher mountains. To the north in Oregon, overnight snowfall ranged from 4 to 6 inches over the northern Cascades to about 3 inches across the southern Cascades. On the Plains, showers and thunderstorms extended from north-central Texas to Oklahoma, south-central Kansas, Arkansas and northern Louisiana. Thunderstorms developed over western Oklahoma in the morning, and hail up to 1 inch in diameter fell south of Taloga and near Aline in the afternoon. Rain also fell from northeastern Nebraska and northern Iowa into northwestern Illinois, changing to freezing rain from north-central Nebraska through southeastern South Dakota. Snow showers reached from north-central Minnesota to North Dakota, western South Dakota, southern and central Montana, western Wyoming, eastern Idaho and northern Utah. In southwestern North Dakota, about 4 inches of snow fell overnight and during the morning between Bowman and Mott. In nearby Buffalo, S.D., 3 inches fell overnight. Unseasonably high temperatures extended over much of the central Mississippi Valley into the Ohio Valley and Pennsylvania. Record highs were 61 degrees at Burlington, Iowa; 62 at Harrisburg, Pa.; 63 at Indianapolis; 60 at Lamoni, Iowa; 71 at Louisville, Ky.; 58 at Moline, Ill.; 57 at Ottumwa, Iowa; 61 at Peoria, Ill.; and 71 at St. Louis, Mo. Wilkes Barre-Scranton, Pa., tied its record of 53. Peoria's old record of 60 degrees had been on the books since 1889. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 19 degrees in Limestone, Maine, to 83 in Naples, Fla. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 3 degrees above zero at Rumford, Maine.

DOC.HEAD: Court Moves Toward Computerized Opinions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout with additional information about distribution system, including AP role.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court took a major step Tuesday toward making its opinions quickly available via computer when it agreed to let a 24-group consortium provide the necessary equipment. The consortium's equipment will be used to disseminate the opinions to 10 to 15 media and legal organizations, which will then relay the information more widely to newspapers, law firms and other consumers. The Associated Press is among the media organizations seeking middleman status as a distributor. A court committee overseeing the project said it had accepted an offer from the Supreme Court Opinion Network, SCON, and soon will begin discussions to determine what kind of equipment is needed. SCON, a non-profit consortium, also includes as its members the American Bar Association, C-SPAN cable television network, Knight-Ridder, Mead Data, United Press International and The Washington Post. The equipment will be provided free of charge. Under the court's ground rules, the parties bidding for middlemen distribution rights had to be willing to supply the computer hardware and software. West Publishing Co., a major legal publisher, had made an offer similar to SCON's. Fourteen groups earlier had proposed separate delivery systems and networks to the court. The court turned down all previous proposals before deciding on this two-year test, which could begin as early as this spring and will be administered by the court. The Associated Press, which was among the 14 originally submitting proposals, intends to receive the opinions electronically and make them available to its membership. The details of the AP plan have not been made final, pending further description of the court's system. The court will choose 10 to 15 middleman ``subscribers'' that, for a $500 annual fee, will receive opinions electronically minutes after they are announced and distribute them. The court describes these middlemen as ``mass disseminators'' of information. The court committee said subscribers will be ``those 10 to 15 organizations the court determines can best provide opinions to the broadest possible audience.''

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Burns $100 Million Worth of Confiscated Animal Skins
DOC.TEXT: Federal troops on Tuesday set fire to hundreds of thousands of confiscated Amazon animal skins valued at $100 million to conclude a year-long government crackdown against smugglers, officials said. Nearly a half-million furs and leather products, including purses, belts and women's shoes, were destroyed in 15 states in Brazil's largest burning of valuable skins in 20 years, said Fernando Cesar Mesquita, president of the Brazilian Institute of the Environment and Renewable Resources. In Rio de Janeiro, troops with flame throwers torched about 100,000 jaguar, crocodile, monkee, deer, cobra and wolf skins valued at $4 million as journalists, ecologists and federal authorities watched. ``This is to show people we mean business and to teach them to respect the environment,'' Mesquita said in a telephone interview from Brasilia, the capital. Most of the skins were confiscated from Brazilian and foreign ships and planes destined for United States, Canada, Asia and Europe, he said. In one raid, 70,000 skins were seized as they were unloaded at the Narita International Airport in Japan, Mesquita said. He said federal police are searching for a Japanese man believed to have arranged the shipment of 40,000 rare Amazonian animal skins to Tokyo. ``One of the problems is that it's sometimes difficult to know the difference between a lion skin and jaguar's,'' said Mesquita. ``You don't know if what shows up in stores is contraband or not.'' He said the burning symbolized a renewed government effort to stop poachers and preserve Brazil's tropical forests and the variety of plant and animal species unique to the jungle. Since the late 1970s, at least 5 percent of the 2-million-square-mile Amazonian rain forest has been cut and burned by locals trying to make a living farming in the region, the government says. In that time, the number of animal, reptile and insect species threatened by extinction has risen from 83 to 250, according to the latest figures from last year, he said. ``People need to know what is happening to our fauna,'' said Mesquita. ``Law enforcement is far below what is needed.''

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Refuses To Hear Harris Appeal, Killer Headed Toward Execution
With AM-Scotus Rdp
DOC.TEXT: A convict who abducted and killed two teen-agers and then ate their lunch was pushed closer toward the gas chamber Tuesday when the U.S. Supreme Court refused to hear the death row inmate's appeal. ``Today's action by the United States Supreme Court makes it almost certain that Robert Alton Harris will be the first murderer executed in California in some 23 years,'' state Attorney General John Van de Kamp said at a news conference. Harris, 37, was convicted in March 1979 in San Diego of shooting John Mayeski, 15, and his friend, Michael Baker, 16, nine months earlier so he could use the boys' car for a bank robbery. The Supreme Court rejected arguments that, among other things, a sentencing jury wrongly was urged to consider Harris' age and mental condition as factors pointing to death as the proper punishment. Tuesday's action marked the fourth time the nation's highest court has acted in the Harris case since 1981 during more than a decade of appeals in state and federal courts. A hearing is expected within two weeks in San Diego Superior Court to set an execution date for Harris, who could be the first inmate put to death in California since 1967, when Aaron Mitchell was led screaming to San Quentin's gas chamber and executed for the killing of a Sacramento policeman. If no more stays are granted in the meantime, Harris could be executed toward the end of March or early April, Van de Kamp said. However, defense lawyers Charles Sevilla and Michael McCabe have a new habeas corpus petition before the California Supreme Court. Among other things, it contains praise for Harris from fellow prisoners and two prison guards, and argues that his progress in prison shows the falsity of a psychologist's testimony at his trial that Harris could never be rehabilitated. ``I urge the courts grant no further stays of execution,'' the attorney general said. ``He's trying to stay alive literally by ping-ponging back and forth between the various court systems. There has to be some kind of end to that. ``These endless appeals and delays make a mockery of justice,'' Van de Kamp said. The defense attorneys issued a statement saying they were disappointed by the Supreme Court's action. They said their appeal filed last November ``raised serious issues we believed undermined the constitutionality of the conviction and punishment.'' Deputy Attorney General Louis Hanoian, who is handling the appellate phase for the state, said there was nothing really new in the latest defense petition in state court. ``I don't believe for a minute he has reformed,'' Hanoian said. ``He hasn't changed.'' According to court records, Harris and his brother, Daniel, decided to steal a car to use as their getaway vehicle in a 1978 bank robbery. They abducted Mayeski and Baker while the boys sat in a car at a San Diego drive-in, taking them and their car to a remote area near Miramar Lake. Daniel Harris, who testified for the prosecution, said his brother shot Mayeski, then Baker. He said they then used the boys' car in a bank robbery. He said Robert Harris later laughed about shooting the boys while eating the meals they never finished.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Expels Peruvian Diplomat
DOC.TEXT: Panama said Tuesday it is expelling Peru's senior diplomat because of scornful remarks made by Peruvian leaders following the U.S. invasion and Peru's delay in recognizing the new government here. In Lima, the Peruvian government said it had protested Panama's decision but would maintain its diplomatic mission in Panama City. Deputy Foreign Minister Juan M. Castulovich of Panama said its decision did not signify a break in diplomatic relations. ``The diplomatic missions are being maintained. They are not closing,'' he said. He said Peruvian Charge d'Affaires Luis Sandiga Cabrera was given 72 hours to leave the country, and Panama is recalling its charge d'affaires in Lima. ``Recent statements by Peruvian authorities make normal relations between the two countries difficult,'' Castulovich said.
