Peruvian Foreign Minister Guillermo Larco Cox said in a communique in Lima that Peru will reduce diplomatic personnel in Pamana City but will keep its embassy open with a first secretary to insure the safety of 12 Panamanians who sought refuge in the Peruvian ambassador's residence last week. Two of those Panamanians are sought by U.S. authorities. President Alan Garcia of Peru has been one of the strongest Latin American critics of the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion of Panama that led to the overthrow and arrest of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and his transfer to Miami where he is awaiting trial on drug trafficking charges in federal court. Larco Cox has called President Guillermo Endara, an opposition leader sworn in as Panama's president hours after the invasion began, the ``Judas'' of Central America. Peru earlier had recalled its ambassador to Panama to protest Noriega's refusal to respect Endara's election victory last May 7. U.S. troops have ringed the Peruvian, Nicaraguan and Cuban missions in Panama City in which Noriega relatives, aides and associates sought refuge. Noriega opponents have been holding demonstrations outside, demanding surrender of the refugees. Noriega himself spent 10 days in temporary refuge at the Vatican embassy before the pope's diplomats persuaded him to give himself up Jan. 3 to American troops. Panamanians granted Peruvian asylum include Gonzalo Gonzales, a close associate of Noriega and his former chief of security, and Maj. Heraclides Sucre, accused of executing Maj. Moises Giroldi, a leader of an Oct. 3 abortive coup attempt against Noriega. Both men are wanted by U.S. authorities. Peru's action in granting asylum to all 12 Panamanians inside the residence drew sharp objections from Panamanian officials. Castulovich said Peru's request for safe conduct for those in the residence depended on whether the government had charges to file. Earlier Tuesday, Larco Cox told an impromptu news conference Peru would give all Panamanian diplomats in Peru 72 hours to leave, after which they ``will lose all their diplomatic rights and immunity.'' The communique did not explain the change in Peru's position, but the aim appeared to be to insure the diplomatic protection of of the Panamanians inside the residence. In another development Tuesday, leaders of the Democratic Revolutionary Party that supported Noriega's regime surfaced to announce they will organize ``as a democratic opposition'' to Endara's government and publicly asked for the immediate withdrawal of the U.S. military from Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Given Slim Chance of Full Recovery
DOC.TEXT: A 5-year-old Centreville boy who fell through ice and was submerged for 40 minutes has only a slim chance for a full recovery, one of the doctors treating him said Tuesday. Police said George Sader was playing with other children on the ice of a drainage pond in the Washington suburb of Centreville when it broke Monday. ``Most of his major organs suffered from the insult of being without any oxygen and blood flow for a prolonged period of time,'' said Dr. Craig Futterman, a pediatric internist at Fairfax Hospital. The boy ``requires quite a bit of effort to keep him stable,'' Futterman added. Among the organs damaged were the brain, liver and lungs, the doctor said. ``We're going to have problems with brain swelling. ``His heart has done surprisingly well, considering the circumstances,'' Futterman said. He said the boy had ``a 1 to 2 percent chance'' of a full recovery. Another pediatrician, Gary Kavit, said it would be days or weeks before doctors could determine the extent of brain damage. In recent years doctors have learned that young children often can survive prolonged periods submerged in cold water because their heartbeat and brain activity are drastically slowed. The colder the water and the younger the child, the better the chances of survival. Adults have lost the reflex that makes the bodily processes slow down. Though paramedics performed CPR, cardio-pulmonary resuscitation, doctors were unable to start the boy's heart once he arrived at the hospital's emergency room. His body temperature was 90 degrees Fahrenheit. He was hooked up to a heart-lung machine so his blood could be warmed outside the body. Two girls with young Sader, Vivian Daniel, 12, and Carol Zakkak, 14, his cousin, fell in trying to rescue him but were not seriously injured, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Colonel, Soldiers Brought Before Judge in Massacre Case
DOC.TEXT: An army colonel, three lieutenants and four soldiers implicated in the massacre of six Jesuit priests were brought before a civilian judge Tuesday to make statements about the slayings. Col. Guillermo Benavides arrived at the downtown office of 4th Penal Court Judge Ricardo Zamora in dress uniform and surrounded by police. He made no comment to reporters, who were kept several yards away. The lieutenants, two sergeants, a corporal and a soldier also implicated in the Nov. 16 massacre arrived moments later. A ninth soldier who allegedly took part in the slayings deserted last month and is a fugitive. Zamora has 72 hours to decide if there is enough evidence to charge the men and hold them for trial. President Alfredo Cristiani on Saturday said the men were the prime suspects in the massacre, which also took the life of a cook and her 15-year-old daughter. The suspects have been under arrest at several unidentified military and police garrisons in the capital. Cristiani told ABC-TV's ``Good Morning America'' on Tuesday that Benavides denies ordering the slayings. ``But the junior officers involved expressly have testified that they received a direct order from him,'' Cristiani said. All the suspects except the colonel are members of the elite Atlacatl infantry battalion. The Atlacatl unit was attached the Military College at the time of the massacre. Benavides is director of the college. Benavides is the highest ranking military officer to be accused of a crime of human rights abuse in the 10-year-old civil war. No military officer has been convicted of rights abuse in the civil war, even though rightist death squads sponsored or tolerated by the armed forces killed thousands of suspected leftists in the early 1980s. The killings of the Jesuit priests shocked El Salvador and the world and prompted calls in the U.S. Congress for reappraisal of the more than $1 million Washington supplies daily in aid to this Central American nation. The slain Jesuits were also professors, the leadership of the Central American University, or UCA, one of the region's top colleges. They were murdered five days after rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front launched their biggest offensive of the war. The far-right had long considered the UCA Jesuits subversive ideologues because of their position that the civil war was the result of gross social injustice rather than international communist expansion.

DOC.HEAD: Radio, TV Stations Suspend Newscasts to Protest Aoun Directive
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-8 `A spokesman...a successor' with 6 grafs to UPDATE with TV suspending newscasts, newspaper editors protesting in meeting with Aoun. Pickup 9th, `The army...'
DOC.TEXT: Christian radio and television stations suspended their newscasts Tuesday to protest a threat by Christian Gen. Michel Aoun to close them down if they continue to refer to President Elias Hrawi as head of state. Voice of Lebanon of the rightist Phalange Party, and Voice of Free Lebanon of the Lebanese Forces militia broadcast a directive from Aoun saying the media should not refer to Hrawi as president or to Prime Minister Salim Hoss as head of government. The directive said Hrawi was merely a ``former member of parliament'' and noted that the general declared the legislature dissolved Nov. 4 to prevent the election of a head of state. After the broadcast, the radio stations said they were suspending their hourly newscasts and ``abstaining from reporting the news until a way is found to cope with the new directive.'' Announcers at the stations indicated they viewed the directive as an attempt to gag the press and introduce censorship. They were later joined by the Lebanese Broadcasting Corp., the nation's widest viewed television station operated by the Lebanese Forces, which said it was suspending its two evening newscasts until further notice. The media in Lebanon reflect a broad spectrum of political thought and take pride in being among the freest in the Arab world despite the 14-year-old Moslem-Christian civil war. Aoun issued the directive in his capacity as information minister of an interim military cabinet he has headed since Sept. 22, 1988, when President Amin Gemayel's term expired with Parliament unable to elect a successor. He later summoned newspaper editors to the bunker of the presidential palace and said he would expel from the Christian enclave anyone failing to abide by his directive. Broadcast editors were not called. ``I am going to apply the law against anyone who doesn't abide by this directive. If you want to refer to Hrawi as the president, you better pack and leave to the other side. If you want to stay on here, then you have to abide by my legitimacy,'' Aoun told the editors. Excerpts of the meeting in which he frequently interrupted the editors when they protested his measures were broadcast by Aoun's Channel-5 TV station. The army command of Gen. Emile Lahoud, who owes allegiance to Hrawi's government, responded by warning the media against obeying Aoun's directive or reporting any of his activity, calling him ``an imposter.'' The Aoun command ``has no legal power. ... Newspapers and other news organizations are hereby warned against publishing its statements,'' the Lahoud command said. Hoss is a Sunni Moslem and Aoun, Hrawi and Lahoud are Maronite Catholics, the Christian community that has dominated Lebanon since it gained independence from France in 1943. Their latest dispute aggravated a split within Christian ranks over an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end the civil war, which has claimed more than 150,000 lives since 1975. Under the plan, worked out by Lebanese parliamentarians in Saudi Arabia, Hrawi was elected president Nov. 24, two days after the assassination of his predecessor, Rene Mouawad, who held office only 17 days. Hrawi dismissed Aoun as army commander and interim prime minister. But the general held out in the Christian enclave and refused to leave the presidential palace. Aoun's 20,000 mainly Christian troops control the 310-square-mile enclave northeast of Beirut. Syria, the main power broker in Lebanon, supports Hrawi and Hoss as the legitimate administration. Aoun's directive described Hrawi and Hoss as ``power usurpers ... and collaborators with (Syrian) occupation.'' It was not known whether the directive also applied to the foreign media. Aoun had warned that it was within his legal power to close any newspaper, radio or TV station that recognizes the Hrawi government. All Western agencies operating in Lebanon have their main offices in the capital's Moslem sector, outside Aoun's power. Moslem and leftist radio stations, based outside the Christian enclave, called Aoun's directive ``an exercise of intellectual terror against the media.''

DOC.HEAD: Peres, Mubarak Reportedly to Meet Next Week
With AM-Baker-Mideast
DOC.TEXT: Vice Premier and Finance Minister Shimon Peres will meet with Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak in Cairo on Jan. 24 to try to break the stalemate in the Middle East peace process, Israel Television said Wednesday. Next Sunday, Peres will leave for Czechoslovakia to meet officials there, the state television said. It would be the first top-level Israel-Egypt encounter since Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin's talks with Mubarak in Cairo in September 1989. Peres aides could not be reached for comment despite repeated phone calls. Earlier, Israeli media reports said U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III may act as host at trilateral talks later this week with Rabin and Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid of Egypt. Abdel-Meguid met unexpectedly with Baker in Washington on Tuesday. Abdel-Meguid said later a date still cannot be set for the first stage of negotiations on the future of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, occupied by Israel since 1967, but said some progress has been achieved. Baker plans to meet Rabin, of Peres' left-leaning Labor party, on Thursday. Peres clashed this month with his coalition partner and political rival, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of the hard-line Likud bloc. Peres threatened to break up the governing coalition if the impasse continues in the peace process. In a policy statement broadcast by Israel Radio Tuesday, Peres listed four conditions Israel should meet to start preliminary negotiations with the Palestinians, who have waged a revolt against Israeli rule in the occupied lands for 25 months. Peres said Israel should agree to participation of two deported Palestinians in the Palestinian delegation to such talks, and should not limit the agenda to a proposal to hold elections in the occupied territories. The Palestinians should consult any party they see fit, he said. Finally, ``We should be content with the (U.S.) assurances we got, since additional assurances would not give us anything,'' Peres said. Shamir opposes the first three suggestions, seeing in them an attempt to bring in the PLO through the back door. Israel views the Palestine Liberation Organization as a terrorist group and officially refuses to negotiate with it. Shamir wants firm U.S. assurances the PLO would be excluded from participation in the peace talks, and is not content with a draft document with such guarantees provided by Baker this month. In addition, Shamir wants the talks limited to his offer of holding elections in the occupied territories. This idea envisages talks with elected representatives over a five-year trial period of autonomy for the 1.7 million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza. Baker is trying to arrange a three-way meeting with Abdel-Meguid and Israel's Foreign Minister Moshe Arens in Washington to set Israeli-Palestinian talks in motion. The question of PLO participation remains the main stumbling block. Egyptian officials, including Abdel-Meguid, denied they had any plans for a tripartite meeting with Rabin at present. Israeli Foreign Ministry officials refused to comment. But some Likud officials said it was ``possible,'' and Israel army radio quoted Peres as saying Tuesday he ``strongly supports'' the idea. Some Israeli reports suggested Baker's hastened pace was an attempt to pressure Shamir. The conservative Maariv daily, the pro-Labor Davar newspaper and the state radio Tuesday quoted unidentified State Department officials as telling American Jewish leaders Israel was holding up peace efforts with ``petty bargaining.'' U.S. Senate minority leader Bob Dole, R-Kansas, on Tuesday proposed cutting U.S. foreign aid to Israel, Egypt and other largest recipients by 5 percent and switching the money to Eastern Europe and Panama. Israel gets $3 billion a year and is the top recipient of U.S. foreign aid. No immediate comment came from Israel, but the TV quoted concerned officials as saying it was the first time a proposed cut in U.S. aid seemed to enjoy White House support. In Washington, the Israeli Embassy issued a statement noting that ``the winds of change'' that blew across Eastern Europe ``failed to reach the Middle East and the dangers Israel faces have even increased.'' ``Cutting military assistance to Israel at this delicate stage of the peace process will send a negative message. Cutting economic assistance at a time Israel gears itself toward the absorption of hundreds of thousands of Jewish immigrants would make it almost impossible to meet this challenge.''

DOC.HEAD: Maoist Rebels Kill 39 Peasants in the Andes
DOC.TEXT: Maoist insurgents attacked three Andean villages while peasants slept, slaughtering 39 people, and army troops killed six rebels who ambushed their patrol, military authorities said Tuesday. The death toll from the violence Monday was the highest for a single day this year. Military officials in Ayacucho, 235 miles southeast of Lima, said the Shining Path guerrillas attacked Acosvinchos, Vinchuspata and San Lucas before dawn Monday. The three villages are about 25 miles from Ayacucho, the state capital. Troops dispatched to the area Tuesday reported that 39 people were slain, including five woman and a one-year-old baby, and 21 people wounded in the attacks. The rebels killed 20 people in Acosvinchos, 10 in Vinchuspata and nine in San Lucas, according to the military report. A survivor in Acosvinchos told military officials in Ayacucho that the rebels surrounded the village and forced people to leave their homes. The military said the guerrillas held a trial of people who belonged to the village's civil defense and then killed them by cutting their throats or bashing their heads with rocks. Many villages in guerrilla regions in the mountains have formed self-defense patrols under pressure from the military. The groups are poorly armed with lances, slings and homemade shotguns. The guerrillas frequently attack communities that have formed the patrols, accusing them of betraying the rebel cause. Elsewhere, military authorities in Lima said army troops killed six Shining Path guerrillas during a rebel ambush of a military patrol in Huanuco state, 132 miles northeast of Lima. According to the report, about 60 rebels ambushed the patrol near Ambo but were driven off by the soldiers. Peru's political violence is rapidly escalating, according to a report issued this month by a special Senate commission. An average of nine people died every day of 1989, most of them civilians, making last year the bloodiest since the Shining Path launched its guerrilla war in May 1980, the report said. The report put last year's death toll from political violence at 3,198, up from 1,986 in 1988. The 10-year toll was put at 17,500.

DOC.HEAD: Syria Denies Soviet Military Advisers Leaving
DOC.TEXT: Syria on Tuesday said all reports about withdrawal of Soviet military advisers from Syria are untrue. An informed Syrian source said Monday, on condition of anonymity, that the withdrawal of a number of Soviet military advisers was agreed on during a visit by Syrian Defense Minister Mustafa Tlass to Moscow last month. Responding, Information Minister Mohammed Salman said: ``Some news agencies have circulated information concerned with the Soviet experts in Syria. All the talk about this subject is absolutely untrue.'' The source said Tlass negotiated the issue with members of the Soviet Union's supreme military council, but the source denied press reports in Israel that withdrawal of Soviet personnel was in the thousands. The source declined to comment on a report in the Kuwaiti newspaper Al-Rai Al-Aam that the number of Soviet military advisers had already dropped from 2,000 to just over 1,000. The 1989-90 Military Balance, a annual survey of global military strengths published by the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies, put the number of Soviet military personnel in Syria last year at 2,000. President Hafez Assad has often stated his belief that to achieve a just peace in the Middle East, Syria must acheive military equality with Israel so that it can negotiate from a position of strength. The Soviets have supplied Syria with combat jets, tanks and a missile capability which includes a powerful air defense network and 18 surface-to-surface SS-21 missiles capable of reaching any Israeli city.

DOC.HEAD: Dukakis Says Presidential Campaign Took Heavier Toll Than Expected
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, in his final State of the State speech, said Tuesday that he hadn't anticipated the damage his presidential campaign would have on Massachusetts and his family. Dukakis said he was ``swept up by the excitement and euphoria'' of what he called the ``Massachusetts Miracle'' when he ran for the Democratic presidential nomination. ``But a funny thing happened on the road to the White House. I ran a great campaign for the nomination, and a lousy one for the final,'' Dukakis said. ``I lost, and in the process Massachusetts took an unfair beating. And I feel terrible about it.'' Dukakis said he underestimated the demands of running for the presidency and managing state affairs. ``It's clear to me now that I underestimated the amount of time and energy it takes to seek the modern presidency. Trying to do two jobs at the same time was more difficuilt and more grueling than I expected,'' he said. ``And I underestimated the toll it would take on my family, too.'' His wife, Kitty, entered an alcoholism treatment program shortly after his defeat. Dukakis, 56, announced a year ago he would not seek re-election. His third four-year term expires at the end of 1990. He also said he was wrong in trying to expand government in his fiscal year 1990 budget, instead of consolidating it and trying to make it work better. The state Legislature still has not balanced the state's $12 billion budget, which remains about $500 million in the red. ``I wish tonight, instead of delivering a State of the State address, I could sit down and talk with each and every one of you and restore the bond that was broken during the campaign, a bond that over a quarter-century of public service I treasure more than you know,'' Dukakis said. ``I know that many of you are angry with me. Feel betrayed. Feel that I put myself before you and the commonwealth,'' Dukakis said. ``But there comes a time _ and I believe it has arrived _ that nobody's interest, and certainly not the public's, is served by laying on more blame,'' Dukakis said in a speech that was conciliatory in tone and upbeat about the state's future. Dukakis repeated his call for new taxes to solve the state's nagging fiscal problems, but said he was optimistic about the long-term future of both Massachusetts and of New England, both suffering economic declines. ``I think we have a great future ahead of us if we stop singing the blues and go to work together to make things happen in the 1990s,'' Dukakis said. Dukakis also made a one-paragraph reference to the nationally publicized case of Charles Stuart, who allegedly plotted the slaying of his pregnant wife and tried to pin the crime on a black man before committing suicide. Dukakis said one of the goals for the coming years would be to help ``heal the wounds that have been reopened by the violence and deception of one man _ wounds that have caused us to look deeply once again into our feelings about each other and our community.''

DOC.HEAD: McCartney Says the Three Surviving Beatles May Play Together
DOC.TEXT: Paul McCartney says he and the two other surviving Beatles, George Harrison and Ringo Starr, may get together again to play some music. Last year in a phone-in radio program with the British Broadcasting Corp., McCartney said the Beatles would never be revived because it would be too difficult to replace John Lennon, the fourth Beatle, who was slain by a gunman in New York on Dec. 8, 1980. But in a recorded BBC television interview, details of which were released early Wednesday, McCartney said: ``There is a chance that we might get back together and just ease our way in with little projects. ``Maybe the three of us will play a bit of music together just for fun. That would be nice. ``It wouldn't be a Beatles' reunion but it would be the three of us getting together again, which would be nice.'' He made no mention of any replacement for Lennon playing with them. The Beatles split in 1970 amid bitter wrangles about money. The interview with McCartney is to be broadcast in the ``Newsroom South East'' program Wednesday night, the BBC said. The British domestic news agency Press Association reported rumors in the pop music world that McCartney, Harrison and Starr could perform together at next month's musical Grammy Awards ceremony in Los Angeles. McCartney, 47, has been nominated for a Grammy award for lifetime achievement. Harrison, 46, has been nominated for a Grammy album-of-the-year award with his group The Traveling Wilburys. Starr, 49, has been nominated for a Grammy best country single award. McCartney is currently on the British leg of a world concert tour undertaken with the environmental group Friends of the Earth. The world tour began last September, took in a visit to the United States at the end of last year, and ends this summer. McCartney's new five-piece band, formed specially for his world tour, includes his wife Linda on keyboards.

DOC.HEAD: 26 Tourists on Hunger Strike to Protest Hotel Robbery
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-six tourists, including two Americans, continued their hunger strike for a second day Tuesday to protest a decision by hotel management not to reimburse them for theft of cash and jewelry from the hotel's safe. ``It's the only way we can pressure the hotel to live up to its responsibility,'' said Rachel Buonavolonta of Cranford, N.J. The group, which also includes Irish, Spanish, Danish, Italian and Austrian tourists, began the protest Monday after the management of the two-star Toledo Hotel in Rio's famous Copacabana beach district refused to negotiate, Ms. Buonavolonta said. She said her losses totaled $1,400 in cash and $300 worth of jewelry. Worst hit was a Spanish couple who had $10,000 stolen. ``It was the hotel's arrogance that put me on the war path. When I complained, the manager told me, `If the money hadn't been in the safe, they (the thieves) might have come room-to-room,' '' she said. Ms. Buonavolonta, 44, who works for a medical equipment company, arrived in Rio last Wednesday and was cleaned out 16 hours later. She said the hotel offered free lodging to the victims until Thursday and provided a nightly sandwich over the weekend. Hotel personnel said the manager was not available for comment and no one else was authorized to discuss the matter. ``We're on strike until there's a solution,'' said 29-year-old Javier Andres of Rosario, Argentina, who lost $300. Ms. Buonavolonta admitted she had cheated on her hunger pledge Tuesday. ``I had a snack after I began to feel nauseated,'' she said. But she said other strikers were holding strong and the group was determined to keep up the pressure on the hotel. Even so, Ms. Buonavolonta said she was not optimistic that the hotel would pay up. ``I'm leaving in a few days and I don't expect to get my money back,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Tells Soviets of Concern over Soviet Ethnic Unrest
With AM-Soviet Unrest
DOC.TEXT: A senior Iranian Foreign Ministry official expressed concern Tuesday in a meeting with the Soviet ambassador about continuing ethnic clashes in the Soviet Union, Iran's offical Islamic Republic News Agency said. ``We believe that a peaceful solution of the disputes and regard for the people's demands will avert any violent clashes,'' Mahmoud Vaezi, deputy foreign minister, was quoted as telling Ambassador Vladimir Gudev. Vaezi told Gudev that Iran was willing to do anything it could to help solve the problem, IRNA said. IRNA, monitored in Nicosia, reported 30 Soviet Moslems swam across the Aras River into Iran Tuesday, defying a state of emergency enforced by Moscow after dozens of people were killed in Azerbaijan in three days of ethnic clashes. The agency reported a similar crossing of 30 Soviet Moslems on Sunday. Gudev told Vaezi a Soviet deputy foreign minister will visit Tehran soon to make final agreements on facilities for cross-border travel between the two countries, IRNA reported. It did not specify a date. Tehran radio, also monitored in Nicosia, said 5,000 Soviet Moslems lined the Aras in below-freezing temperatures Monday, calling for free travel and closer links with their kin on the other side of the river. Shiites in the Soviet republic of Azerbaijan share a common culture, language and religion with their brethren across the Iranian border. They have staged protests since demonstrators rampaged for days this month, tearing down frontier posts, watchtowers and communication lines to press their call for reunification of the Soviet and Iranian Azerbaijans. Azerbaijan, once wholly under Iranian control, was ceded to Russia in 1828.

DOC.HEAD: Two Letter Bombs Found and Destroyed; IRA Suspected
DOC.TEXT: Two letter bombs addressed to army officers in southwestern England were discovered Tuesday before they could explode, and Scotland Yard indicated the IRA was suspected of involvement. ``The public must be vigilant when opening mail,'' said Commander George Churchill-Coleman, head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch. ``If at all suspicious they must be urged to contact police immediately and leave the parcel alone.'' ``Military personnel and those involved in public life who are connected with Northern Ireland affairs are particularly vulnerable,'' he added. The Irish Republican Army is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland and wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland under a socialist government. Both explosive devices, sent in brown padded envelopes, were discovered at the army's district headquarters in Aldershot, 40 miles southwest of London, and they were destroyed in controlled explosions. The army headquarters was evacuated, police said. Two other suspicious pieces of mail were checked and found to be harmless. No group claimed responsibility for the devices, and police said postmarks on the envelopes were smudged. The IRA's last letter bomb campaign in Britain was three years ago when senior civil servants were the targets. Six devices were intercepted.

DOC.HEAD: Egyptian Sees Baker, Claims Progress; No Date Set For Mideast Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 12th graf: ``The state-run,'' with Israeli report of Egypt-Israel meeting
DOC.TEXT: Despite claims of progress, Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid said Tuesday that a date still cannot be set for the first stage of negotiations on the future of the Israeli-held West Bank and Gaza. ``We are still discussing it,'' Abdel-Meguid said after an hour-long meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. The main stumbling block to such negotiations is a dispute over whether the Palestine Liberation Organization will have any role in the discussions, intended to lead to elections to chose Palestinian leaders. As the first step, Baker hopes to hold a three-way session here with Meguid and Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens. ``There is no doubt that Egypt is very much in favor of keeping on with the peace process,'' Abdel-Meguid said. ``And we see that already a lot has been achieved during what I call the first phase.'' Egypt and Israel last month agreed in principle to meet in Washington, but both governments expressed reservations. Israel wants to shut out the PLO while Egypt is trying to secure its influence in the proceedings. ``I had a very interesting and useful discussion with Secretary Baker and we are going to see each other again, and then maybe at the end of the visit, probably on Friday, I'll have something more to say,'' the foreign minister said. Abdel-Meguid met with Baker without any public announcement. The foreign minister was accompanied by Osama al-Baz, a foreign policy adviser to Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. The Egyptian delegation is in Washington to discuss with officials of the International Monetary Fund that nation's massive foreign debt, which the World Bank put at $49.97 billion at the end of 1988. Egypt has been negotiating for more than a year on a loan from the fund. Baker plans to meet Thursday with Israeli Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin. Asked if that session might develop into a three-way meeting, Abdel-Meguid replied: ``I don't have that plan.'' The state-run Israel Television said Tuesday that Shimon Peres, vice-premier and finance minister, would meet Mubarak in Cairo next week. Peres has been threatening to break up Israel's governing political coalition if the stalemate in peace-seeking continues. Baker has conducted most of his diplomacy with Cairo and Jerusalem by telephone. The dealings have left him frustrated and he has warned the parties that problems in other parts of the world were demanding his attention. Egypt, the only Arab nation to sign a peace treaty with Israel, is serving as a channel to the PLO.

DOC.HEAD: Slovenia Demands Political Turnaround
DOC.TEXT: Solvenia's party leadership demanded Tuesday that Yugoslavia's ruling League of Communists transform itself into a loose coalition of regional communist parties. The proposal will be discussed at a national party congress scheduled for Saturday, the state Tanjug news agency reported. If adopted, the proposal would radically alter the traditonal centralized federal party structure. It would significantly reduce the power of the national communist party, known as the League of Communists, and would grant virtual independence to regional party organizations. It is certain to encounter fierce resistance from hard-liners in the Communist leadership of Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six constituent republics, who still favor strong central control in party and state affairs. The liberal Slovenian leadership also reportedly demanded urgent changes in electoral laws to fully legalize opposition political parties. The first democratic, multiparty elections in the 45-year-old history of this Communist country are tentatively planned in Slovenia for April. The proposals came from the Slovenian Communist Party's policy-setting Central Committee. Yugoslavia has not formally adopted a law allowing independent political parties to form, but numerous opposition political groups have sprung up throughout the country in the past few months. Yugoslavia's communists were the first to break with monolithic Soviet-led communist bloc in 1948. But Yugoslavia, faced with its worst economic and political crises, has been slower in adopting the Western-style reforms that have gripped other East European countries. Yugoslav media said an expected clash between conservatives and reformers at the congress could be crucial in determining the country's future. Some media reports said that if the hard-liners prevail, several liberal-minded Yugoslav republics might opt for secession from the federation. ``Slovenia is only for a democratic Yugoslavia based on the achievements of a developed world,'' said Peter Bekes, a member of Slovenia's leadership, according to Tanjug. Slovenian proposals include release of all political prisoners in Yugoslavia; an immediate end to all political trials, and changes in the Yugoslav legal system which would guarantee full respect of human rights. They also call for immediate talks between communists and leaders of the newly formed opposition parties.

DOC.HEAD: Assassins Kill Colonel, Daughter in Ambush
DOC.TEXT: Unidentified gunmen Wednesday killed a Philippine constabulary lieutenant colonel and his daughter while the officer drove the 21-year-old to school, the military and witnesses said. Lt. Col. Nelson Barrion and his daughter, Angelica Jessica, died from multiple gunshot wounds during an early morning ambush in suburban Mandaluyong, a military report said. Barrion's wife, Angelita, told reporters her husband had just driven from their house en route to the nearby University of Santo Tomas to drop off his daughter, who was a nursing student, when she heard gunshots. ``I had just closed our gate when minutes later, I heard successive gunfire,'' Mrs. Barrion said. ``The first thought that crossed my mind was my husband could have been ambushed but I dismissed the thought and went about doing my work even if I was nervous.'' ``Minutes later, a neighbor knocked at our door to tell me that my husband was ambushed,'' she said. A witness, Rey Dizon, said Barrion's car was raked with gunfire and at least one of the assailants went near the officer's car to shoot him at point-blank range. Dizon said he was not sure how many gunmen there were or what firearms they were carrying because he was hiding most of the time. He said the suspects fled in a car. Barrion was the constabulary's narcotics command inspector general but had been on assignment with the armed forces headquarters group since last year.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Says Ethiopian Jews Still Coming to Israel
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Tuesday that ``Operation Moses'' continues and ``I am convinced that in a short while all the Ethiopian Jews will come here, and all the families will be united,'' Israel Television reported. A similar report was carried on Israel army radio. Shamir's office had no immediate comment on the report. In November 1989, Ethiopia renewed diplomatic ties with Israel, severed over the 1973 Middle East war. Senior Ethiopian officials promised to let the country's 16,000 Jews emigrate freely. About 16,500 Ethiopian Jews now are in Israel. An estimated 8,000 of them were brought to Israel in a dramatic, U.S.-assisted Operation Moses airlift in November 1984-January 1985 to join earlier emigrants. The operation was halted after news of it leaked out, to the embarrassment of Addis Ababa's Marxist government. At least 16,000 Jews remain in Ethiopia, which has suffered from drought and civil war. Israeli newspaper Yediot Ahronot said this month Ethiopian authorities were halting the exodus, demanding Israeli military aid in return. State TV Tuesday said, without elaborating, ``The prime minister confirmed that `Operation Moses,' aimed at bringing Ethiopian Jews to Israel, is continuing these days.''

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Undersecretary to Visit Athens
DOC.TEXT: Albanian Foreign Undersecretary Sokrat Plaka will visit Greece this month in an apparent effort to smooth strained relations between the two Balkan neighbors, it was officially announced Tuesday. His visit beginning Jan. 26 comes after charges by the Greek government and Orthodox Church of Greece that the 400,000-member Greek minority in the hard-line Communist state is deprived of human rights. In Albania, ethnic Greeks are not allowed to practice their religion or speak Greek in public. Plaka will be the first senior Albanian official to travel to Greece since Foreign Minister Reiz Malile paid a goodwill visit in April 1988. Greek Foreign Minister Antonis Samaras told reporters he will hold talks with Plaka, ``who requested the visit to Athens.'' Samaras did not disclose what their talks will focus on, but it was certain the problems faced by ethnic Greeks in Albania will top the agenda. The Greek church in December accused the Albanian authorities of killing four brothers of Greek origin after they were caught trying to flee the country. Albanian officials denied the charge, saying the brothers are alive and well in their village. Plaka's visit also comes amid reports of unrest and that special security measures had been imposed in tiny isolated Albania, Europe's last bastion of Stalinism. But Communist leader Ramiz Alia said persistent foreign reports that anti-government demonstrations were sweeping through the country was an attempt to slander Albania. In a speech to workers on Tuesday, he reiterated that Albania will not deviate from its communist course.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Challenge Delay of Civil Jury Trials
DOC.TEXT: A judge's money-saving move to delay jury trials in civil cases has been challenged by two attorneys who said their client may die while awaiting his day in court. Judge James O'Keefe said Tuesday his decision to postpone such trials came as the North Dakota district court system tried to trim $1.5 million from its budget after voters rejected tax increases in a special election last month. ``We're trying to slow down the civil trials,'' O'Keefe said. ``We just won't have the money to pay for them.'' The move by O'Keefe, who is responsible for an 11-county judicial district, drew a challenge to the North Dakota Supreme Court from attorneys for an 80-year-old man with cancer. The man, Bernhard Odden, filed a civil lawsuit in 1988 over a two-vehicle automobile accident that severely injured him and killed his wife in November 1986, court documents said. The lawsuit names as defendants the driver of the other auto, David Paulseth, and Deutz-Allis Corp., which owned the car Paulseth was driving. Odden, from McHenry County about 100 miles north of Bismarck, was willing to accept a trial without a jury, but the defendants' attorney, Donald Peterson, has declined to waive his client's right to a jury trial. The trial was scheduled for Jan. 29, but Odden's lawyers, Michael Geiermann and Casey Chapman, were notified recently it was being delayed at least 18 months under O'Keefe's policy. Geiermann and Chapman want the state Supreme Court to order a trial for Odden, contending their client, who has prostate cancer, may die before his lawsuit is heard. The judge in the lawsuit case, William Neumann, said the cost of a jury trial could force the firing of the district's only juvenile probation officer. ``The district's budget has required that the court choose betweenserving Mr. Odden or serving one-third of the children and youth in the Northeast District,'' Neumann said. ``The court has chosen the young people.'' Peterson described the delay as a temporary inconvenience. ``Nothing in the record indicates that he (Odden) is on his death bed,'' Peterson said. ``In no way is he being denied a jury trial, nor can it be said that he will suffer irreparable harm.'' State government overall has been struggling to cut $94 million from its two-year budget since voters rejected increases in state income, sales and motor fuels taxes in the special election Dec. 5, Criminal defendants have a constitutional right to a speedy trial and are not affected by O'Keefe's policy.

DOC.HEAD: Execution Scheduled for Missouri Killer Who Says He Wants To Die
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The new...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Smith telling attorney not to appeal, RESTORE dropped word `of;' picks up 6th graf, `Last week's...'
DOC.TEXT: The Missouri Supreme Court on Tuesday scheduled a Thursday morning execution for convicted killer Gerald Smith, who says he wants to be put to death. The state court acted hours after the U.S. Supreme Court lifted a stay of execution Tuesday morning for Smith, 31, after rejecting motions by his court-appointed lawyer. The attorney, C. John Pleban of St. Louis, said he might ask the nation's highest court to reconsider its 6-3 decision and will review the court's decision to ``see if anything was overlooked.'' However, Pleban said, ``We are close to being at the end of the road here with the appeals process. I have pretty much raised all the issues I can.'' In a telephone conversation later Tuesday, Smith told his attorney he didn't want him to try to stop the execution, Pleban said. The new execution date _ 12:01 a.m. Thursday _ is one week after the previous date set by the state court to administer a lethal injection to Smith for the 1980 murder of former girlfriend Karen Roberts. Smith is also under a death sentence for murdering a fellow death-row prisoner in 1985. Last week's execution date was stayed by Associate Justice Harry Blackmun until the full U.S. Supreme Court could consider Pleban's motions. Told of the stay being lifted Tuesday, Smith reacted ``very calmly and requested a couple of Snickers candy bars and a Pepsi,'' said prison spokesman Dale Riley. Smith has been in an isolation cell at the maximum-security Potosi Correctional Center since last week. ``He showed no emotion one way or the other,'' said Pleban, who called Smith. He ``didn't say anything, really. He only inquired as to what else I am going to do.'' Smith has had several stays of execution, as he changed his mind about whether he wanted to die. Pleban contends Smith is mentally incompetent to waive appeals. Smith said in a Jan. 6 interview that he still wanted to be executed. The attorney general will fight any request to further delay Smith's execution, said spokeswoman Mary Jenkins. ``Nine years of litigation following the trial is sufficient,'' she said. Bob Ferguson, spokesman for Gov. John Ashcroft, said his boss would not stop an execution. Smith would be the 121st person executed since the U.S. Supreme Court allowed states to restore the death penalty in 1976. Missouri resumed executions a year ago when George ``Tiny'' Mercer was received a lethal injection for murder. There are 70 men and two women under death sentence in the state.

DOC.HEAD: One Killed, Two Wounded in Shooting Near Coal Mine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with description of shooting, statement from union president and names and conditions of wounded. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A dispute between union and non-union miners near a coal mine erupted in gunfire Tuesday, and a union picket was killed and two other people were wounded, authorities said. The shootout occurred on a highway about two miles from the Bailey Energy mine, McDowell County Sheriff's Deputy Vern Walker said. State police said shots were exchanged between gunmen stationed on a hillside above the highway and protesting miners on the road. John McCoy, 42, of Premier in McDowell County, was dead on arrival at Welch Emergency Hospital with gunshot wounds to the chest and neck, according to a statement from the hospital's administration office. McCoy was a United Mine Workers member, and the union on Tuesday afternoon issued a statement condemning the attack. ``As mine workers, they face many dangers, whether the hazards inherent in coal mining, the hardship caused by coal company economics or the threats of bodily harm at the hands of gun thugs,'' said UMW President Richard Trumka. Jim McNeely, general counsel for United Mine Workers District 29, said he knew little about the shooting, but said the mountainous region of southern West Virginia is known for its complexity. ``There are so many conflicts between so many people in that area,'' he said. ``There are creditors' disputes. There are personal disputes. There are a multitude of disputes. It's not just there is a union-non-union dispute down there. ``I've worked with a lot of folks down there who work for the union who have been been stiffed by coal companies. There is a long history of coal companies leaving without paying wages.'' One of the wounded, Darrell Morgan, 41, of Northfork underwent surgery for gunshot wounds to the abdomen and hand, and was in stable condition at Bluefield Regional Medical Center, a nursing supervisor said. Steve Morgan, 33, of Brenton was in stable condition with wounds to the thigh and arm. The Morgans are not related.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Seen More Willing to Solve Territorial Dispute
DOC.TEXT: A Foreign Ministry official said Tuesday the first official visit to the Soviet Union by a delegation from Japan's governing party showed a greater willingness by the Kremlin to resolve a territorial dispute with Japan. But ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe discounted published reports that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ``reversed'' his position on a group of islands claimed by both Moscow and Tokyo. ``I don't think any legalistic talks on who has the right (to the territories) took place,'' he said. Shintaro Abe, a former foreign minister and ex-secretary general of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, met Gorbachev in Moscow on Monday. His delegation was the first from the party to visit the Soviet Union at the invitation of the Soviet Communist Party. In the final days of World War II, Soviet troops occupied several tiny islands off northeastern Japan, the so-called Northern Territories which lie across the Soviet navy's route to the Pacific Ocean from Vladivostok. The Soviets now station troops and jet fighters there. For 45 years, the islands have been the major barrier to improving relations and the reason the two countries never signed a peace treaty. The Asahi Shimbun newspaper said Tuesday that Gorbachev, ``reversing his country's position on the territorial dispute with Japan, ... said Monday that Japan has an inherent right to claim the islands.'' Watanabe called that ``a bold interpretation'' not backed up by Gorbachev's statements. Chief Cabinet Secretary Mayumi Moriyama told a news conference Tuesday ``there has been a gradual, subtle change from the stage when the Soviet Union refused to recognize the problem.'' Soviet interest in the islands is largely strategic. Japanese considerations include many Japanese graves there and the abundance in nearby waters of fish, seaweed and crab _ staples of the Japanese diet. Neither side presented concrete proposals. But maverick Boris Yeltsin, now visiting Japan, offered some ideas at a news conference Tuesday. He suggested the islands be declared a free enterprise zone in three to four years, giving Japan most favored nation status, and then demilitarized in seven to eight years. In 15 to 20 years, the islands could be declared an area of joint management, or free territories not under any country's jurisdiction, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Chamorro: `I'm Not Quitting Race'
DOC.TEXT: Opposition candidate Violeta Barrios de Chamorro returned to Nicaragua Tuesday, vowing to stay in the presidential race to the finish. ``Neither UNO (the National Opposition Union) nor Violeta Chamorro are going to quit,'' she said. ``My spirit is more determined than ever to go forward to build a new republic.'' Chamorro returned from Houston, where she underwent surgery on a shattered kneecap, to confront rumors she was no longer able to campaign and accusations from her main rival, President Daniel Ortega, that the opposition coalition planned to pull out of the race in order to discredit the Feb. 25 elections. ``How could I quit?'' she asked. ``Quitters are cowards.'' Ortega accused UNO of trying to create a situation ``like Panama'' that would invite U.S. military intervention. The UNO campaign, plagued by personal rivalries and money problems, sputtered in Chamorro's absence. More than 100 candidates for local office and the national assembly have resigned since early December. Chamorro, the publisher of La Prensa, Nicaragua's only opposition newspaper, arrived on a private jet loaned by Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez. She was helped off the plane by her son, journalist Pedro Joaquin Chamorro Barrios, and her son-in-law Antonio Lacayo. Her right leg was in a cast and she was using a cane. ``I feel better than ever,'' she declared. ``I am here to continue the campaign. We have only a few days left before victory.'' She said President Bush had called her at the hospital several times to check on her health.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Pleads Guilty in Global Money Laundering Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 10th graf, ```It's pretty ...,' to UPDATE with Kerry criticism of sentence; picks up 11th graf, `A two-year ...'
DOC.TEXT: An international bank pleaded guilty Tuesday to cocaine-related money-laundering charges, agreed to forfeit a record $14 million and to help prosecutors who say the case has ties to Manuel Noriega. U.S. District Judge W. Terrell Hodges accepted pleas from two divisions of the Luxembourg-based Bank of Credit and Commerce International and found them guilty, but has not set a date for formally imposing the sentence. The plea did not affect co-defendants in the $32 million money-laundering case, including top BCCI banking officers and two Colombians the government claims were part of the Medellin cocaine cartel. Later in the day, however, one of the six banking officials was dropped from the case when conspiracy charges were dismissed. The other cases continued with pretrial motions in a proceeding expected to last five months. Under the agreement signed Tuesday, BCCI, S.A. and BCCI Overseas Ltd. are to forfeit $14 million in assets frozen earlier by the government. Prosecutors claim that represents profits made from the sale of cocaine in American cities and laundered in a series of complicated worldwide banking transactions. The banks also are to receive suspended fines and five years probation supervised by the Federal Reserve. The cash forfeiture was the largest ever by a financial institution in the United States, said Dave Runkel, spokesman for the U.S. Justice Department in Washington. ``I think it's a good deal,'' said Bonnie Tischler, head of the U.S. Customs Service in Tampa. But one expert on money laundering said he was surprised and disappointed by the sentences against the bank, which he characterized as lenient. ``It's pretty outrageous. It's just a slap on the wrist,'' said Scott Malone, Washington bureau chief of the newsletter Money Laundering Alert. ``All they have to do is return the proceeds of their crime and pay no penalty. It sends the wrong signal to bankers all over the world.'' Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., said the penalty was legally, morally and politically wrong. ``My impression is when banks engage knowingly in the laundering of money, they should be shut down. It's that simple, it really is,'' said Kerry, who chairs the Senate subcommittee on terrorism and narcotics. ``We send drug people to jail for the rest of their life, and these guys who are bankers in the corporate world seem to just walk away, and it's business as usual,'' Kerry told CBS News in an interview Tuesday. A two-year sting operation called Operation C-Chase began in Tampa in 1986 after an undercover agent conned his way into an international money laundering network. After that, agents helped direct profits from cocaine sales in American cities to Colombia through Panama eventually building a global laundering operation worth an estimated $32 million, investigators said. Some 30 charges against the two bank entities included tax fraud, laundering activities and failing to report currency transactions over $10,000. In return for the plea, the government agreed to waive any future charges against the bank that its investigation might uncover. Hodges approved a gag order to prevent parties in the case from talking to the media, and bank officials and attorneys refused to comment after the agreement was announced. ``I'm going to let the documents speak for themselves,'' U.S. Attorney Robert Genzman said after leaving the courtroom. In December 1987, some officials at BCCI in Panama, which was the bank used to pass funds to Colombia, contacted undercover agents and arranged a meeting to suggest alternate banking methods such as Certificates of Deposit rather than checks to avoid being caught, prosecutors said. Agents said they told high level bank officials the money was from cocaine sales. The agents said BCCI bankers taught them how to use cash to buy CDs, then use the CDs as collateral for loans. The loan proceeds then would be wired into accounts controlled by an agent or smugglers, prosecutors said. Customs agents claimed the money was intended mainly for Colombian drug traffickers, including the Medellin cartel. Altogether, more than 80 people were accused of taking part in drug-related money-laundering schemes in Detroit, Philadelphia, Chicago, Los Angeles, Houston, Miami, New York and Tampa and in London and Paris. The Luxembourg bank is one of the largest privately held institutions in the world with operations in 73 countries. Facing trial is Amjad Awan, assistant division director of BCCI for Latin America in Miami, who claimed he used to be deposed Panamanian dictator Noriega's banker and managed a secret account that held up to $25 million. Also charged are Gonzalo Mora Jr., who federal prosecutors claim was the main drug money-launderer in Medellin, Colombia, and Rudolph Armbrect, Mora's partner. Late Tuesday, prosecutors agreed to drop charges of conspiracy against Iqbal Ashraf, 39, a manager of BCCI's Los Angeles office, after his attorneys moved successfully to suppress statements he gave without counsel present. ``When we lost that, we just didn't have enough evidence left,'' said Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Rubenstein. ``I'm relieved,'' a tearful Ashraf said as he left court. ``I'm just glad to get this behind me.'' The defense asked the court to prohibit prosecutors from bringing Noriega into the case, a move the defense expects because Stephen Michael Kalish is among the drug kingpins on the government witness list. Kalish, arrested in 1984 and serving 15 years, has testified that he secured safe Panama banking for his marijuana smuggling ring in 1983 by giving Noriega $300,000. According to the government, Kalish also met with Awan and deposited an initial $2 million into a BCCI account in Panama City. During U.S. Senate testimony before his arrest, Awan said such a deposit was possible but he had no recollection of it. Awan told Senate investigators he managed a secret account Noriega opened at the bank's Panamanian branch in 1982. Awan said Noriega was the only one who could authorize withdrawals from the account, and he denied knowledge of any drug dealing by Noriega or the bank.

DOC.HEAD: Juror's Illness Halts Deliberations in Pre-School Molestation Case
DOC.TEXT: A juror fell ill Tuesday while deliberating the last 13 counts in the marathon McMartin Pre-School molestation trial, and the panel's talks bogged down on questions about a conspiracy charge. It was uncertain whether the juror would be well enough to return Wednesday to deliberations in the nation's longest, costliest criminal trial. The jury, in its ninth week of deliberations in the 2{-year-old trial, attempted Tuesday to resolve the question they had raised with the court as to whether they could split their verdict on one count against both defendants. The jurors _ who have been considering a total of 65 molestation charges against Raymond Buckey, 31, and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, 63 _ were puzzled about whether they could convict one defendant of a conspiracy charge while acquitting the other. Earlier in the day, Superior Court Judge William Pounders sent attorneys to consult their law books while jurors deliberated on other counts in the case. They have agreed on 52 verdicts, which have been sealed by Pounders. None of the verdicts is official until it is announced in court and affirmed by each juror. No alternates remain in the case, and the judge has expressed concern that losing one of the 12 remaining jurors would force a mistrial. Pounders, responding to a written question submitted Friday, told jurors Tuesday they could indeed split their verdict. The jurors then wanted to know how that could be since the conspiracy law calls for conviction if ``an agreement is entered into by two or more persons with a specific intent to commit a public offense ...'' The jurors asked whom one defendant would if conspired with, if not the other defendant. Pounders suggested telling them that one defendant could have conspired with ``a person or persons whose names are not known,'' but defense attorneys objected strenuously. Dean Gits, who represents Mrs. Buckey, said the jurors should be instructed that they must agree on the identity of a co-conspirator even if the person is unidentified in the charges. Danny Davis, who represents Buckey, said jurors should not be allowed to convict a defendant on the basis of conspiracy with ``a ghost conspirator.'' ``Now we're saying, `Go for a ghost. Don't deliberate the identity of a conspirator,''' said Davis. ``This is not OK for Raymond Buckey.'' Davis moved for dismissal of the conspiracy charge because of insufficient evidence, but the judge denied the motion. Jurors need not identify the unidentified co-conspirator to agree on a verdict, the judge said.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Astronauts Work Quietly in Space
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 7-8, `Meanwhile, flight...', with seven grafs to UPDATE with shuttle crew wakeup. Picks up 9th graf, `The 10-day...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HTN3
DOC.TEXT: The five astronauts aboard Columbia worked quietly in space Tuesday, only occasionally talking to ground controllers as they tended to several scientific and medical experiments aboard the shuttle. Radio traffic between ground and the space shuttle was kept to a minimum ``to allow the crew to stay on the timeline and get all their various chores accomplished without a lot of interference from the folks here,'' Mission Control said. Their workday began late Monday night and ended Tuesday shortly after noon, as the astronauts gradually adjust their workdays forward in preparation for Friday's 2:55 a.m. PST landing at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. On Monday, the astronauts were so busy with their experiments that they went to bed more than two hours late. So Mission Control let them sleep an extra half hour but told them in a morning package of messages and instructions said: ``Your request for overtime has been disapproved.'' Clouds prevented filming parts of Earth with the powerful IMAX camera, but the astronauts otherwise kept to their schedule Tuesday. ``We'll get to bed on time for a change,'' commander Dan Brandenstein told Mission Control. The astronauts were awakened at 9:35 p.m. EST Tuesday with an instrumental rendition of the Irish ballad ``Danny Boy,'' in honor of Bradenstein, whose 47th birthday is Wednesday. The music was followed by a salute from the Boston Celtics' basketball star Larry Bird. He said, ``Congratulations to you and the crew on the slam dunk with LDEF. Happy Birthday and have a safe landing.'' The astronaut corps, which Brandenstein heads, then sang ``Happy Birthday'' to the ``Boss.'' ``I was hoping that flying Mach 25 you didn't age and that this wasn't going to happen this year,'' said Brandenstein. The shuttle is traveling at Mach 25, or 25 times the speed of sound. When Mission Control asked him how old he is, Brandenstein replied, ``Didn't you know this is a classified mission?'' Meanwhile, flight controllers reported that the shuttle continued to perform well. Columbia launched into orbit a week ago, carrying a Navy communications satellite that was released by the crew last Wednesday. On Friday, the astronauts executed a dramatic rescue of the LDEF, an 11-ton floating scientific satellite that is now nestled in the cargo bay for return to Earth. The 10-day mission is the second longest in 33 shuttle missions and is intended as a stepping stone toward longer missions and months-long stays aboard the planned space station Freedom. Medical tests performed during the mission should help scientists learn more about how astronauts adapt to space. One experiment that melts and resolidifies a metal was interrupted Tuesday when a computer showed it had overheated. Although mission specialist Bonnie Dunbar said the experiment was not hot to touch, ground controllers decided to let it have some time to cool as a precaution. The metal sample will be replaced and the experiment will be turned on again Wednesday. Earlier in the mission, the experiment was shut down temporarily when a crack developed in a sealed glass container of the metal. That sample also was replaced.

Business leaders say their young democracy will be threatened unless Panama receives financial aid to compensate for the looting, unemployment and destruction caused by the U.S. invasion. ``If the United States truly expects democracy to flourish, you need a flourishing economy,'' said Laurence Berger, vice president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Panama. ``All the goodwill in the world won't mean much when you have growling stomachs.'' Business leaders say the Bush administration has not yet offered any aid to make up for the millions lost due to U.S. economic sanctions imposed to try to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and the widespread looting after the invasion. ``We've been told, `We gave you your freedom and now it's up to you to do what you will,''' said Alfredo L. Maduro, president of the Panamanian Chamber of Commerce.

Debate over Social Security is heating up even before Congress gets back to business, with the trillions of dollars in baby boomers' future retirement benefits casting a huge shadow over the political argument. Customary political rhetoric has been turned upside down, with a leading Democrat calling for a payroll tax cut and the White House responding, ``No way.'' The outcome may determine whether the massive Social Security trust fund, bolstered by long-range payroll tax increases enacted in 1983, will continue to be used to mask the size of the federal budget deficit. In an era of perennial budget shortfalls, the Social Security trust fund helps pay the government's day-to-day operations instead of building up a nest egg. Lawmakers are faced with whether to take painful action now _ such as tax increases and spending slashes _ or do nothing until the next century.

The U.S. government gives three-quarters of the contraceptives donated to Third World countries, including nearly 7 billion condoms over the last two decades, according to the Agency for International Development. Since 1968, the agency ``has purchased $567.7 million worth of contraceptives for distribution to 75 countries _ 6.9 billion condoms, 1.6 billion cycles of oral contraceptives, 49.7 million intrauterine devices and 16.5 million vaginal foaming tablets,'' the agency reported. Duff Gillespie, the agency's director for population, said overseas orders for condoms rose from 535 million in the 1988 fiscal year to 735 million in the year ending on Sept. 30. He said the increase was due in part to the fight against AIDS, but also to the growth of the agency's population activities. Details of the population program appeared in the fall 1989 edition of ``USAID Highlights,'' an agency publication distributed to reporters last week.

Tourists who ignore warnings not to feed the wildlife are doing so at increasing risk at Yellowstone National Park, where some animals have begun to bite the hand that feeds them. While rangers do not have specific figures showing an increase in animal attacks, they have noticed that in recent years more and more coyotes, bighorn sheep and other animals have learned to associate man with food because of the handouts tourists offer. ``I was riding a snow machine two winters ago, I guess, toward Old Faithful and there was a coyote in the road and we stopped and the guy with me wanted a photograph of it,'' recalled Ranger Norm Bishop. ``He pulled his camera out and I started to pull mine out. The instant I touched that bag the coyote was almost in my lap. ``He instantly associated the sound of that plastic bag with potato chips, Fritos, hamburger, whatever, he was ready for it,'' said Bishop. ``It was really unsettling to me. I didn't like an animal that close to me eager to have what I had.''

DOC.HEAD: NBC's New `Grand' To Premiere
DOC.TEXT: It's midseason replacement show time, folks. Stop grumbling. Anything is better than televised basketball. Besides, there's at least one new sitcom coming up that resembles a good one. It's NBC's ``Grand.'' By the makers of ``The Cosby Show,'' it's light years away from that show's severe case of nice. The newcomer premieres Thursday in the time slot opened by the shift of ``Dear John'' to Wednesdays. ``Grand'' won't bowl you over. But it has a nice, realistic edge to it. Even better, it doesn't depend on a string of one-liners posing as a plot. It gently exaggerates _ and deftly _ both the silly and sad for comic effect. It's set in mythical Grand, Pa., a small town that we are advised, ``prospered and declined around one industry _ the Weldon Piano Works.'' It's what you might call a triad comedy. It tells, in what promises to be a serial style, the stories of three families, all of whom know each other. They're in the top, middle and bottom rungs, respectively, of the social and economic life in this pleasant, tree-filled, fading metropolis. At the top is the patriarch Weldon (John Randolph) with a dim son (Joel Murray) who, having decided to stop thinking, goes into TV, of course. There also is a dry-humored old British butler (John Neville) whom nothing fazes. The in-betweens: Weldon's niece (Bonnie Hunt), who is hot to have a baby, and her late thirtysomething husband (Michael McKean), who aspires to be an executive in the Weldon Piano factory. At the bottom, living in a grubby trailer, is Pamela Reed as a chain-smoking single mother abandoned three years ago by her husband. She has an overweight teen-age daughter (Sara Rue) and a young would-be beau, a motorcycle cop that Andrew Lauer plays with sort of a Tommy Smothers goofiness. Thursday's debut, by ``Grand'' creator Michael Leeson, is your basic meet-the-cast premiere. It tries to get plots going and characters outlined, but at times all this falls flat, usually in the dialogue department. No matter. The uncommonly good cast keeps the show afloat, particularly Reed, a brilliant stage-trained actress. As the tough, but vulnerable Janice Pasetti, her comedy work has the daring and timing of a first-rate burglar. Yet she's equally good with the sad, quiet moments, as when she eagerly awaits the arrival of her wayward husband, only to be told he wants a divorce. No matter what moment is afoot, Reed's character always rings true. Another big plus for ``Grand'' is its sense of place and heart. That's well-illustrated in one scene that makes clear that piano-maker Weldon is a rare bird, a man who still takes pride in his product. His newly hired nephew-in-law notes that Japanese-made electronic keyboards have just about killed the business of making what are called acoustic pianos. He urges his boss to stop making pianos and turn out golf clubs instead. Hundreds of thousands of people play golf, the new executive says. ``Who do you know who plays a piano?'' ``I do,'' roars the old man. And he fires him. You have to like a show that offers such hope. While this ``Grand'' premiere has its problems, it and two later episodes that were made available for screening indicates that this is a different, superior kind of sitcom. Give it a try. You'll like it.

Elsewhere in television... CASTING CALLS _ Bernadette Peters, she of the Betty Boop voice and stardom in films such as ``Pennies from Heaven,'' will play Tammy Faye Bakker in NBC's ``Fall From Grace,'' a soon-to-be-made TV movie about the Rev. Jim Bakker's travails. NBC announced this recently in Los Angeles. And Lee Majors, formerly ABC's ``Six Million-Dollar Man,'' has signed up for a five-episode story ``arc'' in CBS' ``Tour of Duty.'' He'll serve in the show's version of Vietnam as ``Pop,'' a 20-year Army veteran who for various reasons is but a Pfc., or private first class, an E-3, as they say in military pay charts. Only a private is lower than that.

DOC.HEAD: Cheryl Ladd Is Love Interest in `Jekyll & Hyde'
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Cheryl Ladd doesn't think an actor could ask for anything more than the conditions for filming ABC's ``Jekyll & Hyde'' on location in London and Oxford. She plays Sara, the woman Dr. Henry Jekyll loves and the woman John Hyde craves. Michael Caine plays the dual role of good and evil. ``It's one of those wonderful roles that as soon as you go to work you become that character,'' said Ladd. ``You have authentic locales, hair styles and costumes. The clothes, by the way, are excruciatingly uncomfortable.'' Although set in Victorian England, the movie has a theme as contemporary as today's headlines. Jekyll was a man who believed that drugs could alter the way men think and act, for the betterment of mankind, and ease the pains of mind and body. The drugs, however, create his evil alter ego, Mr. Hyde. The two-hour movie, which ABC telecasts on Sunday, is based loosely on Robert Louis Stevenson's classic story ``The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde.'' The story's been portrayed many times on the screen, including Fredric March's Oscar-winning version in 1932. It's also inspired such spinoffs as Jerry Lewis' ``The Nutty Professor'' and television's ``The Incredible Hulk.'' Most recently, Anthony Andrews was in a one-hour drama on Showtime. David Wickes is the writer and director of the current version. Caine also starred in the recent ``Jack the Ripper,'' which Wickes produced, directed and co-wrote. ``There was no woman to speak of in Stevenson's story, so the love interest was created,'' said Ladd. ``Sara's sister had been married to Jekyll, but died five years earlier. Her father, the most pre-eminent medical mind of the day, blames Jekyll for her death because of his experimentation with drugs. ``So, I'm sort of caught between that rivalry. I try to maintain my loyalties to my father and keep my relationship with Jekyll. Although she's married she has a very public affair with Jekyll. My husband is a military officer in the South Pacific and I'm packing to join him when all hell breaks loose.'' Ladd said Caine's transformation from Jekyll to Hyde is shown on the screen by means of stunning special effects. ``You watch him change, and when he becomes Hyde you'd never know it was Michael,'' she said. Ladd, probably best known for ``Charlie's Angels,'' is the only American in the cast. She plays the role with a British accent. ``We were filming one day in a building being used as a restaurant,'' she said. ``There were 50 or 60 people in the crew. People were in and out and security wasn't very tight. All day long between scenes Michael and I posed for press photographers and talked to reporters. ``At one point a girl rushes in and says, `The photographer's waiting.' We go down the hall and pose for pictures for about 10 minutes. Finally, we learned he was a tourist who had wandered in off the street.'' Ladd said it was sometimes difficult to keep a straight face during the filming. ``Michael is probably one of the most innately funny people I've ever known,'' she said. ``He doesn't tell jokes. He just has funny ways of speaking. But I got him sometimes. Once when he was in complete makeup as Hyde and about to rape Sara, I said, `How about a little foreplay?' He got the giggles so bad he nearly ruined his makeup.'' Ladd will also be seen in the spring in the feature motion picture ``Lisa.'' Staci Keanan of ``My Two Dads'' stars as Lisa and Ladd's daughter in this thriller. She was due to begin work on an NBC movie called ``The Face of Love.'' She plays a mother who learns her husband has a daughter from the Vietnam War when she comes to live with them. She and John Ritter are also developing a remake of ``Our Man Godfrey'' as a TV movie. ``We'll play against type,'' Ladd said. ``I'll be flamboyant and John will be restrained. I get to play this wacko character that I've never played before.''

Elsewhere in television: BACK TO ABC _ Ed Weinberger, creator of ``Taxi'' and ``The Cosby Show,'' has two new half-hour comedies for ABC. One show is based on the hit theatrical movie ``Look Who's Talking'' and the other is called ``Honor Bound.'' The former focuses on a young, single mother searching for the right man and on her infant child whose thoughts are spoken to the audience. ``Honor Bound'' is about a young, Brooklyn-born Italian-American who must put aside his womanizing and preoccupation with the fast buck to fulfill a deathbed promise to his father to run the family grocery and become head of the household.

DOC.HEAD: Smartest People Make the Worst Errors
DOC.TEXT: Some of the smartest, most successful business people make the biggest and, in retrospect, the most foolish mistakes _ mistakes of such magnitude that simpler folks find them incomprehensible. Robert Campeau, a successful Canadian developer whose ambition for bigger things brought about the bankruptcy court filing of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., is the latest on a list destined to grow larger. Campeau had what many people would consider ``everything.'' He was highly successful, controlling millions of dollars with which to indulge himself. But he bet it all on something unfamiliar _ retailing _ and in a foreign country no less. The explanation for his behavior, and the many similarly bright people who seem to court disaster, might best be explained someday by psychological rather than financial analysis. But right now it is a major mystery. On the long list are bankers, the people you might think should know better. Bankers repeatedly lend money to builders at the wrong time in the economic cycle, that is, when overbuilding is about to take place. Bankers also are the decision-makers who, at a time 15 years ago when customers couldn't beg a home mortgage, lent billions to Third World nations, explaining to simple folks that ``these loans are guaranteed by governments.'' It happens often in real estate, when successful developers eventually come to love and believe the praise they receive at groundbreaking ceremonies. It lures them into what they believe will be their crowning achievement. So common is the success-failure syndrome in that field that it is all but inevitable that sometime, somewhere, some major developer will be caught bringing a commercial building to completion just as the market is collapsing. In stocks and commodities, successful speculators let their egos talk them into believing they really can see the future, a future that often involves their biggest deal ever, one so sure they cut friends in on it. In business, successful small operators get tired of slow growth, convince themselves that bigger is better, borrow madly and buy up everything in sight. They develop what they call a conglomerate, each part feeding the other. Financial advisers to corporate raiders, dissatisfied with earning only commissions, see the potential for profit enhancement not simply by giving advice but by investing their own money. Too often the result is the same: They overstep their abilities, somehow shielding from consciousness their own fail-safe mechanisms, their instincts, and the years of experience that brought them their success. William Zeckendorf Sr. was a flamboyant and successful developer, famous and feted, reputed to be the man to get things don when nobody else could. He helped put together the land package on which the United Nations stands. For years he was honored. Then he overstepped and failed. Reflecting on his collapsed career, he asked a reporter sadly, ``Did you know they named a park for me in Denver?'' The reporter checked. ``Yes,'' he was told, ``it's about the size of a postage stamp.'' Speculators and investment advisers bite the dust all the time, right after they feel on top of the world. The Hunt brothers garnered a fortune in silver, but lost it all when they sought it all. And Joseph Granville, the investment adviser, was so certain he knew the future that he missed the crash of 1987. And there is Campeau and his backers. All knew that Campeau had little or no experience in retailing or in the United States market, and that the risk was so great the deal might collapse if sales and profits weren't sustained. They knew also that after one of the longest U.S. economic expansions on record a slowdown was inevitable. Or that, at the other extreme, any reheating of the economy might force up interest rates, making debt repayment impossible. Those investors included people and institutions who gobbled up Campeau junk bonds because of the high interest rates, even when warned again and again that repayment was uncertain. It included even the investment bankers who issued the warnings.
