DOC.HEAD: Another Scapegoat Shows Up for Human Conduct _ The `Genome'
DOC.NOTE: With Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: Ever since humans began, they've looked for something to blame for their problems. Adam and Eve blamed the ``serpent.'' Psychiatrists blame childhood traumas. Astrologists lay it to the planets. Anything but self. Now comes an emerging new culprit: the ``genome.'' The genome is the full set of genes, or inherited bodily regulators that determine much of a person's makeup. But just how much is a question that casts a shadow on the essence of humanity itself. The ``mystery of the gene is stimulating a new era of philosophical and theological thinking about the nature'' of human life, said the Rev. J. Robert Nelson, a noted theologian, ecumenist and specialist in scientific ethics. The issue impinges directly on concepts of faith, God, human origins, behavior, sin and morality, he said. To the extent that it is established that genes not only control physical characteristics but also fix certain behavioral traits would to that degree contradict ``free will and self-determination,'' he said. That freedom to decide on one's own conduct and course of action is the basis of individual responsibility and a central biblical view of humanity's special dignity and distinction from other creatures. Nelson, director of the Institute of Religion at the Texas Medical Center in Houston, said in a telephone interview: ``If it is conceded that genetics determines almost the total person, then there's nothing left for morality. ``But I don't think it will go that far. We do have free will. It's the old question of how much nature or nurture has to do with a person.'' Nevertheless, he said the power of the genome to govern human characteristics and dispositions is turning up increasingly, and religious institutions should come to grips with that reality. ``I wonder why moral theologians are not pursuing it,'' he said. He has initiated a three-year project on ``Genetics, Religion and Ethics'' to spur inquiry into the area. A first conference of molecular biologists, doctors, theologians and public policy makers has been scheduled for March 30. It is co-sponsored by the American Medical Association, the National Council of Churches and the World Council of Churches, plus about 10 denominations. ``The whole threat of sociobiology is that we have no free will at all, that we simply do what our genes tell us to do,'' Nelson said. If they ``are the rule of life,'' he added, ``we're going to have a lot of questions for traditional norms. How much flexibility should there be in moral standards, if some behavior is uncontrollable?'' He said evidence is mounting of genetic causes not only of physical makeup and a growing list of diseases and susceptibility to others, but also of ``predermined patterns of personal behavior.'' Some of these are psychopathic, such as schizophrenia and manic depression, he said, but people also may be ``genetically disposed'' or even ``genetically determined'' to alcoholism or sexual deviation. Kleptomania, compulsive stealing, also may be genetically caused, and perhaps even gambling, he said, while ``compulsive inclination toward violent and criminal activity'' is argued among geneticists. All this raises the question of the extent to which good or objectional behavior is ``due to free choice'' or ``due to our genomes.'' Some ``hard-line dogmatism'' in the field maintains that ``our traditional concepts of human free will, voluntary choice, decision making and ethical rectitude are merely illusions,'' he said. To reject this ``extreme ideology'' must not ``make us blind to ... the range of genetic effects on human behavior,'' he said, and the search to understand them is ``as mandatory as it is awesome.'' That search goes on in a longtime tension between two opposing notions of human life, the ``materialistics,'' viewing it as only physical matter, and the ``spiritual,'' seeing its essence as the eternal soul or mind. Biblical insights see humanity as combined body and soul, a ``psychosomatic'' whole. While in the present environment the materialistic theory of life seems to prevail, it is contradicted by ``emerging data of genetic science itself,'' Nelson said, adding: ``Research in molecular biology and biochemistry is rapidly discovering heretofore unknown characteristics of the DNA molecule as the quintessential unit of life. And the new knowledge gives support and comfort to both the materialists and the idealists.'' He said that underlying the chemical interaction making up the genetic unit is the source of energy itself and an emerging theory in physics that ``energy and matter are themselves the products of an immaterial force.'' Thus basically, genetic science may give ``signals both to the consistent materialists and the idealists that they are right,'' he said. ``However, there is a plausible truth in the intuition that human life is an inseparable admixture of material and spiritual dimensions.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush at a High Point as He Begins Second Year in Presidency
DOC.TEXT: George Bush has reason to smile as he enters the second year of his presidency. His standing in the polls is at phenomenal heights, Manuel Antonio Noriega is in U.S. custody, and communist governments in Eastern Europe are toppling. ``I'm finishing with a bit of a glow,'' Bush acknowledged at year's end. But as Bush well knows, presidents before him have enjoyed the glow of favorable circumstances only to suffer the sudden chill of events gone sour. As he celebrated the anniversary of his inauguration, Bush sought to benefit from the political capital gained in recent months as he campaigned to win congressional support for a domestic agenda topped by his long-standing call for a cut in capital gains taxes. With Democrats firmly in control of Congress and in a mood to challenge the president, domestic policy may prove far more troublesome for the president than foreign policy. Prospects are considered excellent for conclusion of agreements this year on long-range nuclear weapons and on reducing conventional military forces in Europe. Assessments of Bush's first year in office were predictably glowing from such partisans as White House chief of staff John Sununu who said: ``It wasn't an easy year. George Bush just made it seem easy.'' But he also earned less partisan praise. Stuart Eizenstat, the Carter administration's domestic policy adviser, said Bush got off to ``a very rocky start'' with surprising difficulties in filling key positions, including a losing battle to get John Tower confirmed as defense secretary. But Bush wound up having a successful first year and left himself in a strong position with Congress for 1990, Eizenstat said. Democrats in Congress were too distracted to make much of any early Bush missteps, as both House Speaker Jim Wright and Majority Leader Tony Coelho resigned last spring under ethical clouds. ``If they hadn't been consuming each other, the Democrats might have treated Bush even worse,'' said Mitchell Daniels, president of the Hudson Institute and onetime political strategist for Ronald Reagan's White House. Bush, after vetoing a $1.20 increase in the $3.35 hourly minimum wage, forced Congress instead to swallow the 90-cent increase he favored. Bush, in this age of ``the extended hand,'' also found compromises with Congress on the deficit and aid to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. He lost a fight for a lower capital gains tax, despite passage in the House and majority support in the Senate, but vowed to win that battle this year. Congress hewed closely to the Bush administration plan in fashioning a multibillion-dollar bailout for the savings and loan industry. They also stuck largely with his blueprint for the war on drugs, although the lawmakers raised the ante by $1 billion. Bush's crime package got mired in the legislative obstacle course, and he has yet to earn his stripes as the self-proclaimed ``education president,'' despite an agreement with governors to develop performance goals for the nation's schools. Democrats who thought Bush would be forced to raise taxes have been disappointed as he held fast to his ``read-my-lips'' campaign pledge. Later this month Bush will send Congress a fiscal 1991 budget certain to meet the Gramm-Rudman deficit target of $64 billion and unlikely to contain the draconian cuts that earned many Reagan budgets a ``dead on arrival'' stamp on Capitol Hill. Despite doomsayers' predictions that a recession was just around the corner, the economic expansion has rolled into its eighth year, with inflation in check and unemployment near a 15-year low. Bush had his share of slip-ups, lost battles and controversies, from the slow-footed response to the oil spill in Alaska to the Tower nomination to the continuing furor over his diplomatic overtures to China after the bloody crackdown in June on student demonstrators. Three times Bush vetoed legislation over abortion financing, even as some Republicans worried that a hard-line stance against abortion hurt GOP gubernatorial candidates in Virginia and New Jersey. Bush, accused by Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell of ``timidity'' in the face of major changes sweeping the Soviet Union and East bloc nations, went to the NATO summit in May with a bold proposal for a troop pullout and convention arms reductions across Europe. Later, he met with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the storm-tossed Malta summit. He visited Poland and Hungary in July and by year's end had signed an aid package of $938 million over three years for the new East Bloc democracies _ and draped a Medal of Freedom around the neck of Solidarity's Lech Walesa. His administration displayed a capacity to learn from mistakes or missed opportunities. If the administration was slow to fathom the gravity of the damage from the Exxon oil spill in Alaska's Gulf of Valdez, it moved with dispatch when Hurricane Hugo devastated Charleston, S.C., and when an earthquake shattered the San Francisco area. In Panama, the United States missed an opportunity by not coming to the aid of mutineers who sought to overthrow Noriega in early October. But the Pentagon's Dec. 20 invasion, the largest U.S. military operation since the Vietnam War, was a textbook operation. Bush provided a show of airpower to help Philippines President Corazon Aquino put down a mutiny and sent special forces to San Salvador when rebels took over a hotel with Americans trapped inside. He visited 14 countries and the Caribbean island of St. Martin in 1989 and is bound for Cartagena, Colombia, next month in a dramatic gesture of support for Colombian President Virgilio Barco and his battle against drug lords. Bush proved himself, in Sununu's phrase, ``the master of the small gesture,'' a telephone addict who reached out to world leaders on a regular basis. That knack came in handy in August when a flurry of Bush calls helped persuade terrorists in Lebanon to lift a death threat against American hostage Joseph Cicippio. Stephen Hess, a Brookings Institution scholar, said Bush had the luck to become president in a year when the Berlin Wall fell and old communist regimes were shaken to their roots. But it was also America's luck that it had a president so steeped in foreign affairs, he said. ``His skills do fit the time,'' Hess said. ``What we've got is a very cautious man. That's exactly what we needed. When you can't predict what's going to happen in the world with any sense of confidence one week ahead, the wise course is the prudent course.'' The Panama invasion also ``reminded the rest of the world that they can't take him for granted,'' said Hess. Bush's public approval ratings exceed 70 percent in some polls _ higher than Reagan ever achieved. His wife, Barbara, proved a big hit with the American public, and Bush attributes some of his own popularity to hers. With the economy still expanding and a ``feast of miracles'' unfolding in East Europe, ``it's hard to be unpopular,'' said Daniels. But the public can be fickle in its love affair with presidents. While Bush stands high in the ratings now, polling experts say he does not command the intense loyalty from a sizable cadre of supporters that Reagan could always count on. ``He hasn't built intensive support. That may come back to haunt him,'' said Larry J. Sabato, a political scientist at the University of Virginia.

DOC.HEAD: After the Euphoria, Romania Has Bills To Pay and Jobs To Fill
DOC.TEXT: Doru Tigau, a philosophy professor, sat in a chair occupied until a few weeks ago by a niece of Nicolae Ceausescu. He smoked an endless chain of cigarettes and talked about trying to run Romania's revolution in an out-of-the way place like Iasi. ``For the time being, this is a nightmare,'' he said. ``There is a leadership in Bucharest that isn't giving us instructions, but giving us a general line.'' But he has ideas. ``Everyone should take as much land as he and his family can work without hiring someone else to work for him,'' he said. ``A hard-working man can have everything, but a lazy man has nothing or changes his job.'' Tigau, 43, is the president of the 24-member local branch of the National Salvation Front, which has taken over Communist Party headquarters in Iasi, a city of 300,000 people on the Soviet border. In his hands, and in the hands of other local leaders like him, may rest Romania's future as a democracy. After the euphoria of victory, nuts-and-bolts administrative problems face inexperienced local leaders like Tigau who are trying to turn an uprising against the leadership into a revolution in every aspect of society: _The revolution has no money, but bills still must be paid. _There is no personal security, but bands of Ceausescu's secret police have disappeared. Nervous soldiers keeping the peace mistakenly have threatened leaders of the revolution as well. _More than 200 Ceausescu loyalists must be replaced in top government jobs in the region. The revolt that led to Nicolae Ceausescu's execution on Christmas Day went off quietly in Iasi. No bullet holes pock the walls of buildings and no memorials mark the places, as they do in the capital, Bucharest, where people fell to the gunfire of Ceausescu's personal guard. Now Tigau is the leader of Iasi, presiding from the long, paneled office where the local Communist Party leader, Ceausescu's niece, Maria Ghitulica, once ran things. Up from his desk and pacing the floor to stay awake, and still smoking, Tigau consulted with subordinates on selecting a new official to take responsibility for cultural affairs and he expounded on the need to put land back in the hands of peasants. Tigau said he never actively opposed the Ceausescu leadership but expressed his opposition in trying to show his students the difference between reality and what the dictator preached. Across the border in Soviet Moldavia, Deputy Premier Mikhail S. Platon said in an interview that contacts with the new local leaders of Iasi showed them to be enthusiastic but inexperienced. ``They are young people,'' he said. One of the problems in Iasi is that the revolution is without money. The hundreds of volunteers racing busily around in the three-story party headquarters are not getting paid for it, nor does the local National Salvation Front have any way of getting money. While willing to help foreign visitors make long-distance telephone calls, Tigau's team insisted that the calls be paid for directly to the telephone exchange in local currency, the lei. So while an operator traveled from the telephone office to collect the money and then put through the call, travelers' dollars were taken to the local bank. There, as under the repressive Ceausescu regime, the serial numbers of the bills were registered before the bank handed over the official exchange of Romanian currency. But lodging in the main tourist hotel, usually the equivalent in leis of about $30 a night, was free. ``You must not pay,'' said a desk clerk named Irina. Why not? ``That's just the new rule.'' After the revolution, the supply of food improved in Iasi. Georgetta Agape, a young sales clerk at a meat counter in an Iasi food store, said she no longer had to experience the shame of asking to see peoples' identifications before she could sell them rationed meat. ``For the first time in many years we had such delicacies as salami, ham and pork,'' she said. But the store was sold out of them by nightfall. Even the unofficial price of Kent cigarettes, for years Romania's unofficial ``black'' currency for the procurement of goods in great demand, dropped dramatically from about 200 lei a pack _ $22.70 at the still-prevailing official rate of exchange _ as Kents went on sale in regular stores, several people said. The old Communist Party Central Committee headquarters is now guarded by soldiers with automatic weapons. Tigau recalled that he and the army captain in charge of security at the revolutionary headquarters were detained as they walked nearby at 4:30 one morning by anxious young soldiers manning an armored personnel carrier. Guns were taken away from the two, and Tigau recalled the young soldier asking the officer in charge: ``What do we do now, shoot them?'' Instead, they were taken to the nearby Palace of Culture where cooler heads checked their identities and let them go. Another time a woman seeking a meeting with Tigau in his office was found to be carrying a knife. Civilians unaccustomed to weapons that had been strictly controlled carried guns in the first days of the uprising, adding to the uncertainty and tension. Mihai Avadanei, a teacher of English and a translator, said in amazement: ``I'm 48 years old, and I was carrying a gun _ and I was ready to use it!'' But in contrast to the heavy cordons of soldiers and paratroopers around leaders in the capital, no security is provided for the new local leaders of the revolution or their families in Iasi. That compounds worries about the 200 members of Ceausescu's Securitate secret police who were stationed in Iasi and who, local officials say, disappeared after the revolt. The army confiscated their weapons, but many people believe that Securitate had secret stocks hidden elsewhere. The Central Committee's stack of books by and about Ceausescu are being gathered for disposal. When Tigau opened cabinets and the safe of Mrs. Ghitulica, Ceausescu's niece, he said, he found packages of foreign-made hose and women's underwear, her Communist Party card, 62,000 lei in checks and a telegram from an unknown source appealing to Iasi to join the revolt against Ceausescu. Beyond the day-to-day problems that take so much of his time, Tigau reserves his revolutionary passion for changing the country's agricultural system and bringing better qualified people into the leadership. ``The only criterion will be the value of the man, his competence,'' he said. ``It doesn't matter if he agrees with us or not.'' ``We don't want to install their terror, the terror of the so-called proletarian revolution,'' he said. ``This is the revolution of intellectual, peaceful people.''

DOC.TEXT: Debt-swamped Campeau Corp. of Canada sought bankruptcy court refuge for its U.S. department stores, keeping open famous chains such as Bloomingdale's, Lazarus and Rich's while struggling to reorganize. The Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing Monday was the biggest ever by a retailing business and affects 258 department stores with 100,000 employees, visited by millions of consumers nationwide. Officials of Campeau's Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. units quickly sought to reassure customers, employees and merchandise suppliers that business would continue as usual. The filing reflected Campeau's problems paying the multibillion-dollar debt it accumulated in acquiring Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988.

The American retail industry, shaken by the financial debacle of debt-choked Campeau Corp., will undergo dramatic change in the 1990s with big mass merchandisers at a disadvantage to specialty chains, store executives and economists said. The days are numbered for giant retailers trying to be all things to all people. Stores without a sharp focus will lose customers while competitors that clearly state their pitches to niches will gobble up market share, according to views presented Monday at the National Retail Merchants Association's 79th Annual Convention. ``In a time-short environment, consumers will be more attracted to stores that have a clear identity,'' said Rosalind Wells, chief economist of the association.

American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said it experienced major problems nationwide Monday connecting long-distance calls due to trouble in new electronic call-switching centers. Half the calls nationwide placed over AT&T's network were not going through, said AT&T spokeswoman Daisy Ottmann. Callers received a recording saying that all circuits were busy. The problem seriously affected telemarketers, airline reservation centers and other heavy telephone users. It was fixed late Monday, said AT&T spokesman Burke Stinson at the company's Basking Ridge, N.J., offices.

Thirty-four countries took the first steps toward creating a new development bank to help East European countries shed their Communist systems and move toward free market economies. ``If we don't move fast enough, we risk being overtaken by events,'' President Francois Mitterrand told monetary officials at a conference Monday. He said he hoped the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development in Eastern Europe could be operating by the spring. The nations are expected to agree to put at least $12 billion into the bank.

The Bush administration is getting ready to offer a new enticement to encourage Americans to be more thrifty and boost the country's low savings rate, administration officials said. President Bush will ask Congress to create a new ``family savings account'' that would allow people to earn tax-free interest and dividends on money that is squirreled away for a specified number of years, officials said Monday. The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the savings accounts would be part of the president's 1991 budget, due to be released on Jan. 29.

U.S. automakers, wrestling with a depressed market, head into 1990 with inventories swollen nearly 40 percent over last year's level. The weekly Ward's Automotive Reports in Detroit said Monday dealers had a 91-day supply of new, North American-built cars on hand as of Dec. 31. Fast Track News in Wayne, Pa. showed a 92-day supply at the same time. Ward's said that at the same time in 1988, dealers had a 66-day supply, one day less than what Fast Track News estimated.

Merrill Lynch & Co. will cut about 3,000 jobs in 1990 that will include another round of layoffs at the nation's largest brokerage, officials said. Merrill spokesman Fred Yager said Monday the reductions would be spread throughout the year and occur through layoffs, attrition and selling off businesses. The firm announced plans for across-the-board cuts in November. The cuts should reduce Merrill's total work force to about 36,800, compared with 40,500 at the end of 1989 and a peak of 47,000 shortly before the October 1987 stock market crash.

International Multifoods Corp. said it had agreed to sell its Mister Donut franchising operations in the United States and Canada to rival Dunkin' Donuts Inc. The deal announced Monday, which is subject to regulatory approval, would combine the two biggest franchised doughnut shop chains in North America, based on sales. Dunkin' Donuts, acquired late last year by Britain's Allied-Lyons PLC, has some 1,600 shops in North America, and Mister Donut has 558. Terms were not disclosed.

American Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, said it is again raising air fares to cover the high cost of jet fuel. The airline plans to increase by 10 percent selected one-way discount fares often used by business travelers, spokeswoman Mary O'Neill said Monday from Fort Worth, Texas. The changes are effective Feb. 1. It wasn't immediately clear whether other airlines would match the increases.

Prices declined broadly on Wall Street Monday as pessimism about the economy _ which sent stocks sharply lower on Friday _ took a further toll. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 19.84 to 2,669.37. The dollar rose and gold advanced in light trading. The government securities market was closed for Martin Luther King Jr. Day, but prices of corporate and municipal bonds were slightly lower and high-yield junk bonds fell as much as { point in response to the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing by Campeau Corp.'s department store subsidiaries. Heating oil futures tumbled as unseasonably warm weather spread across the country. Futures prices for orange juice, precious metals, grains and soybeans, and livestock and meat were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: What Chapter 11 Means for Campeau
With PM-Campeau, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Campeau Corp.'s decision to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors for its two U.S. retailing subsidiaries on Monday means the debt-swamped businesses can operate, and many consumers may never notice a change. None of the 258 stores operated by Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. is expected to close although some may be sold as part of any future restructuring, which will have to be approved by a bankruptcy judge. Under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, companies are shielded from creditors while they remain in business and attempt to reorganize their finances so all debts eventually can be repaid. Many companies emerge from Chapter 11 as smaller but financially sound businesses. In Campeau's case, the Chapter 11 filing's immediate result would be to keep stores open and supplied. Many businesses had been reluctant to continue shipping merchandise to Campeau stores because they weren't sure they'd be paid, but the filing will establish a timetable for payment that could help reassure these suppliers. It was unclear how the filing may affect Campeau's 110,000 employees in the United States, some of whom presumably could be laid off in any bankruptcy restructuring. Immediately, however, the company's stores have indicated that employees would continue to receive pay and benefits and business would continue as usual. Uncertainty over whether Campeau would be able to repay the $8 billion in debts it has acquired through takeovers of Federated and Allied was the main reason the parent company sought bankruptcy court refuge for its U.S. units.

DOC.HEAD: Rundown of Major Dates Marking the Rise and Fall of Campeau's U.S. Empire
With PM-Campeau, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of events chronicling Campeau Corp.'s debt-financed expansion into a U.S. retailing giant and its rapid descent into a financial crisis, which forced the Canadian company to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for its American department store chains on Monday: Dec. 31, 1986 _ Campeau buys Allied Stores Corp. for $3.4 billion, marking the real estate development company's first major foray into the American retailing industry. Jan. 5, 1987 _ Documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission show Campeau plans to sell 16 Allied divisions and cut its holdings of nearly 700 stores by more than half in order to pay $1.1 billion in bank loans used to finance the takeover. April 13, 1987 _ Campeau agrees to sell Allied's 260-store Joske's chain and four-store Cain-Sloan chain to Dillard Department Stores Inc. for $255 million. April 30, 1987 _ Campeau agrees to sell Allied's 13-store Bonwit Teller chain for $101 million to Hooker Corp. Ltd., one of Australia's largest and oldest conglomerates that would later encounter financial trouble itself. Jan. 25, 1988 _ Campeau, still digesting its takeover of Allied, makes a $4.2 billion bid for Federated Department Stores Inc., but the nation's fifth-largest retailing company vows to resist. Feb. 3, 1988 _ Campeau sweetens the offer to $5.2 billion, but Federated rejects the offer as inadequate and indicates it's talking with other possible suitors about a ``white knight'' purchase. Feb. 16, 1988 _ Campeau again sweetens the offer to $5.7 billion but Federated rejects it. Feb. 29, 1988 _ R.H. Macy & Co. Inc. makes a surprise $6.1 billion offer for Federated. Campeau scrambles to respond and within hours makes a competitive offer. March 8-31, 1988 _ In a flurry of complex legal steps and countersteps, Campeau and Macy maneuver to win control of Federated in a bidding war that raises the price by nearly $2.5 billion above Campeau's original offer. April 1, 1988 _ Campeau wins Federated in a $6.6 billion compromise deal, arranged in a three-hour meeting between chairman Robert Campeau and Macy chairman Edward Finkelstein. Under the arrangement, Macy buys two Federated divisions, 29-store Bullock's and Bullock's-Wilshire and 25-store I. Magnin, for $1.1 billion, giving Macy's a strong presence in California. In addition, Campeau agrees to sell Allied's 46-store Brooks Brothers unit to Britain's Marks & Spencer PLC for $750 million, and agrees to sell Federated's 16-store Filene's and 37-store Foley's chains to May Department Stores Co. for more than $1 billion. Sept. 7, 1988 _ Campeau sells Federated's Gold Circle and Richway chains totaling 76 stores to Kimco Development Corp. for $325 million. Nov. 1, 1988 _ Uncertainty over the outlook for junk-bond financing forces Campeau to delay a planned sale of more than $1 billion in the debt securities. The delay is seen by some retailing analysts as a sign that Campeau may have taken excessive risks in relying heavily on debt to expand. Nov. 29, 1988 _ Campeau sells Allied's 91-store Ann Taylor specialty clothing chain for $430 million to an investor group that includes the chain's management and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The sale marks a reversal for Campeau, which had once vowed to keep Ann Taylor as one of its crown jewels, and is seen as another sign that Campeau is having trouble financing its debts. April 28, 1989 _ Campeau President James Roddy and a key financial executive quit over differences with the chairman over how to approach the company's growing financial problems. It is the latest of many departures that undermine the company's senior management. Sept. 8, 1989 _ Under growing pressure because of debts approaching $10 billion, Campeau announces a major financial restructuring that would involve an emergency $250 million loan from Canadian developer Olympia & York and the sale of its prized Bloomingdale's chain. Robert Campeau loses effective control of the retailing side of his empire. Dec. 13, 1989 _ Campeau admits for the first time that its retail subsidiaries may have to seek Chapter 11 protection to resolve their financial problems. Dec. 14, 1989 _ Merchandise credit firms, worried that Campeau's retailing units could run out of cash in weeks, cut off credit on shipments to Campeau stores. With Christmas sales showing disappointing results, speculation grows over how the stores will pay for the merchandise in their Spring 1990 season. Dec. 23, 1989 _ Citibank tells Campeau it is technically in default on more than $2.3 billion in debt and requests an explanation that would show the company's operations are solvent. Jan. 2, 1990 _ Citibank gives Campeau more time to provide reassurances on its financial conditions. Jan. 4, 1990 _ National Bank of Canada seizes 35 percent of Campeau Corp. voting stock after another company controlled by Robert Campeau defaults on a loan. Jan. 10, 1990 _ Campeau's U.S. retailing operations say they have mailed payments to apparel suppliers on time. But speculation persists that the units will seek bankruptcy court refuge. Jan. 15 _ Campeau's U.S. retailing units file for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws, which allows them a repreive from creditors while working out a way to pay their debts and keep stores open.

DOC.HEAD: A Brief Look at Campeau and What Bankruptcy Means for U.S. Store Chains
With PM-Campeau, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Chapter 11 petition Monday by Campeau Corp.'s department store operations in the United States marked the biggest bankruptcy court filing ever for a retailer. Here is a brief look at Campeau Corp., what happened and who is immediately affected:

Once a construction and real estate development company, Toronto-based Campeau Corp. became primarily known for acquiring Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. in the United States, where founder Robert Campeau gambled he could make an immense fortune. The chains operate 258 stores throughout the country, ranging from Bloomingdale's in the East to Lazarus in the Midwest and South to the Bon Marche in the West. The immense debt the companies incurred in the buyout by Campeau, combined with disappointing retail sales, crimped their ability to meet interest payments and merchandise bills.

Bank creditors led by Citibank pressured Campeau last month to show it could pay $2.34 billion in loans, a fraction of its total obligations. Suppliers of credit and merchandise to Campeau stores began to withhold delivery, fearing they wouldn't get paid. Some employees and Campeau stores reported local banks wouldn't cash their paychecks. Many observers speculated that bankruptcy court was the most logical strategy for allowing the retailing operations to remain open while the parent companies worked out a way to pay their debts.

Under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy law, Campeau's retailing units will get an immediate reprieve from creditor bills while a reorganization plan is devised to satisfy debts. Suppliers likely will resume or continue shipments, confident they will be paid. Federated and Allied said the stores will continue to operate as normal, employees will still get pay and benefits, and customer services _ credit card sales, merchandise returns, gift certificates, for example _ would continue as normal. A reorganization plan, which might include the sale of some stores, and all other major business moves must be approved by a bankruptcy judge.

The 66-year-old French Canadian entrepreneur, largely unknown in the United States until a few years ago, made a fortune in construction and eventually became one of Canada's biggest real estate developers. He spent $10 billion, much of it in borrowed money, to buy Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc., confident the debt could be repaid despite widespread skepticism and a mixed outlook for the retailing industry.

DOC.HEAD: Temple Offers To Drop Sea Containers Bid In Return For Asset Sale
DOC.TEXT: Temple Holdings Ltd. has offered to drop its hostile $1.04 billion offer for Sea Containers Ltd. if its target agreed to sell Temple substantial portions of its ferry and container businesses. In a letter Monday to Sea Containers Chairman James Sherwood, Temple offered pay $967 million in cash plus the more than 838,000 Sea Containers shares Temple now holds in return for the assets. Temple offered to buy part of Sea Containers' British ferry service and facilities and its dry cargo and tank container business. A Sea Containers spokesman did immediately return a reporter's call for comment on the offer. Temple's offer was subject to several conditions, including Sea Containers' termination of agreements to sell some of its assets to Genstar Container Corp. and Itel Corp. Sea Containers, which operates ferries including those in the English Channel, had agreed to $1 billion in asset sales as part of its defense against Temple. The company also decided to pursue a recapitalization plan offering $70 a share to sellers of up to 7 million shares. Shareholders were scheduled to vote on the plan late next month. Investors, speculating Monday that Sea Containers would agree to the Temple offer and give up its plan to buy back shares, took their profits while they could. Sea Containers stock fell $7.37{ to $59.37{ a share in New York Stock Exchange composite trading. Temple, a ferry consortium owned by Sweden's Stena Holdings AG and Britain's Tiphook PLC, first offered last May to buy Sea Containers for $824 million, or $50 a share per common share and $80.50 a share for preferred. After Sea Containers rejected the overture, Temple sweetened the bid twice, most recently offering $70 a share for Sea Containers' common stock and $112.70 a share for its preferred issues. Sea Containers turned down the second and third bids as well.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Customers Can Use Other Carriers' Services
With PM-Phone Problems, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: AT&T customers can use the long-distance phone services provided by MCI Communications Corp., US Sprint and other companies despite the fact they are wired directly to the AT&T system. To use Sprint, AT&T customers must dial the Sprint access code, 10333, then 1, then the area code they are calling, then the phone number. ``That will bypass the AT&T lines and put them directly onto US Sprint lines,'' said US Sprint customer service representative Frank Dotson. ``They'll get the charge on their local telephone invoice.'' To use MCI, call the MCI access code, 10222, then 1, the area code and the number. These calls likewise will be billed through the caller's local phone company bill. The access codes work in most parts of the country, the companies said.

DOC.HEAD: Merrill Lynch To Cut About 3,000 Jobs This Year
DOC.TEXT: Merrill Lynch & Co. plans to slash about 3,000 jobs in 1990 _ including about 1,000 layoffs _ in another sign of hard times on Wall Street. The cuts should reduce the total work force at the nation's largest brokerage to about 36,800, compared with 40,500 at the end of 1989 and a peak of 47,000 shortly before the October 1987 stock market crash. ``What we've seen is just a continuation of the staff reductions all over Wall Street,'' said John Keefe, a securities industry analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ``Merrill is a big place. In terms of numbers they have the biggest potential for cuts.'' Merrill spokesman Fred Yager said Monday that the reductions would be spread throughout the year and occur through layoffs, attrition and selling off businesses. The firm announced plans for across-the-board trimming in November. Yager said the firm had no target for the size reductions. But a Merrill official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the reductions would total about 3,000, including as many as 1,000 layoffs. ``We are going through a selective process and there will be selective layoffs as we go along,'' Yager said. Merrill reduced about 700 positions earlier this month by selling its Canadian retail brokerage operation and eliminated 300 more jobs through cuts in its Broadcort Capital Corp. account-clearing business. Since November, Merrill also has abandoned the European commercial paper business, eliminated one equity division at its New York headquarters and reduced trading of British stocks. Merrill has slashed about 40 out of 600 jobs in its equities trading area and 10 of 130 in equities research this month. Brokerage firms across Wall Street have suffered because of overcapacity stemming from pre-crash days and too little business. More than 23,000 jobs have been cut on Wall Street in a retrenchment since the crash. Despite strong stock and bond markets last year, the industry has been in a downturn in part because of an exodus by individual investors and a decline in businesses such as investment banking. ``Merrill is one of the powerhouses on the Street,'' Keefe said. ``They have just about every business there and business is in a slowdown generally.'' For the first nine months of 1989, Merrill earnings fell 20.8 percent to $148 million, compared with $187 million in the same 1988 period. The firm has not yet released its fourth-quarter results. Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., the No. 2 brokerage, said Monday it expects to report a fourth-quarter profit of $1 million to $5 million, compared with a $13 million loss in 1988. Before taxes, though, the firm said it would lose $7 million to $13 million, down from $17 million a year ago. Shearson said fourth-quarter expenses also would include about $7 million in severance payments from previously announced staff reductions. For the full year, Shearson said it expects net income of $107 million to $111 million, up from $96 million in 1988. Shearson in December announced a $900 million recapitalization plan to preserve its credit rating and reduce American Express Co.'s ownership to below 50 percent. The firm also began laying off 800 workers, reshuffled its senior management and slashed stockbroker commissions.

DOC.HEAD: Mass Retailers Headed for Rough Times
DOC.TEXT: Specialty chains will have an edge over mass merchandisers as the American retail industry adapts to changing consumer needs in the 1990s, executives and economists say. The days are numbered for giant retailers trying to be all things to all people. Stores without a sharp focus will lose customers while competitors making clear pitches to niches will gobble up market share, according to views presented Monday at the National Retail Merchants Association's 79th Annual Convention. And on a day when debt-choked Campeau Corp. announced it was sheltering its U.S. retailers in bankruptcy court, industry executives predicted a bleak future for heavily leveraged store groups. Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc. _ operators of many prominent U.S. department stores _ were placed under court protection from creditors. It was the largest filing under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code ever made by a U.S. retailer. Chains run by Allied and Federated, accounting for nearly 260 department stores, will stay in business while a reorganization plan is plotted. Campeau took on a crushing debt burden when it bought Federated for $6.6 billion in 1988 and Allied for $3.4 billion in 1986. William R. Howell, chairman and chief executive officer of J.C. Penney Co. Inc., said it will become increasingly difficult for debt-laden retailers with weak balance sheets to remain independent or even survive. ``We'll continue to see a shake-out process in the years ahead,'' he said at the convention held in a New York hotel. ``The retail business has been hurt by overpriced mergers _ and by the resultant over-leveraging of companies.'' Thomas E. Swanstrom, chief economist of Sears, Roebuck and Co., said some of the problems caused by the Campeau crisis should subside in a few months. Campeau's desperation for cash late last year forced its stores to slash prices to attract customers and boost sales. Competing stores had to follow suit, which pinched profits. Retailers face other challenges to profitability, partly due to weak consumer spending. Forecasters agreed the economy will remain sluggish but stay out of a recession. Robert T. Parry, president and chief executive officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, predicted the gross national product, after adjustment for inflation, will rise only about 2 percent in 1990. Norman Robertson, chief economist for Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said American consumers will channel more of their income into savings. ``For retailers, it's going to be a tough year'' requiring an adjustment after the prolonged economic strength during the 1980s. One bright spot is that general merchandise inflation has been receding, according to Swanstrom of Chicago-based Sears, the nation's biggest retailer. He said sales of general merchandise, apparel, furniture and appliances should grow by about 6 percent this year, the same as in 1989. But inflation will be lower so real sales growth will be greater this year, he predicted. Convention speakers said retailers who want to thrive in the '90s, when customers will prefer to devote less time to shopping, must take steps to set themselves apart. ``In a time-short environment, consumers will be more attracted to stores that have a clear identity,'' said Rosalind Wells, chief economist of the retail association. She said retailers can use a range of characteristics to achieve the goal, including price, service, quality, convenience, fashion, assortment and inventory depth. Sprawling general merchandise chains that don't tailor their strategy to appeal to particular population segments could suffer. ``Today, it is accepted that the general merchandiser is a dinosaur,'' said Howell of Dallas-based Penney. ``The '90s will confirm that the future belongs to retailers who choose a niche _ and then focus on demographic and lifestyle trends within that niche to keep up with the consumer.''

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Filing Doesn't Disrupt Business at Campeau Stores
With PM-Campeau Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Campeau Corp.'s department stores placed under bankruptcy court protection are trying to carry on as if nothing happened and customers are not likely to notice any immediate disruption in business. ``We are open. We are open normal hours. We have a lot of merchandise to sell,'' Chairman Mark Cohen of Cincinnati-based Lazarus said after the bankruptcy filing Monday. Executives at the other eight chains owned by heavily indebted Campeau also sought to reassure customers that they were open for business as usual, and employees were told their jobs weren't in jeopardy. Vendors said they would continue to ship merchandise to the 258 department stores operated by Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc., Campeau's biggest U.S. retail subsidiaries. Campeau, saddled with heavy debts from trying to build a coast-to-coast retail empire, filed for protection from creditors on behalf of Allied and Federated under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. The filing allows the retailers to remain in business while they reorganize. Store officials tried to put the filing in as positive a light as possible. By placing the chains' financial fate in the hands of a bankruptcy court judge in Cincinnati, where Allied and Federated are based, the stores could operate free from debt worries, the officials said. In addition to Lazarus, Campeau's chains include Abraham & Straus, Bloomingdale's, The Bon Marche, Burdine's, Maas Brothers, Jordan Marsh and Rich's-Goldsmith's. The Bloomingdale's flagship store in New York City opened 10 minutes late because employees were still listening over intercoms to a statement from Chairman Marvin S. Traub and President Jeffrey Sherman. ``Chapter 11 signifies a new beginning and is certainly the best alternative for us at Bloomingdale's,'' the statement said in part. ``It provides us with a fresh start and enables us to go forward.'' Similar statements were issued elsewhere. At Jordan Marsh in Boston, Richard Van Pelt, chairman and chief executive officer, and Sam Simmons, president and chief operating officer, said all stores would remain open, merchandise shipments would continue, and all employees would continue to be paid and receive benefits. Store policies, such as credit, gift certificates, billing adjustments, merchandise returns, and service contracts also would continue, the executives said. Normalcy also was the operative word at The Bon Marche, based in Seattle. John Buller, vice president of sales and marketing, said the chain has been doing well and sales were unaffected Monday by the filing. ``In fact, business has been very good. We're having a heck of a January.'' Cohen of Lazarus said he is confident the store group has a bright future. He said all customer services will be continued, employees will be paid on schedule and suppliers will be paid under the Bankruptcy Court's supervision. Meanwhile, Ralphs Grocery Co., a separate subsidiary of Campeau, called a news conference to say the southern California supermarket chain was in fine financial shape and was not included in the Allied-Federated filing. Clothing and other manufacturers who supply Allied and Federated stores seemed comforted by the filing. Several who had previously suspended merchandise shipments said they would start supplying the stores again. ``We intend to commence shipments of our products as soon as the bankruptcy courts allow us to do so, thereby averting any disruption in delivery of our merchandise to these stores,'' said Howard Cooley, president of Jockey International, an underwear maker. Shoppers expressed surprise and sadness that some of their favorite stores were having to cope with severe financial problems. ``It's a sad move,'' said Maria Perez, a customer at Miami-based Burdine's. She said that with the stores in bankruptcy proceedings, she wasn't sure whether she would continue shopping there. ``I've been seeing it coming,'' she said. ``The clothes now are not as good quality as a couple of years ago.'' Other shoppers at Miami's International Mall said they would remain loyal to Burdine's. ``It's a good store, with good merchandise and the workers are always helpful. I hope they stay open and have business the same way,'' said Sixto Hernandez of Miami. For the most part, customers took a practical approach. On the main floor of Rich's flagship store in downtown Atlanta, Evelyn Oglesby of Stone Mountain, Ga., said she hoped the store would survive the financial problems of its parent company. But if it didn't, Mrs. Oglesby said, ``I'm hoping they have a big sale, and I hope I won't have to pay off my credit card.''

DOC.HEAD: Chip Consortium Blames Demise On Lack Of Long-Term Strategy Of Industry
DOC.TEXT: The leaders of U.S. Memories said the planned computer chip-making consortium failed because the electronics industry lacks a long-term strategy to compete with Japan. ``We had an opportunity as a nation and an industry to send a message and we missed it,'' said Sanford L. Kane, president of the now-defunct joint venture. U.S. Memories, formed six months ago with the hope of expanding America's small output of dynamic random access memory chips, or DRAMs, announced Monday it was dissolving because of inadequate financial support from computer companies. Japanese companies now supply about 75 percent of the market while U.S. manufacturers have less than 10 percent. U.S. Memories hoped to take 25 percent of the U.S. market. The consortium was born at a time when short supplies had driven up the price of DRAMs, which store data in a wide range of electronic products and are often compared to crude oil in their importance to industry. Since then, chip supplies have increased and prices have dropped, in part because several companies, including Samsung of South Korea, have started production, analysts say. At a meeting in Dallas on Wednesday, most of U.S. Memories' original seven investors and four potential backers were unwilling to put up enough money to enable the consortium to build a $1 billion plant, Kane told a news conference. The companies also would not promise to buy enough of its 4-megabit DRAMs, he said. U.S. companies apparently no longer think they have a problem with chip supplies, Kane said. ``What happens today does not bode well for an industry that has made a technical decision rather than a tactical one,'' Kane said. Wilfred Corrigan, U.S. Memories' chairman, said the issue for American companies wasn't simply one of adequate supply but more a matter of control over it. He gave grudging praise to Japan's ``coaching and quarterbacking.'' ``You look at a U.S. laptop computer today, and the display comes from Japan, the memory comes from Japan,'' he said. ``The computer has simply become the gift box in which Japanese products get mailed to the user.'' One analyst predicted the collapse of the consortium would have no immediate effect. ``The bottom line is today there's a good supply (of DRAMs) and the prices are low and going lower,'' said Fred Jones of Dataquest in San Jose. Officials in states that vied for the planned U.S. Memories plant and industry representatives were disappointed by the announcement. ``It is truly a shame that the facility plans could not go forward,'' said Arizona Gov. Rose Mofford in a statement. Phoenix, Colorado Springs, Colo., Austin, Texas and Middletown, N.Y., were the four sites U.S. Memories was considering for its plant. The consortium's original investors were International Business Machines Corp., Digital Equipment Corp., Hewlett-Packard Co., Intel Corp., Advanced Micro Devices Inc., National Semiconductor Corp. and LSI Logic. Although U.S. companies in several industries have cooperated in recent years on joint research projects, U.S. Memories was planned as the first consortium to manufacture products. U.S. Memories originally planned to pay for the plant with $500 million in equity financing from chip makers and users and $500 million in debt, with fund-raising expected to be completed last year. The consortium later decided it would need only $400 million in debt and $350 million in equity _ $150 million from industry investors and the rest from outside backers. Computer companies, however, also would have had to agree to buy 75 to 80 percent of the consortium's chips. But at the meeting last week, only IBM and Digital maintained the ``major'' commitment to the venture, Kane said. Kane declined to give details of the commitments from individual companies, however. He also declined to criticize individual companies for their decisions. Hewlett-Packard said through a spokeswoman that it was disappointed by U.S. Memories' announcement and expressed surprise at ``the lack of the support for it among computer-systems companies.''

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Sharply Lower at Midday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: will be led after closing
DOC.TEXT: Stocks fell sharply at midday Tuesday amid concerns about price declines on overseas markets and the possibility over higher British interest rates. At noon local time, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 31.4 points at 2,334.8 points, compared with an opening peak of 2,369.7 points. At its lowest, the index briefly touched 2,332.7 points. Midday volume fell to 258.6 million shares from 207.2 million Monday. The index opened slightly higher, despite a sharp 666.41-point fall to 36,850.36 in Tokyo's Nikkei index earlier Tuesday. But, when other European markets opened lower, including the important West German market, London felt compelled to follow. The downward trend was accentuated by an early fall in the stock index futures contracts, which encouraged the underlying market to move lower. ``Quite a few sellers emerged which was enough to harm already nervous sentiment,'' one dealer said. Also, a rise in three-month interbank money rates, which provides an early signal of the expected course of British interest rates, helped sour sentiment, dealers said.

DOC.HEAD: Bjorn Borg Sued By Former Partner
DOC.TEXT: Former tennis star Bjorn Borg went on trial Tuesday to face an $82 million lawsuit by a former business partner. The suit was brought by Lars Skarke, his former partner and managing director of the Bjorn Borg Design Group, the fashion business which filed for bankruptcy last summer. Skarke, who owned 25 percent of the group, claimed Borg violated a shareholder agreement. He also sued the five-time Wimbledon champion for his original investment, for damages, and for loss of income. The group filed for bankruptcy after quick expansion left it short of cash, and Borg turned down financing offers for fear of losing majority control.

DOC.HEAD: Agrees to Joint Venture in East Germany
DOC.TEXT: Honeywell Inc. says it has agreed to establish a joint venture in East Germany that would provide industrial automation equipment to the country's petroleum and chemical plants. In what would be its third Eastern bloc joint venture, Honeywell said Monday that it has signed a letter of intent with VE AHB Industrianlagen Import, an East German-owned trading company with which the Minnesota-based company has had a 30-year business relationship. In 1983, Honeywell established a joint venture with a Bulgarian ministry and did the same in 1988 in the Soviet Union. Honeywell's initial investment in the East German venture probably will be less than $1 million, with the deal expected to generate about $50 million in revenues for Honeywell over five years, said Mike Bonsignore, the company's international president.

DOC.HEAD: Talks Begin with LTV
DOC.TEXT: Contract talks opened Tuesday between the United Steelworkers and LTV Steel Co., which employs more than 12,000 union members in six states. The current five-year contract was signed in 1987 after LTV Corp. and its subsidiaries sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. It can be re-opened on economic issues this year. ``It's going to be a long road,'' USW spokesman Gary Hubbard said Monday. ``There are are lot of issues to contend with.'' In a 1986 agreement, USW members gave up about $3 per hour in wages and benefits, subject to recoupment through profit-sharing and stock in an employee stock ownership plan. The USW represents 12,855 LTV employees at 18 locations in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, New York and Minnesota.

DOC.HEAD: Coffee Exports Soar After Controls Lifted
DOC.TEXT: Coffee exports rose by more than 20 percent in the first five months after international controls on sales were lifted in July, the International Coffee Organization reported Tuesday. Figures released by the 69-nation organization showed that its 50 coffee-producing member countries, which account for 99 per cent of all coffee exports, shipped 32.51 million bags in July-November 1989, compared with 25.58 million in the same period in 1988. One bag equals 132 pounds (60 kg). The coffee organization lifted its export quota system on July 4 after consumers and producers failed to agree on terms for maintaining it. The system was aimed at stabilizing prices by balancing supply with import demand. The organization's 16-member executive board opened a two-day meeting Tuesday to discuss the impasse which led to the decision. Prices have fallen sharply in the free market, and reached a 14-year low on the London market on Tuesday. Coffee for March delivery traded at $968.55 a metric ton Tuesday morning, $6.60 below the previous low reached Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Accounting Newsletter Can't Print Article About Firm, Judge Says
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for a business newsletter say a court order preventing publication of an article about the Big Six accounting firm Ernst & Young violates freedom of the press. The order, issued Jan. 8 by New York Supreme Court Judge Beatrice Shainswit, bars Bowman's Accounting Report, a newsletter based in Atlanta, from disclosing confidential or proprietary information on Ernst & Young. The article planned for the front page of the January edition was to have analyzed the merger in June of Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young, a story the newsletter broke in May. Editor Arthur W. Bowman instead published the issue with a black cover and the word ``censored'' in bold white letters. Ernst Young alleges in court papers that the newsletter has confidential information on the company. Keegan Federal, an attorney for the newsletter, on Tuesday called the order a ``major First Amendment issue. This is an unconstitutional prior restraint.'' But Carl Liggio, general counsel for Ernst & Young, said the issue has nothing to do with prior restraint. ``He can write any stories he wants. But he can't make use of confidential information in any manner, shape or form,'' Liggio said. A hearing is scheduled for Jan. 22 in New York. Federal said he will argue that the restraining order should be lifted.

DOC.HEAD: More Details Revealed on Big Bankruptcy Filing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 new grafs to UPDATE with info on assets, liabilities and major creditors; picks up 5th graf pvs, The filing...
DOC.TEXT: Bankruptcy court filings released today show Campeau Corp.'s two department store divisions owe billions of dollars to a range of unsecured creditors, mostly banks and Wall Street firms that helped finance the retailing giant's expansion. The filings in the largest bankruptcy proceeding in retailing history showed total assets of $9.1 billion and liabilities of $7.7 billion for the units of the Canadian company. Campeau placed them under federal bankruptcy court supervision Monday so they could reorganize to pay their debts under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. In another development, Campeau's U.S. subsidiary appointed G. William Miller, former Federal Reserve Board chairman and Treasury secretary, as its chairman and chief executive officer. The company also announced that it would change its name from Campeau Corp. (U.S.) Inc. to Federated Stores Inc. The U.S. subsidiary of Toronto-based Campeau operates such well-known department stores as Bloomingdale's, Rich's and Lazarus. The filing allows the stores to continue operating while the company reorganizes. In papers filed in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Cincinnati, Federated Department Stores Inc. listed assets of $6.2 billion and liabilities of $5.3 billion. Allied Stores Corp. listed assets of $2.9 billion and liabilities of $2.4 billion. Federated said its largest unsecured creditor is First Boston Corp., which holds $428 million in bonds. Allied listed Campeau Corp. as its largest unsecured creditor, with $100 million in bonds outstanding. The filing Monday was the largest under Chapter 11 by an American retailer, affecting about 100,000 employees and 258 stores in the United States, and the second largest ever by a non-financial company after Texaco Inc., which sought court protection in April 1987. Miller, currently chairman of G. William Miller & Co. Inc., a Washington-based merchant banking firm, has served on the boards of Campeau, Federated and Allied since 1987. He originally joined Federated's board in 1976 but resigned two years later when he became the Fed chairman. From 1979 to 1981, Miller served as Treasury Secretary under President Carter. Miller was re-elected to the Federated board in 1981 and after Campeau bought the retailing company he joined the boards of Campeau and Allied. Campeau also announced other changes regarding senior management at its U.S. operations, including the resignation of the chairman of its retailers. Ronald W. Tysoe, currently president of both Campeau Corp. and Campeau (U.S.), will continue as president of the newly renamed Federated holding company but he will phase out his responsibilities at the Canadian parent. John W. Burden III, chairman and chief executive officer of Federated and Allied, has quit effective Jan. 31 ``to pursue other interests,'' Campeau said. The company said it expects to name a successor soon to run the retailing operations. James M. Zimmerman will remain as president and chief operating officer of Federated and Allied. The management teams at all department store chains will continue in place. The management at Ralphs Grocery Co., a southern California supermarket chain owned by Campeau that was not part of the bankruptcy court filing, will not be changed, Campeau said. Miller, 64, steps into a job created when Campeau last week split its U.S. operations from the parent company, giving them operating independence. ``The company is now positioned with a strong and experienced management team at all levels to manage what has always been a highly successful group of American retail businesses _ with a new name that reflects our retailing orientation,'' he said in a news release. Tysoe said he has been asked by Miller to focus full time on restructuring the retailers. The decision to seek court protection was made late Sunday by the boards of Campeau and the two divisions and reflected Campeau's inability to pay off $8 billion in debt, much of it resulting from the $3.4 billion acquisition of Allied in 1986 and the $6.6 billion purchase of Federated in 1988. ``The decision to seek Chapter 11 relief was based on a conclusion that action was required at this time in order to preserve the operations' strength and assets of the two department store companies while the corporate debt is restructured,'' Campeau said in a statement Monday. Under Chapter 11, the companies get a reprieve from creditors and can continue operating while reorganizing their finances. But all decisions regarding the companies must be approved by a bankruptcy judge. Federated's stores include Abraham and Straus and Bloomingdale's of New York, Burdine's of Miami, Lazarus of Cincinnati and Rich's of Atlanta. Allied's stores include The Bon Marche of Seattle, Jordan Marsh of Boston, Maas Brothers of Tampa and Stern's of Paramus, N.J.

DOC.HEAD: Junk Bond Prices Fall After Campeau Filing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with prices falling further
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Campeau
DOC.TEXT: Junk bond prices fell further today in reaction to the bankruptcy court filing by two Campeau Corp. divisions and early declines in the stock and government bond markets. Prices of high-yield debt securities were quoted down about ] point to { point on average, or about $3.75 to $5 per $1,000 in face value. Junk bonds fell slightly Monday after the Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc. sought bankruptcy court protection. But traders said reaction was muted because of slow trading on the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday and because the filing was expected. When the stock market and government bond markets opened sharply lower today, junk bonds followed suit, traders said. ``A lot of the better-quality names have been quoted down,'' said Joan Greenberg, manager of the high-yield group at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``It wasn't very surprising considering the government securities market and the stock market opened down.'' She said today's early declines were not entirely a reaction to Campeau but added, ``What's scary now is not that Campeau filed but the publicizing of how much unsecured debt is outstanding. ... The Campeau story is definitely right up front in everybody's minds.'' Traders said most high-yield issues fell about \ point to { point Monday, or $2.50 to $5 for every $1,000 in face value of the bond. Widely held 13.71 percent RJR Holdings Capital Corp. convertible bonds due in 2009 were down about | point at 90\ after falling about ~ point on Monday. RJR 13.71 percent debentures of 2007 were at 78\, down { point. The two units of Toronto-based Campeau operate 258 stores in the United States, including Bloomingdale's, Jordan Marsh, Abraham & Straus, Lazarus and Stern's. Allied's 10.5 percent bonds were quoted steady with Monday at about 42, while its 11.5 percent bonds were quoted in a wide range, on average near Monday's close at 11. Federated's 16 percent bonds due 2000 were down about { point to 11{. Bonds of Ralphs Grocery Co., a Campeau-owned southern California chain held steady this morning at 95 after falling about 3 points Monday. Ralphs was not included in the bankruptcy filing but traders said there is concern bondholders may seek to claim they were defrauded because of Campeau's troubles. Among other notable issues, R.H. Macy & Co. 14{ percent bonds due 1998 were quoted at 94} down } point. High-yield bonds _ called junk because they are rated below investment grade _ also fell sharply on Friday in tandem with a sharp drop in the stock market. Monday's decline was the junk market's fourth straight. The $210 billion high-yield bond market has slumped since Campeau's surprise disclosure of liquidity problems last September. Prices have not recovered entirely and new issues of junk bonds have been squelched because of the selloff. For the 1989 fourth quarter, analysts said, high-yield bonds showed a total return of negative 4 percent. Moody's Investors Service Inc. said it lowered the ratings on all Allied and Federated subordinated debt because of the filing. Moody's said about $2.2 billion in Federated and $1.6 billion in Allied debt securities were affected. It said the companies were in default on a $2.34 billion bank loan. Due to the bankruptcy filing, the Allied and Federated bonds were trading ``flat,'' that is, without accrued interest. Junk bonds normally pay interest twice a year. In flat trading, sellers do not receive interest accrued from the last payment and buyers do not have to pay it.
