DOC.HEAD: Business Inventories, Sales, Up In November
DOC.TEXT: Business sales and inventories both rose in November, the government said Tuesday, but economists noted that slower sales the following month could worsen the December situation. The Commerce Department said inventories rose 0.5 percent to a seasonally adjusted $796.8 billion in November after rising 0.3 percent a month earlier. The November figure was slightly higher than the 0.4 percent increase originally reported. Business sales were up 0.7 percent to a seasonally adjusted $523.6 billion, after falling a revised 0.5 percent in October. That revision compared with the initially reported 0.7 percent drop. Inventories often rise during periods of slow economic growth and could result in production cutbacks and loss of jobs as businesses try to reduce the accumulation of goods on shelves and backlots. Such activity is taking place in the auto industry, for example, as carmakers try to shrink bloated inventories with production cuts and layoffs. ``Retail sales were relatively modest in December,'' said Evelina Tainer, senior domestic economist for the First National Bank of Chicago. ``Autos were still weak. So there's a potential for the (inventories-to-sales ratio) number to worsen.'' The November business activity caused the ratio of inventories to sales to decline slightly to 1.52, meaning it would take 1.52 months to exhaust inventories at the November pace. The ratio was 1.53 in October. Ms. Tainer did not consider the ratio to be alarming, saying it was relatively low compared to 10 years ago. ``Producers used to keep more inventories and I think they have become leaner,'' she said. ``So we're not in the same problem area that we would have been several years ago.'' Ms. Tainer said the inventory problems that do exist are concentrated in certain areas such as automobiles. Chrysler Co., Ford Motor Co. and General Motors Corp. all have announced temporary layoffs to reduce their vehicle inventories. Mazda Motor Corp. of Japan also is trimming production at its U.S. plant this month. Retail inventories rose 0.6 percent in November, while sales increased 0.5 percent. The Commerce Department reported last week that retail sales gained only 0.2 percent in December. Inventories at the manufacturing level, which represent about 45 percent of the total, rose 0.3 percent. Manufacturing sales increased 0.5 percent. Wholesalers' inventories advanced 0.5 percent, while their sales jumped 1.2 percent. Overall, inventories were 6.8 percent above those of a year ago, while sales were up 4.4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Offer $500 Million Assistance to Hungary
DOC.TEXT: Japan offered Tuesday to extend Hungary an assistance package that includes $500 million in credit plus technology and managerial expertise to help the country with economic reforms. Shigeo Takenaka, an aide to Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, made the announcement after an initial round of talks between Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu with his Hungarian counterpart Miklos Nemeth. Kaifu arrived in Budapest Monday on the last segment of a seven-nation 10-day tour of Europe. He returns home Wednesday. The credit package from the Japanese Export-Import bank is to be distributed over three years and is designed to promote economic development in Hungary, Takenaka said. The terms of the credits are to be discussed later.

DOC.HEAD: Say Some Foreign Majority Ownership Allowable
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's Economics Minister on Tuesday conceded two more exceptions to joint-venture regulations that will allow numerous West German firms to hold majority shares. Economics Minister Christa Luft told reporters after her talks with West German counterpart Helmut Haussmann that small- and medium-sized companies, as well as those large firms with ``superb know-how,'' will be allowed to become majority owners. The East German Parliament approved draft regulations on Friday that established 49 percent as the upper limit for foreign ownership of enterprises in East Germany. East Germans fear that allowing foreign companies _ especially wealthy and influential West German industrial giants _ to hold majority ownership could lead to a ``buyout'' of the economically troubled state struggling toward democracy. But West German firms have rejected the 49 percent limit as too restrictive and insufficient to attract the major infusions of capital East Germany needs to turn around its stagnant economy. Ms. Luft said East Germany plans to retain the 49 percent ceiling ``in principle,'' but that exceptions will be made. East German openness to exceptions for firms with special technical know-how appears to open a wide door for West Germany's numerous aerospace, computer, chemical and engineering firms that are seeking to establish themselves in the reform-minded nation next door. Hundreds of small, family-run companies have expressed interest in setting up inter-German ventures, but only on condition that they own controlling interest in the companies. An influential delegation of West German industrialists traveled to East Berlin over the weekend for talks with Ms. Luft, Communist Premier Hans Modrow and other officials and political leaders for talks on how to boost business ties. Edzard Reuter, chairman of the Daimler-Benz conglomerate that is West Germany's largest company and one of the biggest defense and technology firms in the world, told reporters after the visit that the 49 percent limit was ``businesswise and psychologically wrong.'' Ms. Luft and Haussmann said they made good progress in closing gaps between East German and West German economic cooperation during their talks in Bonn. They announced that a joint committee had been established to work out the details of an investment protection agreement.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Long-Distance Calls Were Hung up Nine Hours
Precede NEW YORK
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 13 new grafs to UPDATE with morning news briefing; Picks up 10th graf pvs, About half ...
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. has traced a computer software failure that blocked millions of long-distance calls on Monday to a backup system in New York, a top company official said today. Chairman Robert E. Allen also said AT&T plans to offer a discount day for businesses who may have lost money because customers were unable to do business by telephone. Allen made the comments at a late-morning news conference at the company's Network Operations Center in Bedminster, N.J. The company said Monday's outage, which blocked long-distance calls nationwide for about nine hours, was its most widespread ever, but the Martin Luther King Day holiday prevented the impact from being worse. AT&T said it discovered the problem in mid-afternoon and corrected it shortly before midnight, well before the start of the regular business schedule today. The company said the system was operating normally today as business hours began, although AT&T did not know exactly what went wrong Monday. ``We're seeing traffic starting to build up and the network is operating flawlessly,'' spokeswoman Daisy Ottmann said at mid-morning. At the news conference, Allen said the company did not believe the problem was rooted in a computer virus, but workers were still investigating that possibility. ``It does not act like a computer bug,'' Allen said. He said the proposed special discount calling day required approval from the Federal Communications Commission. He said AT&T had no liability insurance for regular long-distance phone lines, but would be covered for any damages resulting from loss of business on its toll-free 800 system. Ms. Ottmann said the company had recently installed new software in its system and that the trouble was somewhere within the software. AT&T removed the new software late Monday, and with it the problems that plagued the long-distance network. The removal of the new software ``didn't take away any processing power of the network,'' Ms. Ottmann said. About half the long-distance callers on the AT&T network got a busy signal or a recording saying all circuits were busy, the company said. Arizona Telemarketing Inc. of Phoenix, which places 4,000 to 9,000 calls a day, gave its 40 employees an unexpected holiday in the afternoon. ``We had to close the place down,'' said Miriam Benson, company president. Janice Falwin, a Montclair, N.J., graphics designer who relies on her fax machine to present projects to clients in Los Angeles, New York and Boston, said the outage caused her to miss a deadline, and that could cost her $1,000. ``Deadlines are my life. If I miss a deadline, I don't eat. The telephone is like a lifeline to me,'' said Falwin, who works out of her house. On an average business day, 80 million calls go through the AT&T system, said Sally Sherwood, another AT&T spokeswoman. She said she did not know how many calls were attempted Monday or how many actually went through. The problem apparently began in one of the company's electronic switching centers, which transfer calls from one line of the long-distance network to another, Ms. Ottmann said. It then spread to the other 100 or so switching centers, she said. ``It's like striking the church bell in a steeple and all the other bells resonate _ this is a vibrating or resonating problem,'' she said. AT&T controls about 70 percent of the long-distance market. Its major competitors, MCI Communications Corp. and US Sprint, reported no problems. AT&T customers are able to use the MCI and Sprint systems by dialing special access codes. However, AT&T operators were forbidden, even when asked, to give out this information for competitive reasons, Ms. Sherwood said. Ms. Sherwood said experts from Bell Laboratories, AT&T's research arm, assisted in fixing the problem at the company's Network Operations Center in Bedminster, N.J., the hub of its phone system. ``Certainly `intense' would an accurate description of the activity,'' she said. A technician at the operations center who spoke on condition of anonymity described the scene to The New York Times as ``chaotic and almost out of control'' as engineers worked on the problem. Past problems have been limited to a certain region. AT&T began installing the electronic call-switching gear in 1987, Ms. Sherwood said. ``Nothing like this has happened before,'' she said. The company said the problem affected all its phone lines, including toll-free 800 numbers and overseas calls, except for private lines that companies lease between their offices or plants. Some calls were deliberately blocked by AT&T to enable it to isolate the problem, it said. Hotel and airline reservations offices were among hard hit businesses. Cindy Sheffield, phone systems manager for the Marriott hotels reservation office in Omaha, Neb., said the problem was ``devastating'' because her office wasn't receiving calls from customers. The office received only 10 percent of its normal call volume, she said. American Airlines spokeswoman Mary O'Neill in Fort Worth, Texas, said the carrier was experiencing about two-thirds fewer calls than normal on its reservation lines. Trans Mid-America, an Omaha-based marketing company that sells temporary motor vehicle licenses, couldn't make any long distance or 800-number calls, said Florence Waymire, a company vice president. ``We're dead in the water here today,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates thruout with closing figures
DOC.TEXT: Share prices fell sharply Tuesday on London's Stock Exchange, weighed down by declines on stock markets in Japan and the United States and fears that British interest rates may be headed higher. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index fell 17.1 points, or 0.7 percent, to 2,349.1. It had risen as high as 2,369.7 points early in the session, and its low for the day was 2,329.5. The Financial Times 30-share index fell 21.2 points to close at 1,875.7. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 11.33 points to close at 1,281.59. Volume amounted to 479.9 million shares, compared with 360.7 million shares Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher in Europe, Gold Gains
DOC.NOTE: Eds: AMer planned by 5:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed higher against all major currencies except the West German mark in European trading Tuesday while gold prices also advanced. Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar opened on a strong note because of the political tensions in the Soviet Union, but trading turned choppy in the afternoon. The mark has benefited the most from the upheavals in Eastern Europe as investors looked forward to large-scale increases in West German trade and investment. However, the latest turmoil, with riots in the Caucasus and rising unrest in East Berlin, persuaded investors to sell marks and buy dollars. The dollar faltered against the West German currency Tuesday when it reached 1.7125 marks. It eventually closed at 1.6945 marks, down from 1.6965 late Monday. In London, one British pound cost $1.6560 late Tuesday, compared to late Monday's $1.6620. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.5160 Swiss francs, up from 1.5120; 5.7635 French francs, up from 5.7625; 1.9195 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9015; 1,261.50 Italian lire, up from 1,261.375; and 1.1648 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1622. Earlier in Tokyo the dollar rose to 145.75 Japanese yen from the late London price of 145.50 yen on Monday when Tokyo markets were closed. In London, the dollar was unchanged against the yen. Gold bullion prices moved higher and dealers said concern about declines on world stock markets had raised investor interest in gold. Gold closed in London, the major market, at a bid price of $413.25 a troy ounce, up from $412 late Monday, and in Zurich at $413 bid, up from $412.40. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at a bid of $415.45, up from $413.95. Silver bullion traded late in London at a bid $5.25 a troy ounce, up from $5.24.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Washes Buyers From Soybean Futures
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices tumbled Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as reports of rain in key growing areas drove buyers from the market. Grain futures closed mostly lower. The soybean market opened lower following reports of rain overnight in southern Brazil, a major soybean-producing region that had been suffering from unusually dry weather until last weekend. Rain also fell overnight and Tuesday in the U.S. corn and soybean belt, spurring selling of futures contracts, especially those for delivery of soybeans next fall. Although the U.S. planting season is still months away, ``there's all this apprehension'' about this year's soybean crop, said analyst Pat O'Connell of Refco Inc. in Chicago. ``People are trying to crunch the numbers, trying to figure out how many bean acres we have,'' he said. At the close, soybean futures were 4 cents to 8 cents lower with the contract for delivery in January at $5.60 a bushel and the November contract at $6.04 a bushel. Wheat futures closed 1 cent to 1} cents lower with March at $3.98{ a bushel; corn was 1\ cents lower to \ cent higher with March at $2.42{ a bushel; oats were unchanged to } cent lower with March at $1.43 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Citicorp To Restructure British Equities Business, Cutting 215 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. banking giant Citicorp said Tuesday that it will cut 215 jobs in a retructuring of its money-losing Citicorp Scrimgeour Vickers equities unit. Citicorp said up to 140 employees will be laid off while another 75 are being transferred within the organization, which will be integrated more closely with Citicorp's pan-European capital markets group. Another major investment firm, County Natwest Securities Ltd., said earlier Tuesday it will prune 79 jobs in its London equities unit in a move designed to eliminate overstaffing resulting from the 1988 merger with Wood Mackenzie Ltd. Citicorp Scrimgeour Vickers will be left with a total of 110 employees, it said. The banking company said Scrimgeour Vickers would cease to deal in fixed income securities, equities and related products. Anticipating Europe's anticipated removal of trade barriers among European nations in 1992, Citibank said that these activities would be better dealt with on a pan-European basis. Meanwhile, the on-going equities business will be built around what the bank called profitable areas, continental European equities, British growth companies and British and continental related products. Previously, the company made markets in 250 of the largest stocks on London's Stock Exchange. Now, it on will only deal in about 100 stocks which it classifies as growth companies. Citicorp Scrimgeour Vickers lost $65 million during 1989, its parent said.

DOC.HEAD: Hilton Profit Down In Quarter, Year
DOC.TEXT: Hilton Hotels Corp. profits fell 24 percent in the fourth quarter and 16 percent for the year, largely because of poor returns from Nevada casinos, the hotel-casino concern announced Tuesday. In the October-December quarter, net income totaled $26.9 million, or 55 cents per share, down from $35.2 million, or 73 cents per share, in 1988. Revenue rose 2 percent, to $259.6 million from $254.4 million. Hotels income increased 5 percent in the fourth quarter to $36 million, while gambling income fell 28 percent to $20.7 million, the company said. Nevada operations suffered from a low win percentage in the casinos, ongoing construction on the Las Vegas Strip and start-up costs at new theme casinos next to the chain's Flamingo hotels in Las Vegas and Reno, said Hilton Chairman Barron Hilton, son of founder Conrad Hilton. Hilton put itself on the auction block last summer after settling a dispute over Conrad Hilton's estate and the stock soared to $115.50 a share on reports of interested buyers. At that time, some analysts estimated the likely price at $120 per share, and possibly as much as $140. Annual net income was $110.1 million, or $2.27 per share, compared with $130.9 million, or $2.72 per share, in fiscal 1988. Revenue for fiscal 1989 rose 5 percent, to $998.2 million from $953.6 million. The 1989 results include a $2.4 million after-tax loss from a property transaction, which knocked 5 cents per share off earnings, Hilton said.

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Dips by 10
DOC.TEXT: The number of working U.S. oil and gas rigs dropped by 10 in the latest week to total 1,019, marking the fourth straight week the count has declined, Baker Hughes Inc. reported. The latest rig count remains above the 840 rigs posted a year earlier, the company reported Monday. The number of rigs dropped by a total of 50 in the three previous weeks after increasing by 21 the week before. Baker Hughes' rig count _ the widely watched industry index of drilling activity _ reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. Houston-based Hughes Tool Co., an oil toolmaker company that merged with Baker International Corp. of Orange, Calif., has kept track of the rig count since 1940. In December 1981, at the height of the oil boom, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But oil prices plunged to less than $10 per 42-gallon barrel in the summer of 1986, prompting a collapse in the rig count that bottomed out at 663 _ the lowest since Hughes began compiling figures. Among the major oil producing states, Texas posted the biggest gain with nine. Other states recording increases were Pennsylvania, three; Colorado, two; and Oklahoma and Wyoming, one each. California and Louisiana had the largest decline with five each followed by Kansas and North Dakota, three each; and Michigan and New Mexico, two each. Ohio remained unchanged from last week.

DOC.HEAD: General Electric, Partners Planning New Jet Engine
DOC.TEXT: General Electric Co. said Tuesday a partnership it is organizing will spend about $2 billion during the next five years to develop a cleaner, more fuel-efficient and quieter long-range engine for commercial jetliners. The company says the GE90, designed for long-range widebody jets, would cost $10 million per unit, according to Brian H. Rowe, senior vice president of GE's Aircraft Engines division, based in this Cincinnati suburb. The company envisions a potential $50 billion worldwide market for the engine. Rowe said the engine could reduce fuel consumption by about 10 percent. He estimated a widebody jetliner using two of the engines could save about 400,000 gallons of fuel a year. General Electric hopes the GE90 would reduce emissions by 30 percent from long-range engines now used, Rowe said. He also said the engine would be designed to meet more stringent Federal Aviation Administration noise-reduction standards. Rowe acknowledged that GE's major competitors _ the Pratt & Whitney division of United Technologies Corp. and Britain's Rolls Royce _ are developing rival engines. Rowe said he hopes GE can land at least 30 percent of the global market with the GE90. The GE90 is to be designed for Boeing's planned 767X twin-engine widebody jet, being marketed but not yet in commercial service. GE also is looking for other markets and is talking with jet makers McDonnell Douglas and the French producer Airbus Industrie, Rowe said at a news conference. ``Our main emphasis at this time is to get the engine launched on the 767X,'' Rowe said. ``But if somebody else comes along with a new application, we'll be very happy.'' The French manufacturer SNECMA, a 50-50 partner with General Electric during the past decade in the CFM International joint engine-making venture, is expected to be a 25 percent partner in the GE90 project, Rowe said. The engines would be produced in France and the United States. Paris-based SNECMA, under its current CFM International operation with GE, produces some CFM engines at a plant in Villaroche, France. Other CFM engines are made at GE's Evendale plant. General Electric also hopes MTU, a manufacturer based in Munich, will be a partner. That is subject to approval by MTU's board of directors, Rowe said. Rowe said GE expects that Swedish automaker Volvo and the Italian automaker Fiat will produce parts for the GE90. Both companies have produced parts for other GE engines. Other partners may enter the project as well, GE officials said. Some of the GE90 parts are likely to be produced at GE's plant in Lynn, Mass., Rowe said. He said the company will spend the next six months lining up its partners and getting the research program established. Developing and testing the engine could take five years. GE hopes to obtain commercial certification of the engine in May 1994 and enter it in commercial service in 1995. The engine will provide 75,000 to 95,000 pounds of thrust. GE's current CF6 engine used in long-range flight develops power of 52,500 to 75,000 pounds of thrust, GE spokesman Dwight Weber said.

DOC.HEAD: Cray To Reorganize Field Staff
DOC.TEXT: Cray Research Inc. will reorganize its 1,000-member field staff to separate sales and service functions and make prices more uniform, the supercomputer maker announced Tuesday. The move is not expected to have a ``significant'' financial impact and it won't significantly alter the number of jobs within the organization, said Ed Masi, senior vice president of marketing. But company spokesman John Swenson said there is a chance Cray would close or change its regional offices in San Ramon, Calif., Houston, Tex., and Calverton, Md. ``They may or may not go away,'' Swenson said. Under the new system, the 1,000-member field staff will be headed by Mike Wilhelm, previously general manager for the company's western region. Wilhelm will be based in Minneapolis. The sales effort will be divided East and West and all service activities will be brought together, the company said. Cray's field employees have had joint responsibility for service and sales, but those jobs will be separated under the new system, Swenson said. The move also is designed to bring uniformity to prices. Under the old system, equipment and service prices could vary depending on region.

DOC.HEAD: Big Three Automakers Report Higher Early January Sales
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.NOTE: Eds: AMs version planned.
DOC.HEAD: Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The Big Three automakers got off to an upbeat start for 1990, selling 26.4 percent more U.S.-built cars and light trucks in early January than in the same period last year, the companies said Tuesday. Truck sales rose 25.5 percent for General Motors Corp., Chrysler Corp. and Ford Motor Co., and car sales increased by 27.1 percent. The Big Three said they sold cars and light trucks at a daily rate of 30,844 during the Jan. 1-10 period this year, compared with a rate of 24,393 during the same time last year. Chrysler's car sales rose 14.4 percent in early January from the same period last year, while truck sales jumped 43.7 percent from last year's early January figures. Automotive industry analysts said Chrysler's gain in the truck market this period shows the automaker's incentive program on minivans has boosted consumer interest in the vehicles. One reason for the higher sales overall was unusually low sales in January 1989, which followed a December 1988 buying rush. Consumers hoping to take advantage of incentive packages that expired at the end of 1988 boosted December sales and that contributed to the January 1989 slump. GM's car sales increased 40.4 percent in early January and truck sales rose 28.4 percent over 1989's first reporting period. Ford said its sales rose 15.4 percent for cars and 10.9 percent for trucks in early January, compared with same period last year.

DOC.HEAD: Intel Says Profit Up in Fourth Quarter, Down in Year
DOC.TEXT: Intel Corp., Silicon Valley's leading vendor of microcomputer chips, on Tuesday reported a 43 percent jump in fourth-quarter earnings but said its profit for all of 1989 fell 13.7 percent partly due to the cost of closing two of its oldest plants. Last year's profit deterioration was caused in part by writeoffs connected to the closure of a Santa Clara fabrication plant and another decade-old facility in Livermore, said company spokeswoman Pamela Pollace. Intel will focus fabrication operations on its newer facilities in Arizona, New Mexico and Arizona, she said. Another factor contributing to the decline was the dissolution of Intel's joint computer venture with Siemens, called BiiN, after Intel decided the company would take too long to turn a profit, Pollace said. Net income for the fourth quarter of 1989 increased to $123 million, or 64 cents per share, from $86 million, or 46 cents per share, during the same period in 1988. For the year ended Dec. 30, 1989, net income totaled $391 million, or $2.07 per share, a drop from the $453 million, or $2.51 per share, reported in 1988. Fourth-quarter revenue increased 16 percent from the previous quarter to $895 million. The surge was a 23 percent increase from $727 million recorded during the same period in 1988, the previous company record, Pollace said. Revenue for 1989 set a record increasing 9 percent to $3.1 billion, from $2.9 billion for 1988. She attributed the increased revenue to higher demand for Intel's high performance chips, including the ultra-fast i960C chip, the fastest 32-bit processor to date when it was announced with much fanfare last August. She said the decrease in profits overall was not affected by Intel's decision to halt production of a brand new super-charged computer chip, the i486, which the company found had trouble carrying out certain mathematical calculations. Intel last year introduced three new microprocessors, including the i960C and the i860 64-bit microprocessor for supercomputing applications, the world's first one-million transistor microprocessor. Intel, which has been shifting production to newer plants in other states, is building a new $400 million facility in Dublin, Ireland. The company said the high cost of housing in the San Francisco Bay area is one reason it decided to close its two plants in the region.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Met To Buy Into Remy Martin, Cointreau Brands Of France
DOC.TEXT: Grand Metropolitan PLC, a British food and liquor giant, said Tuesday its International Distillers and Vintners unit will buy a 49 percent stake in the French liquor company Remy Martin et Cie SA and a 19 percent holding in Cointreau et Cie SA. Grand Met is buying the stakes from the Max Cointreau family. The remaining stakes in the companies are held by Cointreau family members. The price tag is under 140 million pounds, or $231 million, said a Grand Met spokesman, who asked not to be identified. Last November, Remy and Cointreau linked up to create a wines and spirits group with combined revenue of around 6 billion French francs, or $1 billion. The companies specialize in cognac, champagne and Cointreau. The Grand Met spokesman said the two companies are combining and the final size of Grand Met's stake in the combination is yet to be determined. International Distillers and Vintners has a distribution agreement with Cointreau in Europe.
