DOC.HEAD: Nike Agrees to Delete Three Announcers from Commercial Slated for Super Bowl
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version is also running on sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: Officials of Nike Inc. said they have agreed to remove Marv Albert, Dick Enberg and Al Michaels from a commercial scheduled to run during the Super Bowl because of pressure from CBS, which doesn't want rival announcers on the air during its telecast. Tom Clarke, Nike's vice president and director of marketing, and Scott Bedbury, director of advertising, said Monday that the shoe company would tape three more announcers and that the spot, titled ``The Announcers,'' would be revised. ``We are a major advertiser and we don't want to be in an adversarial relationship with a major network,'' Clark said. Sandy Genelius, a spokeswoman for CBS, said the network would make no comment on the matter. The original commercial, the start of Nike's new campaign, uses announcers Pat Summerall, Tom Heinsohn, Tony Trabert and Ben Wright of CBS; Enberg and Albert of NBC; Michaels of ABC; Dick Vitale of ABC and ESPN; Harry Caray of WGN in Chicago; and Don Cherry of CBC in Canada. A copy of the commercial with the original announcers was made available to reporters by Nike on Monday night. According to officials at CBS and NBC, who spoke on the condition that they not be identified, Enberg, Albert and Michaels were being removed because the public recognizes them as announcers who compete against CBS. ``They only wanted CBS announcers in it,'' said Albert. ``Obviously, on the spots that will be on NBC and ABC, we'll be back in. It's surprising. I think it's looking at things a little closely.'' The NBC official pointed out that NBC runs commercials with Summerall and John Madden, the CBS team that will broadcast the Super Bowl.

DOC.HEAD: New Top Management at Security Pacific
With AM-Earns-Banks
DOC.TEXT: Security Pacific Corp. said Tuesday that Chairman Richard J. Flamson III has been replaced as chief executive by Robert H. Smith, his expected successor. Flamson, 60, said he would continue to serve as chairman of the board of the nation's fourth-largest banking company. Smith, 54, former president and chief executive of Security Pacific Bank, becomes president and CEO of the parent company and chairman of the bank. Commenting on his decision to step down as chief executive before reaching the company's retirement age of 65, Flamson said the change had been contemplated for some time. ``We all believe Bob Smith and his team are well-equipped to provide the leadership needed for Security Pacific as we move into the new decade,'' he said. In Flamson's 11 years as chief executive, Security Pacific grew from assets of $21.6 billion and stockholders' equity of $920 million to assets of $84 billion and stockholders' equity of $4.6 billion. During that time, the company developed into a complicated and profitable financial services company, including recent alliances with Japan's giant Mitsui Bank. Security Pacific became a leader in investment banking, and additional alliances with companies, particularly Asian ones, are expected. Smith, who joined Security Pacific as a trainee 28 years ago, has spent most of his time in Security Pacific's huge retail system.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Market's Plunge Seen as Fall from Record Highs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS date to Oct. 19, 1987 in 4th graf
DOC.TEXT: Unrest in the Soviet Union, Japan's weakening yen and a decline in the New York market have combined to help send prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plunging from recent record highs, analysts said Tuesday. Renewed buying interest is not likely before national elections in February clear up political uncertainties, they said. The Nikkei Stock Average on 225 selected issues fell 666.41 points, or 1.8 percent, on Tuesday, after a fall of 653.36 points last Friday. Markets were closed Monday for a national holiday. These were the worst one-day plunges since 731.91 points on Oct. 19, 1987, when the Black Monday crash on Wall Street sent stock prices around the world plummeting. Tuesday's close of 36,850.36 was the lowest since 36,881.53 last Nov. 27. The Nikkei average had ended 1989 trading with four consecutive days of record high closes. So far this year, it has lost nearly 2,000 points, or 6.8 percent. ``Share prices were lifted artificially at the end of last year as institutional investors, especially foreign securities firms, bought up Nikkei index-related shares in exchange for Nikkei futures in program trading,'' said Keiichi Nishida, a dealer at Kidder Peabody Securities. ``As a result, the Nikkei index soared regardless of the market environment, and since the beginning of the year, those index-related shares are being sold off, depressing the index,'' he said. Dealers blamed the dive of the last two days partly on falling government bond prices, caused by the weakening yen. But on Tuesday, there was a ``combination of unfavorable factors hitting the market all at once,'' said Ichitaro Watanabe, a dealer at Nikko Securities Co. On top of the bond and yen worries and the index's decline during the year's first two weeks, ``over the weekend, the regional conflict worsened in the Soviet Union and the New York market fared poorly overnight, aggravating the market's pessimism,'' Nishida said. Dealers said the fall in bond prices is likely to stop soon because yields are approaching the appropriate level, around 7 percent, but a recovery in stock prices is unlikely before the February elections. ``Right now, market players see no encouraging sign to buy issues,'' said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst at Nomura Securities. Dealers said most private and institutional investors are waiting to see whether the elections leave the pro-business Liberal Democratic Party still in control of the government. The party, in power since its formation in 1955, lost its majority in Parliament's upper house for the first time in elections last July as voters showed displeasure over a new sales tax and sex and money scandals. The February elections are for the more powerful lower house, which chooses the prime minister and decides the budget. The LDP's standing in opinion polls has improved since last summer, but uncertainties remain. ``The unrest in the Soviet Union was also a severe blow to the stock market,'' said Watanabe. He said the wave of democratic movements in Eastern Europe last year pushed up prices of shares in trading companies, expected to benefit from expanded Japan-East European trade. ``Hardly any new money is coming into the market,'' Watanabe added. ``It it clear by looking at the volume traded on the exchange.'' Volume traded Tuesday on the first section of the exchange, where most major shares are listed, was estimated at 450 million shares. The dollar closed Tuesday at 145.75 yen, up 2.35 yen from its 1989 year-end close of 143.40 yen despite recent Japanese central bank intervention in support of the yen. The Soviet unrest and Japan's political uncertainty also have been seen as factors boosting the dollar.

DOC.HEAD: Widely Varying Earnings Performance Reported by Leading Banks
DOC.TEXT: Five big banks reported sharply mixed results for the 1989 fourth quarter and year Tuesday, reflecting strength in their corporate and consumer finance businesses and weakness caused by shaky real estate loans and Third World debt. Severe quarterly declines were reported by Citicorp, Manufacturers Hanover Corp., and Mellon Bank Corp., while Security Pacific Corp. and Wells Fargo & Co. reported big earnings increases. New York-based Citicorp, the nation's biggest banking company, said it lost $784 million or $2.52 a share in the quarter ended Dec. 31, vs. earnings of $747 million or $2.19 a share a year earlier. The bank attributed the drop largely to a $1 billion increase in its provision for possibly bad loans to developing countries, as well as a $68 million cost to restructure unprofitable operations in Britain. Citicorp said strong earnings from its gloabal consumer business offset weakness elsewhere. For the year, Citicorp earned $498 million or $1.16 a share, down 73 percent from $1.86 billion or $5.36 a share earned in 1988. New York-based Manufacturers Hanover, the sixth-largest U.S. banking company, earned $62 million or 82 cents a share in the fourth quarter, down 70.5 percent from $210 million or $4 a share a year earlier. Part of the decline reflected costs from a previously reported fraud at its Geneva branch. For 1989, Manufacturers Hanover lost $518 million or $10.21 a share, reflecting an increase of $1.1 billion to loan-loss reserves for Third World debt. In 1988 the bank earned $952 million or $18.27 a share. Pittsburgh-based Mellon said fourth-quarter earnings plunged nearly 88 percent in the fourth quarter to $6 million, which after payment of preferred dividends meant a loss of 20 cents a share. A year earlier the bank earned $48 million or $1.02 a share. Mellon attribued the decline to the addition of $100 million to its reserves to cover possibly bad Third World loans. For the year, the 17th largest U.S. banking company earned $181 million or $3.33 a share, rebounding from a loss of $65 million or $3.65 a share in 1988, when the bank had fewer shares outstanding. The bank said the improvement resulted from significantly lower operating expenses, as well as increases in service fee revenue and other revenue. Security Pacific of Los Angeles, the fifth largest U.S. banking company, earned $191.7 million or $1.59 a share in the fourth quarter, up 13 percent from the $169.5 million or $1.46 a share reported a year earlier. The bank said strong growth in its California and Washington businesses and financial service operations offset big losses in Arizona real estate. For the year, Security Pacific earned a record $740.6 million or $6.26 a share, up 16 percent from the $638.9 million or $5.59 a share earned in 1988. San Francisco-based Wells Fargo, the 11th largest banking company, said fourth quarter earnings rose 17 percent to $158.5 million or $2.95 a share, vs. $136 million or $2.45 a share a year earlier. The bank said the improvement stemmed largely from increases in domestic loans. For the year, Wells Fargo earned $601.1 million or $11.02 a share, up 17.3 percent from $512.5 million or $9.20 a share in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures End Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices ended mixed Tuesday, with crude and gasoline posting gains while spring-like weather in the Northeast dried up buying enthusiasm in the heating oil pits. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the February contract for West Texas Intermediate, the major U.S. grade of crude oil, rose 42 cents to close at $22.78 per 42-gallon barrel. Tuesday's gains follow a 77-cent loss on Monday. Crude contracts for delivery through August also advanced. Wholesale unleaded gasoline staged a broad-based advance, with the February contract gaining 0.71 cent to 64.30 cents a gallon after dropping 1.50 cents in the previous session. The March contract increased 0.78 cent to 63.82 cents a gallon. Meanwhile, heating oil prices slid further after a brief rally fizzled. The February contract for No. 2 heating oil fell 0.57 cent to 64.03 cents a gallon after tumbling 5.05 cents on Monday. Other contract months closed mixed. Analysts said warm weather in the Northeast continued to pressure heating oil prices. ``With warm weather, who wants heating oil?'' asked Madison Galbraith, energy specialist with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. Traders said news of a strike by a majority of workers at Petrobras, Brazil's state-owned oil company, boosted gasoline prices and helped pull crude higher. Brazil ships up to 1.4 million barrels of gasoline to the United States per month and a strike could effectively cut into shipments, analysts said. Brazil's refineries were reported to be operating but at a lower capacity after the strike began. Buying ahead of the American Petroleum Institute's weekly inventory report also helped support gasoline prices, said Linda Simard, energy broker for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed in Lackluster Trading
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in lackluster trading Tuesday amid few developments to affect the currency markets. Gold prices were also mixed. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, a troy ounce of gold fell $2.90 to $410.80. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $409.80, down $5 from late Monday's bid. Foreign exchange analysts said the dollar fluctuated during the day on largely technical factors. The dollar was steadied by rising interest rates in the bond market and from uncertainty about the political situation in the Soviet Union, said Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Asset Management Inc. Higher interest rates in this country make the dollar a more attractive investment for foreigners, and the dollar also gains from overseas political problems because investors consider it a safe investment. The yield on the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond rose to 8.24 percent Tuesday from late Friday's 8.17 percent. The government bond market was closed Monday for the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday. Meanwhile, rioting between Armenians and Azerbaijanis continued in the Caucasus region of the Soviet Union. The dollar gained against the British pound. In New York, one pound cost $1.6585 late Tuesday, compared with late Monday's $1.6630. In earlier London trading, sterling fell to $1.6560 from $1.6620 late Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.6950 West German marks, down from 1.6967; 1.5116 Swiss francs, up from 1.5110; 5.7630 French francs, down from 5.7635; 1,262.25 Italian lire, up from 1,261.625; and 1.16375 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16575. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.6945 West German marks, down from 1.6965; 1.5160 Swiss francs, up from 1.5120; 5.7635 French francs, up from 5.7625; 1.9195 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9015; 1,261.50 Italian lire, up from 1,261.375; and 1.1648 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1622. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 145.75 Japanese yen from the late London price of 145.50 yen on Monday, when Tokyo markets were closed for a holiday. In London, the dollar was unchanged against the yen, and in New York, the U.S. currency fell to 145.30 yen from late Monday's 145.55 yen. Gold bullion prices moved higher overseas, before slipping in New York. Gold closed in London, the major overseas market, at a bid of $413.25 a troy ounce, up from $412 late Monday. It rose in Zurich to $413 from $412.40. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at a bid of $415.45, up from late Monday's $413.95. Silver was also mixed. It fell 1.2 cents on the Commodity Exchange to $5.230 a troy ounce after rising 1 cent in London to a bid $5.25.

DOC.HEAD: TWA Sells 11 Jets to Raise Cash, Reduce Debt
DOC.TEXT: Trans World Airlines Inc. has sold 11 jumbo jets for $210 million to two leasing companies in an effort to raise cash and reduce its large debt, company officials said Tuesday. It's the second time in less than a month that the airline has announced the sale of assets. On Dec. 18, TWA said it planned to sell its Chicago-London route and related assets to American Airlines for $195 million. That deal must be approved by the federal government. The news has angered many employees who believe TWA owner Carl Icahn is slowly dismantling the airline, which is $2.7 billion in debt and lags behind other major carriers in capital investment. But industry analysts say selling airplanes and leasing them back from the leasing companies is quite common. ``Most airlines are doing it to raise cash and take advantage of high values for aircraft right now,'' said Paul Turk, an analyst with Avmark Inc., an aviation consulting firm in Arlington, Va. But with only 74 of its 213 aircraft owned outright, TWA has one of the lowest ownership percentages in the industry, Turk said. TWA spokesman Don Morrison said the airline will use half of the $210 million from the sale of eight Lockheed L1011s and three Boeing 747s to boost its cash reserves to nearly $1 billion. The airline will use the other half of the proceeds to trim its $2.7 billion in long-term debt, Morrison said. TWA sold the eight Lockheed jets to Potomac Leasing Inc. It sold the Boeing jets to a unit of American Express Co. Icahn has assured employees, in a letter last month, that he does not intend to dismantle TWA.

DOC.HEAD: Orange Juice Futures Soar On Supply Fears
DOC.TEXT: Orange juice futures prices rose sharply Tuesday following a report that Brazil expects to export about 450,000 metric tons of frozen concentrate to the United States this year, an amount that might not meet U.S. demand. On other commodity markets, soybean futures fell sharply; energy futures were broadly mixed; precious metals slipped; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Frozen concentrated orange juice futures rose 2 cents to 4.35 cents on the New York Cotton Exchange with the contract for delivery in January at $1.9525 a troy ounce. Futures prices have shot up about 70 cents a pound since a Christmastime freeze that destroyed an estimated 30 percent of Florida's orange crop, and the market is ``on a collision course'' with the all-time high spot price of $2.05, said analyst Judy Ganes of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. U.S. processors have been counting on Brazilian imports to make up any supply shortfall caused by the freeze. Brazilian citrus officials reportedly said Tuesday that they were prepared to meet America's needs. But the amount of prospective exports to the United States reportedly mentioned by Umberto Marconi, administrative director of the Brazilian Association of Citrus Juice Industries, would still leave U.S. consumers thirsting for orange juice, Ms. Ganes said. The prospective Brazilian exports of 450,000 metric tons of concentrate would translate into 155 million gallons of juice. ``Based on my calculations, we need to import about 200 million gallons overall this year to overcome the shortfall from the freeze,'' Ms. Ganes said. ``That puts us about 45 million gallons short.'' She said that between its 1989-90 harvest and its 1990-91 crop, Brazil should be able to meet America's needs, ``but we're at their mercy.'' Soybean futures tumbled on the Chicago Board of Trade as reports of rain in key growing areas washed buyers from the market. Grain futures closed mostly lower. The soybean market opened lower following reports of rain overnight in southern Brazil, a major soybean-producing region that had been suffering from unusually dry weather until recently. Rain also fell overnight and Tuesday in the U.S. corn and soybean belt, spurring selling of futures contracts, especially those for delivery of soybeans next fall. Soybean futures settled 6 cents to 11 cents lower with the contract for delivery in January at $5.58 a bushel and the November contract at $6.01{ a bushel. Wheat futures were 1\ cents to 2{ cents lower with March at $3.98\ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1\ cents lower with March at $2.42{ a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1\ cents lower with March at $1.42\ a bushel. Gasoline and near-month crude oil contracts made strong gains on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid supply fears linked to an oil workers strike in Brazil. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 3 cents lower to 42 cents higher with February at $22.78 a barrel; heating oil was 1.19 cents lower to .44 cent higher with February at 64.03 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .55 cent to .84 cent higher with February at 64.30 cents a gallon. Precious metal futures slumped on New York's Commodity Exchange in response to the stronger dollar and stronger stock market, which overshadowed such positive signals for the gold market as higher spot crude-oil prices and unrest in the Soviet Union. Gold futures finished $2.70 to $2.90 lower with February at $412.20 a troy ounce; silver was 1.2 cents to 1.6 cents lower with March at $5.285 a troy ounce. Livestock futures finished mostly lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, with some of the selling attributed to positioning ahead of next week's quarterly Agriculture Department cattle-on-feed report. Pork bellies advanced in technically-inspired trading. Live cattle futures settled .20 cent lower to .33 cent higher with February at 77.60 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .03 cent to .30 cent lower with January at 83.32 cents a pound; live hogs were .60 cent lower to .05 cent higher with February at 49.70 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .10 cent lower to .40 cent higher with February at 55.62 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Random Drug Testing Begins for Many Railroad Workers
With AM-Drug Testing, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf to show it was Amtrak-Conrail crash; SUBS 12th graf, The presence ... to INSERT Ricky Gates conviction, sentencing. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Mandatory random testing for drugs and alcohol went into effect Tuesday for the 90,000 men and women who operate the nation's railroads. Testing began one year after drug abuse was singled out as a factor in a 1987 Amtrak-Conrail crash near Baltimore that killed 16 people and injured 175. The testing program, delayed because a lengthy series of court battles between the government and railroad unions, requires that at least 25 percent of railroad engineers, brakemen, dispatchers, signalmen, conductors and all other railroad employees directly involved in the movement of trains be subjected to random testing this year. A full 50 percent of the operations personnel of the nation's largest railroads must be tested by the end of 1991 for the presence of alcohol and such drugs as marijuana, cocaine, opiates, amphetamines, and phencyclidine, also known as PCP. But Claire Austin, a public affairs officer for the Federal Railroad Administration, said federal officials expect as many as 40 percent of those affected by the new requirement to be tested by the end of this year alone. She said railroad administrators expect results will show that drugs are a far more serious problem among rail workers than is alcohol. ``It is very evident to us that drugs are the problem rather than alcohol,'' she said, pointing to the results of post-accident drug and alcohol testing, a requirement since 1986. In that year, 738 people were tested with 27 testing positive for drugs and seven for alcohol. In 1987, 770 persons were tested with 39 testing positive for drugs and just three testing positive for alcohol. In 1988, 682 people were tested with three testing positive for alcohol and 39 testing positive for drugs. Of 21 railroad accidents linked to drugs or alcohol last year, 14 were drug-related while alcohol was involved in seven of the incidents. The National Transportation Safety Board found in 1988 that marijuana use was a factor in the Jan. 4, 1987, accident at Chase, Md., which left 191 people dead or injured. The board said drug impairment caused Conrail engineer Ricky Gates to speed through several warning systems and into the path of an Amtrak train. The presence of marijuana was found in blood and urine samples taken from Gates. He was later convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to five years in prison after admitting he smoked marijuana and violated several safety procedures. The board said the effects of the drug caused Gates not to notice warning signals both inside the engine's cab and suspended over the tracks until it was too late to make a safe stop. At the time of the safety board's findings, John Riley, the federal railroad administrator, said it was clear a random drug testing program was needed. ``It is not enough to simply talk about the impact marijuana use had on this accident,'' Riley said at the time. ``If we don't do something to prevent it from happening again _ I mean authorized random testing _ then the lives lost at Chase may well have been lost in vain.''

DOC.HEAD: East, West Call for Creation of East Europe Development Bank
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf `The money...' to CORRECT that total debt over $100 billion. Pickup 10th, `The idea... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Nations from the East and West nations took the first step Tuesday toward creating an East European development bank that one official said could be working by the end of the year. Delegations from 34 countries, including the United States and Soviet Union, ended their first meeting by appointing experts to work out specific plans for the proposed European Bank for Reconstruction and Development in Eastern Europe, said Jacques Attali, France's presidential adviser on economic affairs. ``We need to be generous, but also to help these countries learn what they need to learn to transform them into market economies,'' said Attali, who had presided at the two-day meeting. Attali said three groups of experts would begin work and report their progress at a second session scheduled for Paris on Jan. 30. He said a drafting session would be held in Paris March 10-11 after which delegations hopefully would be able to sign an agreement. The plan reasonably might be ratified and the bank established and operating some time this year, Attali said. Some countries, particularly the United States, have expressed concern about the role of the Soviet Union in the bank, both as participant in the capital and eventually even a borrower. Attali said the issue would be addressed during negotiations over the draft plan. Disagreements among representatives generally were minor and would not stop eventual approval of the bank, Attali said, describing the meeting's atmosphere as constructive. French President Francois Mitterrand proposed creation of the bank during a European Parliament session Oct. 25 as a way to help East European countries, which have removed their hard-line Communist leaders in the past year. The money will be used for loans for projects in Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Poland and Romania _ countries already burdened by foreign debts totaling more than $100 billion. The idea was endorsed in December at the summit of the 12 European Community countries, which proposed a plan for the bank. Delegations on Tuesday proposed several amendments to the EC plan. Using the amendments, France will draw up a new proposal to be presented at the Jan. 30 session, Attali said. Attali listed seven issues the working groups would address: _ The mission of the bank and whether it should fund only private sector projects or include the public sector. This is a particular concern of the United States. _ The conditions under which the new bank's money will be lent, whether at current market rates, or in some other way. _ Criteria for eligibility to borrow from the bank, whether those criteria will be based on the state of economic reforms in any individual East European country. _ The amount of capital with which to found the bank. Attali said the current thinking is about $12 billion, but no firm figure has been reached. _ The breakdown of capital participation by each country. Attali said the question had not been studied, but no one had rejected the idea of the European Community holding a majority stake. _ The bank's method of operation, who will run it, who will be its directors and officers. _ Where the headquarters will be located. Attali indicated there was no shortage of candidates, but refused to reveal them. The conference participants were all 12 EC members: France, West Germany, Britain, Italy, Ireland, Spain, Portugal, the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg, Denmark and Greece; six members of the European Free Trade Association: Austria, Switzerland, Finland, Sweden, Norway and Iceland; and the United States, Canada, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, Turkey, Cyprus, Malta, the Soviet Union, Yugoslavia, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Poland and Romania.

DOC.HEAD: Federated, Allied Filings Detail Billions in Bond Debts
DOC.TEXT: Bankruptcy filings released Tuesday provided a 6,000-page look at the crushing debts plaguing Campeau Corp.'s department stores, listing billions of dollars owed to 50,750 creditors ranging from Wall Street bankers to underwear makers. The bankruptcy petition by Campeau divisions Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., listed $9.1 billion in total assets and $7.7 billion in total liabilities. Toronto-based Campeau, the real estate company that bought Federated and Allied with borrowed money in the 1980s, placed them under bankruptcy court protection Monday because of the debt burden. The divisions will reorganize under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, which gives them a reprieve from creditors while they devise a way to repay them and stay in business. Campeau made the filing in Cincinnati, where its most important U.S. retailing operations are based. The 6,000-page filing, half of it a list of creditors, was made available for the first time Tuesday by the bankruptcy court, where lawyers, accountants and creditor representatives scrambled to make copies on two machines. The biggest listed creditors were mostly banks and Wall Street investment firms, some of which played roles in helping Campeau expand into a retailing giant. However, while some listed as creditors owned the bonds, others were only holding them in trust for investors. The creditor list ranged from First Boston Corp., holder of $428.8 million in Federated debt securities, to a $96,074 bill owed to the Hanes hosiery maker by Lazarus department stores, a Federated subsidiary. Campeau's U.S. holding company also announced G. William Miller, 64, a former Treasury secretary and Federal Reserve chairman, is the company's new chairman and chief executive officer. Miller also is a former Federated executive. The U.S. unit also changed its name from Campeau Corp. (U.S.) Inc. to Federated Stores Inc. Miller said holders of bonds Campeau sold to finance its takeover of Allied in 1986 and purchase of Federated in 1988 should expect to take losses. ``They bought speculative securities, and they had high interest rates which were compensation,'' Miller said on NBC's ``Today'' show. ``I think the marketplace has already reflected in the discounts at which they are selling the fact that they probably will not be paid in full.'' Jack Cowell, a managing director for First Boston, called Federated's figure on the debt to the investment bank ``vastly inflated.'' He said First Boston bought many of the bonds at lower market prices and that First Boston had invested $75 million to $100 million in Federated bonds. Cowell said that despite marking down the bonds' values at the end of 1989, the Wall Street firm had a profitable year in bond trading. Damage to reputations could be more costly in the long run than money losses for companies that invested in Campeau's debt-financed takeovers, said Perrin Long, an analyst for Lipper Analytical Securities Corp. in New York. ``You don't want to associate with banks that had a failure in that respect in the past,'' Long said. The Northern Trust Company, which Allied listed as its sixth largest creditor, said in Chicago the company holds Allied bonds for clients and had none of its own. The trust company said outside advisers had recommended the purchase of the bonds. The filing was the largest under Chapter 11 by an American retailer, affecting about 100,000 employees and 258 stores in the United States. It also was the second-largest ever by a non-financial company after Texaco Inc., which sought court protection in April 1987. Harvey Miller, a New York bankruptcy lawyer who represented Texaco, indicated that the size of Campeau's filing and the large part of the company's debt that is in junk bonds will lead creditors to create new legal arguments to pursue repayment. He said creditors who don't qualify for repayment ``will try to come up with some sort of leverage device, whether they call it fraud ... or something else.'' Campeau also announced other changes involving senior management at its U.S. operations. Ronald W. Tysoe, currently president of both Campeau Corp. and Campeau (U.S.), will continue as president of the newly renamed Federated holding company, but he will phase out his responsibilities at the Canadian parent. John W. Burden III, chairman and chief executive officer of Federated and Allied, has quit effective Jan. 31 ``to pursue other interests,'' Campeau said. The company said it expects to announce a successor soon to run the retailing operations. James M. Zimmerman will remain as president and chief operating officer of Federated and Allied. The management teams at all department store chains will continue in place. Chapter 11 grants the companies a reprieve from creditors' lawsuits while they formulate a plan to repay their debts. All financial decisions for the companies must now be approved by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug. He declined to comment on the case. Federated's stores include Abraham and Straus and Bloomingdale's of New York, Burdine's of Miami, Lazarus of Cincinnati and Rich's of Atlanta. Allied's stores include The Bon Marche of Seattle, Jordan Marsh of Boston, Maas Brothers of Tampa and Stern's of Paramus, N.J.

DOC.HEAD: Fuji Proposes Buyout of Subaru of America
DOC.TEXT: Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd., which owns 49.6 percent of Subaru of America Inc.'s outstanding shares, proposed Monday to buy the remaining stock for $6 a share, or $147 million. Subaru of America has a total of about 48.5 million outstanding shares of common stock, and the $6 a share offer would value the entire company at about $291 million. Some traders expect the bidding may go higher. Subaru stock rose $1 a share to $6.12{ per share Tuesday in national over-the-counter trading. ``We believe that our proposed cash price is fair to Subaru of America's shareholders, especially in light of the uncertain outlook for the U.S. automobile industry,'' Fuji Heavy Chairman Toshiro Tajima said. ``Only by controlling 100 percent of Subaru of America will we be in a position to effectively integrate the manufacturing and distribution process which, we believe, is critical to the growing demands of our U.S. dealer network and the interests of our customers,'' he said. Subaru of America, headquartered in Cherry Hill, N.J., operates an assembly plant jointly with Isuzu in Lafayette, Ind., which Fuji Heavy officials said would benefit from the merger. ``I think the transaction will affect the Indiana plant positively. We hope to increase the manufacturing of cars and that would provide more jobs for the American people,'' said Dairoku Hosoki, director and general manager of Fuji Heavy. Officials at Subaru-Isuzu Automotive Inc. refused to comment on the proposal, spokeswoman Chris Miller said. Negotiations on the merger are expected to take a minimum of three months, said Peter Rona, president and chief executive officer of IBJ Shroeder Bank & Trust Co. of New York. The proposed cash merger is between Subaru and a wholly owned Fuji subsidiary. Fuji is one of Japan's largest manufacturers of transportation equipment, including Subaru cars. In fiscal 1989, auto exports to North America accounted for nearly 30 percent of Fuji's total revenues. Fuji sales for the fiscal year ending March 31, 1989, were more than $5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Singapore Airlines Orders Aircraft from Two U.S. Manufacturers
DOC.TEXT: Singapore Airlines said Tuesday it has placed orders and options for 50 aircraft from Boeing Co. and McDonnell Douglas Corp., and valued the proposed purchases including engines and spares at $8.6 billion. The airline plans to buy 30 747-400 aircraft from Boeing and 20 MD-11s from McDonnell Douglas, the company said in a statement. It said it ordered 15 aircraft and an option for 15 more from Boeing, and ordered 5 aircraft and an option for 15 others from McDonnell. Total cost of the purchase including engines and spares is $8.6 billion, the airline said. The aircraft are scheduled to be delivered between 1994 and 1999. Singapore Airlines is evaluating engines to power the aircraft, the airline said in a statement without giving details. Three companies, for example, make engines for the 747-400, including Pratt & Whitney, Rolls Royce and General Electric Co. ``Singapore Airlines should be able to fully finance the purchase, but it may take advantage of available financing ... that can reduce the cost of aquisition,'' the airline said. The statement said Singapore Airlines plans to grow at an average rate of 8 percent a year in the 1990's.

DOC.HEAD: Aristech Chairman Launches Bid for Company
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of Aristech Chemical Corp. and a Japanese trading company launched a $900 million takeover bid Tuesday for the chemical manufacturer as the company reported a sharp drop in earnings. A management group led by Chairman Thomas Marshall in association with Tokyo-based Mitsubishi Corp. offered $26 per share of outstanding stock at the company's board meeting, Aristech said in a statement. About 34.6 million shares of stock were outstanding at the end of 1989, said company spokesman David Higie. That would make the offer worth about $899.6 million. Aristech stock jumped $5.50 Tuesday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange to close at $24.62{. Marshall said commitments for financing were arranged by Mitsubishi, according to Aristech. The board appointed a committee to evaluate the proposal, which expires at the close of business next Tuesday. It is subject to completion of definitive agreements and approval of the board. ``It's a friendly effort,'' said Peter Rosenthal, a Mitsubishi spokesman. ``Aristech and Mitsubishi are working together jointly to accomplish this transaction.'' Rosenthal said that under the deal Mitsubishi would be a joint owner of Aristech, but he declined to elaborate. ``It's a strategic investment. They believe they can bring their expertise and know-how to bear for the benefit of the company,'' he said. Mitsubishi invests in a broad range of companies around the world. Pittsburgh-based Aristech said its fourth-quarter profit totaled $15.1 million, or 43 cents a share, on revenue of $222.6 million. That compares with a profit of $34.9 million, or 97 cents a share, on revenue of $258.5 million during the same period in the previous year. The profit for all of 1989 fell to $82.1 million, or $2.36 per share, on revenue of $996.4 million. That compares with 1988 earnings of $188.2 million, or $5.04 per share, on revenue of $1.07 billion. Marshall said price drops for polypropylene were a major factor in the reduced revenue and operating income in 1989. Polypropylene, a thermoplastic resin, is one of Aristech's major products. Major expenses for maintenance and expansions at Aristech plants during the year also decreased operating income, he said. ``All things considered, 1989 was a good year, with a return on equity of 20 percent and a healthy balance sheet,'' he said. USX Corp. sold Aristech to the unit's managers in 1986. The company employs about 1,800 people at 10 plants in eight states, Higie said. Utah industrialist Jon M. Huntsman launched an unsuccessful takeover bid for the company in last fall. The board rejected the $25-per-share offer Nov. 28.

DOC.HEAD: Hasbro Selling Pennsylvania Plant
DOC.TEXT: Hasbro Inc. plans to sell a plant in Lancaster, Pa., to Bulova Systems and Instruments Corp. and move the plant's toy production to plants in Rhode Island and Massachusetts, the company announced Tuesday. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. Hasbro said it plans to end manufacturing at the plant in late March or early April and to close it by June 30. The plant employs about 750 people. Production of Playskool toys will shift to existing Hasbro plants in Pawtucket and Central Falls, R.I., and in East Longmeadow, Mass., the company said. Bulova said it will consolidate its Lancaster operations at the plant and also will move operations from Freeport, N.Y., to the plant. Hasbro acquired the plant four years ago when it bought the assets of the CBS Toy Division. At the time, Hasbro thought it would need the additional manufacturing capacity ``and that didn't really materialize,'' said Wayne Charness, a spokesman. Hasbro is developing severance packages for salaried employees of the plant and will negotiate with the Glass, Molders, Pottery, Plastics and Allied Workers union for a similar package for hourly employees, the company said. Hasbro, which had 1988 revenues of nearly $1.36 billion, manufactures toys and games under the trade names Playskool, Milton Bradley and Hasbro.

DOC.HEAD: Texan Abandons Questionable Bid for Bond Corp.
DOC.TEXT: A young entrepreneur who sought control of Bond Corp. Holdings Inc. without explaining how he would finance his $197 million bid or deal with the Australian conglomerate's immense debt said Tuesday he had abandoned his offer. The statement from Jeff H. Reynolds came five days after Bond, the brewing and media company controlled by millionaire Alan Bond, said Reynolds did not appear to have the capacity to undertake the deal. Bond had said earlier it was willing to talk to Reynolds. Beginning with a news release issued Jan. 5, Reynolds said he was negotiating to take over Bond through his Weatherby Investments Inc. and its parent, Singapore-based California Pacific International Holdings Co. Pte Ltd. Newspapers and news agencies worldwide ran stories on his friendly offer to save Bond, which was near collapse under a nearly $6 billion load of debt and related legal problems. Reynolds, a 28-year-old Texan operating out of his mother's house in Houston, claimed he had lined up the $197 million and was negotiating financing to service Bond's debt. But checks by The Associated Press showed that Weatherby, once run by Reynolds' father, lost its corporate charter in Nevada in 1987 after failing to file its annual list of officers. The younger Reynolds was never listed as an officer or director of Weatherby. The address Reynolds gave for investors was a mail drop in Beverly Hills. He refused to reveal the location in Century City from which he said his associates were operating, and he never revealed his source of funds. He described the lapsed corporate license as a ``screw up'' by his staff or attorneys, and even said he might undertake a hostile bid for Bond after the company rejected his offer last week. On Tuesday, he issued another news release saying his companies were ``withdrawing from negotiations'' with Bond Corp., mainly because of the Australian company's legal and financial problems. Last Thursday, Bond Corp. released a statement from its headquarters in Perth, Western Australia, saying it had been unable to obtain information about the proposed cash offer. It said Reynolds' bid was doubtful and causing the company ``considerable embarrassment.'' ``It was made very clear to Mr. Reynolds and his associates right from the very beginning that there would be no discussions until Bond Corp. was satisfied that Mr. Reynolds and-or his companies have the financial capacity to undertake a transaction of the size and nature he proposes,'' Bond Corp. spokesman Peter Lucas said. ``In the absence of any such information having been made available so far, despite repeated requests, we are taking the view at this time that he does not have that capacity,'' Bond's statement read. Reynolds on Tuesday maintained his offer had been real. ``There's not much to say'' to detractors, Reynolds said. ``I don't think it's worthy of a response.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Let Eastern Machinists' Strike Spread to Commuter Railroads
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 21st graf, which is 2nd bullet graf: ``Agreed to,'' to CORRECT that producers and pipelines are defendants, not utilities.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Scotus-Supermarkets
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court, in one of two suits arising from strikes against airlines, refused Tuesday to allow a machinists union walkout at Eastern Airlines spread to commuter railroads. The court also refused to revive a suit brought by Trans World Airlines flight attendants, who accused TWA owner Carl Icahn of sex bias in seeking wage cuts and other concessions that triggered a 1986 strike. The court's ruling in the Eastern case resolved a question left by the walkout by the International Association of Machinists that began more than 10 months ago. The justices, without comment, left intact lower court decisions barring sympathy strikes against railroads in New York City, Philadelphia and their suburbs. The machinists, who walked off the job last March 4 after refusing to give more than $150 million in concessions sought by Eastern, remain on strike. Pilots and flight attendants supported the strike for eight months before ending their walkouts in November. The machinists and unions sympathetic to the Eastern strike sought to extend its impact by setting up picket lines at facilities run by the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority in the Philadelphia area and by Amtrak, the Long Island Railroad, Metro-North Commuter Railroad and NJ Transit Rail in the New York City metropolitan area. Federal judges barred the secondary strikes, and the restraining orders were upheld by the New York-based 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and the Philadelphia-based 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. In the TWA case, the flight attendants had sought back pay and other benefits from the airline. The Independent Federation of Flight Attendants called a strike against TWA on March 7, 1986. Two months later, the union offered to return to work and accept TWA's demands. The strike was called when Icahn insisted on wage and other concessions for attendants _ 85 percent of them women _ that were greater than cuts he sought to impose against the airline's pilots, machinists and other workers. During the negotiations with the attendants union, Icahn said it would be easy for him to find young, untrained women to be stewardesses for less than he was paying the attendants. When union negotiators said janitors who belonged to the machinists union were offered a better deal than the attendants, Icahn remarked: ``A janitor is a breadwinner (who) probably has got a family at home to support (while) you girls are second incomes and you don't need the money.'' The union said the statement demonstrated bias against women and violated fair bargaining procedures mandated by the federal Railway Labor Act, which governs labor negotiations for airlines and railroads. U.S. District Judge Howard F. Sachs in Missouri rejected the union's claims that Icahn was guilty of sexual stereotyping. Icahn's ``breadwinner'' remarks were ``foolish and offensive,'' Sachs said. But he said Icahn apparently was trying to rationalize his negotiating strategy of demanding more cuts from the attendants. The judge said the real reason Icahn made a more generous offer to the machinists was because that union could ``do greater damage to TWA in a strike'' and because Icahn believed it would be easier to replace the attendants with untrained workers. The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the judge's ruling dismissing the case last June. In other business-related cases Tuesday, the court: _ Said it would consider limiting the power of environmentalists to prevent the opening up of federal lands to commercial development. _ Agreed to a request by 34 states that it consider broadening their power to sue gas producers and pipelines on behalf of consumers allegedly overcharged as a result of ilegal price-fixing. _ Left intact a ruling that cities may fine cable television companies for failing to broadcast enough locally originated programs. _ Agreed to decide whether non-profit social clubs that are generally exempt from federal income taxes can use losses incurred from selling food and drink to non-members to offset investment profits. _ Let stand a ruling that a state may ban pharmacists from selling prescription drugs at a discount. _ Blocked the effect of a lower court ruling that could have provided natural gas consumers with tens of millions of dollars in refunds. The justices are to hear a formal appeal by 21 energy companies in the case, in which a lower court invalidated a federal regulation that allowed gas producers to raise some prices. The court also heard arguments Tuesday in the California attorney general's attempt to break up the $2.5 billion merger of Lucky Stores Inc. and American Stores Co. California officials asked the court to allow states and private citizens to use federal antitrust law to stop corporate mergers. The attorney general's office argued that the Clayton Act, passed in 1914 when Congress was preoccupied with trust busting on a national scale, empowers the state to challenge the merger. Less competition in the industry, leading to higher grocery bills for consumers, will result from the merger, said Deputy California Attorney General H. Chester Horn Jr. Rex E. Lee, representing the supermarket chains, said only the federal government is empowered by the 1914 law to force divestiture in a completed merger. Lucky operated California's largest supermarket chain, and American, the fourth largest. American acquired Lucky in June 1988 to merge the two chainsder the Lucky name. The company has 550 stores in California.

DOC.HEAD: GM Orders Cuts in Advertising
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. has ordered its divisions to cut or delay media advertising spending by 25 percent as the company continues to cut costs, according to a report published Tuesday. The Detroit News said it obtained an internal memo ordering each GM division to cut or defer media spending in the first six months of this year. Spokesman Terry Sullivan confirmed the memo Tuesday. He said he had no details on specific cuts and there was no firm target for cuts. GM does not disclose its advertising budget. Sullivan said GM is scrutinizing all its operating budgets to see if they can be cut. ``I think the key there is the term `cut or `defer,''' he said. ``Defer, it just means hold off spending for a time period and then see if we really need it and how important it is to us. I mean everything in general, I don't just mean advertising. ``Some of it is a retiming. What it does reflect is increasing competition within the industry ... and the ongoing need to become cost competitive.'' The memo, titled ``1990 Quick Start Program,'' also said GM would reduce sponsorships in motor sports and related activities by 20 percent, the newspaper said. ``We're looking at a lot of things,'' said Phil Guarascio, GM executive director of advertising. ``I don't think the door is closed on (cutting) anything.'' The nation's largest automaker launched a $13-billion cost-cutting program in 1987 to last several years. As part of that program, the company last week confirmed cuts that published reports have put at $1 billion. Car sales were slow in 1989, and the Big Three automakers have shut down or slowed production at 13 U.S. plants this week to lighten inventories. Incentives launched in 1989 to try to get rid of slow-selling cars have proven costly. GM on Tuesday reported a 40.4-percent increase in car sales and 28.4-percent increase in truck sales for the first 10 days of January.
Eds: Upcoming within 10 minutes, the Japanese government has announced it will maintain voluntary restraints on exports of passenger autos to the United States at 2.3 million cars for another year.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Japan to Continue Voluntary Auto Export Restraints
DOC.TEXT: Japan will continue to voluntarily restrict exports of passenger autos to the United States to 2.3 million cars a year in the coming year, Trade Minister Hikaru Matsunaga said Wednesday. The export limit for fiscal 1990, which begins April 1, is the same as in the current fiscal year, although actual exports are expected to total only 2 million autos because of increased production in the United States by Japanese automakers. ``Auto exports to the United States in fiscal 1989 are expected to be down again from the previous year's level,'' Matsunaga said at a news conference. ``Although we consider this trend of decline constant, for fiscal 1990 we will keep the previous year's measures in place to confirm the tendency of decline.'' The export restraint, which dates from 1981 when the U.S. government put strong pressure on Japan in order to bolster U.S. automakers, has been considered obsolete for several years because Japan's auto shipments have been under the quota. But it is still regarded as politically important to keep the quota in place while Japan and the United States are at loggerheads over ways to reduce the $50 billion annual surplus Japan runs in trade between the two countries. Wednesday's announcement was virtually identical to the one last year, when the government said the export restraint should be kept even though exports to America were declining. When the export restraints started, Japanese automakers had a big price advantage over U.S. manufacturers, but the yen's rise against the dollar since 1985 has reduced Japan's price advantage. Japanese car companies have turned increasingly to making autos in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: G-P, Great Northern Distribute Competing Proxies for Shareholder Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Georgia-Pacific Corp. on Tuesday began asking Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. shareholders to cast votes to oust Great Northern's directors and replace them with a board that favors Georgia-Pacific's unsolicited $3.8 billion tender offer for the paper company. Meanwhile, a federal judge in Portland, Maine, rejected Georgia-Pacific's challenge of a provision in Great Northern's bylaws that is intends to make a hostile takeover of the company more difficult. As Georgia-Pacific began soliciting proxies supporting its proposals, to be considered at the March 2 meeting in Portland, Great Northern urged its stockholders to retain its current board. Great Northern spokesman Stephen Hill said Tuesday that the Norwalk, Conn., company is distributing its own proxy statements that urge shareholders to reject Georgia-Pacific's bid. ``They're competing, really,'' Hill said of the proxies. Hill said shareholders of record Jan. 12 will be eligible to vote at the meeting. Great Northern claims that Georgia-Pacific's attempt to buy the competing paper company would violate antitrust laws. Great Northern also contends Georgia-Pacific would sell Great Northern's valuable land holdings in Maine if it acquired the company. Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific denies both allegations and has charged that Great Northern's management has resisted the takeover in an attempt to hold onto their own jobs at the expense of the shareholders' interests. Georgia-Pacific Chairman T. Marshall Hahn Jr. said 75 percent of Great Northern shares have been tendered under the $63-a-share offer. The two companies also are haggling over how large a vote would be required to pass any of the proposals. Great Northern's articles of incorporation say 75 percent of the shares must approve the removal of the board. Georgia-Pacific says the laws of Maine, where Great Northern is incorporated, require only 66 2-3 percent. In U.S. District Court in Portland, Judge Gene Carter on Tuesday denied Georgia-Pacific's request for injunctive relief against Great Northern's ``poison pill'' stock purchase plan. Carter said Maine law ``specifically allows the corporation to set the terms and conditions for the exercise of the rights to purchase stock.'' Georgia-Pacific's corporate communications manager, Sheila Weidman, said the company was disappointed by the ruling, but that it was not unexpected. She said that the company is ``pursuing many other avenues'' and that the ruling ``won't adversely affect the company's ability to complete the merger.''

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Stocks Rebound, Dollar Falls ^Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, dollar
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices recouped more than half the previous session's sharp losses Wednesday morning while the U.S. dollar fell slightly. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which shed 666.41 points Tuesday in the biggest one-day point loss in more than two years, rebounded 360.66 points, or 0.97 percent, to close the morning session at 37,211.02. The index was up some 430 points at one point, responding favorably to a 23.25-point overnight gain in the Dow Jones industrial average on Wall Street, before slipping back, dealers said. A recovery in Japanese government bond prices also supported stocks, dealers said. ``The recoveries on Wall Street and bond prices are major contributing factors for the rise,'' said Hisato Haganuma, an equity researcher with Nomura Securities, Japan's largest brokerage. Dealers have blamed the big slump in stock prices in the past two weeks on sharp falls in the prices of government bonds, which drives up interest rates and makes stocks less attractive. The Nikkei has lost nearly 2,000 points, or 6.8 percent, following four consecutive days of record high closings toward the end of last year. The dollar closed the morning session at 145.47 yen, down from 145.75 yen late Tuesday. After opening at 145.40 yen, the currency ranged between 145.37 yen and 145.48 yen. Dealers said trading was generally calm, with many players waiting for the release of U.S. merchandise trade figures for November, scheduled for later Wednesday in Washington. Some economists predict the figures will show the trade deficit narrowed to $9.4 billion from $10.2 billion in October.

DOC.HEAD: Accounting Newsletter Can't Print Article About Firm, Judge Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf to UPDATE with Atlanta Journal-Constitution supporting newsletter.
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for a business newsletter said Tuesday they would fight a court order that halted plans to print a front-page story containing confidential information about the Big Six accounting firm Ernst & Young. The attorneys said the court ruling amounted to unconstitutional prior restraint and charged that Ernst & Young made no attempt to notify newsletter editors that it was seeking the court order. ``They received no prior notice,'' James Grossberg, a Washington attorney who is part of the team representing the newsletter, said Tuesday. ``That in itself makes this decision blatantly unconstitutional.'' Carl Liggio, general counsel for Ernst & Young, told The Atlanta Constitution, ``If we had notified him, he would have gone to press and defeated the purpose.'' Arthur W. Bowman, editor of Bowman's Accounting Report, said he was served with a temporary restraining order at his home the night of Jan. 8 _ while the January edition of the newsletter was at the press _ stopping him from publishing the article. The issue was published two days later with a black cover and the word ``Censored'' printed in bold white letters. The order, issued by New York Supreme Court Judge Beatrice Shainswit, restrains Bowman's Accounting Report from ``using, referring to, disseminating or in any way disclosing any confidential and@or proprietary information of Ernst & Young that has come into (its) possession.'' ``I've been in the newsletter business a decade and I've never seen anything like this,'' Bowman said Tuesday. The article was to have analyzed last June's merger of Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young. Bowman said his newsletter was the first to break the news of that deal when it reported it in the May 17, 1989, issue. Neither the accounting firm nor the newsletter would discuss the nature of the information in the article. Bowman said Ernst & Young learned of the planned article when he called the firm to check some facts. Mort Myerson, a spokesman for Ernst & Young, said the issue has nothing to do with freedom of the press, but centers instead on privacy. ``This is an issue of proprietary, confidential information, not the First Amendment,'' Myerson said. A number of news organizations, including The Associated Press, The New York Times, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, The Wall Street Journal, Newsday and the Newsletter Association of America Tuesday said they would support the newsletter in its attempt to lift the restraining order. A hearing is scheduled Jan. 25 in the Supreme Court of New York on Bowman's bid to have the order reversed.
